Project Description: A rich platform of cutting-edge technologies will be built for collaborative, inquiry-based learning and instruction, developed within a wider community of learning scientists, where scholars from different institutions jointly develop shared technology frameworks and curriculum activities.

Project Title: Behavioural and Neural Correlates of Perceiving People
Project Description: My work examines our perceptions of others and how those perceptions influence our thoughts and behaviours. I focus on the accurate judgment of others from their nonverbal behaviour and appearance, showing that first impressions have important consequences for the mind, brain, and society.

Project Title: Imaging of Bone Structure Using Micro-Computed Tomography
Project Description: Dietary strategies that reduce the risk of debilitating fractures during aging will be developed. Micro-computed tomography identifies critical information about bone structure. It can also identify how diet during infancy and childhood promotes development of strong, healthy bones by adulthood.

Project Title: Computational Geophysics Laboratory at Western
Project Description: The Computational Geophysics Laboratory (CGL) will provide infrastructure to facilitate the computational study and modelling of a spectrum of geophysical phenomena, providing research opportunities in resource exploration, and in the forecast and mitigation of natural hazards.

Project Title: Pathogenic Bacteria Membrane Protein Purification and Crystallization Facility
Project Description: Using structural biology approaches, Dr. Moraes elucidates the three dimensional visualization of membrane proteins at atomic resolution. These snapshots of the membrane proteins, coupled with biochemical characterization, will provide an understanding of how these proteins function to aid in bacterial pathogenesis and virulence. Dr. Moraes’ research will determine how these bacterial membrane proteins function, which lays the groundwork for designing novel antimicrobials, therapeutics and/or vaccines use against bacterial pathogens.

Project Title: Renewable Bioactives from cereal byproducts and fruit leftovers/wastes
Project Description: Investigate the potential of peptides and oligosaccharides from grain and fruit processing by-products for the production of value-added ingredients that prevent and contribute to the management of inflammation and oxidative stress and therefore, improving intestinal and cardiovascular health.

Project Title: The Protein Engineering and Computational Protein Design Laboratory
Project Description: The proposed research focuses on the development of useful proteins for their application in chemistry and biology using state-of-the-art protein engineering and computational protein design techniques.

Project Title: State-of-the-Art Measurement Systems to Transform the Health and Well-Being of Urban Neighbourhoods
Project Description: The research will document how urban neighbourhoods shape residents’ health and well-being. Combining the study of video data on neighbourhood characteristics in a virtual 3D environment with surveys, insights will be gained to reduce social inequalities and improve population health.

Project Title: Brain Metal Imaging Laboratory
Project Description: This research will develop imaging methods to accurately detect trace metals, including iron and manganese, in normal and diseased brains.  This will lead to a better understanding of the role of metals in serious neurological disorders and suggest effective treatments for patients.

Project Title: Local Indicators Database for Economic Analysis (Local IDEAs)
Project Description: This project will construct an information database by assembling key statistical indicators at the city-region level in Canada. It will include a research tool to analyze the extensive set of indicators in the database to address key questions about the social and economic performance of city-regions.

Project Title: Lentiviral-mediated RNAi technology and high-content screening to systematically analyze programmed cell death in cancer cells
Project Description: The research seeks to identify new specific targets for the treatment of cancer and to improve the therapeutic impact of current treatments.  By using Lentiviruses to shut off genes we will identify the genes required for cells to respond to or evade current chemotherapy drugs.

Project Title: Laboratory for Architecture Intelligence Research (LAIR)
Project Description: LAIR will explore the wide-ranging opportunities that embedded computation and responsive systems bring to the field of architecture, landscape and urban design. The laboratory activities will focus on the design, fabrication, and testing of full-scale working prototypes of high performance building systems and responsive environments.

Project Title: Laboratory for Neural Circuits and Cognitive Control
Project Description: The applicants will establish a novel laboratory that employs multiple-electrode neurophysiology in nonhuman primates to study local and large- scale neural circuits that underlie the cognitive control of behaviour, and understand how alterations in these circuits lead to cognitive dysfunctions in psychiatric disorders.

Project Title: Molecular Characterization of Proteins Critical to Xenobiotic Disposition and Cancer: Enhanced Detection and Quantitation
Project Description: The design of more effective, targeted cancer therapies will rely on a molecular-level understanding of how cellular proteins interact with and metabolize carcinogens and therapeutic agents.  Enhanced mass spectrometry methods for proteomics-based research are critical tools in these investigations.

Project Title: Targeting receptor-receptor interaction for development of novel therapeutics to treat neuropsychiatric diseases
Project Description: Dr. Liu is responsible for the discovery of key protein peptides that specifically target brain pathways involved in certain illnesses. She will identify and validate small molecules that exert the same effect as these peptides, enabling new treatments for stroke, nicotine addiction, schizophrenia and depression.
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: Applied Biotechnology Laboratory
Project Description: The project seeks funding for an advanced applied biotechnology lab for the biochemical production of fuels and chemicals from renewable, non-food resources. It will enable micro-scale screening in oxygen-free environments, followed by process characterisation at bench-scale and scale-up to pilot scale.

Project Title: Advanced Microstructure Characterization Lab
Project Description: The aim of the proposed research is to test nuclear materials through the investigation of irradiation induced microstructures and correlate structure factors with mechanical degradation of nuclear materials, which will further our understanding of irradiation and  lead to the development and design of future nuclear materials.

Project Title: Research Facility for Global Change Molecular Physiology of Trees
Project Description: The research facility for Global Change Molecular Plant Physiology will support Ingo Ensminger’s research on the mechanisms controlling the responses of trees to changing climate - from molecular, to species to ecosystem levels and to answer the question of how trees will respond to climate change.

Project Title: Early detection of deterioration mechanisms for civil infrastructure
Project Description: The proposed research program will develop models that will allow engineers to better determine the effects of complex deterioration mechanisms on Ontario’s aging infrastructure. This research will be supported by the acquisition of two new sensor systems that will provide high quality data to determine the structural response to deterioration. The research will also be enhanced by renovations to lab space that will support precision testing and instrumentation of specimens as well as long-term load testing to determine the effects of sustained loading on structural deterioration.

Project Title: Integrated Field- and Laboratory-Based Mapping Facility for Active Faults and Landscape Evolution
Project Description: Mapping the location and determining how fast faults are moving is crucial both to determining seismic hazard and to understanding the nature of climate-tectonic interactions. An integrated field and laboratory mapping facility to an accurate determination of fault slip rates.

Project Title: Facility for electrochemical engineering of advanced energy conversion systems
Project Description: The research program addresses environmentally important issues through combined fundamental and applied research related to the development of nanostructured electrodes for proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, electrochemical promotion of catalysis and Lithium-ion batteries.

Project Title: Solar Energy Systems Laboratory
Project Description: The scope of the proposed infrastructure is aimed at discovering innovative concepts to significantly increase the use of solar energy in buildings, and improve the design and integration of these technologies into conventional building systems and facilitate their installation.

Project Title: Cellular and Molecular Neuroendocrinology Laboratory
Project Description: The main objective of this proposal is to establish a world class, state-of-the art facility to study hormones that regulate food intake, body weight and blood glucose levels. The three key elements of this research are: significant improvement to existing knowledge, tremendous opportunities for training highly qualified personnel and the potential to translate research findings for human benefit. The outcome of this research will help Ontarians to develop treatment strategies for obesity and diabetes, and to enhance aquaculture productivity.

Project Title: Compression, Transmission and Representation of 3D video over networks
Project Description: The proposed research will provide a facility for developing state of the art solutions for 3D video acquisition, compression and transmission. It will lead to new breakthroughs in applications such as interactive mobile video conferencing and broadcasting live TV programs to millions of consumers over Internet.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: The Organization of Verbal Memory in the Human Brain
Project Description: The goal of the project is to investigate the way in which verbal memories are stored, maintained, and accessed in the brain. The neural systems that underlie memory for verbal information will be examined using neuroimaging tools to uncover how neural systems function to support memory for speech.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Macromolecular Crystallography
Project Description: This project will upgrade the X-ray facility for macromolecular crystallography at the University of Toronto by replacing outdated and adding urgently needed infrastructure equipment. It will advance work on antibodies interacting with HIV, HCMV and BSE-causing prions as well as membrane proteins.

Project Title: Plant Growth and Molecular Profiling Facility
Project Description: We are using state-of-the-art genomics technologies to study a native plant (Thellungiella salsuginea) that thrives in an environment prone to drought, cold temperatures, and low soil fertility.  Genes we identify will be used to design crops with improved performance under poor growing conditions.

Project Title: Cooperative mining machines research test-bed
Project Description: There is an unexplored opportunity in the combination of ideas from the emerging field of cooperative control with real problems in mining machine coordination.  The proposed research aims to study the potential for cooperative behaviour in mining toward improving the safety and productivity of operations.

Project Title: Mechanical and spectroscopic properties of nanoscale soft materials
Project Description: The infrastructure will enable new research on soft material properties on the nanoscale or with nanoscale precision. This research will characterise new material properties not observed on macroscopic samples, and will investigate the interaction of proteins with nanoscale objects.

Project Title: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory for Theoretical and Applied Neuroeducation Research
Project Description: A laboratory for research on education and the brain is proposed, including equipment for measuring brain electrical activity and eye movements. Resulting neuroeducation research will inform educational practice and policy, through increased understanding of cognitive flexibility, learning, and memory.

Project Title: Laboratory for Applied Single-Molecule Biophysics
Project Description: The proposed research program is dedicated to the development of novel techniques and methods to manipulate and characterize single-molecules using nanoscale devices, and to translate these discoveries into new tools for the life sciences.

Project Title: Experimental channel for river hydraulics
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to build an experimental river channel equipped with cutting-edge instrumentation.  This infrastructure will propel research into new topics in sediment transport and flow turbulence as a means of improving the management and restoration of degraded river systems.

Project Title: Groundwater-Coastal Water Interactions Laboratory
Project Description: This proposal seeks infrastructure to enhance understanding of the interactions between groundwater and coastal waters. This is urgently required to develop effective policy and management actions to protect coastal areas and waters that are critical to the well-being and health of Ontarians.

Project Title:
High resolution real-time 3D imaging of bacterial infection in living hosts:
Investigation of blood-borne dissemination mechanisms of the Lyme disease pathogen
Project Description: Hematogenous (blood-borne) dissemination is a critical but poorly understood stage of many infectious diseases. The proposed project will use recently developed intravital microscopy approaches to study dissemination mechanisms of the Lyme disease bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and other pathogens.

Project Title: Laboratory for Rare Stable Isotope Research
Project Description: A state-of-the-art analytical facility for rare stable isotope research will be established at McMaster University to conduct leading-edge research on Earth’s past and current environmental changes by developing environmental proxies and documenting climate changes from the prehistoric world.

Project Title: Peptide-Based Molecular Imaging Agents
Project Description: The Molecular Imaging Synthesis Lab will allow the research group of Dr. Luyt to discover peptide-based compounds that target cancer and will lead to the development of non-invasive imaging agents resulting in earlier cancer diagnosis, more accurate disease staging and superior treatment monitoring.

Project Title: Advanced Membrane Bioreactor (MBR) Process Lab for Wastewater Treatment, Reuse, and Energy Recovery
Project Description: This project proposes to build a process lab to conduct fundamental process research for the development of innovative membrane bioreactor technology for the wastewater treatment, reuse, and energy recovery.

Project Title: Laboratoire des français d’Amérique
Project Description: The Laboratoire des français d’Amérique will examine linguistic practices and identities with which Francophone communities have associated themselves from the 17th century to the 21st century. An extensive language engineering program supports this research, to help identify the specifics of French in North America.

Project Title: Resources and Sustainable Development in the Arctic
Project Description: This proposal seeks to support the establishment of a Northern Social Science Laboratory at Lakehead University and smaller regional social science laboratories at northern research centres. The laboratories will support the work of the Resources and Sustainable Development in the Arctic (ReSDA) proposal currently being considered under the SSHRC MCRI program.

Project Title: Characterizing flavours in foods
Project Description: The objective of the proposal is to acquire infrastructure which will be used to identify and quantify volatile flavours released during chewing. These volatiles will be related to trained sensory panel data to identify important compounds contributing to flavours in foods.

Project Title: Multidisciplinary Laboratory for Innovative Catalytic Science
Project Description: This project enables the initiation of the Multidisciplinary Laboratory for Innovative Catalytic Science. The mission is to deepen the understanding of fundamental knowledge and provide molecular solutions and technologies to address the grand challenges in the fields of energy and environmental science.

Project Title: Integrative & Innovative Biodiversity Analysis from the Tundra to the Tropics
Project Description: Sarah Adamowicz, Mehrdad Hajibabaei, and Alexander Smith study broad biodiversity patterns from tundra to tropical environments. They use innovative genetic tools to investigate cryptic species diversity, trophic structure, latitudinal patterns, and the ecosystems and control mechanisms of forestry pests.

Project Title: Identifying hippocampal neural circuits underlying anxiety
Project Description: Anxiety is an emotional state that arises in anticipation of future or potential threat. Using the mouse as a model organism, the proposed study employs various genetic approaches to identify hippocampal circuits underlying anxiety and understand how they control anxiety-related behaviours.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of Adaptive Development and Emotions in Children and Youth
Project Description: The main aim of the proposed Laboratory for Adaptive Development and Emotions in Children and Youth is to crucially advance our understanding of the role of emotions in children’s and adolescents’ maladaptive and adaptive mental health outcomes.

Project Title: Combined in vitro/in vivo Bioimaging Approach for Translational Research in Lung Injury and Repair
Project Description: Progressive lung injury and repair characterizes a group of frequent, incurable and often fatal lung diseases. Here, we propose an innovative combination of in vitro and in vivo bioimaging techniques to elucidate cellular mechanisms underlying lung disease, and to identify the basis of new therapies.

Project Title: Brain plasticity, neuronal and metabolic adaptations
Project Description: The research program will measure the plastic adaptations of the brain that matches brain energy uptake to local brain activity. Also, the project will study the source of new neurons in the adult brain produced by intense behavioural training.

Project Title: Laboratory for Interactive Research on Environmental and Policy Change
Project Description: This project will integrate natural and social sciences to analyze historical and prehistoric biophysical processes and human-climate interactions; investigate past, current and emergent climate processes and impacts through modeling, traditional environmental knowledge and community-based vulnerability studies; and to generate research for decision-making.

Project Title: Animal Resources to Support Cardiovascular and Cancer Research
Project Description: Leading Ontario cardiovascular and cancer research programs require cutting-edge animal resources to enable the next generation of research discoveries. Drs. Gordon Keller and Pamela Ohashi will receive the necessary research tools to continue moving their programs towards pre-clinical phases of research.

Project Title: Interactions between the respiratory sinus arrhythmia and the efficiency of pulmonary gas exchange, cardiac output, muscle oxygen consumption, and heart rate variability during exercise in humans.
Project Description: The overall goal of the research program, is to identify fundamental mechanisms controlling (or limiting) muscle oxygen utilization in humans during exercise, through non-invasive, integrative exercise physiology research in the area of time-frequency modelling of biological signals recorded in humans during exercise.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Pediatric Exercise and Environmental Testing and Flow Cytometry Suite
Project Description: The research will explain the physical activity-to-health connection, under the principles that physical activity behaviours begin early in life; physical activity is essential for optimal health even in disease; and promotion of physical activity for health is more effective when mechanisms involved are understood.

Project Title: GPU servers for large-scale neural simulation
Project Description: This project will install high performance computers that will allow Dr. Eliasmith to build and simulate large-scale models of the brain.  These models will be unique in their combination of size, biological realism, and their ability to explain cognitive function.

Project Title: Video-on-Demand System to Enhance Research at the University of Waterloo Centre for Mental Health Research
Project Description: The funds requested will be used to promote the continued development of facilities for world-class research into the nature and treatment of psychological disorders. The proposed cutting-edge video-on-demand equipment will facilitate collaborative research ventures, enable major scientific advances, and promote innovative psychotherapeutic treatment to the community.

Project Title: Automation of trace analysis of emerging contaminants
Project Description: A wide variety of emerging contaminants threaten our water resources and therefore the health of our communities and the ecosystems on which we depend. The proposed infrastructure will support the automation of sample extraction, clean-up and preparation of environmental samples for trace analysis of emerging and priority contaminants of concern.  This will enable leading-edge research to support the development of innovative technologies and solutions to manage the risk of these chemicals and complex mixtures in the environment.

Project Title: The Brock Center for Narrative, Visual and Digital Methodologies
Project Description: The Brock Center for Narrative, Visual, and Digital Methodologies aims to be a provincial and Canadian leader in conducting, analyzing, and training in narrative, visual and digital qualitative research methods in sociology and the dissemination of these knowledge forms to scholarly, policy, and wider publics.

Project Title: Infrastructure for comparative analysis of boreal forest dynamics and water use
Project Description: To improve our capacity to predict responses of boreal systems to climate change, we must identify both tree stand and tree species responses to environmental variation. The proposed infrastructure will support large forest plot investigations across Canada and sap flow instrumentation to quantify water use in boreal trees.

Project Title: High content and high throughput technologies for studying cellular functions
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will provide Dr. Daniela Rotin and her team with the necessary resources and equipment to further her groundbreaking research into the regulation and function of transmembrane proteins by two important cellular mechanisms: ubiquitination and reversible phosphorylation. Ubiquitination serves to target proteins for degradation or other cellular fates, while reversible phosphorylation, the addition or removal of a phosphate (PO4) group from proteins by kinases (phosphorylation) and phosphatases (dephosphorylation) of many enzymes and receptors, functions as an "on" or "off" switch. Dysfunction of these processes can lead to diverse human diseases such as hypertension, cystic fibrosis (CF), inflammatory bowel disease and cancer – something which high-content imaging can help decode by uncovering the cellular mechanisms behind these diseases.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Consumer Research Laboratory
Project Description: Using an inter-disciplinary approach, the research will examine barriers to the adoption of new convergent or counter-stereotypical products that disrupt conventional categories and propose marketing strategies to overcome these barriers.

Project Title: Laboratory for Environment, Society & Policy (ES&P)
Project Description: Many communities are socially and economically reliant on vulnerable environmental resources. This research outlines factors that influence community and industry resilience in the context of transitioning economies with the goal of contributing to sustainable livelihoods and strong economic systems.

Project Title: Bioorganic Chemistry Laboratory
Project Description: The struggle to keep degenerative disease from overwhelming our society is key to our future. The requested infrastructure will enable Dr. Pratt’s research group to work towards a better understanding of the molecular basis of the pathogenesis of these processes and strategies to treat and/or prevent them.

Project Title: High-density electrophysiology setup for neural ensemble recording
Project Description: This project will install experimental equipment for the electrical recording of brain activity in behaving rodents. It will enable the direct observation of neural processing during decision-making, and the identification of neural mechanisms that contribute to normal and dysfunctional decision-making.

Project Title: An integrated crystallization robot/imaging system for structural studies of protein phosphorylation systems
Project Description: The research group of the Canada Research Chair in Structural Biology aim to carry out an in-depth study of several key bacterial kinases and phosphatases through integrated structural and functional characterization. These proteins are involved in bacterial pathogenicity or metabolism. The knowledge gained will help novel antibiotics development and the reduction of water bacterial contamination.

Project Title: Laboratory for Integrative Stem Cell Biology
Project Description: The Laboratory for Integrative Stem Cell Biology will establish models of human diseases and pursue greater understanding of the biology of stem cells in order to develop new therapeutic approaches for chronic and degenerative diseases.

Project Title: Integrative Cancer Informatics
Project Description: This project lies at the junction of two strategic priorities for Ontario:  ICT and advanced health technologies.  Dr. Jurisica develops and applies next-generation informatics tools to identify cancer biomarkers for improved diagnosis, prognosis, therapy planning and, ultimately, personalized medicine.
Keyword: Artificial Intelligence

Project Title: Investigation of Pathways to Natural Killer Cell-Mediated  Immunoregulation during Viral Infection
Project Description: This proposal requests infrastructure for studying the functions of natural killer (NK) cells, a component of the immune system vital for protection against viral infections.  Knowledge gained from this project will lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of persistent infections.

Project Title: Laboratory for Structural Immunovirology- integrated infrastructure for mammalian protein expression and microfluidic crystallization screening
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will establish a mammalian expression and microfluidic protein crystallization facility specialized to handle difficult to express and crystallize human and viral proteins. This facility is unique to Canada and will positively impact the academic and biotech sectors in Ontario.

Project Title: Laboratory of Complex Fluids
Project Description: Our goal is to develop tools to understand soft particle mixtures (complex fluids) using a bottom-up approach, and apply these tools to advance the fields of medicine, water treatment, detergents and the oil industry.  This proposal requests funds to establish a laboratory that realizes our research program.

Project Title: Design and Test Laboratory for Implantable Integrated Circuits
Project Description: The objective of this research is to design, fabricate and test an ultra-small sized wireless transmission system intended for providing data and power link to an integrated circuit that will serve as a novel miniature pressure/volume sensor with implantable telemetry for cardiac monitoring in small animals.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Miniaturized Power Sources for MEMS Applications: Novel Microfluidic Rechargeable Batteries
Project Description: The major share of micro electro mechanical systems is still electrically-powered by relatively large power supplies, leading to several problems and compromising the advantages of reduction in device size. This research proposal addresses the development of a novel miniaturised and rechargeable battery.

Project Title: Development of a novel luminescence detector for measurements in proton therapy beams
Project Description: This work aims to develop a novel technology for monitoring radiation delivered in proton therapy cancer treatments. Proton therapy is a new way to treat cancer using highly energetic proton beams. Reliable and practical radiation monitors that can be used in proton therapy beams are currently limited.

Project Title: New generation biosensors for the discovery of effective therapeutics targeting Alzheimer's disease
Project Description: To address the urgent need for effective Alzheimer’s disease treatment, the requested infrastructure will equip a unique research facility to develop a new generation of biosensors that target Alzheimer’s disease therapeutics discovery. The proposed research will benefit Ontario economically and socially.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of Optimal and Thriving Relationships
Project Description: The main aim of the proposed Laboratory for the Study of Optimal and Thriving Relationships is to crucially advance our understanding of the role of prosocial behaviours and emotions (i.e., sacrifice and gratitude) in enabling dating and married couples to maintain happy and long-lasting relationships.

Project Title: Advanced Imaging Platforms for Basic Cancer Research
Project Description: Cancers derived from epithelial cells are responsible for the vast majority of cancer mortality. Dr Tepass’ research investigates the mechanisms required to maintain normal epithelial cells to develop a rational basis for the diagnosis and, ultimately, the effective treatment of individual cancer patients.

Project Title: Laboratory for Interdisciplinary Microbiome Research in Health and Disease
Project Description: The research will examine mechanisms of inter-bacterial and host-bacterial interactions within the human body with the aim of developing novel strategies for the treatment of prevalent medical problems such as cystic fibrosis, asthma, and functional and inflammatory bowel diseases.

Project Title: The Carleton Research and Innovation in Sustainable Energy (C-RISE) House
Project Description: The C-RISE research house will be used to explore and develop innovative concepts to significantly increase the use of solar energy for proving space heating, domestic hot water heating, and space cooling for single family detached housing.

Project Title: Structural Biology Facility for New Generation Cancer Research
Project Description: This innovative program will characterize structures of important cancer-related proteins, perform high throughput screening for compounds that inhibit these proteins and execute state-of-the-art studies of the dynamic behaviour of proteins, which is central to understanding their functional mechanisms.

Project Title: Facility for Nanoscience, Surfaces, and Sensor Interfaces (FANNSI)
Project Description: The facility will allow the integration of nanoelectronic fabrication into research in microelectronics, sensors, photovoltaics, and others. The principle techniques will be atomic layer deposition, chemical vapour deposition, and physical vapour deposition.

Project Title:
Environmental Facility for Investigating Transient Dynamics of Wind
Turbines
Project Description:
The objective is to develop a unique facility at Carleton University that combines
atmospheric wind, motion capability, and sophisticated instrumentation. The
resulting Wind Induced Dynamics Laboratory (WInDLab) will enable research and HQP
training related to wind turbine dynamics, aerodynamics, performance, and control.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the characterization of proteins and their modifications
Project Description: This proposal is for the purchase of a LTQ-Orbitrap Velos mass spectrometer to perform state-of-the-art proteomics experiments on stem cells, cancer cells and human brain tissues as well as for developing novel software tools for the identification of proteins and their modifications.

Project Title: Earth and Planetary Materials Imaging and Analysis Laboratory
Project Description: This proposal will establish a new Earth and Planetary Materials Imaging and Analysis Laboratory. The core of this facility is a field emission electron microprobe (FE-EMP), which will be the first of its kind in Canada. The emphasis on two core themes of research: 1) Impact Cratering; and 2) Mineral Deposits.

Project Title: Sensorimotor Neuroscience: Examining sensory plasticity associated with motor adaptation
Project Description: The goal of the proposed research is to understand the ability of the sensory and motor systems to change.  These results have important implications for the design of motor-skills training and rehabilitation programs for people with neurological disorders and fundamental understanding of sensorimotor control of action for teleoperations and robotics.

Project Title: Laboratory Support for Model Driven Engineering of Software for Automotive Applications
Project Description: The “SoftAuto” Laboratory will dramatically improve the quality of software in automotive systems by supporting both software and electronics modeling and analysis capabilities using appropriate software and hardware tools to support Formal Verification with Hardware In The Loop.

Project Title: Parametric Imaging Program: 3D Strain and Stress for the Detection of Cardiovascular Disease
Project Description: The Parametric Imaging Program is designed to harness the potential of 3D ultrasound to detect cardiovascular disease early.  ‘3D Strain’ is a new, advanced imaging technology that measures heart function and our objective is to investigate its role in improving the cardiovascular health of Canadians.

Project Title: Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Stroke in Diabetes and its Potential Therapeutic Treatments
Project Description: Identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying brain damage after stroke and its targets for neuroprotection. Develop novel therapeutic strategies to prevent neuronal damage and to promote neuronal survival, regeneration, and functional recovery in the injured brain after ischemia and stroke.

Project Title: Innovations and Advances in Youth Mental Health
Project Description: This infrastructure will support research involving the novel application of technology to understand the impact of non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI) material online, to conduct longitudinal studies of NSSI in people’s daily lives, and to develop online resilience programs and resources for youth.

Project Title: Tools for Sustainable Polymerization: Polymer Synthesis, Molecular Weight Measurement and In-line Reaction Monitoring
Project Description: The objective of this request is to seek funding to upgrade the aging infrastructure for sustainable polymer synthesis, in-line reaction monitoring and polymer product characterization.

Project Title: Facility for Emerging Energy Research
Project Description: The funds requested will provide the infrastructure to build the Laboratory for Emerging Energy Research (LEER) at the University of Waterloo. This laboratory will be dedicated to developing sustainable energy and environmentally friendly technologies through multidisciplinary approaches and the application of nanotechnology.

Project Title: Infrastructure for advanced analysis of genome organization and stability
Project Description: DNA holds the genetic information of life and is non-randomly arranged inside the cell nucleus. Defects in spatial order of DNA precipitate aging and its related diseases. Investment in innovative technologies will uncover factors that ensure spatial order of DNA; this knowledge will benefit longevity and health.

Project Title: Characterization and Testing of Smart Hydrogel Materials for Biomedicine
Project Description: “Smart” materials can be triggered to shrink, swell, or degrade “on-demand” upon the application of a physical or chemical stimulus. Drug delivery devices based on these materials can release drugs at targeted sites in the body at optimized rates, improving both the efficacy and comfort of drug therapies.

Project Title: Characterization of Cement-Based Materials using a MicroXRF for Durable Concrete Infrastructure
Project Description: This proposal requests funds that will be used to purchase a micro x-ray fluorescence (microXRF) unit.  This will enable transformative research in the area of durable cement-based materials, leading to significant contributions related to complex age-related degradation mechanisms that ageing concrete structures and infrastructure are vulnerable to.

Project Title: Centre for Multiliteracies for CRC in Multiliteracies
Project Description: The proposed funding will support a centre for innovation in literacy education for a Canada Research Chair in Multiliteracies at Brock University. Facilities and equipment in the centre will be used for national and international research projects on twenty-first century literacy investigating: digital reading and writing; videogame play and literacy learning; and twenty-first century teaching methodologies that promote literacy in a digital age.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Magneto-Optoelectronic Materials Chemistry Laboratory
Project Description: The project`s objective is to investigate and understand the role of structure and morphology on the properties of advanced functional materials. The requested infrastructure will enable Dr. Brusso`s research team to design and develop new materials for molecular electronic applications.

Project Title: Control Mechanisms Regulating Human Memory B Cell Responses and Biomarker Discovery Using Novel Lamprey VLR Monoclonal Antibodies
Project Description: The proposal focuses on two research areas. One part aims at elucidating mechanisms that regulate memory B cell responses via Fc receptor-like molecules. The second part is directed at harnessing structurally unique antibodies of the sea lamprey for the discovery of novel biomarkers.

Project Title: Features of activation and antigen recognition by invariant Natural Killer T cells
Project Description: Invariant Natural Killer T (iNKT) cells hold great potential as future targets for vaccination and immunotherapeutic strategies. This project aims to decipher the fundamental mechanisms that control their activation and to study their potential protective role in intestinal inflammatory disorders.

Project Title: Innovative cancer therapies targeting the perioperative period – A Translational Research Program
Project Description: The proposed project will support the collaborative research program of recently recruited clinician scientists Drs. Rebecca Auer and Marc Carrier which is dedicated to elucidating the mechanisms that link surgical interventions to the spread of cancer in patients as well as developing and testing therapeutic strategies to prevent this spread.

Project Title: Surface nanoengineering of implantable metals to guide cell activity and fate
Project Description: The physicochemical characterization of materials at various length scales, as well as the investigation of how cells and proteins respond to micro and nanoscale surface features, are fundamental prerequisites to design a novel generation of biomaterials capable of guiding the molecular and cellular events that occur at the implant-host tissue interface and that ultimately determine the overall biological outcome of an implanted device.

Project Title: Sample Preparation and Screening Study for Fundamental Studies in Analytical Toxicology and Molecular Genetics
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure is a facility for preparation and screening of complex biological samples for studies in analytical toxicology and molecular genomics. Diverse areas such as monitoring toxins in decomposed tissues to correlation of gene function and biochemical characteristics will be investigated.

Project Title: Completion of the Growth Chamber Facility at the Vale Living with Lakes Centre to Support Restoration Ecology and Climate Change Research
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will outfit a new laboratory that is nearing completion at the Vale Living with Lakes Centre complex at Laurentian University, to support a series of research projects addressing stressed aquatic ecosystems in the Boreal Shield and Hudson Bay Lowland areas of Canada.

Project Title: Arctic Mechanistic Research System for Studying the Integrated Effects of Physiological State and Environmental Variation on Reproductive Decisions in Birds
Project Description: The proposal focuses on an Arctic Mechanistic Research System promoting innovative research on the individual mechanisms driving ecosystem health in sensitive Canadian Arctic habitats via the training of highly qualified personnel capable of entering academia, the government or the private sector.

Project Title: High-resolution NMR spectrometer
Project Description: Purchase of an NMR spectrometer is proposed in support of research in green chemistry developing catalytic hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds, amination and dehydrogenative coupling of alcohols, and alkane dehydrogenation – novel clean technologies with excellent selectivity and atom economy.

Project Title: Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) for Mineral Processing Applications
Project Description: This project will greatly improve our capacity to identify, inspect, analyse and characterize minerals and materials through the acquisition of a tabletop Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The primary goal of our research is to innovate efficient methods to separate and recover minerals from mined ores.

Project Title: Elemental Dynamics in the Environment
Project Description: The proposed research seeks to understand how the relative supply of multiple limiting nutrients available to algal producers affects aquatic ecosystems. These studies will be used to predict how food webs in Canadian lakes will respond to future changes in the ratios of nutrients supplied from internal and external sources. These results will clarify whether managers of lake ecosystems should incorporate control and abatement of non-P nutrients in their future best management plans as they work to protect and improve water quality in ecologically and economically important ecosystems.

Project Title: Chemically-induced Ventricular Septation Defects; Mechanisms and Long-term Health Consequences
Project Description: The purpose of this proposal is to further our understanding of both the mechanisms and the long-term health consequences of the most common of birth anomalies, a hole between the left and right heart chamber.  This information will be used to develop intervention strategies to prevent their occurrence.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the study of soil microbial and plant ecology in the context of exotic biological invasions
Project Description: Dr. Pedro Antunes, OMNR Research Chair in Invasive Species Biology at Algoma University, will utilize ORF-RI funding to acquire molecular microbiology infrastructure to investigate plant-microbe interactions capable of altering the growth of invasive plants in economically important ecosystems of Ontario.

Project Title: Neural organization of long-term memories
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will support the construction of a state-of-the-art behavioural neuroscience laboratory at Trent University for investigating the neural bases of memory in animal models. Specifically, the requested infrastructure will support research into the neural organization of long-term memory with the overarching goal of providing knowledge for the treatment and reversal of amnesia due to neuronal loss. The infrastructure will enable innovative, cutting-edge research examining the organization of memory from a cellular to behavioural systems level.

Project Title: CryoVent – Low or zero carbon cryogenic ventilation for mines
Project Description: The aim of the proposed work is to reduce the energy, cost and carbon intensity of delivery of cool air to the production faces of mines. The research will investigate using a wind turbine to provide work to an air liquefaction plant and delivery of liquid air produced to the subsurface through a bespoke borehole.

Project Title: Laboratory for Cardiovascular Engineering
Project Description: Adult heart tissue cannot regenerate on its own. Our goal is to engineer a replacement tissue starting from human pluripotent stem cells. We will also develop new biomaterials to keep the heart cells alive and functional upon implantation.

Project Title: BD-Influx Cell Sorter
Project Description: This project is for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art flow cytometer and cell sorter, which will dramatically increase the ability to perform analytical and preparative experiments with human stem cells in support of Dr. Zúñiga-Pflücker’s regenerative medicine research program.

Project Title: Multimedia production and analysis studio for interactive research
Project Description: The aim is to develop an “artificially intelligent” software engine for the purpose of creating and implementing sound in interactive media like video games. There are 3 components to the project: algorithmic generation, accessibility, and an audio extraction and analysis.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Interactive Research Innovation Zone (IRIZ) and Digital Archive at the Modern Literature and Culture Research Centre (MLCRC)
Project Description: When World War I erupted in 1914, Canada was one of the first countries to be centrally involved in the world’s first industrial warfare. As the world commemorates the centenary of WWI during 2014-18, Ryerson University Canada Research Chair Dr. Irene Gammel proposes to dedicate her world-class CRC research renewal program to the exploration of "Women, Modernism and World War I."  With the help of the proposed new Infrastructure, the Interactive Research Innovation Zone and Digital Archive at the MLCRC, the research is expected to yield important new insight on Ontario-born war artist Mary Riter Hamilton, and on the war writings of Ontario author L.M. Montgomery, while also centrally advancing Ontario’s Innovation Agenda.

Project Title: Applying the power of molecular biophysics approaches to characterize the functions of natural actin-binding cytotoxins and the molecular performance of novel kinesin motors
Project Description: One of Dr. Allingham’s objectives is to learn how cytotoxic marine natural products can be used to fight cancer. Another objective is to determine the structures and functions of unusual kinesin motor assemblies that are unique to pathogenic fungi, and to understand how they may be used as new fungicidal drug targets. To meet these objectives, Dr. Allingham will apply a multipronged approach that includes x-ray crystallography, protein biochemistry and biophysics studies, cell biology, and high-resolution microscopic imaging.

Project Title: Laboratory and field equipment to support stable isotopic  investigations of North American environmental change since the last Ice Age
Project Description: We will interpret the record of environmental change in the Americas since the end of the last glacial period using the isotopic compositions of ancient and modern water, sediments, plants and animals. We will use the lessons from going ‘back to the future’ to anticipate impacts of climatic change to come.

Project Title: Biorefining facilities for the production of second generation biofuels and renewable chemicals
Project Description: Innovative techniques will be utilized to overcome the major bottlenecks in the production of biofuels and renewable chemicals from ligno-cellulosic woody residues which are abundantly available in Ontario and many other parts of Canada. This will help overcome our dependence on petro-based products.

Project Title: Methods and Tools for Building and Monitoring Reliable and Secure Software Systems
Project Description: This research will investigate and develop methods and tools for building reliable and secure software systems and for their subsequent online monitoring to detect software failures and potential security violations such as unauthorized use or misuse.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Parallel sequencing facility for environmental, ecological and evolutionary research
Project Description: This project will provide equipment support for the Canada Research Chair nomination of Dr Brian Dixon, a world leader in fish immunology. Dr Dixon’s research focuses on current challenges in assessing and diagnosing the effects of climate change on fish health (both at the individual and population level).  The requested equipment will facilitate research which seeks to understand and propose evidence-based solutions for management of fish populations both in fisheries and in the wild.

Project Title: Representations of the hand in higher-order somatic loci and their neural interactions with primary motor cortex
Project Description: The infrastructure will enable new research in the field of human hand control.  Using Functional magnetic resonance imaging and Transcranial magnetic stimulation, the research program will identify novel neural pathways and methods for modifying the neural output directed to the muscles of the hand.

Project Title: Platform for the Analysis of Nanostructured Materials
Project Description: The requested funds will enable the implementation of a state-of-the-art platform dedicated to the multi-scale analysis of both size and porosity of new nanostructured materials developed to fulfill needs in areas such as sustainable energy sources, chemical sensors and materials for catalysis and health.

Project Title: Laboratory for Research to Study Community Integration of People with Mental Illness
Project Description: Dr. Forchuk's mental health systems research will test innovative approaches to care. Information technology infrastructure will provide a “high-tech” research platform to study the use of smart technologies, such as mobile devices, so the "right care is delivered to the right client, at the right time".

Project Title: Spine and muscle injury and adaptation laboratory
Project Description: This project is designed to create a spine and muscle injury and adaptation laboratory at the University of Guelph. This laboratory is dedicated to the study of spinal muscle and soft tissue adaptations in response to spine injury, and of how these relate to prevention and rehabilitation of low back disorders.

Project Title: Laboratory for Social Neuroplasticity
Project Description: Social status can influence the structure of the mammalian brain in adulthood. Dr. Holmes’s research team uses a highly unique animal model, the naked mole-rat, to determine the functional significance of these structural changes and the mechanisms that control them.

Project Title: High-Performance Adaptable Electric and Hybrid Electric Vehicle Powertrain Dynamometer Facility
Project Description: The main objective of the project is to develop a high-performance adaptable powertrain dynamometer facility to support the research program of the Canada Excellence Research Chair (CERC) in Hybrid Powertrain in the areas of advanced electric, hybrid electric, and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles.

Project Title: Integrated microscopy and imaging infrastructure for the physiology and genetics of zebrafish
Project Description: The project`s main goals are to characterize the physiological mechanisms underlying the capacity of fish to adapt to environmental stressors and to investigates aspects of developmental neurobiology and in particular in using zebrafish as a model for human disease.

Project Title: Integrative Computational Biology for Cancer Genomics
Project Description: Cancer is the number one killer of Ontarians, causing one-third of premature deaths in the province. The proposed research will combine computational biology and genomics approaches identify new cancer drug targets and develop new treatments. Ontarians will derive tremendous health and economic benefits from this research.
Keyword: Artificial Intelligence

Project Title: In Situ Characterization of Electrochemical Processes in Lithium Ion Batteries
Project Description: Better lithium batteries are essential for the next generation of electric cars and Ontario’s automotive industry. Studying the real time, nano-scale processes of lithium cells, with magnetic resonance and electron microscopy, will reveal the processes that lead to degradation and improve battery lifetimes.

Project Title: A transmission electron microscopy facility for biomaterials and cell biophysics research
Project Description: The proposed research focuses on imaging nanocomposite biomolecular assemblies, and on advancing the rational design of macromolecules in cell cryopreservation applications. The proposed research will offer better understanding of fundamental cellular processes in regenerative/personalized medicine.

Project Title: Centre for Integrated Bioarchaeological Research in Human Health, Diet, Disease and Migration
Project Description: Three key methodological approaches – microscopy, radiography and stable isotope analysis – will be integrated in the study of human remains to understand past health, nutrition and migration.  Isotopic techniques used to investigate past migration will be expanded for use in modern forensic contexts.

Project Title: High-Pressure Facility for Biomass Conversion, Hydrothermal Chemistry and Corrosion Research under Hydrogen and/or in Super-Critical Water.
Project Description: The requested High-Pressure Facility will allow the research team to study the behaviour of aqueous reaction mixtures under extreme reaction conditions. This will enable new approaches to the conversion of non-food biomass to fuel, and contribute to the development of the next generation of CANDU nuclear power plants.

Project Title: Computational infrastructure for three-dimensional simulations of environmental and geophysical fluid dynamics
Project Description: This project will expand computer facilities used for computer model development and applied research on the dynamics of fluids in natural bodies of water such as Ontario’s thousands of lakes. It will enable us to strengthen our research group’s strong international stature and help attract top talent.

Project Title: Laboratory for neuroscience and musical rhythm investigation
Project Description: The proposal creates a world-class facility to explore connections between music and movement in brain and behaviour. The infrastructure will enable examination of how music affects non-musical capacities, the neural basis of rhythm, and how music can be therapeutically applied to gait disorders.

Project Title: Bioorganic Laboratory
Project Description: The equipment will outfit a bioorganic laboratory for the proper handling, storage, purification, and measurement of biological samples including cells, lipids, proteins, DNA/RNA, and will aid in the organic synthesis of novel biomolecules and potential pharmaceuticals.

Project Title: Integrative Cell Mechanics Studies Using Liquid Cell Atomic Force Microscopy
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure and related research will enable systematic development of new, more accurate diagnostic methodologies for the critical early detection of diseases with clear links to cellular abnormalities, such as cancer, cardiovascular disease, and arthritis.

Project Title: Comparative genetics of innate disease resistance in domestic animals
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will support a research program studying the genetic regulation of innate resistance to infectious diseases. The basic aim is to understand how the innate immune response is regulated at the genetic level with a long term goal of identifying selection markers for increased disease resistance in production animals.

Project Title: High-capacity Dynamic Testing System for Energy Pipelines
Project Description: The objective of the proposed project is to carry out state-of-the-art experimental investigations on the fracture toughness of pipeline steels and apply the test results in the development of the strain-based design and assessment methodologies for energy pipelines.

Project Title: High-energy X-ray micro-computed tomography scanning system for Earth material research
Project Description: Funding is requested for the acquisition of a high-energy X-ray micro-computed tomography scanner to enable novel research on the atomic-scale processes that govern the formation of rocks, with fundamental applications for the exploration and protection of Ontario’s natural resources.

Project Title: Hybrid biomedical optical platform for improved detection and management of brain injury
Project Description: The objective is to combine optical hardware for near infrared spectroscopy, diffuse correlation spectroscopy, and photoacoustic imaging to enable research into a method that is capable of early detection of brain injury in babies born prematurely.

Project Title: Understanding pathogenesis of and immune responses to HIV and tuberculosis co-infection
Project Description: This experienced team of investigators will launch an innovative research programme that will focus on understanding mucosal immuno-pathogenesis and vaccine development for HIV-Tuberculosis co-infection to improve clinical management of these global epidemics.

Project Title: Driver-Truck-Road Interaction Simulator
Project Description: A Truck-Driver-Road Interaction Simulator will be purchased to support research in vehicle dynamics, particularly in the area of human factor studies and highway safety.  This research will be of great benefit to Transport Canada and improve highway and driver safety.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Innovative Nutritional and Activity-based Interventions to Improve, Maintain, or Regenerate Skeletal Muscle Health
Project Description: The research will aim to identify activity- and nutrition-based interventions to increase the mass of skeletal muscle, particularly in aging. This is because skeletal muscle is a key tissue in the development of chronic disease, which currently represents almost 80% of healthcare spending.

Project Title: Pediatric Pain, Health, and Communication Laboratory
Project Description: Pain in children is common and unmanaged pain has significant short and long-term consequences. This proposal will enable the development of a leading-edge research facility investigating the complex interplay of factors that impact children’s pain and identifying ‘best practices’ for intervention.

Project Title: Facility for Applications of Advanced Nanomaterials in Energy Storage for Electric Vehicles
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will create the first laboratory at Western equipped to work on nanomaterials for energy storage - and in particular for Lithium ion batteries and Lithium-Air batteries which are used in electric vehicles (EV) and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEV).

Project Title: Muscle and adipose stem cell analysis
Project Description: Dr. Anthony Scimè conducts state of the art research on adult (i) fat and (ii) muscle stem cells. His research will help unlock answers to questions regarding the emerging field of stem cell commitment to specific muscle and fat tissue subtypes. This has ramifications for contributing innovative and vital data on the Metabolic Syndrome and its primary cause, obesity, which represent a significant Ontario health care problem.

Project Title: Laser Induced Incandescence Instrument for Characterizing the Size and Concentration of Aerosolized Nanoparticles
Project Description: Engineered nanoparticles are important to materials science, but their functionality depends strongly on their size. This research will transform laser induced incandescence, a combustion diagnostic used to measure soot, into a tool for characterizing aerosolized metal and metal oxide nanoparticles

Project Title: Global Employment Standards Database (GESD)
Project Description: Funds are requested for essential infrastructure and the acquisition of small and large-scale survey data from four jurisdictions (Canada, United Kingdom, United States and Australia) to support the development of a Global Employment Standards Database.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of Biomolecular Interations through Micropatterning and High Resolution Fluorescence Microscopy
Project Description: This research will develop novel methods to engineer artificial environments that mimic the complexity found in nature. Combined with high resolution microscopy, this research will yield a glimpse into how cells recognize, interact with, and respond to biomaterials at the micro and nano-scale.

Project Title: Studying the Relationship between Social Interaction and Mathematics Learning: The Learning Interaction Lab (LILa)
Project Description: This project will develop sophisticated, multi-camera video data collection and analysis methods and technology, to address how social interaction and diverse contexts, within and outside classrooms, support success in mathematics learning in Ontario, Canada and internationally.

Project Title: Bridging the Gap Between Childhood Health and Mental Health
Project Description: One of the primary aims of this infrastructure project aims to expand the scope of an existing cohort (The OUCH Cohort) of over 700 Ontario children followed over the first 18 months during immunization (now one of the largest in the world).  This cohort aims to better understand and help prevent the significant challenge of not being able to recover from distress properly by examining how caregivers soothe their infants in a routine distressing context. The infrastructure we are proposing enables us to assess these same children in the immunization clinic, school setting and laboratory setting.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the establishment of the laboratory for the Thermographic Investigation of Sexual Health (TISH)
Project Description: This proposal is to build a cutting edge research facility for the thermographic study of sexual health that will add to our understanding of: 1) sexual functioning across the lifespan; 2) the interaction between chronic health conditions and sexual functioning; and 3) diagnosis and treatment of sexual dysfunction.

Project Title: Laboratory for multiphase flow and mass transfer in porous media
Project Description: The proposed research will use detailed laboratory experiments to better understand the flow of multiple fluids and the mass transfer between those fluids in the subsurface.  Insights will be applied to the cleanup of contaminated soil and groundwater and the geological storage of carbon dioxide.

Project Title: In Vivo Imaging of Cardiovascular Function
Project Description: The objective of the proposal is to investigate the underlying molecular and cellular changes associated with heart disease.  The requested infrastructure will be used to examine the function and structure of healthy and diseased mouse hearts.  With the infrastructure, it will allow the applicant to conduct non-invasive longitudinal analysis of heart size and contractile activity in order to examine the development and progression of heart disease.

Project Title: Acquisition of a Time-Resolved Stereoscopic Particle Image Velocimetry System for Fluid-Structure Interaction Investigations
Project Description: Coupled interactions between flowing fluids and deformable structures form a rich field of practical engineering problems. The proposed infrastructure will enable a nascent research problem examining the critical issues of speech disorders, flow around implanted stents, and small-scale energy harvesting.

Project Title: Solid-State Bioreactor and Environmental Biocatalysis Facility
Project Description: The proposed laboratory facility will enable multiscale studies of biocatalytic processes in soils and other solid-state systems such as municipal, agricultural, or forestry wastes. The research program supported will develop environmental processes for bioremediation, waste treatment, and biofuels production.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Study of Host-Pathogen Interactions
Project Description: This award enables Dr. Brumell to advance his research elucidating the underlying mechanisms of host-pathogen interactions to inform development of novel treatments for bacterial infections and many other common diseases.

Project Title: Centre for Embryonic Health & Viability (CEHV)
Project Description: The objective of the present proposal is to develop markers of embryo health and viability. The proposal integrates single embryo culture, biopsied single blastomeric gene expression profiling and mitochondrial function assessment to delineate the molecular and cellular pathways of embryo health.

Project Title: Nipissing University Organic and Medicinal Chemistry Research Laboratory
Project Description: Leading-edge research is being conducted which will help target osteoporosis and breast and prostate cancers. Simultaneously, the laboratory is also committed to developing novel efficient green synthetic methodologies to access new and diverse forms of biologically and medicinally relevant organic materials

Project Title: Simulation and Imaging Laboratory for the Study of Ischemia Reperfusion Injury and Inflammation in Transplantation
Project Description: Ischemia reperfusion injury (IRI) is a major cause of kidney failure and is a limitation to kidney transplantation. This proposal, submitted by two emerging clinician scientists, will use advanced technologies to study the key elements of IRI, including inflammation, to improve patient outcomes.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Integrated Cardio-Respiratory Research
Project Description: Dr. Simpson's research focuses on understanding cardiac endocrine biology in relation to cardio-respiratory function in health and disease states (e.g., heart failure).

Project Title: Research Laboratory for Integrated High-Speed Broadband Wireless Communication Systems
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure aims at building integrated multigigabits broadband wireless networking system that is of high-performance and high-efficiency. Its supported research programs focus on multi-antenna cooperative communication techniques and micro/millimetre-wave RF front-end circuit design.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Imaging for Management of Cardiovascular Diseases
Project Description: ORF funding will support upgrades and modifications to the MRI suite within the Imaging Research Centre for Cardiovascular Intervention at Sunnybrook Research Institute, to facilitate innovative research into image-guided therapies for cardiovascular disease.

Project Title: Pre-clinical development of cardiovascular stem cells for diagnosis and treatment
Project Description: The infrastructure will establish a state-of-the-art cardiac stem cell culturing facility which will focus on modifying a patient’s own stem cells to repair damaged hearts and to better understand individual disease as well as evaluate and implement novel cell-based therapeutics for patients with heart failure and disorders of cardiac rhythm.

Project Title: Utilizing New Media to Mobilize Knowledge on Race
Project Description: This research program will examine the uses of new technology and digital media to mobilize humanities and social sciences research on issues central to Canadian public life. Relying primarily on films and interactive websites, the project will focus on transferring knowledge about race in Canada.

Project Title: Spinal Muscular Atrophy – Pathogenesis and Novel Therapeutics
Project Description: Spinal Muscular Atrophy is the most common genetic cause of infant death.  Led by two senior scientists at the Ottawa Hospital Research Institute, this project endeavours to further understanding of the pathogenesis of the disease and develop novel therapeutics for this currently incurable disease.

Project Title: Systems-based approach for optimizing field crop production using novel technologies
Project Description: The strength of Ontario agriculture will depend on scientific breakthroughs that increase production efficiencies.  The proposed infrastructure of a combine harvester is THE tool for measuring crop responses to novel systems that will increase competitiveness of the industry in constantly changing global markets.

Project Title: Assessment of pulmonary artery calcification and vascular hemodynamic parameters in horses.
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will support a research program that investigates the effects of pulmonary artery calcification on the pulmonary vascular physiology and potential repercussion on health and performance in racehorses.

Project Title: Novel Ultrasound Instrumentation for Therapy and Imaging
Project Description: This project will use new ultrasound equipment to develop personalized medicine through new cancer response imaging methods and the development of novel ultrasound-based cancer therapies.

Project Title: Wireless acoustic location system, focal recording, and playback technology for studying avian communication networks and night migration in Northern Ontario
Project Description: This request for $26,460.00 in bioacoustics infrastructure will increase understanding of communication networks, singing and migration behaviour of Northern Ontario avian communities. The research will generate important environmental risk assessment tools to inform green energy development in Ontario.

Project Title: Bioorganic Chemistry Laboratory
Project Description: The proposed research focuses on studying the detailed mechanisms by which enzymes function, synthesizing and testing inhibitors with therapeutic potential and engineering enzymes. It also involves the study of structure, localization and trafficking of the related enzymes.

Project Title: Parallel sequencing facility for environmental, ecological and evolutionary research
Project Description: The requested NextGen sequencer will build upon the existing infrastructure at U Windsor’s Environmental Genomics Facility, thereby enhancing our internationally-recognized aquatic environmental research capacity. Specific applications will include; aquatic species invasion monitoring, aquatic food web characterization, species at risk genetic profiling and gene expression of stress in aquatic ecosystems.

Project Title: Specialized Physiological Laboratory for Testing of Therapies for Neuromuscular Disorders
Project Description: This proposal requests infrastructure to support the study of muscle functional recovery following cell, gene and/or pharmaceutical-based treatment strategies for a variety of neuromuscular diseases. Knowledge gained from this project will lead to development of novel therapeutic treatment options.

Project Title: Neural correlates of attention, response suppression, and multisensory processing
Project Description: We are interested in understanding how attention directs or suppresses our actions to external or peripersonal space.  To this end, we use cutting edge research tools and techniques to begin to examine brain-behaviour relationships involving frontal cortex central executive mechanisms.

Project Title: Precise measurements of the proton charge radius and of the fine-structure constant
Project Description: The requested infrastructure (an atomic beam system, a microwave system and a laser system) will be used to measure the radius of the proton and to measure the fine-structure constant (the fundamental constant of nature that determines the strength of all electric and magnetic interactions).

Project Title: Informing Music Performance by Exploring the Production and Perception of Music for Percussion
Project Description: This proposal will establish Ontario’s first music cognition lab with a percussion focus, using recordings of expert percussionists to explore how physical gestures shape the way audiences “hear” music. This will also assist those suffering from deficits in audio-visual integration, such as children with autism.

Project Title: Personalized Metabolomics for Assessment of Nutrition and Exercise Intervention in Human Health
Project Description: The economic burden of chronic diseases in Ontario is unsustainable without practical measures for prevention. The infrastructure will enable the translation of evidence-based nutritional and exercise interventions that improve human health while alleviating risk factors to prevent chronic disease.

Project Title: Laboratory for Human-Centered Computer Science Research
Project Description: This Laboratory’s objective is to enable empirical observation of how real users interact with information technology in desktop, mobile, and touch display environments.  A key element of this laboratory is a mobile eye-tracker, which will reveal what parts of user interfaces are successful at drawing attention.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Integrated Research Platform for Pattern Recognition of Machining Errors
Project Description: The objectives of this project are to better understand the behaviour of non-systematic machining error, modeling relationships between these errors and actual machining forces, and employing the developed knowledge to control and compensate these errors during machining to reduce manufacturing waste.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Infrastructure for Population-Based Infectious Diseases Research
Project Description: The objective of the research is to define the immunologic and genetic predictors of severity in influenza and dengue.  The research will also examine underlying genetic, epigenetic, and immunologic determinants of influenza vaccine response.

Project Title: Behavioral Research Laboratory for the Study Of Consumer Behavior, Consumer Welfare and Well-Being
Project Description: Problems related to consumption are wide-spread and profound, ranging from problematic over-consumption to stress resulting from too much choice. Consumers, as well as government and other groups, are in need of recommendations aimed at helping consumers cope with a consumer society.

Project Title: User interface feedforward and feedback supporting and enabling ubiquitous computing
Project Description: The study and design of user interfaces supporting multi-device computing. Dr. Wigdor will develop user interface tools and other necessary technologies for the construction of decentralized computing experiencesi.e. spread across car, mobile phone, tablets, television, office computer, laptop, etc.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Veterinary Regenerative Medicine Laboratory
Project Description:
This proposal is aimed at identifying the mechanisms that control the biology of domestic animal stem
cells and establishing stem cell lines and tissue-engineering methods for developing transplantationbased
therapies in domestic animals and in particular dogs and horses with orthopedic problems.

Project Title: A high-performance computing system for the simulation of multi-scale systems
Project Description: Developing next-generation technology requires design methods that capture nanoscale features and mechanisms. This research aims to accomplish these goals through development of innovative multiscale modelling design techniques that capture both device-scale and nanoscale functionality.

Project Title: Laboratory for Atmospheric Remote Sounding Technology
Project Description: The funding from this proposal will equip a new laboratory at York University for the development and application of instrumentation for the remote sounding of atmospheric composition. The goal of this research program is to make high-quality, space-based atmospheric measurements that will improve our understanding of air quality issues and climate change.

Project Title: X-Ray Diffractometer for Materials Characterization
Project Description: This proposal is to purchase a X-ray Diffractometer, with a high temperature stage, to assist in materials characterization research being conducted at UOIT. This is a fundamental piece of equipment and will be used in support of research in energy systems, biomaterials, and corrosion.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: High Pressure Pump and Imaging Equipment for Gas Hydrate Experimentation
Project Description:
Ontario has the potential for non-conventional energy resources in the form of natural gas hydrates. The high pressure infrastructure requested here will support fundamental studies in gas hydrates. This type of research is important for
economical and responsible exploitation of the hydrate resource as well as to develop novel CO2 sequestration technologies.

Project Title: Establishing a laboratory to study the influence of parent-child feeding interactions on children's dietary intake and weight outcomes
Project Description:
The objective of this proposal is to develop a laboratory that will focus on understanding parent-child
feeding interactions. The results of this research will inform public health and clinic-based obesity
prevention interventions in Ontario.

Project Title: Evaluation of Physical Activity, Cognitive Function, and Brain Correlates
Project Description: To acquire infrastructure to assess cognitive, physical, and neurophysiological function to identify strategies to prevent dementia, with focus on physical activity. This research will produce social and economic benefits to Ontario families and the province and backs Ontario’s Aging at Home strategy.

Project Title: Infrastructure to identify drugs that modulate trinucleotide repeat expansions to treatneuromuscular diseases
