Project Description: Over 40 neuromuscular/-degenerative diseases are caused by expansion of repetitive DNA sequences like CAG/CTG (trinucleotide repeats), including myotonic dystrophy type 1. This disease impacts ~ 7000 Canadians and is the most common, impairing muscular, nervous, respiratory,cardiovascular, and reproductive systems.

Project Title: Advanced Simulation of Critical Structures under Extreme Loading
Project Description: The objective of the proposal is to develop the Structural Dynamics and Advanced Simulation Laboratory. The laboratory will be equipped with seismic simulators, a ten-element hybrid simulator, dynamic actuators, controllers, and a reconfigurable reaction systems.

Project Title: Infrastructure for studying amphibian pathogens, genomics, and diversity.
Project Description: The proposed research will explore amphibian genomics, epidemiology, and biodiversity. Results will assist in the management of an emerging amphibian pathogen, increase understanding of economically important species with duplicated genomes, and assist in the discovery and description of new species.

Project Title: From Cognitive Neuroscience to Clinical Practice
Project Description: Detecting and measuring residual brain function in behaviourally non-responsive patients with severe brain injuries, establishing research into the cognitive deficits that characterize neurodegenerative diseases, and continuing to deliver research into memory, attention and other ‘higher’ functions of the human brain.

Project Title: Discovery of new genes in brain lipid metabolism for health and disease
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to establish infrastructure for a world-class program on discovery of new genes in brain metabolism. The equipment will support biomedical research leading to advances in understanding, preventing, and treating neurological disease and promoting brain health with aging.

Project Title: Industrial Bioproducts Laboratory (IBL)
Project Description: The infrastructure requested in this proposal is for a new Industrial Bioproducts Laboratory (IBL) at Western, to support research and technology development on production of industrial bioproducts (green fuels, biochemicals and bio-based materials) from non-food renewable resources.

Project Title: Role of Bacterial Toxins in Infectious Diseases: MolecularMechanisms and TherapeuticOpportunities
Project Description: This award will enable Dr. Melnyk, a repatriate, to establish an innovative laboratory to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying bacterial pathogenesis. Knowledge gained will inform development of novel therapeutics to address hospital-acquired infectious diseases such as those caused by pathogenic strains of C. difficile, thereby resulting in improved healthcare and decreased healthcare costs in Ontario.

Project Title: Platform for the study of bioactive compounds in health and environmental sciences
Project Description: The proposal requests funding for infrastructure for studies on the mode of action of novel bioactives in health and environmental sciences. Results from the research will provide innovative developments toward use of bioactives as alternatives to synthetic pesticides and as novel nutraceutical compounds.

Project Title: Analysis of developmental cell fate and function through application of advanced flow cytometry and microscopy
Project Description: The project provides for a high throughput, 5 laser multi-parameter cytometric cell analysis capabilities for understanding mechanisms of stem cell development for regenerative medicine. Requested equipment will also enable live deep tissue imaging of protein complexes in the brain.

Project Title: Advanced pharmaceutical therapies: Developing mechanism-based bioactive molecules through an integrated approach
Project Description: Design and development of novel therapeutics such as small molecules, peptide and proteins to treat chronic  disorders and their delivery using gemini surfactants as nanoparticle based macromolecular drug delivery systems

Project Title: Quantitative Morphogenesis and Wound Repair Laboratory
Project Description: Deficient healing of skin wounds in diabetics often leads to limb amputation. In embryos, the skin heals rapidly and with no scars. We use advanced microscopy and computational analysis to investigate wound healing in transparent fruit fly embryos and develop strategies that accelerate wound closure in humans.

Project Title: Infrastructure for a cutting-edge integrative physiology laboratory for examining the effects of environmental stress on animals
Project Description: The research will determine the physiological basis for how climate change and other forms of environmental stress are impacting fish and wildlife in Ontario. It will use innovative and integrative methods to explain the variation in how animals respond to low oxygen stress, in the lab and in the field.

Project Title: Digital Tools for Music Education
Project Description: iSCORE, a web-based tool that helps students learn music, contains structures to support self-regulated learning and to deepen communication amongst students, teachers, and peers. We hypothesize that iSCORE will enhance intellectual and social engagement, thereby resulting in better learning.

Project Title: Direct and indirect regulation of NMDA receptors by 5-HT7 receptor signaling
Project Description: The objective of the research outlined in this proposal is to elucidate signal transduction pathways in nerve cells that alter brain function. We will examine how serotonin receptors modulate the activity of glutamate receptors at synapses both directly and via signaling to growth factor receptors.

Project Title: Placental Pathophysiology Research Laboratory
Project Description: The key research objectives of the current proposal are to: a) determine how placental dysfunction is established, b) design effective screening tools to identify women at risk early in pregnancy, and c) identify therapeutic targets which can be modulated to improve fetal and maternal health outcomes.

Project Title: Creative Practices Centre / Centre de Pratiques Créatives
Project Description: The CPC will be a bilingual research hub for interdisciplinary health research, addressing topics related to the social and rehabilitation sciences. The main focus of this research is on chronic illnesses, such as cancer, and interventions related to improving quality of life for those experiencing illness and disability.

Project Title: Broadband Seismograph Network for Passive Seismic Imaging of Earth Structures
Project Description: The objective of the project is to improve characterization of subsurface Earth structures and tectonic activity in the northern Canadian Cordillera by temporarily deploying an array of 10 state-of -the-art broadband seismograph stations in the Yukon and Northwest Territories.

Project Title: High-repetition-rate laser diagnostic facilities for studies of flow and combustion dynamics
Project Description: This proposal is for a high-repetition-rate laser diagnostics facility with which to measure the harmful flow and combustion dynamics occurring in advanced engines. The knowledge and technology generated will lead to transportation and power generation systems with reduced environmental impact.

Project Title: Evolutionary Consequences of Losing Recombination and Segregation in Plants: Infrastructure for Interdisciplinary Research
Project Description: This proposal seeks funding for infrastructure for Dr. Marc Johnson’s interdisciplinary research on the evolutionary consequences of sexual reproduction in plants and plant-insect interactions. This research addresses some of the most fundamental problems facing today’s basic and applied biologists.

Project Title: Analysis of Signaling Networks Evolution, Function and Their Role in Disease
Project Description: Every living cell senses and responds to external signals, through the action of complex protein networks. Malfunction of these networks can lead to severe diseases, such as cancer. The proposed research will investigate how protein networks evolve and how their malfunction leads to disease.

Project Title: DLL4-Notch as a novel strategy to improve tumor radiation response
Project Description: Dr. Liu’s research aims to improve the effectiveness of radiation treatment for cancer by investigating novel targeted drugs. His research will investigate how Notch inhibitors effectively delay tumor growth following radiation treatment, so that it can be translated to improve outcomes for cancer patients.

Project Title: Multidisciplinary Laboratory for Development of Next Generation MRI Contrast Agents for Biomedical Imaging
Project Description: The proposed research aims to develop next generation MRI contrast agents with high sensitivity, minimum toxicity, and molecular specificity for 1) noninvasively detecting diseases at an early stage, and 2) real-time imaging of specific physiological or pathological processes at the molecular level in vivo.

Project Title: Food, Health and Aging for reduced health care costs
Project Description: Many health-related syndromes of modern civilization can be traced back to poor eating habits. In this work we seek to use food structuring as a means of improving the health characteristics of manufactured food products, thus mitigating the ever increasing costs of health care.

Project Title: Dissection of Legionella pneumophila virulence factors through the integration of experimental adaptation and high-throughput genomics.
Project Description: The severe pneumonia, Legionnaires’ disease, is caused by exposure to Legionella pneumophila bacteria. The Ensminger lab uses several advanced technologies to understand how L. pneumophila has evolved into a pathogen and the mechanisms by which it continues to cause disease.

Project Title: An advanced, integrated instrumented vehicle laboratory for assessing and improving driver behaviour through on-road experimentation
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will enable real-world observation of driver behaviour. The focus of research is on improving (1) driver behaviour through augmented feedback using emerging technologies and (2) existing traffic models by incorporating stochastic sub-models of driver behaviour.

Project Title: Infrastructure for an integrative laboratory studying normal and aberrant cerebral cortical development
Project Description: Developmental brain disorders that cause attention deficits impose significant costs on affected individuals, their families and Ontario’s society. Dr. Craig Bailey will employ a multidisciplinary approach to discover neurological mechanisms underlying attention deficits caused by specific developmental brain disorders with the long term goal of identifying new and more effective therapies.

Project Title: Research Infrastructure for Experimental Spatial Ecology
Project Description: Global changes, such as global warming and fragmentation, are causing ecosystems to change at unprecedented rates. The Research Infrastructure for Experimental Spatial Ecology (RIESE) will enable researchers to determine the processes that underlie ecological responses to global changes.

Project Title: Molecular Analysis and Imaging of the Ubiquitin-Proteasome-System Facility
Project Description: Proteasomeseliminate cytotoxic proteins that if not degraded seedharmfulaggregates that are typical features of neurodegenerative diseases. Dr. Enenkel will establish an imaging facility using fluorescence microscopy and gel documentation systems to determine how proteasome diversities and dynamics are regulated by a mechanism conserved from yeast to man. Her research will providethe groundwork for designing novel drugs to prevent the early onset and to improve the treatment of neurological diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and Huntington’s.

Project Title: Development of Micro and Nano-structured Biomimetic Adhesion Technology
Project Description: Development of micro and nano-structured biomimetic technology for effective adhesion and/or joining of similar and dissimilar material components, one key technical prerequisite for manufacturing biosensors, medical devices, microelectronics and many other technologies at ever-smaller scales.

Project Title: RESEARCH CENTRE FOR ENVIRONMENTAL TOXICOLOGY & MOLECULAR PHYSIOLOGY (RCETMP)
Project Description: RCETMP will study environmental pollutants to identify their effects and mechanisms of action in frogs and to discover novel molecular biomarkers associated with specific chemical exposure.

Project Title: The production of biochemicals from organic wastewater using biocathode microbialelectrochemical cells
Project Description: Research supported by the requested infrastructure will introduce an innovative biotechnology capable of recovering hydrogen gas and pure chemicals from waste biomass. This research will contribute to energy security and the development of green technologies in Ontario.

Project Title: Dance: Quantifying Interpersonal Synchronization of Movement and Social Interaction
Project Description: Dance is a universal human behaviour with social, cognitive and physical consequences. We will scientifically study this most complex and interesting form of inter-personal coordination using 3-D movement modeling in adult dancers and children with developmental coordination disorder.

Project Title: High Speed Test Cell for Next Generation Electric and Hybrid Powertrain
Project Description: The proposed test cell will enable research into the latest generation of Electric (EV) and Hybrid Electric (HEV) Vehicles. The test cell will allow design and analysis of powertrains using electric motors (e-motors) with speeds of up to 22,000rpm. The system will be used to reproduce in-vehicle loading of e-motors in a controlled, repeatable laboratory setting.

Project Title: Stereoscopic 3D Lab (S3DL)
Project Description: The proposed CFI LOF grant will upgrade and expand the capabilities of the Stereoscopic 3D Lab (S3DL) facilities at York University. The vision is a flexible laboratory containing state-of-the-art equipment for the capture, post-production and display of stereoscopic 3D (S3D) cinematic content. The twin pillars of this research are leading edge film production and pioneering stereoscopic vision science.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: PALEOGENOMICS: STATE-OF-THE-ART HIGH-THROUGHPUT ENRICHMENT AND SEQUENCING FACILITY FOR FOSSIL AND FORENSIC REMAINS
Project Description: The research will use novel enrichment strategies to extract DNA from pathogens and past peoples in order to understand issues of disease dynamics through time by contextualizing disease severity, human susceptibility and the interplay between host-pathogen co-evolution.

Project Title: Application of High Performance Parallel Computing to the Numerical Simulation of Biofuel Combustion and Combustion-Generated Emissions
Project Description: Biofuels have great potential to reduce the carbon dioxide and particulate emissions into our atmosphere. This project will apply high performance parallel computation to study the combustion and emissions of biofuels, facilitating their inclusion in power generation and transportation technologies.

Project Title: WATGAME: Waterloo Games Analysis and Monitoring Environment
Project Description: The proposal’s objective is to create a leading-edge games research facility to enable the study of player immersion, presence, and relationships in videogames. Infrastructure requested includes 1) configurable games space, 2) media, 3) capture and recording equipment, and 4) a research and analysis lab.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: National Centre for Audiology
Project Description: The National Centre for Audiology focuses on research in hearing and hearing health care.  It addresses issues in basic and applied research in normal hearing, hearing loss, and hearing technologies bringing together researchers in the biologic and behavioural sciences and engineering technology.

Project Title: Advanced methods for synthesis, biosynthesis, and biomanufacturing
Project Description: The project focus is the manufacture bioproducts of importance to human health and wellbeing using transgenic microorganisms and plants (tobacco). The development of environmentally friendly “Green” processes for biomanufacturing is strategically important to Ontario for the creation of new pharmaceutical industries. The repurposing of tobacco for biomanufacturing valuable bioproducts will create new farming opportunities for approximately 100,000 acres of land in Southern Ontario that are no longer being used for the cultivation of smoking tobacco.

Project Title: Imaging the Mouse
Project Description: Much of the understanding of the genetic basis of human diseases will be learned from mice. To learn what happens when genes are abnormal in mice requires imaging. This imaging infrastructure will characterize mouse models of mental health, cancer, heart and genetic abnormalities.

Project Title: Privacy Enhancing Technologies at a Global Scale
Project Description: This project seeks to acquire leading-edge equipment to develop testbeds for large-scale experiments on next-generation privacy-enhancing technologies.  This will enable the development of new products and services allowing Ontarians to participate in the digital economy without sacrificing their privacy
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Small Angle Neutron Scattering for Advanced Characterization of Nanostructure in Materials
Project Description: The unique SANS for Nanostructured Materials facility will enable unique and definitive advanced characterization of structure at the nano scale. It will create knowledge about new materials to create applications relevant to energy, communications, transportation, human health and the environment.

Project Title: Enhancing the Spectromicroscopy Beamline and Endstations at the Canadian Light Source
Project Description: Soft X-ray spectromicroscopy beamline at the Canadian Light Source, one of the beamlines funded from the CFI/OIT (1999), has been operational since fall 2006. The proposed infrastructure is critical to significantly improving performance and adding new, unique capabilities, critical for planned research.

Project Title: Ontario Centre for Characterisation of Advanced Materials
Project Description: Hundreds of research and technology development projects, industrial and academic, need atomic-scale characterisation (bulk and surface) of their materials to maintain/advance Ontario leadership in energy, medicine, electronics, resource recovery, etc. OCCAM, an open-access CFI-ORF funded analytical facility, fills this need.

Project Title: The Centre for Applied Genomics:  Paediatric Genomes to Outcomes
Project Description: Infrastructure enhancement to increase genome sequencing and analysis capacity at The Centre for Applied Genomics. The new infrastructure will enable a massive Ontario-led international paediatric disease sequencing project, laying the groundwork for an era of genomic medicine in the province.

Project Title: A Distributed Data Management Infrastructure for Indigenous Knowledge Research with Inuit and First Nations Communities
Project Description: This infrastructure project will build on and deploy an atlas-based research data management system specifically designed for indigenous and local knowledge. It will enable new forms of collaborative community-based research in support of communities and will facilitate enhanced decision-making.

Project Title: AFAR takes flight: new technologies to study global-, regional-, and local-scale movement ecology of free-living birds
Project Description: We will develop and use next-generation space and ground-based telemetry, stable isotopes, and radar to study natural and human factors that influence the movements of birds to advance scientific knowledge, promote environmentally sound land use, and advance Ontario’s green energy objectives.

Project Title: Green and Intelligent Automotive (GAIA) Research Facility
Project Description: Waterloo will establish a world-class Green and Intelligent Automotive (GAIA) Research Facility to support the development of new plug-in hybrid and electric vehicle technologies, tightly integrated with wireless sensing and communication innovations, to reduce vehicle emissions and fuel consumption.

Project Title: Centre for Functional and Metabolic Mapping
Project Description: The program involves innovative neuroimaging research in challenging populations such as neonates, patients with involuntary movements, subjects performing goal-directed movements and non-human primates. It will also facilitate the development of MRI compatible devices for neurological applications

Project Title: Development of open-access research tools for epigenetics
Project Description: We will build on our consortium’s expertise to generate knowledge and research tools in the pioneer area of epigenetics; including 3D structure of key proteins, in vitro and cellular screening assays and 15 chemical probes that together will enable Ontario scientists to discover new drug targets and medicines

Project Title: Facility for Global Quantum Communication and Security Certification
Project Description: Quantum cryptography is the first wave of a quantum information technology revolution. This research facility will help Ontario lead this revolution. It will enable the development of techniques and devices to guarantee unprecedented data security, and prototypes for a global quantum satellite network
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Full field vision and spatial orientation
Project Description: This unique sensory display infrastructure will be used to: 1) quantify the role of vision in the far periphery for posture, orientation, locomotion and driving, 2) inform the development of health technologies to aid balance and movement, and 3) enable the development of advanced serious-games-based training systems.

Project Title: The Centre for Cancer Epigenomics: Advancing Personalized Medicine Through Epigenomics and Genomics
Project Description: The Centre for Cancer Epigenomics will reveal the role and regulation of the cancer epigenome and its potential modification to advance patient diagnosis and treatment through fundamental cutting-edge epigenomics research and data integration.

Project Title: Host-Microbiome Research Network
Project Description: This proposal will build upon existing infrastructure to develop and link two state-of-the-art facilities, both with the goal to explore the relationship between the gut microbiota and human inflammatory diseases. The overall goal is to gain a better understanding of disease and develop new preventative and treatment strategies.

Project Title: Ontario Materials Technology: Harnessing the power of strategic multifunctional materials for emerging clean technologies
Project Description: Ontario Materials Technology will provide a unique, state-of-the-art, multidisciplinary materials research facility for fundamental research of multifunctional materials and 3D device prototyping for targeted applications, with the goal is to dramatically transform the way we advance new materials technologies.

Project Title: Facility for load-bearing imaging, biomechanics and clinical orthopaedics research (LIBCOR)
Project Description: We propose to develop a facility to image bone and joint tissues during functional loads and movements. We will combine different methods of imaging joint anatomy to investigate biomechanics and compare treatments – ultimately decreasing the burden of bone and joint disorders on Ontarians.

Project Title:
Technology and Instrument Developments for Space and Ground-based
Astronomy
Project Description: We will develop a novel astronomical spectrograph based on recently-developed technologies in the fields of telecommunication, MEMS, optical fabrication, etc. We will use the unprecedented capabilities of the spectrograph to carry out observational research into fundamental questions in astronomy

Project Title: High pressure blow-down facility for gas turbine combustion research
Project Description: Combustion in gas turbines occurs at high pressures and temperatures. However, our knowledge of combustion at engine-relevant conditions is very limited. The research program will address this gap in knowledge to improve energy efficiency and pollutant emissions by experiments at realistic conditions

Project Title: A large Area Detector Dual Energy CT Scanner for Low Radiation Dose Functional Imaging Research in Oncology and Cardiology
Project Description: To acquire the first large coverage CT scanner dedicated to the development of dual energy, low radiation dose CT scanning methods to measure regional blood flow in whole organs. These methods can be used to predict and monitor response of cancers and heart attacks to treatment.

Project Title: Enhancement and development of new assessment tools for evaluation of brain function and dysfunction
Project Description: The research group has developed core facilities that will now be exploited to develop novel assessment tools for the evaluation of brain function using nonhuman primate (NHP) behavioural neurophysiology, NHP and human brain imaging, and clinical behavioural assessment.

Project Title: Laboratory for ultrafast ultrasound and optical methods used to probe cell and tissue structure and function
Project Description: Methods combining light with ultrasound to image and treat cancer will be developed. To assist in this effort, microscopic agents that find and treat cancer cells will be developed. The proposal has relevance to the well-being of Canadians in a key and growing segment of the Ontario / Canadian economy.

Project Title: Centre for the Evaluation of Technological Innovation (CETI)
Project Description: Our research group is seeking funding for infrastructure support to expand our work into early Health Technology Assessment (HTA) of pre-market health technologies in order to ensure proven technologies for the health system and support technological innovation for the Ontario economy

Project Title: Leading the Search for Dark Matter and Double Beta Decay: Improved Discovery Potential for DEAP-3600 and SNO+ Experiments
Project Description: Significant improvement in discovery potential for the DEAP-3600 and SNO+ experiments to enable Ontario to lead the world in particle astrophysics and attract and retain the best scientists and students. Infrastructure: 4000 kg of very low radioactivity argon (Ar), 1932 kg of Nd, computers and storage.

Project Title: Deterioration and long term performance of buried infrastructure
Project Description: Augmentation of the leading international buried pipe test facility at Queen’s will accelerate studies of deteriorated and long term pipe strength, and the quality of the water within, enabling Ontario companies to develop better pipe and storm-water detention products and extend public infrastructure longevity.

Project Title: Human Laboratory for the Study and Treatment of Gastrointestinal Disorders
Project Description: The proposed cutting-edge Human Laboratory will be a research facility for the study of digestive diseases that will expedite treatments and technology in patients without impeding patient care, and will be driven by first-in-the-world discoveries of human treatments and strong industrial partners.

Project Title: Centre for Advanced Photonics: Translating Discovery to Innovation
Project Description: With this infrastructure, the photonics teams in science and engineering at University of Ottawa will translate discoveries in nanophotonics to innovations in sensing and sustainable ICT. In a purpose-built new centre, they will position Ontario as a strategically-significant centre in global photonics R&D.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Environmental stressors in the Great Lakes: assessment, functional analysis and remediation
Project Description: As a centre of agriculture, fishing and industry, the Great Lakes region is critical to Ontario’s economic and environmental wellbeing. The University of Windsor will use a multifaceted scientific approach to identify, analyze and remediate the threats impacting the area, such as pollution and invasive species

Project Title: Centre for the development and testing of MR-compatible medical devices and technology
Project Description: We seek to establish “The Centre for the Development and Testing of MR-compatible Medical Devices and Technology” to attract and support industrial and academic partners in Ontario, Canada, and abroad for the purpose of testing and developing MR-compatible medical devices.

Project Title: Moving Load Facility for Assessment of Bridge Strength and Durability
Project Description: This project will enable cutting edge research toexplain how moving loads on bridges and climate changes impact bridge deterioration. The research will extend the life span of existing and new bridges,improve sustainability, reduce maintenance costs and traffic disruption,and enhance public safety.

Project Title: Sustainable Chemical Synthesis From Renewable Feedstocks
Project Description: A transformative flow chemistry platform and new tools for biocatalysis research and light-driven catalysis will enable the multidisciplinary Centre for Catalysis Research and Innovation to better serve Ontario and Canada’s chemical manufacturing sector with a focus on value-added chemicals from renewable feedstocks such as agricultural and wood waste.

Project Title: Identification and validation of novel drug targets in cells, animals and humans
Project Description: Cell models and automated microscopy will be used to identify genes involved in disease processes with a particular emphasis on cancer. The identified genes will be validated as potential drug targets in cultured cell and animal models of disease, and in patients using cellular and molecular imaging.

Project Title: A digital radio telescope for CHIME: Making a 3D map of the largest volume of the Universe to date.
Project Description: The CHIME project plans to survey the largest volume of the universe to date, which allows an accurate measure of the mysterious dark energy. It builds on Ontario leadership in the field of 21cm cosmology intensity mapping, using a purpose-built digital radio telescope to map the emission of cosmic hydrogen.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Nanomaterials for Energy.
Project Description: Ontario is a leader in clean energy policy and renewable energy, home to a rapidly growing solar industry. The infrastructure built through this project will enable world class research at the University of Toronto on sustainable energy harvesting and energy conservation, supporting the Ontario’s innovation economy.

Project Title: New horizons for research at the Trent University Water Quality Centre using high resolution mass spectrometry
Project Description: The requested upgrade/expansion of Trent’s Water Quality Centre will facilitate many internal and external research projects, resulting in environmental pollution reduction and better understanding of fate and impact of aquatic pollutants. It will also provide specialized training for environmental scientists

Project Title: Inclusive Design Institute
Project Description: The Inclusive Design Institute will establish a focal point for innovative applied research in inclusively designed information and communications technologies. This much-needed regional platform will maintain and enhance Ontario’s lead in this critical area of the knowledge economy, supporting Ontario’s commitment to inclusion.
Lead Research Institution: Ontario College of Art and Design University
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Intravital microscopy infrastructure for the study of nanoparticle efficacy and toxicity in vivo.
Project Description: With the requested infrastructure, the proposed Chair's research will create an innovative program for developing advanced targeted delivery systems composed of nano-structured materials by combining the intrinsic properties of nanoparticles with micro-scaled drug delivery devices.

Project Title: Techniques and Tools for the Development and Evolution of Service Oriented Architecture Applications
Project Description: Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) applications, eg. e-commerce applications, play a critical role in our daily lives. The proposed infrastructure permits the creation of techniques and tools to support evolution of SOA applications, ensuring the delivery of reliable services with enhanced user experiences.

Project Title: Molecular Dissection of immunologic disease
Project Description: Immunologic diseases are among the most common and debilitating of human maladies and there is an urgent need for strategies to improve outcomes. This project supports research aimed at defining the molecular pathways that underpin such conditions to ultimately identify potential therapeutic targets.

Project Title:
Next generation sequencing capacity for functional genetic screens in mammalian cells and
synthetic antibody development.
Project Description: To identify novel cancer cell vulnerabilities through functional genetic screens and develop new tools and technologies to gain deeper biological insight into oncogenesis and, ultimately, serve as diagnostic and/or therapeutic agents.

Project Title: Dissecting the Roles of Gene Silencing Pathways in Chromatin Modulation, Development, and Adaptation
Project Description: The Claycomb lab will use a variety of technologies in the model nematode C. elegans to understand the conserved mechanisms and functions of cellular small RNA-mediated gene silencing pathways and RNA interference (RNAi), which may aid in the development new small-RNA/RNAi based therapeutics

Project Title: High resolution confocal cell imaging platform.
Project Description: The objective of Dr. Angers’ research program is to understand both the communication between cells during embryonic development and tissue homeostasis, and how this communication is malfunctioning in human diseases such as cancer.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Membrane Protein:Protein Interaction Facility
Project Description: Membrane proteins represent the majority of novel drug targets. Dr. Moraes will dissect the function of membrane proteins from bacterial pathogens and examine their interactions in molecular detail in order to develop novel antimicrobial therapeutics.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Integrative Neuroscience
Project Description: We investigate the neural mechanisms and circuits by which the brain integrates information across the different senses into a coherent percept, and how failure of this process may contribute to neuro-cognitive disorders.

Project Title: Infrastructure to support the study of perinatal programming of offspring physiologic function and disease risk
Project Description: Perinatal nutrition critically impacts fetal development and offspring susceptibility to disease.  This research investigates the drivers underlying perinatal programming of disease risk and how early life nutritional adversity alters reproductive and metabolic development.

Project Title: Imaging Research Laboratory
Project Description: Focused ultrasound (FUS) is a non-invasive method used for diagnostic and treatment purposes and is capable of inducing biological effects without causing damage to surrounding tissue. This research aims at developing FUS image-guided devices for various clinical applications.

Project Title: Motivational Science Laboratory to Support Research in Motivated Social Cognition
Project Description: The proposed research program uses Dr. Scholer’s innovative hierarchical model of self-regulation to advance our understanding of how people manage goal conflicts, make decisions, and embrace change. Research results will contribute toexciting new intervention possibilities to help people reach their full potential.

Project Title: Facility for analysing mixtures of contaminants in groundwater and sediments for remediation studies
Project Description: Our team of researchers will develop innovative approaches for remediating industrial residues containing mixtures of metals and organic compounds. The infrastructure will facilitate research which will positively impact Ontario’s ecosystem and provide competitive financial and scientific advantages.

Project Title: Establishment of the Sensory-Movement Behaviour Lab to examine the visual-motor regulation of upper limb actions
Project Description: The sensory-movement behaviour lab will examine how typically developing people and those compromised by disorders, disease, or trauma control their movements. The goal of the lab is to identify human capacities and reduce barriers with the intention of increasing the quality of life of all Canadians.

Project Title: Genomic technologies for mapping pathways and understanding diseases
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to develop infrastructure to support a research effort aimed at more efficiently mapping functional relationships between genes and proteins by exploiting current next-generation sequencing technology.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Development and Study of Extracellular Matrices
Project Description: The LABORATORY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND STUDY OF EXTRACELLULAR MATRICES will support the development of new polymer-based extracellular matrices (ECM) for stem cell research, and for immuno-isolation of transplanted therapeutic cells.

Project Title: Multi-Scale Environmental Particle Analysis Laboratory (MEPAL): A Core Facility of the CERC in Ecohydrology
Project Description: The Multi-Scale Environmental Particle Analysis Laboratory (MEPAL) is a facility dedicated to the chemical and structural analysis of (nano)particulate materials in groundwater and surface waters. It yields essential information on the fate and fluxes of nutrients and contaminants at the watershed scale.

Project Title: The role of exercise and mitochondrial dysfunction in neuromuscular disorders and aging
Project Description: This “bench to bedside” research programme will examine neuromuscular disorders and aging associated muscle loss to determine novel therapeutic approaches, including exercise, as a prescription for disease management, improved health and lesser disability.

Project Title: Brewster’s Angle Microscopy, PM-IRRAS, and Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy facility for the characterization of mixed lipid monolayers
Project Description: Our work focuses on the study of lipid membranes as models for cellular membranes, and how these membranes change when exposed to a drug or drug delivery system.  The information gained from this study will be used to develop new drug therapies, and to optimize existing ones so as to make them more cost effective. This study will utilize leading edge microscopic methods that will be enabled by the instruments requested in this proposal
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Refining phenotypes and endophenotypes of alcoholism risk and treatment response
Project Description: Alcohol use contributes to as many as 3-4% of deaths in Ontario each year. The infrastructure will support biobehavioural research on alcoholism risk and treatment response and seeks to reduce the burden of alcohol use in Ontario with more effective and targeted treatment and prevention measures.
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: Laboratory for Integrated Transportation and Traffic Engineering Research
Project Description: The proposed project will establish a research laboratory for integrated transportation and traffic engineering at the University of Windsor and promote world-class research on driver and travel behaviour within an integrated passenger and freight transportation system.

Project Title: Lymphocyte Biology Laboratory for the study of the mechanisms of immune cell activation and signalling
Project Description: This proposal seeks funding to establish the first Lymphocyte Biology Laboratory at University of Toronto Scarborough which will focus on studying the mechanisms of immune cell activation through the application of cutting-edge microscopy techniques.

Project Title: Signal Analyzer, Tunable Laser and Optical Spectrum Analyzer for Photonics, Biophotonics and Nanophotonics Research Facilities
Project Description: The proposed project requests (1) a signal analyzer; (2) a tunable laser (C and L band); and (3) a spectrometer. The proposed research program is to develop fiber lasers in the near infrared (NIR) and mid-infrared (MID-IR) regions of the electromagnetic spectrum, and to use these lasers to develop sensors. The requested infrastructure makes it possible for Dr. Das’s research group to study important characteristics of lasers.

Project Title: Hyperpolarized Gas MRI for Collaborative Studies on Asthma
Project Description: This proposed program utilizes the requested polarizer to perform 3He MRI studies to test the hypothesis that hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas levels are inversely correlated with hyperreactivity in a mouse model of asthma.  It is predicted that these discoveries will enhance the success of treatments for asthma.

Project Title: Nanosized Air Pollution Research (Nano-APR) Laboratory
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will be used to study thermal rebound of airborne nanoparticles and indoor nanoparticle transport and, supported by this basic research, to develop novel technologies for cost-effective monitoring and control of nanosized air pollutants. These new technologies will provide critical breakthroughs in environmental and human health protection.

Project Title: Examining protein: protein interactions in cellular membranes relevant to the treatment of human diseases
Project Description:
Dr. Andrews has worked to understand an unusual class of membrane-binding proteins, the Bcl-2 family, that were shown to cause cancer, not by causing cellular growth, but by preventing programmed cellular death. This discovery caused a paradigm shift in cancer biology and interest in regulated apoptosis exploded. It is now apparent that the Bcl-2 protein family regulates the response of tumour cells to chemotherapy by altering their own binding interactions. 

The Bcl-2-mediated interactions depend on where the proteins interact in part because the structural changes resulting from membrane insertion lead to dramatic changes in interacting partners. Thus it is challenging to extrapolate measurements of binding interactions conventionally made in vitro using truncated proteins to what happens in live cells. Furthermore, there are few approaches that can be used to study protein:protein interactions in membranes in vitro and even less for studies in live cells.  Dr. Andrews has developed fluorescence spectroscopy and fluorescence imaging spectroscopy methods to examine them, respectively. These new techniques are now being used by pharmaceutical companies to make new anti-cancer drugs to improve chemotherapy. The infrastructure requested includes core and ancillary equipment required to perform these techniques at an internationally competitive level. Because regulation of apoptosis is thematic to several human diseases including stroke, autoimmune and degenerative diseases, the scope of this work will be broadened by general knowledge of protein:protein interactions, putting Ontario at the forefront of innovation science and providing excellence in improving methodologies to treat human disease on a number of fronts.

Project Title: Advances in Magnetic Resonance Neuro-Imaging Technology
Project Description: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging is a novel, non-invasive method to study and map the function of brain with broad emerging clinical applications. The requested infrastructure will expand SRI’s research capabilities in this field, capitalizing on prior investments, and enhancing the position of Ontario in medical imaging technology.

Project Title: Connecting DNA Dynamics to Gene Expression One Molecule at a Time
Project Description: We will develop instruments formanipulating single DNA molecules and for observing the conformations of DNA within cells.These instruments willlet us explore an uncharted realm of genomics, namely, the mechanics of gene regulation, which has vast implications for our understanding of health and disease.

Project Title: A nanosecond laser spectroscopy facility for interdisciplinary research
Project Description: Our goal is to establish a world-class research facility that utilizes laser-based spectroscopy to perform highly interdisciplinary research that will make fundamental contributions in several fields of physics as well as microbiology, astronomy, environmental engineering, medicine, and analytical chemistry.

Project Title: Therapeutic Interaction Research Lab
Project Description: Therapeutic Interaction Research (TIR) lab will be situated in an active training and counselling facility. This infrastructure will allow for recording, archiving, and analysis of therapy sessions in order to answer a range of questions on therapy processes and social interaction.

Project Title: Multimodal Sensory Feedback and Learning for Synthesized Skilled Motion
Project Description: Research enabled by the proposed infrastructure will apply computational neuroscience principles to the development of viable intelligent motion control solutions to realize a new generation of adaptable and dexterous robot manipulators for agile manufacturing, health care systems and service automation.

Project Title: Computational Health Informatics Laboratory
Project Description: Ontario’s population is rapidly aging, leading to increased demand for health services. Basic and applied research is required to develop technologies to facilitate aging at home, promote safe and independent mobility, automatically monitor health indices and optimize clinical decisions.  This proposal requests funds to establish a new Computational Health Informatics Laboratory (CHIL) at the University of Waterloo to enable cutting-edge research and technology development in Health informatics, driven by computer science basic research.

Project Title: Determining the Structures and Reactivities of Nanoclusters
Project Description: This research will explore the chemical and physical properties of nanoclusters at the quantum level. We will prepare and isolate clusters of 2 – 30 atoms, then interrogate them with laser light to study their structures and how they chemically react.

Project Title: Laboratory for Low Temperature Magnetic and Electronic Characterization of Novel Materials
Project Description: The proposed research will explore the novel properties of a new class of materials which exhibit topological order. The requested infrastructure will allow study of magnetic and electronic phenomena at extremely low temperatures, leading to materials with potential application to quantum computing.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of Structure and Dynamics in Solid Materials
Project Description: The Centre for Catalysis and Materials Research will utilize the new X-ray and NMR equipment to study the dynamic motion of the molecular components of new high technology materials. The ‘smart’ materials being developed have properties that respond to external stimuli (heat, light and pressure)0.

Project Title: Comparative Epilepsy Program Infrastructure Development
Project Description: The objective is to position the Comparative Epilepsy Program at the forefront of epilepsy research. The wireless video-EEG system will take epilepsy research out of the clinic and into the field while the neuronavigation system will give access to the intimate brain, thus broadening research horizons.

Project Title:
Facility for Research in Structural Dynamic Performance of
Advanced Aero-Engine Systems
Project Description: The goal of the project is to establish an Advanced Structural Dynamics research laboratory containing the proposed infrastructure to perform vibration and high cycle fatigue testing of critical aircraft engine components incorporating advanced geometry and material innovations.

Project Title: Laboratory for Non-Linear Optical Characterization of Biomaterials
Project Description: Needed infrastructure for the creation of a laboratory dedicated to the nonlinear optical characterization and imaging of biomaterials is being requested. This ultrafast laser lab will develop and advance label-free and chemically-specific imaging techniques based on resonant vibrational excitations.

Project Title: Social Cognitive Science of Dynamic Evaluation
Project Description: The act of assigning positive or negative valence is crucial for survival, whether it involves guiding immediate behavior or the anticipation of future events. The infrastructure in the proposal will be used to establish a world class social & affective neuroscience lab to study these fundamental processes.

Project Title: Attentional Control Functions in Neuronal Microcircuits and Large Scale Brain Networks
Project Description: To flexibly focus attention on the most relevant aspect in our environment is controlled by networks of brain cells. This proposal aims to identify the underlying neuronal network mechanisms of attentional control by measuring cell activity at multiple parts of the network with the most advanced technologies.

Project Title: Protective mechanisms of Treg lymphocytes in osteoimmunology: Investigation of hypoxia effects in bone resorption
Project Description: This study aims to explore the influence of hypoxic conditions on the protective immune mechanisms promoted by T-regulatory lymphocytes in regulating bone resorption.

Project Title: Cooperative Autonomous Vehicle Network Test-Bed
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will be used to conduct rapid experimental evaluation and validation of newly developed reliable coordination and control algorithms for multiple autonomous vehicle and/or robot networks performing collaborative tasks(surveillance, driving, rescue, manufacturing, etc.).

Project Title: Next-Generation Structural Systems for Seismic Protection of Infrastructure
Project Description: The Simulator for Innovative Next-Generation Structural Systems will enable research on advanced structural technologies that not only protect people inside buildings during earthquakes, but also minimize post-earthquake recovery costs by avoiding structural and non-structural damage.

Project Title: Micro-Scale Separations and Analysis Suite (MSAS) for Bio-Processing and Environmental Applications
Project Description: The requested Micro-scale Separations and Analysis Suite (MSAS) will develop novel separation processes for applications related to wastewater purification and the production of bio-therapeutics. The research will benefit the Clean Technology and Life Sciences sectors of the Ontario economy.

Project Title: Improved Neuroendocrine Tumor Management Through RNA-Based Diagnostics
Project Description: My objective is to transform molecular diagnostics for cancer management. Starting with neuroendocrine tumors, my plan is to identify and visualize informative biomarkers in pathology specimens using a powerful molecular diagnostics platform that I co-developed for improved clinical decision-making.

Project Title: Laboratory Facility for the In Situ Characterization of Metal-Bacteria Interactions
Project Description: We will develop a laboratory facility for the in situ analysis of metal bacteria interactions that will be used to assess the role played by biogenic minerals (i.e., minerals formed in the presence of bacteria) in metal sequestration in environments impacted by new and existing mines.

Project Title: Sustainable Chemical Synthesis In Batch and Flow
Project Description: Chemistry is everywhere in our lives, from the fuels in our car to the screens in our phones. Our research program seeks to reduce the environmental impact that the chemical industry has by developing new, waste-free reactions and processes that utilize renewable feedstocks.

Project Title: Developing a Supercritical Fluid Extraction Process for Rare Earth Materials
Project Description: The goal of the proposed research is to develop a novel, efficient, and environmentally friendly extraction process, using supercritical fluids, to separate individual rare earth elements after the initial hydrometallurgical leaching step.

Project Title: Structure and Dynamics of GPCR Membrane Proteins
Project Description: The proposed research will enhance our understanding of the inner working of cell surface receptors and ion channels in health and disease. The requested equipment will enable new insights into the large class of membrane proteins and contribute to understanding the molecular architecture of life.

Project Title: Infrastructure for an Integrative Genomics and Phenomics Lab to Identify Mechanisms Generating Phenotypic Variation
Project Description: The proposed activities will provide a platform for development and discovery in integrative genetics research. The research integrates genomic, developmental, morphological and behavioural approaches in genetic analysis, and thereby reveals how mutations with subtle effects influence organism function.

Project Title: Center for Cardiovascular Assessment
Project Description: A state-of-the-art Centre for Cardiovascular Assessment is proposed. This will be a major component of the Muscle Health Initiative at York University. Our focus is understanding, treating, and preventing cardiovascular disease and the associated arrhythmias, which remains the number one killer in Canada.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Deciphering Molecular Events Leading to Bacterial Pathogens Sensing and Adaptation to their Environment
Project Description: The aim of this proposal is to identify the mechanisms that contribute to bacteria sensing and adaptation to their environment, using Shigella flexneri as a model and cutting-edge microscope imaging approaches. Potential applications stemming from this work include identification of novel antibiotics.

Project Title: Lanthanide-based Nanophosphors for Bioimaging and Energy Conversion Applications
Project Description: This research project seeks the development of novel lanthanide-based nanophosphors with controlled surface chemistry as multifunctional carriers. The goal is to provide novel near-infrared and opto-magnetic hybrid biomarkers as well as new phosphors for solar-driven energy-conversion technologies.

Project Title: High resolution mass spectrometry for metabolic profiling to discover enzymes and observe cell growth regulation
Project Description: This work will form a complete map of cellular metabolism, and discover how metabolism is regulated during cell division. High resolution liquid chromatography mass spectrometry equipment will be used to measure the metabolism of cells engineered to knockout specific enzymes.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Advanced Biomolecular Materials Laboratory at York University
Project Description: Interfacing man-made materials with human cells is critical for understanding fundamental cell behaviour and for developing new health-based biotechnologies.  The Advanced Biomolecular Materials Laboratory at York University will generate new surface chemistry knowledge and capabilities that will significantly progress human health diagnostics and therapeutic treatments.

Project Title:
Large-scale Experimental and Computational Infrastructure for Assessing Wind Effects on
the Built Environment
Project Description: The main objective is to assess effects of extreme wind, wind-driven-rain and -snow on the built environment using a combination of large scale experiments and computer simulations to enhance the safety of the public and maintain the resiliency of Ontario’s built environment against natural hazards.

Project Title: Processing and Development of Next-Generation Natural Biotherapeutics
Project Description: This research program will use cutting edge strategies to engage in microbial natural product mining to identify novel bioactive compounds that have enormous potential to become the next wave of therapeutic drugs to combat infectious diseases and to treat diseases such as cancer.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Infrastructure for the combined optical coherence tomography (OCT) and optical topographic imaging (OTI) for laser cutting surgery
Project Description: The infrastructure in this proposal enhances existing Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) instrumentation for applications in surgical navigation and precision surgery. Dr. Yang will utilize his expertise in OCT to develop optical topographic imaging (OTI) technology and implement the knowledge of OCT and OTI for laser ablation in surgery.

Project Title: Biomedical Signal Analysis Research Laboratory
Project Description: The objective of the proposal is to develop advanced biomedical signal analysis algorithms for non-invasive diagnosis, monitoring and understanding of complex cardiovascular dynamics, human gait and neuromuscular disorders. The tools will help the development of better information technologies for health care applications.

Project Title: Digital Media Centre for the Global Study of Social Movements
Project Description: The project provides a digital means to create, analyze, store and exchange data on contemporary social movements. The centre will facilitate advanced technological communications equipment for collaboration with practitioners and researchers worldwide and will train junior researchers.

Project Title: Integrated Environmental Physiology Tools for Transpecies and Field Research
Project Description: This proposal will enable an integrated environmental physiology research team at Brock University. This will be done by providing advanced tools for studying the effects of extreme heat and cold, along with low oxygen, on both animal and human responses. The proposal will also provide portable equipment that can maximize field research and industrial collaborations.

Project Title: Interdisciplinary Research Laboratory in Statistical Methodology and Applications
Project Description: The objective of the proposed research program is to develop cutting-edge statistical methodologies to estimate complex dynamical models from massive data. One major goal is to identify genes that control dynamic systems such as the infection dynamics of HIV virus and the dynamic system of the absorption and distribution of an administered drug in the human body.

Project Title: Sequence analysis of development and disease
Project Description: The focus of this project is on placental dysfunction that affects foetal and maternal health. The aim is to identify changes in the expression of genes that relate to the clinical outcome of human pregnancies, with the goal of developing diagnostic, prognostic tools as well as innovative therapeutic approaches.

Project Title: Crystallization and Imaging Facility
Project Description: Understanding biological processes requires knowledge of the structure and function of each component of the system. X-ray crystallography is the most powerful method to determine the structure of a protein. This project provides infrastructure for automated protein crystallization; the first essential step in this process.

Project Title: Mobile Computer-Assisted Survey Research Laboratory for HIV Vaccine Implementation Science
Project Description: The proposed research is at the cutting edge of innovation in addressing the social and behavioral challenges of HIV vaccines; ensuring ethical conduct of clinical trials and fully informed consent; and laying the groundwork for acceptability and access to future vaccines among most-at-risk populations.

Project Title: Canada Research Chair in Organizational Behaviour: Organizational Behaviour Research Laboratory
Project Description: This program of research examines the experiences and effective management of contingent workers, how employees interpret and respond to the emotional content of electronic communication, the reasons why employees hide knowledge from their coworkers, and the workplace stress of leaders.

Project Title: Biogeochemistry and microbial ecology research facility for studies of environmental change in Canadian forests and wetlands.
Project Description: The infrastructure will enable timely research on poorly understood soil microbial feedbacks to environmental disturbances (forestry, including biomass/bioenergy harvests, climate change, invasive species, and mining-related pollution) in Ontario’s northern forests and wetlands.

Project Title: Testbed for Cyber-Physical Urban Logistics System
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure is a first-of-its-kind testbed with the capacity to evaluate transport system designs with embedded computer decision-making. The infrastructure includes a centralized facility with six workstations, a video wall, and 30 tablets to equip on a fleet of vehicles.

Project Title: Earthquake Simulation Facility with Network Interface Capabilities for Collaborative Earthquake and Vibration Research
Project Description: The proposed earthquake simulator facilitates earthquake research by creating a device that can reproduce the earthquake ground-shaking loading in order to perform seismic testing of large size soil-structure models, such as high-rise buildings, bridges and other critical infrastructure.

Project Title: Development of a Comparative Hemostasis Laboratory at the Ontario Veterinary College Health Sciences Centre, University of Guelph
Project Description: The Comparative Hemostasis Laboratory aims to investigate disorders related to hemostasis in multiple species.   Research goals include investigating the effects of drugs & disease on the hemostatic system in veterinary species, and to extend the information gathered to human medicine where applicable.

Project Title: Universal testing facility for advanced characterization of automotive materials
Project Description: This research infrastructure will enable the applicants to carry out advanced characterization of automotive materials. The experimental data will be used to develop and validate predictive numerical models that will accelerate the implementation of lightweight and crash-resistant structures into vehicles.

Project Title: Attention laboratory for high-temporal resolution behavioural, eye movement, and electrophysiological recording.
Project Description: An Attention Lab will be constructed to: 1) uncover the neural mechanisms that allow our finite brains to make sense of the overwhelming visual world we live in; 2) translate these discoveries to applied domains by improving driving safety and eliminating age related declines in vision; and 3) develop cutting-edge neuroimaging tools to assess the health of brain function.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of the Psychophysiological Effects of Stress on Physical Health
Project Description: The purpose of this laboratory is to study the impact of severe stress on physical health and designing psychological interventions to ameliorate elevated chronic disease risk following traumatic events. Dr. Andersen combines psychophysiological, behavioural, and experience-sampling methods to examine disease risk associated with trauma exposure and psychological treatments that promote mental and physical health thriving during and following severe stress.

Project Title: Musculoskeletal spinal disorders laboratory
Project Description: The funding requested will be used to purchase equipment for Dr Gregory’s musculoskeletal spinal disorders laboratory at Wilfrid Laurier University.  Dr Gregory’s research laboratory focuses on identifying and reducing  potential risks of low back pain that exist in occupational and daily living tasks.

Project Title: Computing Infrastructure for Control of Complex Physical Systems
Project Description: The requested high-performance shared memory computer will provide the means to develop models and control strategies for complex systems such as smart materials and intracellular networks. This will lead to breakthroughs in the manipulation and control of these systems.

Project Title: Investigating Microbial Biosynthetic Capacity
Project Description: The vast reservoir of unexplored microbial metabolic diversity in Canada undoubtedly possesses novel molecules with potential benefits to health, agriculture and the environment. Infrastructure is requested to discover and characterize these molecules and the mechanisms of their biological synthesis.

Project Title: Creation of the Diabetes Discovery Core to facilitate innovative new directions in understanding diabetes pathophysiology and in developing new clinical modalities to manage the disease.
Project Description: Diabetes is a growing epidemic that contributes to the death of thousands of Ontarians each year. The proposed research will explore new directions in diabetes research using state-of–the-art equipment to examine conditions such as inflammation, cell stress and beta cell dysfunction that drive this disease.

Project Title: Intestinal mucosal immunity and host-pathogen interactions during mycobacterial infection in cattle
Project Description: This research proposal seeks to understand fundamental mechanisms of host resistance to Johne’s disease, which is a chronic and universally fatal bacterial infection affecting the gastrointestinal tract of cattle resulting in an estimated economic loss of $90M per year for the Canadian cattle industry.

Project Title: Carleton's Human Oriented Research in Usable Security (CHORUS) Lab
Project Description: The CHORUS lab is a centre for multi-disciplinary research on improving computer security and privacy for end-users and for experts. This applied research integrates human-computer interaction (HCI) and computer security disciplines.

Project Title: Movement for Performance Biomechanics and Ergonomics Laboratory
Project Description: This proposal is aimed at enhancing the health and occupational performance of the Canadian workforce. This goal will be achieved by innovating holistic strategies and tools that can be applied to reduce physical demands in the workplace, and to enhance the functional capacity of the workforce.

Project Title: Research Infrastructure for Computational Analytics on Big Data in the Cloud
Project Description: Business decisions and scientific discovery are increasingly reliant on complex analysis of Big Data from multiple sources. This project will provide essential infrastructure for research that will enable innovative and novel types of Big Data analytics leading to advances in business, science, and public policy.

Project Title: Tracking Nanoparticles with Whole-Animal Imaging and Hyperspectral Microscopy: A Novel Strategy for Identifying Biomarkers and Treating Diabetes
Project Description: Diabetic patients develop multi-organ complications. The advanced imaging equipment requested will allow us to study for the first time, diabetic models in vivo, from the macroscopic to cellular level. These studies will move findings quickly from the laboratory to patient care, to prevent diabetes complications.

Project Title:
A Laboratory of Clinical Exercise Physiology
in Chronic Cardiopulmonary Diseases (LACEP)
Project Description: This proposed research aims to generate breakthroughs in our understanding of the causes and treatment of disability in chronic heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, two leading diseases affecting the health-related quality of life of Ontarians.

Project Title: Understanding the role of block copolymers in metal coordination polymerization for Prussian blue nanoparticle design
Project Description: The project intends to understand metal coordination supramolecular chemistry in the presence of block copolymers using electron microscope (EM) as a major analytic tool, which will lead to functional materials useful for clean technologies, pharmaceutical research, andinformation technologies,etc.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the characterization and analyses of sedimentary processes
Project Description: This research program investigates the impact of climate and environmental changes on sedimentary processes.  Changes to these processes impact water quality, infrastructure and landuse management practices.  Through field and laboratory studies this research will help inform better policy decisions.

Project Title: Data Analytics and Computational Biostatistics
Project Description: The server, computer workstations and videoconferencing equipment will enable two research objectives. First, the development of new and innovative statistical and computational methodologies. Second, the application of these methodologies to medical, environmental and industrial research.

Project Title: Evaluating the anti-cancer treatment applications of nutraceuticals
Project Description: Using tissue culture equipment and a flow cytometer, my research will provide scientific validity for the use of nutraceuticals by cancer patients through the systematic evaluationof their anti-cancer treatment propertiesand their pharmacological and anti-tumor assessment in animal models.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Challenging Depression in Canadian Youth: Building Mobile, Online, and Interactive Assessment and Intervention Tools
Project Description: By developing and rigorously investigating mobile/online innovative approaches for mental health assessment and intervention, the applicant aims to improve youth access to empirically supported strategies for challenging depression and promoting positive functioning.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Bionanotechnology Laboratory
Project Description: Developing sensing tools, and imaging techniques using bionanotechnology for the biological, food and agricultural systems. Generation of new concepts, innovative, novel, high-value products in sectors such as healthcare, bioenergy, bioremediation, agricultural, environmental and food quality monitoring.

Project Title: Muscle Stem Cell Bioengineering Laboratory
Project Description: Skeletal muscle is critical to our day to day movement and loss of muscle mass and/or function due to genetic disorders, aging, cancer or physical inactivity impairs quality of life and increases the risk of mobility related accidents. Adult skeletal muscle contains stem cells that are responsible for the daily repair of skeletal muscle injury.  The research in this proposal uses an interdisciplinary approach and is focused on identifying the mechanisms regulating muscle stem cells in the tissue and aims to harness this knowledge to develop novel strategies that promote skeletal muscle repair for Ontario patients.

Project Title: Water and Ice Research Laboratory (WIRL)
Project Description: The Water and Ice Research Laboratory is a new facility at Carleton University that examines the impacts of climate change and other environmental issues on aquatic and cryospheric systems. Our research makes use of innovative field approaches, laboratory equipment and geospatial computing.

Project Title: Research and Development for Optical Identification of Single Barium Ions
Project Description: Optical detection of single barium ions. Novel technique to eliminate background contributions in large-scale xenon detectors enhancing their sensitivity for measuring the absolute scale of the neutrino mass via the observation of the neutrinoless double-beta decay.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support an Integrative Cardiovascular Circadian Research Laboratory
Project Description: Dr. Martino is investigating the link between circadian physiology and the pathogenesis of heart disease and heart failure. The infrastructure requested is essential to an innovative research program designed to lead to new approaches to understand, prevent, and treat cardiovascular disease.

Project Title: Cryo-Prep and Transfer System and Accessories for Atomic-Scale Characterization of Nuclear Materials
Project Description: The Cryo-Prep and Transfer system with accessories will be used to investigate the microstructural evolution by Atom Probe Tomography at the nanoscale of structural and cladding materials used in current or future CANDU reactors to open pathways for designing better performing materials.

Project Title: Biochemical and Molecular Infrastructure to Unlock the Secrets of Plant Extracellular Lipids: Manipulating Pathways to Create Novel Bioproducts for Agriculture, Forestry and the Biofuels Industry
Project Description: Algoma U. is establishing a new biochemistry/molecular laboratory for our newest Research Chair, Dr. Isabel Molina. She will investigate novel fatty acids and lipid-based compounds from higher plants and microalgae that show potential to yield new bio-products for industry, medicine, forestry and agriculture.

Project Title: Electrical Neuromodulation of Spinal and Supraspinal Reflexes for Treatment of Lower Urinary Tract Dysfunction
Project Description: Chronic overactive bladder (OAB) symptoms negatively affect the quality of life of millions of Canadian adults. The proposed infrastructure will help develop technology that will mitigate the socioeconomic burden of chronic OAB, while also contributing to the commercial development of new therapies.

Project Title: A Translational Pipeline for Personalized Diagnostics in Myelodysplastic Syndromes
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to innovatively transform and personalize the practice of pathology.  Starting with a common and burdensome blood cancer, we will validate next-generation genomic technologies alongside traditional pathology, to detect cancer earlier and better inform treatment.

Project Title: Research on portable multidimensional micro-nano biological sensing devices
Project Description: The proposed research will develop a platform for prototyping enhanced Point-of-Care devices integrating two complementary detection principles on a single microfluidic chip. Dual detection will permit analysis of both acoustic and electric impedances that will improve their diagnosticreliability.

Project Title: Refill Friction Stir Welding of Lightweight Materials
Project Description: The proposed equipment will facilitate research in advanced joining technologies for the transportation industries. This research will help overcome barriers to implementation of lightweight materials, thereby decreasing fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

Project Title: Infrastructure for developing new imaging technologies to enhance the sensitivity of Positron Emission Tomography (PET) for molecular imaging
Project Description: This proposal is dedicated to developing novel imaging technologies to enhance the molecular sensitivity of Positron Emission Tomography (PET). The research tasks include developing novel photodetector technology and PET systems, using a fully-digital high speed Data Acquisition System (DAQ).

Project Title: Developing broad antiviral strategies to protect the health of Canadians and their environment
Project Description: Dr. DeWitte-Orr studies how animals defend themselves from virus infections using their innate immune responses. The requested infrastructure will allow Dr. DeWitte-Orr’s lab to further understand these antiviral mechanisms at the cellular level, with the future goal of developing novel antiviral therapies.

Project Title: Cellular and Molecular Sensing Laboratory
Project Description: The research focuses on developing a new class of handheld molecular diagnostic platforms for biological cell processing and analysis. Electrical chips featuring highly optimized nanomaterials with exceptional sensitivity, precision, integration, and speed form the innovative foundation of this system.

Project Title: Development of innovative methods for wastewater treatment using bioelectrochemical systems for biosolids minimization and effective removal of nutrients and heavy metals
Project Description: This research seeks to eliminate or mitigate major challenges in wastewater treatment using bioelectrochemical systems. Bioelectrochemical systems will be examined for their capacity to minimize biosolids generation, maximize wastewater treatability, and separate nutrient compounds and heavy metals from wastewater.

Project Title: Organic Photovoltaics Laboratory
Project Description: The Organic Photovoltaic Laboratory (OPL), sits at the interface between fundamental research and device production, by using an integrated glovebox incorporating both vacuum evaporation and solution deposition methods to create low cost, organic photovoltaic devices (OPVs) as needed for sustainable energy economy.

Project Title: Arts Integrated Research Lab
Project Description: The Arts Integrated Research Lab will support the development of Arts Integrated Studies across disciplines and programs in Canada. Arts integrated studies use the arts such as film, fiction, plays, or paintings as generative mechanisms in the research process to discern relational connections, represent data, and disseminate research.

Project Title: Biodiversity –  Ecosystem Function Laboratory
Project Description: Dr. Lindo’s research focuses on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem function in Canadian forest ecosystems. Analytical tools in the laboratory and the field measure soil biodiversity, and carbon and nitrogen flux, to develop strategies for the enhancement of forest carbon sequestration.

Project Title: Technology for exploring cellular mechanisms underlying cognitive function in health and disease
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to acquire cutting edge technologies needed for the assessment of cognitive function in different rat animal models for neurodegenerative diseases, in order to enable the  testing of drugs and manipulations that reverse cognitive deficits and halt neurodegeneration.

Project Title: Hardware-in-the-Loop Simulation Platform for Intelligent Hybrid Cars
Project Description: We will establish an innovative test platform at uWaterloo to support the development of new intelligent controllers for hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), plug-in hybrids (PHEVs) and electric vehicles (EVs) that will improve their performance characteristics and, consequently, their market share.

Project Title: Infrastructure for molecular to whole-animal analysis of inflammation, infection and immune function.
Project Description: The infrastructure will enable the study of pathological processes driving atherosclerosis, multiple sclerosis and human immunodeficiency virus, and the impacts of new treatments, at the molecular level through to the pathology of whole tissues within animal models.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
