Project Title: Gene-Environment Interplay Research Laboratory
Project Description: The project is for renovation and equipment for a Gene-Environment Interplay laboratory. The research performed in this laboratory will be to investigate the mechanisms (epigenetic and gene-environment interactions) whereby our early experience is embedded in our biology. Specifically, the Drosophila foraging gene model with its many genetic, molecular and behavioural technologies will be used to investigate how early nutritional and social adversity affect food-related behaviours, metabolism  social cognition.

Project Title: Personalizing Drug Therapy to Increase Safety and Efficacy of Medications
Project Description: The objective of this project is to improve the safety and efficacy of commonly used medications by personalizing drug therapy. The proposal seeks support for the purchase of an Ultra High Performance Liquid Chromatography system equipped with a state-of-the-art quan/qual mass spectrometer.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: A Testbed for Empirical Cloud Computing Research
Project Description: Our objective is to improve the performance, manageability, and reliability of cloud applications in domains such as e-commerce and entertainment.  We propose to do this by enhancing the data management and delivery infrastructure on which these applications depend.

Project Title:
Sorption Phenomena of Actinides in Brine/Solid Interface 
- Development of Sorption Model and Evaluation of Sorption Data -
Project Description: Speciation and sorption of actinides in brine - a typical property of Ontario’s groundwater - is a very important factor in assessing the long term radiotoxicity and safety of radioactive waste disposal. A model will be developed to evaluate these processes and the sorption thermodynamic data of actinides.

Project Title: University of Windsor Occupational Biomechanics Research Facility
Project Description: Computer-aided ergonomics is important in manufacturing and the drive to improve its accuracy and validity is necessary. This work will improve upon or develop predictive whole-body posturing, body-size scaling, physical fatigue as well as, determine joint strengths of various populations and physical states.

Project Title: Infrastructure for a Bioelectronic Systems Laboratory
Project Description: New semiconductor devices developed in the proposed Bioelectronic Systems Laboratory will vastly enhance drug-screening technologies, which will allow new pharmaceuticals to be brought to market more rapidly and at a lower cost, leading to significant health benefits for Ontarians.

Project Title: Reverse-Engineering Platform for Human Visuo-Motor System
Project Description: The goal of this project is to develop a model of the human brain as it controls a complex manual task. The infrastructure will consist of a robot that interacts with a software model of dozens of brain regions. This work will improve our understanding of brain function, and lead to advanced robot control systems.

Project Title: Integrated Million Death Study (MDS) e-Platform
Project Description: The Million Death Study (MDS)-e Platform enables rapid collection of health data worldwide. It has 3 components: (1) multi-user, remote capture laptops; (2) software for innovative data capture, geospatial linkage, and computer-assisted physician coding; and (3) secure data storage to enable multiple users to analyze the data.

Project Title: Neuropsychiatry Imaging Lab (NeuroPIL) hybrid PET/MRI infrastructure
Project Description: Establish the NeuroPsychiatry Imaging Lab (NeuroPIL) and leading edge simultaneous positron emission tomography (PET) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) infrastructure to examine the function and chemistry of brain networks involved in schizophrenia, depression and bipolar disorder.

Project Title: Nanomechanics and Nanotribology Platform for Characterizing Energy Efficient Materials
Project Description: The goal of the project is to utilize the proposed infrastructure as a platform for conducting Nanomechanics and Nanotribology characterization of nanostructures in the NanoMechanics and Materials research laboratory in order to guide the design of advanced energy-efficient materials based on nanostructures.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Cluster Computing Infrastructure for Big Data Management and Analysis
Project Description: The massive amounts of data that are being generated today in every economic and social activity have given rise to the Big Data problem. This research project focuses on foundational issues in Big Data management and analysis using a state-of-the-art cluster infrastructure.

Project Title: Migration, Gender, and International Development Research Laboratory
Project Description: The Migration, Gender, and International Development Research Laboratory will enable Victoria Esses, Bipasha Baruah, and their research teams to conduct multi-year projects on the settlement and integration of immigrants in Canada, and on gender and international development.

Project Title: Quantitative data collection for model-based biotechnology
Project Description: This project aims to increase biomanufacturing production efficiency by applying computational modelling to bioprocess production of therapeutics, biofuels, and other high-values molecules. The requested imaging flow cytometer will directly support the commercialization of this novel approach.

Project Title: Design Environment for Creating Physical Interactive Technology
Project Description: This project will develop new interactive technologies using a rapid, iterative prototyping methodology. These novel technologies will include flexible multi-touch displays, next generation video game controllers, and large digital surfaces that allow non-experts to create complex physical artifacts.

Project Title: Research Infrastructure for Continuous Stream Analytics in the Cloud
Project Description: This proposal requests funding for a cluster of 28 computing servers.  The cluster will be used as an experimental cloud computing environment for research in big-data analytics.  The goal of the proposed research is to develop software tools for analyzing high volumes of continuously-generated data.

Project Title: Functional significance of binocular vision
Project Description: The goal of Dr. Niechwiej-Szwedo’s research is to investigate the role of binocular vision in the development of eye movements, eye-hand coordination, and reaching and grasping movements. This research will also examine how these processes are disrupted by visual and oculomotor impairments.

Project Title: Structural and Systems Pharmacology Laboratory for Drug Discovery
Project Description: The Structural and Systems Pharmacology Laboratory for Drug Discovery at the University of Toronto uses theory and experiment to make discoveries that help us understand drugs: how they work and how to find new ones. It develops software tools and databases which are used worldwide for drug discovery.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Astronomical Instrumentation Development for Large Optical and Future Giant Segmented Telescopes
Project Description: Coupling advanced instrumentation to large and future giant optical and near-infrared telescopes will revolutionize astronomical discoveries. The Dunlap Institute at University of Toronto will develop the infrastructure to be leaders in advancing innovative astronomical instruments in the 21st century.

Project Title: The relevance of DNA methylation processes in serotonin genes for the diagnosis and treatment of mental illness
Project Description: Low levels of the brain chemical serotonin combined with early life stressors can increase the risk for depression and chronic aggression. Recent findings by Dr. Booij suggest it may be possible to use DNA methylation as a non-invasive biomarker for low serotonin in the human brain, prompting further exploration for its use in determining associated risk of (recurrence in) mental illness in which serotonin plays a major role. Dr. Booij’s studies at Queen’s University will investigate DNA methylation as a measure for diagnostic and treatment outcome in individuals diagnosed with Major Depression and in individuals with chronic aggression problems.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Digital Rhetorics Laboratory
Project Description: The requested lab infrastructure will provide multitouch computing surfaces and interactive devices to support research into innovative forms of communication, relationality, and ethical subjectivity—forms that will be more commensurate with the ways in which we interact through increasing digitization.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the biomechanical analysis of high flexion activities of daily living
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will be used for dynamic measurement of joint motion, muscle activation, and lower limb interactions between segments. These capabilities will enable the study of knee joint mechanics with the objective of preventing joint injury and disease initiation and progression.

Project Title: A laboratory for freshwater chemistry and northern permafrost change
Project Description: Permafrost is degrading throughout the Canadian Arctic and Ontario’s north. This facility will focus on understanding the effects of changing permafrost on water quality and the broader carbon cycle. This work will enable significant skills development for numerous Ontarians, and have direct implications for northern infrastructure and the well-being of northern residents.

Project Title: Microstructured Surfaces and Adaptive Materials Engineering
Project Description: Problems of microbial contamination continue to affect our healthcare environments and society; patient health, resources, and severe financial costs. This project aims to develop antimicrobial materials having microstructured surfaces to control and prevent bacterial attachment, contamination and transfer.

Project Title: Monkey models of movement disorders: Electrophysiology and neuromodulation therapies
Project Description: Dr. Levy aims to study Parkinson’s disease and dystonia and their treatment with neurosurgery. He will develop animal models of these illnesses to describe the long-term changes in abnormal brain electrical activity and the therapeutic effects of novel brain modulation techniques.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Microbial Evolutionary Genomics
Project Description: Dr. Wong studies the evolution of genomes, with a particular interest in the evolution of antibiotic resistance in disease-causing bacteria. Genome sequencing of bacterial populations will be used to clarify the principles by which antibiotic resistance evolves, and to devise novel treatment strategies.

Project Title: Neuromuscular recovery after stroke: assessment and intervention
Project Description: The goal of this research is to reverse the negative impact of stroke on the ability to control movement. The specific objectives are to characterize changes in brain and muscle properties that occur after stroke and to utilize this knowledge to develop new combinations of neurotherapies to enhance motor recovery.

Project Title: Printed Flexible Electronics: Transformational Technology for Electronics Manufacturing
Project Description: This research program will explore the use of printed flexible electronics to foster disruptive manufacturing technologies. The novel technologies will enable new global leadership and commercial opportunities in large-area electronics for the Province of Ontario.

Project Title: Advanced Development & Test Facility for Heavy- Duty Electrified Transportation Systems and Components
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will support the development of a test facility for heavy-duty electrified transportation systems and components. Hybrid, plug-in hybrid and full electric vehicle components such as electric motor, power converters, control algorithm and battery simulator will be developed and tested with the proposed equipment.

Project Title: Innovations In Automobile Design For An Aging Population
Project Description: This research addresses problems experienced by seniors when using their automobile by improving vehicle design. It will link evidence gathered through ergonomic analysis with advanced prototyping techniques to develop designs that consider the needs of older users.

Project Title: Imaging infrastructure for engineering materials and biological tissues characterization
Project Description: The proposed research will address the need for efficient and innovative materials for use in structural repair and renewal applications, in addition to accurate and realistic characterization of biological tissues for effective medical interventions, including radiotherapy, surgery and brachytherapy.

Project Title: Electrical Synapses: From genes to function using transgenic zebrafish
Project Description: This proposal seeks infrastructure to enable biomedical research that will address a fundamental process of neuronal communication with the power to catalyze translational research assisting in the treatment and prevention of mental health and neurological disorders.

Project Title: Infrastructure to study brain development disorders using neural cellular models
Project Description: This research program will investigate the genetic risk factors that cause brain development disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. The program will use innovative technology to study how the genetic risk factors impair brain cell function, and perform novel drug testing to correct identified deficiencies.

Project Title: Inert atmosphere glovebox for the synthesis of arsenic compounds and the live-harvesting of environmental samples
Project Description: An inert atmosphere glovebox will enable the safe and efficient synthesis of arsenic compounds believed to be intermediates in the biogeochemical cycling of arsenic. The toxicity, reactivity and ability of the compounds to be transformed by microorganisms to non-toxic arsenic will be investigated.

Project Title: Centre for Indigenous Knowledge and Education
Project Description: The Centre for Indigenous Knowledge and Education will be established, supported by multi-media, collaborative suites and a unique database to foster links between academic and community-based groups to significantly impact issues in Aboriginal Education, psychology, and mental health.

Project Title: Interconnects Characterization Facility
Project Description: Interconnect design is a crucial yet complex phase of the development of a modern electronic system. The proposed interconnects characterization facility will be used to test new interconnect structures and develop novel methods for their design, supporting microelectronics innovation in Ontario.

Project Title: High Resolution Imaging of Cell Matrix Signaling: Investigation of Mechanisms by Which Chemical and Mechanical Signals are Transduced Through Cell Adhesions
Project Description: The generation of signals that control cell activity is dependent on the formation of specialized types of cell adhesions. The objectives of this proposal are to identify how signals are transmitted through cell adhesions using state-of-the-art microscopy methods and to apply this information to drug discovery.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Early Innovative Rehabilitation Interventions for Critically Ill Patients in the Intensive Care Unit
Project Description: Dr. Kho’s research focuses on effective and creative methods of physiotherapy to help Intensive Care Unit (ICU) patients stay as strong as possible.  Infrastructure from this application will help her study how early physiotherapy in the ICU can help improve ICU survivors’ function and quality of life.

Project Title: Scanning Probe Microscope For Imaging and Mechanical Measurements of Biopolymers, Biological Structures and Bacterial Cells
Project Description: Infrastructure is requested to expand and enhance Professor Dutcher’s range of capabilities in scanning probe microscopy (SPM) imaging and mechanical property measurements of biomolecules and bacterial cells at surfaces.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Analysis of Changes in the Hydrology at the Arctic Treeline
Project Description: Surface water, a key part of the Canadian landscape, is facing serious threats due to both climate change and resource development. This program will consider the effects of changes on streamflow and lake levels and develop predictive tools.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Characterizing Iron Carbon Associations in Soils
Project Description: The global carbon balance & sustainable food production depend on the management of soil carbon, which is governed by interaction with soil minerals. The infrastructure will support comprehensive assessments of carbon-mineral interactions in soils to mitigate climate change and improve agricultural sustainability.

Project Title: Novel Molecular Imaging Platform to Elucidate the Role of Membrane Lipids in Neurodegeneration
Project Description: The infrastructure requested in this proposal will lead to an innovative molecular imaging research facility that will enable the PI and collaborators to identify the role that membrane lipids play in conferring vulnerability to cell death of brain cells.

Project Title: Creating QU-MOLTAH: Queen's University's Mobile Laboratory for Technical Art History
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to create a mobile laboratory for technical art history, to enable scientific examination of art works without having to move these vulnerable and priceless objects. Such research provides key information about issues of authenticity, artist’s intent, and state of conservation.

Project Title: Establishment of DeCiMaL the Digital Culture and Media Lab at UOIT
Project Description: Funds are sought to establish DeCiMaL (Digital Culture and Media Lab) to spearhead core humanities-based, critical inquiries of emergent wearable interface paradigms, (i.e, computers worn on the body) along with augmented reality interfaces to assess the impact on individuals, society, and “digital life”.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Engineered Quantum Systems for Quantum Information
Project Description: I am requesting funding for a state-of-the-art microwave test system for my new lab at the Institute for Quantum Computing at UWaterloo. The system will be custom built for quantum applications, enabling my work developing quantum networks, a potentially revolutionary information technology.

Project Title: Innovative Sustainable Agriculture Research Laboratory
Project Description: The research program will focus on refining nutrient management practices within agricultural systems to improve environmental sustainability, as well as protecting the quality of soil and water.

Project Title: Establishment of the Nipissing University Occupational Biomechanics and Ergonomics Laboratory.
Project Description: The primary research goal of Dr. Graham and the occupational biomechanics and ergonomics laboratory will be to enable Canadian individuals and society to better cope with the economically costly low back pain (LBP) pandemic by improving: LBP preventative measures, LBP diagnostic and assessment tools, and LBP rehabilitation practices

Project Title: Developing Novel Cancer Biotherapies: Infrastructure to Support Translational Research in Companion Animals
Project Description: Cancer is the primary cause of death in Ontario and conventional treatments are costly.  This proposal aims to establish an innovative biotherapy program focused on translational research.  Cost-effective immune-based oncolytic virotherapies will be developed to enhance treatment of cancer patients.

Project Title: Continuous and Remote Aquifer Monitoring Using Innovative Telemetry Systems: Enhancing Advanced Data Collection and Analysis Capabilities of G360- The Centre for Applied Groundwater Research
Project Description: The aim is to improve groundwater monitoring methods and data collection capabilities to address resource sustainability. Telemetry and associated groundwater monitoring equipment will be used to obtain and analyze continuous, in situ, long-term, remote subsurface water quality and quantity data.

Project Title: Drinking Water Treatment Laboratory and Tools
Project Description: This proposal is for funding to expand laboratory space and acquire tools to support a research program that is exploring novel methods to treat drinking water. The research will help to support Ontario’s initiative to become a world leader in water-related technologies.

Project Title: Laboratory for Forest Biorefinery and Biofuel Production
Project Description: In this program, novel processes for extracting lignocelluloses from wasted spent liquor of pulping processes and for converting the extracted lignocelluloses to value-added chemicals and biofuel will be developed.

Project Title: Mechanical Characterization Platform for Integrated Computational Materials Engineering Laboratory
Project Description: The acquisition of a mechanical platform for an integrated computational materials engineering lab at University of Toronto will support the development of new technology for lightweight materials. This will lead to increased energy efficiency in industries such as aerospace as well as improved renewable energy technology.

Project Title: Integrated Infrastructure for Avian Cognitive Ecology Research
Project Description: This project will bridge the gap between animal cognition and evolutionary ecology by examining the adaptive value of learning and memory in wild bird populations, using a modern aviary complex, cognitive devices, and population monitoring equipment.

Project Title: Drive Lab 2.0: Driving Simulator and Motion Capture System for a Multidisciplinary Team to Study Age-Differences in Collision Risk, Innovations in in-vehicle Devices and Vehicle-controls
Project Description: This grant is for a driving simulator and motion-capture system for a multidisciplinary team to study ways to reduce collision risk and to help a new generation of product designers develop in-vehicle devices with the needs of older drivers in mind, making driving safer, more comfortable, and more convenient.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support the Development of Peptide Vaccines for Peanut Allergy, Rheumatoid Arthritis and Transplant Rejection
Project Description: Chronic inflammatory diseases represent a major economic burden for healthcare systems. Most drugs for these diseases only treat symptoms and do not reduce the numbers of people with the disease. This proposal seeks to create curative vaccines for peanut allergy, rheumatoid arthritis and graft versus host disease.

Project Title: Massively Parallel Hardware Accelerators for Large-Scale Machine Learning
Project Description: Dr. Taylor’s research program focuses on Deep Learning: methods that can automatically extract useful representations and abstractions from data. This proposal seeks cutting-edge compute accelerators that will aid the group in their pursuit of new algorithms and architectures that learn from rich sensory input.
Keyword: Artificial Intelligence

Project Title: Sensory Ethnography Research Laboratory
Project Description: A Sensory Ethnography Research Laboratory will be established to examine the dynamics of community change related to issues of art and gentrification in southern Ontario and produce innovative public policies using sensory means of knowledge transfer.

Project Title: The Innovation, Design, and Consumption Laboratory
Project Description: The project will enhance our understanding of how consumers respond to innovation, and how marketers can better communicate innovative goods and services to facilitate adoption, and ultimately enhance the future economic sustainability of Canada.

Project Title: High-performance Computing Facility for Research in Theoretical Nuclear Physics
Project Description: This project involves state-of-the art theoretical research on cold atoms, nuclei, and neutron stars. Large numbers of processors as well as newly released “coprocessors” will be used to perform simulations for strongly interacting systems, where simpler approaches are known to fail.

Project Title: Remote Sensing for Advances in Terrestrial Hydrological Modelling
Project Description: The infrastructure will be used for the development of tools for detection, modelling and forecasting of emerging threats to water resources using satellite observations, field observations and computer modelling.

Project Title: Advanced Equipment for Solid State NMR Studies of Biomedically Important Membrane Proteins
Project Description: The project will advance experimental tools for studying structure and function of membrane proteins. The proposed research program bridges the fundamental aspects of membrane protein structure with the development of novel therapies to treat various diseases.

Project Title: ITRAX Core Scanner for Geoarchaeological and Paleoenvironmental Studies
Project Description: New geoarchaeological techniques will be used to examine the long-term interrelationship between climate change and human impacts on the landscape setting benchmark goals for remediation and protection of natural systems.

Project Title: Optofluidic-Based Technology for Biomedical Diagnostics and Cell Studies
Project Description: The proposed research will develop microtechnology based on the fusion of optics and microfluidics – optofluidics – for analytical and diagnostic applications in biomedicine and health care that will bring improved healthcare and economic benefits to Ontarians.

Project Title: Structural and Mechanistic Studies of Nano Carbon Electrodes and Polymer Electrolytes for Electrochemical Supercapacitors
Project Description: This proposal requests a Raman spectrometer equipped with a confocal microscope to complement electrochemical characterization tools and to conduct structural characterizations and mechanistic studies on electrochemical energy storage materials.

Project Title: Establishing a Retinal Disease Translational Pipeline:From Pathways Governing Adult Retinal Homeostasis Towards Cone Photoreceptor- based Therapies for Age-related Vision Loss
Project Description: Dr. Wallace’s research focuses on retinal diseases such as age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of vision loss in Ontario. Her approach is to: (1) identify and improve our understanding of retinal repair mechanisms, and (2) develop innovative cell-based therapies to restore vision loss.

Project Title: Research Infrastructure for an Integrative Research Program in Freshwater Ecology
Project Description: Funding for this proposal will support research investigating the processes that structure and maintain biodiversity in freshwater ecosystems on the islands of Ontario’s Georgian Bay and in lakes and ponds throughout Ontario.

Project Title: Atomic Force Microscopy for Force Measurements, Adhesion Studies, Nanotribology and Mechanical Testing of Cellulose Nanomaterials
Project Description: The proposed research aims to design functional materials from nanocellulose by elucidating structure-property relationships using the atomic force microscope with a sample stretching stage. Interfacial properties, adhesion, morphology and mechanical properties of novel nanomaterials will be investigated.

Project Title: Immunohistochemical Profiling of the Unfolded Protein Response in Chronic Respiratory Disease
Project Description: The objective of the proposed research program is to create tissue micro arrays from patients with chronic lung disease. The tissues will be screened for pathway specific gene expression patterns to identify molecular targets and thereby improve our understanding of the molecular pathogenesis of disease.

Project Title: Toronto Western “Investigational New Drug" Design & Discovery Lab (WIN-D3): an Innovative Centre of Drug Design and Discovery for Protein Misfolding Disorders, Stroke, Retinopathy and Epilepsy
Project Description: The goal of the project is to establish an innovative centre of drug design and discovery for multiple neurodegenerative disorders including protein misfolding disorders, stroke, retinopathy and epilepsy. This centre will act as a drug design pipeline for innovative therapies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Microparticles as Biomarkers, Pathogenic Mediators and Novel Therapeutics in Acute and Chronic Lung Disease
Project Description: Chronic and acute lung diseases are hard to detect prior to reaching advanced and incurable stages and have very poor available treatments. We here propose to utilize novel cell-derived microparticles to act as biomarkers of disease state and as innovative new therapies to successfully treat lung disease.

Project Title: Pilot Scale Water Flow Loop for Testing Water Treatment Systems and the Validation of Models
Project Description: The purpose of this grant is to fund a pilot scale water Flow Loop System in which different water and wastewater treatment technologies can be tested and models validated. Through validated models, it will be possible to optimize these technologies for enhanced treatment at reduced energy costs.

Project Title: Software-Defined Radio Enabled Wireless Surveillance and Security
Project Description: This project aims to acquire necessary equipment to build a software–defined, radio-enabled testbed for devising, implementing, and validating innovative solutions to wireless surveillance and security. The research program will greatly enhance information security and service availability of operational wireless systems.

Project Title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Technology to Evaluate Sustainable Cropping Systems
Project Description: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) can monitor soil quality, crop production and resilience. Contrasted with satellites, UAVs fly low and slow to improve resolution and timeliness, at reduced costs. Contrasted with ground based methods, UAVs are rapid, non-invasive, non-destructive and apply to large scales.

Project Title: Cutting-edge Echocardiogram: Understanding Heart Failure and Identifying Lifestyle Interventions
Project Description: The ultimate goal of the proposed research is to elucidate novel mechanisms causing heart failure, as this information will hopefully provide insight into the development of lifestyle interventions (nutrition and exercise) that are successful in preventing and/or recovering heart function in the failing heart.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Establish an Injury Biomechanics Laboratory for Experimental and Numerical Research
Project Description: The objective of the research is to develop comprehensive bone fracture limits and identify appropriate surrogates (test devices and numerical models) to predict injury.  These studies will reduce the incidence of fractures through enhanced safety, and improve surgical treatment of these injuries.

Project Title: Development of Sensory and Neural Cells in the Mammalian Cochlea
Project Description: Dr. Dabdoub’s research will lead to the development of new fundamental knowledge and improve therapies for deafness.  His research will investigate the factors responsible for the generation and development of the hair cells (sound detection) and the cochlear neurons (transmit sound to the brain).

Project Title: Infrastructure for Modeling Human Adipose Tissue Development in the Context of Metabolic Disorders
Project Description: Canada is in the midst of an obesity epidemic, thus the main goal of the proposed research is to bridge human stem cell and fat development in the context of metabolic diseases, such as obesity and type II diabetes, to identify innovative and novel therapeutic approaches that reduce disease burden.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Establish an Exercise Physiology Laboratory and to Study and Mathematically Model the Entrainment of the Heart, Lungs, and Locomotor Muscles in Humans Exposed to Environmental Stress
Project Description: A state-of-the-art Exercise Physiology Laboratory at Nipissing University will support Dr. Raymer’s interdisciplinary study and mathematical modeling of the entrainment of the heart, lungs, and locomotor muscles in humans exposed to environmental stress.

Project Title: Innovation in Quantum Nonlinear Optics
Project Description: We will be using recent advances in our understanding of the properties of light to develop the technology of tomorrow. This includes light-based microchips, quantum computing, tamper-proof quantum communications systems, and miniaturized environmental and medical diagnostics tools.

Project Title: Galvanizing Simulator Upgrade for NSERC-USSC IRC
Project Description: This project will research the metallic coating and physical metallurgy of advanced high strength steels (AHSS), and will contribute to the development of galvanizing techniques for the Third Generation of AHSS, to maintain Ontario’s leadership position in steel and automotive manufacturing.

Project Title: Infrastructure for a Computational Genomics Lab
Project Description: Using advanced computing and genomic methodologies, this project will develop biological databases and computer tools for effective identification of genetic variants based on genome sequencing. These genetic variants contribute to biological diversity and are linked to genetic diseases in humans.

Project Title: Developing Quantum Photonic Technology: An Integrated Optics Platform for Quantum Information Processing and Quantum Metrology
Project Description: With the control of single photons, scientists could build sensors with dramatically higher sensitivity, computers than can solve intractable problems, and the first provably secure communication systems. This project will develop techniques to produce and manipulate individual photons on optical microchips.

Project Title: Carbon and Nitrogen Analysis in Agroecology
Project Description: This research will shed light on biophysical interactions in agricultural ecosystems. We will integrate advanced techniques in ecophysiology and biogeochemistry to develop innovative and resilient agriculture production systems, and establish predictive measures for agroecosystem management.

Project Title: Child and Family Mobile and Fixed Observation Laboratories and Caring Dad’s Database
Project Description: This project will build world-class mobile and fixed labs, and a unique, comprehensive database, to support research to better understand and treat high-risk, violent, abusive and neglectful men and fathers and to continue to reduce violence against women and children in families in Ontario.

Project Title: Development of Innovative Monitoring Tools to Capture the Early Warning Signs of Future Landslide Instability
Project Description: The proposed research aims to produce the knowledge, highly qualified graduates, and practical tools to better understand and manage the risk posed by climate change on the soil slopes of Ontario’s natural and built environment.

Project Title: Methods and Tools for Developing and Operating Ultra-Large-Scale (ULS) Software Services
Project Description: Ultra-large-scale (ULS) services (like BlackBerry, Gmail and Facebook) have increasingly become an essential part of our lives. Ensuring their reliability is an important and challenging task given the scale of such services and the impact of their downtime. The requested infrastructure permits the creation of techniques and tools to support the cost-effective development and operation of high-quality ULS services through the use of Software Intelligence techniques that mine the rich, yet-rarely-explored repositories associated with these services.

Project Title: High-Frequency Trading in Global Financial Markets
Project Description: The proposed program will study recent proliferation of algorithmic and high-frequency trading on quality, stability, and efficiency of financial markets in Ontario and around the globe.

Project Title: Mitochondrial Dynamics in Pulmonary Hypertension and Lung Cancer
Project Description: Dr. Archer and his colleagues discovered that inhibiting mitochondrial division increases cell death, and slows cell proliferation, a characteristic in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Dr. Archer will define and target mitochondrial dynamics to create new therapies.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Canada Research Chair in Microbial Chemical Biology
Project Description: Multidrug resistant bacteria continue to be a health care burden in both hospital and community settings. Recognizing the need for new therapies, the proposed research program will uncover weaknesses in the survival strategies of bacteria for the design of truly novel antibacterial drugs.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Canada Research Chair in Integrative Wildlife Conservation
Project Description: This research and infrastructure is important to enable the establishment of an Integrative Wildlife Conservation research program that will provide improved understanding of factors affecting the distribution and abundance of animal populations and the structure and function of their ecosystems. Through computing, we will develop state-of-the-art models of species distribution and abundance, using radio-telemetry we will determine causes and consequences of animal population declines, whereas through experimentation and related bio-assays we will identify mechanisms affecting animal health, immunecompetence, and condition.

Project Title: University of Guelph, Comparative Obesity Research Program, Infrastructure Development
Project Description: The Comparative Obesity Research Program aims to advance knowledge of the molecular basis of obesity in multiple species. Research goals are to study the impact of macronutrients and nutraceuticals on body composition and energy metabolism and their use for weight loss and prevention of weight gain.

Project Title: Establishing a Stable isotope Mass Spectrometry Facility for Environmental Research in Northern Ontario
Project Description: With the equipment acquired, a newly formed isotope geochemistry facility will analyse tree rings and other organic materials in order to understand past climate and ecosystem function, as well as use stable isotopes to answer environmental, geological, and biological questions.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Optically Guided Laser Ablation with Integrated Surgical Navigation
Project Description: The goal of this research is to advance minimally invasive diagnostic imaging and therapeutic monitoring in surgical procedures. The key elements highlight collaborations between existing imaging modalities, optical coherence tomography, and medical laser ablation during clinical and pathological correlations.

Project Title: Spinning Disk Confocal Microscope and Capillary Electrophoresis Coupled to Mass Spectrometry
Project Description: The applicants include two Tier I Canada Research Chairs and one “junior” faculty member who seek to (i) add a capillary electrophoresis front end to a Q-Tof mass spectrometer, and (ii) upgrade an obsolete confocal microscope to a cutting-edge spinning-disk laser confocal microscope system.

Project Title: Mass Spectrometry Laboratory for Solid Earth Geochemistry and Environmental Biogeochemistry Research at Waterloo
Project Description: The proposed research will measure the abundance and isotopic composition of metals in solid Earth materials, petroleum, and waters. This data will help improve genetic models and exploration efforts for Ontario natural resources, as well as contribute to contaminant remediation efforts.

Project Title: Time and Frequency Domain Hyperspectral Imaging for Photovoltaic Applications
Project Description: Solar cell technology, deployed on a large scale, has the potential to substantially contribute to Ontario’s energy mix.  This project will develop new techniques to directly image the defects and imperfections in solar cells that limit their efficiency, providing new tools to improve solar cell manufacturing processes.

Project Title: Laboratory for Biomimetic Microchip Technologies
Project Description: Our goal is to develop biomimetic microchip technology for applications in cancer research. The requested infrastructure will create an integrative lab environment to enable high quality original research that has potential to improve cancer treatment and human health in Ontario and worldwide.

Project Title: Real-Time Digital Simulation of Renewable Powered Distribution Systems with Energy Storage
Project Description: Renewable energy sources add to power system variability. Energy storage interfaced through power electronics can balance this variability, but the coupled system’s dynamic behaviour is unknown at fast time scales. This research will use real-time digital simulators to investigate and optimize this scenario.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Integrated Research of Wildlife Responses to Changing Habitats, Climate, and Human Activities
Project Description: Ontario wildlife species are one of our provinces greatest resources. This proposal uses an integrative approach to assess wildlife responses to changing habitat, climate, and human activities. This research will help planning and mitigation for the many pressures facing wildlife species in a changing world.

Project Title: Temporal Integration in Human Brain Networks
Project Description: How do our brains integrate patterns of information over time? This occurs, for example, when each word in a sentence is understood in the context of words that came before. Dr. Honey aims to answer this question using a range of experimental methods, based in a new cognitive neuroscience laboratory at the University of Toronto.

Project Title: A Long-Wavelength Instrumentation Laboratory
Project Description: This proposal seeks funding for the infrastructure required for development of next-generation long wavelength instrumentation technologies. These technologies are ultimately aimed at collecting faint light from the distant cosmos, to build our understanding of the fundamental properties of the Universe.

Project Title: Geospatial Mobility Lab: A Testbed for Merging Geographic Information and Mobile Technology
Project Description: The Geospatial Mobility Lab is a first-of-its kind testbed that will be used to support research developing location-based mobile device applications. Findings will evaluate the use and impact of mobile devices within a variety of application areas, including citizen science, public health, and citizen participation.

Project Title: The Sustainability Challenge for Global Food Security Governance
Project Description: This project will undertake research that improves understandings of the complex linkages between environmental sustainability and global food security policy and governance outcomes. It further aims to contribute to policy recommendations to improve both food security and sustainability goals.

Project Title: Q-Exactive Instrument to Advance the Drug Discovery Program
Project Description: By utilizing a Q-Exactive Mass Spectrometer, Dr. Moran’s proposal aims to show that tumors originating from different cancer patients have distinctive proteomic profiles (i.e. proteomic “signatures”), which can be used for effective tumor classification and to personalize cancer therapies.

Project Title: Evaluating the Performance of Low Impact Development at the Catchment Scale
Project Description: The infrastructure requested will be used to develop the Mobile Urban Water Processes Laboratory (MUWP Lab) and used to evaluate the performance of Low Impact Development (i.e. next-generation stormwater technologies) at the catchment or neighbourhood-level and assess the implications to receiving water systems.

Project Title: Laboratory for Atmospheric Organics
Project Description: The goal of our research is to understand the sources and formation processes of organic aerosol in the atmosphere, a major fraction of ambient particulate matter. Through chemical characterization, we will elucidate the contributions of these complex mixtures to climate change and adverse health impacts.

Project Title:
Revolutionizing Electron Microscopy: Energy Filter with a Direct
Electron Detector Added to Existing CFI Infrastructure
Project Description: This proposal aims to obtain cutting-edge instrumentation to be added to an existing powerful electron microscope. This new infrastructure will dramatically increase the ability to visualize cellular structures that have never been seen before, identifying novel therapeutic targets for a variety of human diseases.

Project Title: High Performance Muscle Metabolism Suite
Project Description: The research will determine the synergies between physical activity and proper nutrition for the optimal development of musculoskeletal health and performance across the lifespan.

Project Title: Wireless Transceiver Characterization Facility
Project Description: This research program will study and design new integrated circuit architectures for the next generation of wireless communication transceivers: a low-cost, adaptive universal mobile terminal and a wireless node for a peer-to-peer wireless social network.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Modelling Human-Environment Interactions in Agricultural Systems
Project Description: Effects land management decisions and subsequent agricultural production, farm livelihoods, and ecosystem function are investigated using unmanned aerial vehicle infrastructure, socio-ecological field equipment, and new agent-based simulation models.

Project Title: Augmentation of Neurorehabilitation Training using Targeted Brain Stimulation.
Project Description: This research aims to improve applications of brain electrical stimulation to treat neurological disorders. Advanced neuroimaging techniques will be used to measure the brain’s short-term and long-term responses to stimulation, and thereby optimize stimulation techniques to maximize the benefits.

Project Title: Dynamics of Coupled Wave-current-sediment Processes in Coastal Environments
Project Description: Coastal research is needed to accurately predict storm hazards and to reduce risks to society. These hazards, which include coastal erosion and flooding from storms, can impact the Canada’s Great Lakes and ocean coasts that represent an area of high economic and environmental importance.

Project Title: Understanding the Daily Lives of Purpose and Conscientiousness
Project Description: This proposed infrastructure acquisitions will provide increased opportunities to understand the daily lives of individuals imbued with purpose and conscientiousness. Understanding these characteristics at cognitive, emotional, and behavioural levels will allows us to begin developing new programs and interventions to encourage others to grow these traits over time. Such advances would be immensely beneficial for Ontario, given that these characteristics appear critical for benefitting the health, productivity, and well-being of the workforce.

Project Title: Early Developmental Trajectories and Intervention for Life-Long Well-Being
Project Description: Early experience becomes embedded into physiological and brain structures that are the basis for learning and behaviour. The requested infrastructure enables three study designs to track and change the early trajectories of children’s learning and health.

Project Title: The In Vivo Metabolic Characterization Laboratory
Project Description: Diabetes and obesity have reached epidemic proportions on a global level. The proposed facility will allow the study of whole-body metabolism in experimental models of diabetes and obesity. It will provide new drug targets and behaviour strategies to more effectively treat these diseases.

Project Title: MPARC – Mental Health and Physical Activity Research Centre
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will support a one-of-a-kind research facility dedicated to developing, evaluating and implementing interventions to promote physical activity and mental health among the high number of Ontarians at risk of physical inactivity and mental health problems.

Project Title: Laboratory for Evolution and Ecology of Disease
Project Description: We apply evolutionary and ecological thinking to the study of parasites. Using a combination of theory and experiments, we will investigate the role of parasite plasticity in infection dynamics and intervention failure, explore the evolution of parasite circadian rhythms, and develop new tools for detecting drug resistance.

Project Title: A Super-Resolution Microscopy System for Dynamic Analysis of Multimolecular Complexes
Project Description: Our proposal aims to bring super-resolution microscopy and light-sheet fluorescence microscopy to researchers in Ontario. This revolutionary technology will enable scientists to visualize cellular structures with up to 10-fold greater resolution, leading to a better understanding of the pathogenesis of disease.

Project Title: Failure Diagnosis Testbed
Project Description: Software systems are becoming ever more powerful and intelligent. This rising complexity increases the risk of failures, and every minute of down-time is costly. This project will build a unique computer server cluster platform that will automatically diagnose failures in cloud-based distributed software systems

Project Title: Quantifying the Hidden Thaw
Project Description: This will provide a new class of measurements suitable to quantify permafrost thaw. This is important because large areas of permafrost are thawing. Research based on this infrastructure will result in next-generation monitoring and simulation supporting infrastructure and development in the North.

Project Title: Molecular Pathology of Cardiovascular Disease
Project Description: There are very few molecular markers that are effective in the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular  disease (CVD). We propose to acquire innovative screening platforms to discover (and apply) novel “biomarkers” in CVD affected human blood vessels, especially the vascular lining (endothelium).

Project Title: Laboratory for Molecular Interfaces
Project Description: Organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) offer energy savings in indoor lighting. We will create a unique laboratory facility to explore the relationship between the molecular structure inside OLEDs and their performance, and to prototype new device structures and materials based on this understanding

Project Title: Mobile Mapping and Manipulation
Project Description: The objective of the proposed research is to develop autonomous mapping and dexterous manipulation capabilities for mobile robots to facilitate planetary exploration. These will be validated on a state-of-the-art rover testbed. The work will help to maintain Ontario’s reputation for excellence in space robotics.

Project Title: Exploring the Secret Life of Indoor Particles
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure is essential to develop and apply innovative methods to study indoor particles and dusts.  The overall objective of the proposal is to understand the size distribution of these particles so that risk can be assessed and control strategies that mitigate exposure can be developed.

Project Title: Enhancing Programmable Silicon: Increasing Efficiency and Ease-of-Use and Broadening Its Application
Project Description: The ever increasing capability of computer chips has brought huge benefits, enabling for example the wireless communication revolution and greatly improved medical therapy. To reap even further benefits, we seek to develop new, highly capable and power-efficient  “programmable hardware” chips.

Project Title: Control of Chromosome Dynamics and Genome Integrity
Project Description: Cancer and infectious disease are two leading causes of premature death in Ontario. The research team will explore how antibiotic production is influenced by regulatory factors, and examine how protein interactions and modifications stabilize our genetic material.  The findings will allow them to identify new cancer therapeutic targets and develop new antibiotics.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Public Use Microdata Sample of the 1861 Canadian Census
Project Description: This research infrastructure is a 10% representative public use microdata sample (PUMS) of the 1861 census enumeration of Canada. The database provides a detailed profile of the Ontario population at a critical point in its history.

Project Title: Large Scale Analysis of Textual Repositories
Project Description: The project deals with the discovery of structure from textual data. We will develop novel algorithms, prediction techniques, compression schemes, as well as new approaches for data collection and mining. We will use different signals in the text to enable a shift in scientific and commercial applications.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Collaborative Decision Support in Complex Systems Design
Project Description: The proposed research will develop novel computational paradigms to design complex engineering systems. The methods developed will be validated on a state-of-the-art collaborative decision making infrastructure. This work will help maintain Ontario’s reputation for excellence in aerospace design.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Advanced Business Analytics: Creating and Analysing Big Data for Canadian Distribution Channels
Project Description: A framework for using pan-supply chain big data analyses will be created to reduce distribution channel conflict among small and medium enterprises, thereby enhancing competitiveness through innovation in marketing and operations processes.

Project Title: Regulation of Spinal Cord Excitability in Acute and Chronic Pain States
Project Description: Better pain treatments require a molecular identification of what goes wrong in chronic pain.  Through neuronal recordings, we will study how changes in the activity and regulation of electrical proteins called ion channels generates dysfunctional spinal cord pain signalling and pain hypersensitivity.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Centre for Workers’ Health and Well-being
Project Description: This multi-method and innovative infrastructure will enable research to improve worker health and well-being by: 1) examining the dynamic and causal processes among work demands, resources and their distribution; 2) designing specific, practical and evidence-based interventions.

Project Title: Advancing Novel Small Molecule Strategies Towards Translational Medicine
Project Description: Dr. Kotra’s unique research program links basic research with advanced drug discovery infrastructure and industry partners to develop therapeutics for a wide variety of diseases, including infectious diseases (malaria, viral infections) and neurological diseases (multiple sclerosis, diabetic neuropathy).
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: A Combined Microanalytical-Experimental Laboratory for Improved Understanding of Ore-Forming Processes
Project Description: High-temperature geofluids transfer and precipitate economically important elements and generate most of our mineral resources. The proposed research investigates this process by combining high pressure-temperature experimental work with state of the art microanalytical investigation of geologic samples.

Project Title: A Tellurium Upgrade for the SNO+ Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay Search
Project Description: We seek to determine whether or not neutrinos are their own antiparticles by carrying out one of the world’s most sensitive searches for neutrinoless double beta decay. To do this, we will dissolve tellurium metal into the 760 tonnes of ultrapure liquid scintillator in the SNO+ experiment at SNOLAB.

Project Title: Advancing Mobility Rehabilitation Treatments and Technologies
Project Description: The goal of this proposal is to develop ways to enable us to study how mobility assistive devices work in real world environments, where they would typically be used. The new information will make it possible to develop more effective devices and provide better treatments for individuals with mobility problems.

Project Title: Spinal Cord Injury Clinical Research Unit: Optimizing the Translation of Basic Discoveries
Project Description: Spinal cord injury is a debilitating injury that results in physical impairment and an increased burden of care. The Spinal Cord Injury Clinical Research Unit is a dedicated research space that will evaluate new treatments for the recovery of patients with spinal cord injury.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Culture of Complex, Human-Associated, Microbial Communities
Project Description: This proposal seeks to build on a previous, highly successful CFI/MRI award that created the “Robogut” model of the gut microbiota. Infrastructure is requested to update and expand existing equipment to improve capacity and enhance the translational potential of gut ecosystem modeling to health

Project Title: Epigenetic Regulation in Cancer Development and Progression
Project Description: This innovative research program will elucidate the functional role of epigenetic regulation in cancer development and progression and will yield key mechanistic understanding that will lead to the identification of new and better diagnostic/prognostic markers for more effective anticancer therapies.

Project Title: Biocontainment Facility Enhancement
Project Description: This is a request for infrastructure support to obtain biocontainment isolators for research on infectious diseases and development of vaccines against poultry pathogens. The program is focused on mechanisms of immunity to viruses and developing the next generation of prophylactic means against these viruses.

Project Title: Discovery of Oncogenic Mechanisms Through Hospital-Based Molecular Profiling
Project Description: Using state-of-the-art genomics and bioinformatics technologies, Dr. Pugh’s innovative program will realize the molecular classification of tumours and link specific genome alterations to cancer phenotypes and treatment outcomes through analysis of clinical cases.

Project Title: Science Operating Room Extension (ScORE)
Project Description: This project will build on significant prior investments to develop the capability for the high-precision testing and evaluation of new imaging agents. These agents will be used to guide cancer therapy through advanced imaging. The validation experiments will also advance our understanding of cancer.

Project Title: Centre for Arrhythmia Research in Toronto (CART)
Project Description: To help establish a Centre for Arrhythmia Research in Toronto (CART) with expertise in basic and clinical electrophysiology focused on increasing our understanding of arrhythmias and advancing development of new therapies to treat them.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: The Translational Stroke Research Program
Project Description: Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability. The conventional model of translating promising stroke therapies from rodent experiments to human clinical trials has failed to provide new efficacious treatments. This project aims to utilize stroke models in higher-order animal species to bridge this gap.

Project Title: Respiratory Infection Secure Containment (RISC) Facility
Project Description: The Respiratory Infection Secure Containment (RISC) Facility will provide a biosafe and biosecure laboratory environment in which infectious disease-focused researchers can safely develop new vaccines and antimicrobial therapies to combat deadly bacterial and viral pathogens that spread through the air to infect humans.

Project Title: Prevention and Personalized Treatment in Hereditary Cancer
Project Description: Our research program aims to decrease both direct and indirect costs of cancer in Canada by reducing the number of new cases and cancer-related deaths. This goal will be accomplished through our individual- and population-based work to identify individuals at-risk of developing hereditary cancers and treat patients using a personalized approach with targeted therapies.

Project Title: A Facility for Multi-stressor Biology on Aquatic Organisms
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will support research to investigate the effects of multiple environmental and pollution-based stressors, such as temperature, salinity, pH, and chemical contaminants, upon aquatic animal development, behaviour and physiology.

Project Title: Multi-Axis Dynamic Simulator for Testing Operational and Functional Components and Advanced Seismic Isolation Devices
Project Description: This research program will generate critically needed knowledge on the earthquake behaviour of nonstructural components. This knowledge will facilitate the development of innovative technologies to protect nonstructural components from earthquake damage.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Algorithm Development, Verification, and Proof of Principle for Wireless and Computing Systems
Project Description: Establish a research infrastructure that supports innovation in digital communications and computing spanning theory, algorithms, and hardware.  Develop proof-of-principle implementations for next-generation digital communication systems and methods for power-efficient computation in data centers.

Project Title: Integrative Mitochondrial Bioenergetic Facility for the Study of Muscle Wasting Diseases
Project Description: The aim of this proposal is to identify novel cellular pathways responsible for causing muscle wasting in muscular dystrophies and aging in many Ontario citizens.  Once these mechanistic links are identified, numerous drugs known to affect these pathways will be tested for their ability to prevent muscle wasting in these diseases.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Airborne Electromagnetic Sea Ice Thickness Sensor
Project Description: The proposal aims to obtain the key data for better understanding and predicting sea ice conditions in the Arctic, and for preparing for increased Arctic resource exploration and shipping. Data will be obtained by airborne and satellite surveys, particularly with the requested novel ice thickness sensor

Project Title: Toronto Western Investigational New Drug Design & Discovery (WIN-D3) Lab
Project Description: The goal of the project is to establish an innovative centre of drug design and discovery for multiple neurodegenerative disorders including protein misfolding disorders, stroke, retinopathy and epilepsy. This centre will act as a drug design pipeline for innovative therapies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Obesity and Metabolism Research
Project Description: The project will test the effects of exercise, nutrition and genetics on adiposity in mice.   It will also investigate the mechanisms mediating these effects by examining modifications that occur on proteins.

Project Title: High Content Analysis Nanoscope to Study Neurodegeneration and Discover New Compounds for Neurodegenerative Disease
Project Description: Our goal is to discover new chemical family leads as potential new therapies for Huntington's disease, from working at the single cell level, at nanometer resolution focusing efforts on the molecular trigger of this devastating disease.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: New Tools for Automated and Non-invasive Animal Welfare Assessment
Project Description: This research will refine measures for assessing laying hen welfare, find causes and solutions for health and behaviour problems in alternative housing and optimize the design of new hen housing systems in order to maintain the sustainable delivery of safe, high quality and affordable eggs to consumers by Ontario egg producers.

Project Title: Advancing Paediatric Surgical Techniques and Childhood Nutrition Research by Utilizing Isotope-Ratio Mass Spectrometry
Project Description: Utilization of a state-of-the-art Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer will leverage existing expertise at SickKids to further ground-breaking research into two very important areas of paediatric research: (1) Novel paediatric surgical techniques, and (2) Childhood nutrition.

Project Title: Cannabinoid Drug Discovery
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to discover and develop novel small molecules that target the endocannabinoid system and related novel orphan receptor targets that are important in human disease. This research is also directed towards understanding the pharmacology underlying both the detrimental consequence of recreational cannabis smoking and the potential for cannabis used as a medicine.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Analysis of Global Change Impacts on Tree and Forest Function
Project Description: This proposal seeks infrastructure to determine how boreal tree species growth, survival and physiology respond to climate change stress, including rising temperatures, CO2 and drought. This understanding is critical for maintaining forest productivity for sustainable economic development in Ontario.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Multisensory Laboratory
Project Description: The proposed research will analyze the way our brain integrates multisensory information. Sensory cues can conflict with technology, ageing, injury and disease. The applicant will build the WaTerloo Immersive Multisensory Environment (WaTIME) system to assess and resolve sensory conflict that occurs during self-motion.

Project Title:
Establishing a Knowledge Translation Centre for Identifying Inhibitors of
Protein-Protein Interactions
Project Description: Our goal is to establish a facility that can rapidly design, synthesize and identify preclinical candidate, hit-to-lead molecules targeting STAT3 and STAT5 for in vivo analysis in relevant human cancer models.

Project Title: Deconstructing Biases in the Fossil Record of Exceptional Preservation: Experimental and Geochemical Studies in Soft-Tissue Preservation
Project Description: The Advanced Taphonomy Laboratory (ATL) will aid in elucidating the pathways responsible for exceptional fossilization by identifying physical, chemical, and biological controls biasing the fossil record. The ATL is unique to Canada, focusing on modeling fossilization through real-life experiments.

Project Title: Towards an integrated picture of sensory learning in neural circuits
Project Description: This research seeks an integrated picture of how the brain learns from sensory experience. Dr. Richards' laboratory will use a combination of electrophysiology, computer models, and behavioural experiments to understand how billions of tiny changes to the connections in the brain produce new skills.

Project Title:
Computational Approaches to Causal and Social Learning in
Children and Animals
Project Description: From learning to flip a light switch to using a remote control, children must uncover the world’s causal structure, including the causes and consequences of other people’s actions. At the University of Toronto, Dr. Buchsbaum will use experimental and computational techniques to understand children’s causal and social reasoning abilities.

Project Title: Equipment for Studies of Hybrid Quantum Systems of Spins and Superconductors
Project Description: This project is to install novel infrastructure that enables the development of a first generation of hybrid quantum processors including ones that combine spins and superconductors as quantum bits. Such processors are an essential step towards larger, general-purpose quantum computers.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Combining Brain Imaging and Genetics for Treatment Innovation in Mental Illness
Project Description: This proposal aims to develop infrastructure and resources to support two complementary thematic objectives: 1) to use a combination of brain imaging and genetics to understand the effects of mental illness risk genes on the structure and function of the brain; 2) to use advanced neuroimaging approaches in clinical trials to better understand the effects of existing and novel treatments for mental illness on brain structure and function.
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: PEDAL 2.0: Secure Data Linking to Quantify Impacts of Social Intervention
Project Description: Researchers will develop methods to collect, transform, and link sensitive, proprietary administrative data from sources including school boards and charities in order to quantify the impacts of social policies and programs on individuals and communities.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Linking Current and Future Environment, Physiology, Behaviour, and Life History in Birds
Project Description: The objective of this project is to investigate how environmental challenges influence animals. We will address this goal through experimental manipulations of the environment and hormones in black-capped chickadees, and measurement of effects on resource investment and population dynamics.

Project Title: Causes of Inadequate Reading Comprehension in Young Adults
Project Description: The research goal is to identify common causes of the failure to develop adequate reading comprehension in young Ontarians, a social condition that affects over 40% of 16-25 year olds in the province. The findings will inform reading remediation programs in schools and adult literacy centres.

Project Title: Engineering a Smart Microgrid Test Platform
Project Description:
As Ontario continues to close down coal-fired generating plants, our existing power grid must become ‘smarter’ to accommodate wind, solar and other renewable energy sources more reliably.

A microgrid is an autonomous generating unit operated in isolation locally, or networked to provide energy to Ontario’s power grid. A smart grid test platform consisting of four microgrid test platforms will provide a comprehensive experimental setup to enable increased renewable energy use in a more efficient and reliable manner.

Project Title: Immune Cell Contributions to Endometrial Health and Disease
Project Description: Infertility and cardiovascular health impairment in mothers and offspring who experience pregnancy complications are significant health issues in Ontario. Our objective is to develop new, clinically important knowledge that will enhance the quality of pregnancy and reduce infertility from endometriosis.

Project Title: Monitoring Cancer Therapy Using Magnetic Resonance Imaging
Project Description: Dr. Stanisz’s research will lead to the development of new fundamental knowledge and improve non-invasive monitoring of therapies for cancer treatment. His research will cultivate new imaging techniques that will allow a detailed characterization of the complex tumour environment.

Project Title: Biophysics and Evolulionary Dynamics Laboratory
Project Description: Sidhartha Goyal's lab will study rapid evolution in the context of (A) mitochondrial genome maintenance, and (B) role of adaptive evolution through CRISPRs in bacteria-phage competition, which will provide insight into age-associated diseases and the role of gut micro biorne in human health and disease.

Project Title: Mechanisms of Anesthesia and Sleep
Project Description: Our goal is to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying general anesthesia and sleep, and use this knowledge to develop new treatments for common anesthesia- and sleep-related disorders. The requested infrastructure will allow us to create new animal and human tissue models, which will be used to identify novel drug targets.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Comparative Molecular Physiology Imaging Infrastructure (CoMPII)
Project Description: The CoMPII project will establish a core biological imagine suite that will be used to address some basic biological questions about how fish and other aquatic animals manage to balance their internal salt, water and pH levels under changing environmental conditions.

Project Title: Infrastructure for an Immunometabolism Laboratory
Project Description: This research addresses the obesity epidemic by investigating the underlying bacterial and immune causes of diabetes during obesity. The aim is to discover new diagnostics and therapeutics by understanding how the bacteria that live in our gut cause inflammation and disease during obesity.

Project Title: Characterization of the Alternative Oxidase of Pathogenic Protists and Treatment of Human Disease
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to develop detection methods and treatment options for human diseases caused by parasitic protists. The goal is to ensure the safety of freshwater and the food supply in Ontario. The research impacts the aging population and immuno-compromised or -suppressed individuals.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Functional Genomics
Project Description: Dr McKay studies the role of post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression in DNA damage responses including the p53 tumour suppressor pathway.  RNA-sequencing, microarrays and flow cytometric analysis of fluorescent reporter genes will be used for analysis of these post-transcriptional processes.

Project Title: Optimizing Use of Human Milk for Preterm Infants
Project Description: This grant will enable the purchase of specialized equipment to perform direct nutrient analysis of human milk, known for its nutrient variability. This capacity will improve the rigor of the evaluation and translation into practice of promising nutritional strategies to improve the health of very preterm infants.

Project Title: Enhanced Characterization Infrastructure for Canada Research Chair in Polymer Nanomaterials
Project Description: This proposal is to acquire enhanced characterization infrastructure for supporting Dr. Zhibin Ye’s Canada Research Chair (CRC) research program in polymer nanomaterials. The goal of the research is to produce value-added multifunctional polymer nanomaterials for use in various industries.

Project Title: From Fracture to Fluids to Combustion: Infrastructure to understand the implications of hydraulic fracturing
Project Description: Hydraulic fracturing (“fracking”) is a rapidly emergy technology for natural gas production, but many fundamental aspects remain poorly understood, with significant implications for all forms of power generation in Ontario. This work will answer key questions regarding fluid transport, rock fracture and ultimate greenhouse gas emissions.

Project Title: Infrastructure for a Nanomaterials Laboratory
Project Description: Functional materials are important for technology development. The proposed research will investigate innovative ways of assembling and organizing nanostructures with other materials (including biomolecules and polymers) for advancing biodiagnostic tools and clean energy technologies.

Project Title: Structure and Function of Carbohydrate-Active Enzymes
Project Description: Beyond their key role as nutrients, carbohydrates are also important cellular communication molecules. Using a dual approach of structural and functional characterization we will investigate how this important class of bioactive molecules are synthesized and degraded in health and disease associated settings.

Project Title: Brain Health in Aging: Preventing Dementia Through Exercise and Developing Biomarkers for Early Detection
Project Description: The proposed research will help Ontario reduce the burden of Alzheimer’s disease on Ontario families and the economy by improving screening protocols for early disease detection and developing exercise interventions to reduce memory loss in seniors.

Project Title: High-performance Polymer Materials for Printed Electronics
Project Description: This proposed research will address the key challenges associated with printed electronics by developing novel electronic polymer materials, which will be enabled by the requested infrastructure for the materials evaluation.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: McMaster Decision Science Laboratory
Project Description: Using experimental economic methods we will investigate health system outcomes under alternate systems of health care finance and elicit Canadians’ views on the allocation of health care resources, aiding the development of an efficient, equitable health care system.

Project Title: Removal of Micro-Particles in Steel Processing
Project Description: The objective of this project is to develop and implement a high temperature microscopy technique in order to gain a fundamental understanding of the interaction between micro-particles and liquid oxide systems. This technique will be used to improve micro-particle removal during liquid steel refining.

Project Title: Preparation of Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) Foils from Ion Irradiated Samples
Project Description: A key step in understanding the effects of irradiation on materials is the preparation of foils for study in the electron microscope.  High precision sample preparation is required, with physical cutting followed by ion milling to prepare a sample with better than 0.1mm precision for subsequent viewing.

Project Title: The Role of Astroglial Cells in Psychiatric Illness and Its Treatment
Project Description: This proposal includes two major aims that will elucidate molecular underpinnings of mental illnesses, particularly disorders associated with prematurity (aim 1) and anxiety disorders (aim 2).

Project Title: Hardwiring Protein Modifications As Probes of Signalling, Epigenetic, & Redox Networks
Project Description: The proposed research will establish systems that synthesize proteins with multiple non-canonical amino acids to investigate the role of protein modifications in cellular signalling pathways and cancer mechanisms and to create proteins with novel properties.

Project Title: Parallel Computer for the Development of New Algorithms in Quantum Mechanics
Project Description: I shall develop and apply new theoretical/computational methods for studying the motion of molecules.  An important goal is to develop methods that will permit us to study larger molecules.  Understanding the motion of molecules enables scientists to identify and study molecules in the atmosphere and in combustion processes.  Our work will provide information necessary for understanding how molecules in the atmosphere absorb and emit radiation which is important for modelling global warming

Project Title: A Natural Behaviour Laboratory for the Investigation of Embodied and Embedded Cognition
Project Description: The requested funds will be used to set up a natural behaviour laboratory for the investigation of embodied and embedded cognition.
