This equipment will enable basic research investigating how we use our body and physical environment to help us think and how this coupling ultimately shapes our thinking.

Project Title: NMR Enhancement at Moderate Magnetic Fields
Project Description: The objective of this grant is to secure funding for the renewal of the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Center at the University of Toronto by purchasing state of the art moderate field spectrometers. These will be used for obtaining three-dimensional images of proteins that are implicated in a variety of diseases, leading to an understanding of molecular function and the design of new therapeutics.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Canada Research Chair in Evidence-Based Orthopaedic Surgery
Project Description: Trauma is the fourth leading cause of death in the first four decades of life worldwide and many experience temporary and permanent disability as a result (ACSCT 2003, CIHI 2013). The research program will identify and disseminate novel therapies to improve the lives of persons with musculoskeletal trauma.

Project Title: Tools for Synthesis and Characterization of Inorganic Materials
Project Description: Dr. Stephan's research program targets new compounds, materials and catalyst technologies for chemical transformations in a program of synthetic inorganic/organometallic chemistry involving air- and moisture-sensitive materials and the subsequent characterization of the resulting products.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Investigation of Neuromuscular Plasticity in Health and Disease
Project Description: This research will use innovative strategies to investigate whether physical activity and drug interventions can result in beneficial neuromuscular remodeling to slow, reverse or prevent the progress of neuromuscular disorders.

Project Title: Genomics and Transcriptomics Laboratory for Model and Non-Model Species (GenTranLab)
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to create a facility to explore the connection between genetic complexity and biological diversity. The key elements of this facility are instrumentation for genome sequencing, quantification of gene expression, and culturing of microbial strains and communities.

Project Title: Centre for Comparative and Evolutionary Biomechanics
Project Description: The Centre for Comparative and Evolutionary Biomechanics (CCEB) will address evolutionary, ecological, and engineering questions, to foster the designing of new biomimetic materials and robots through the study of aquatic animals such as the armoured fish Polypterus senegalus.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Cancer Risk Assessment Research
Project Description: This epidemiologic study investigates whether alterations of micro Ribonucleic Acids (miRNAs), a class of molecules that controls many genes and proteins often related to cancer, are associated with the development of cancer many years later in a large cohort of women.

Project Title: Integrated Quantum Photonics for Secure Communications
Project Description: As computers become more powerful, traditional methods for encrypting data can be more easily compromised. Quantum key distribution (QKD) offers unparalleled security for data communication. The research will contribute to the development and cost reduction of QKD devices and systems.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Research Platform for Development of Devices and Assays for Drug Discovery
Project Description: This project will develop innovative new tools and methods that will extract medicinally important bioactive and concentrated forms of compounds and mixtures from natural products and test them on animal models in a comprehensive manner thereby accelerating the process of drug discovery for treatment of neurological diseases such as Parkinson’s.

Project Title: Merging Mathematical Cognition and Instructional Intervention
Project Description: The Mathematical Cognition and Instruction Lab (MCIL) will improve our understanding of the mental processes that underlay children’s mathematical thinking. Advanced technologies will illustrate both proficiency and learning disabilities in math, and lead to interventions that alleviate difficulties in learning.

Project Title: Neurochemical Basis of Behaviour
Project Description: Dr. Parker, a world leader in the neurobiology of nausea, will study the neuroanatomical and neurochemical basis of the sensation of nausea, as well as the therapeutic efficacy of manipulations of the endocannabinoid system to reduce nausea, a sensation which is highly resistant to available treatments

Project Title: Laboratory for Cell-based Regenerative Strategies with Adipose-derived Stem Cells
Project Description: This research is focused on soft tissue engineering using adult stem cells isolated from fat and naturally-derived biomaterial scaffolds for the development of new cell-based therapies for applications in soft tissue reconstruction, wound healing, the treatment of cardiovascular disease, and joint regeneration.

Project Title: Bidirectional Cyclic Simple Shear Testing of Soils
Project Description: During earthquakes, storms or hurricanes cyclic shear loads are actually applied in more than one horizontal direction to the ground. A bidirectional cyclic simple shear testing apparatus, which applies monotonic and cyclic stresses, is requested in this proposal to study these complex loading patterns.

Project Title: Neural Mechanisms of Natural Scene Perception
Project Description: How do we see the world around us? Using brain recordings of people viewing images of natural scenes and measurements of eye movements, Dr. Bernhardt-Walther will decipher the codes and algorithms used by the brain to interpret our visual environment.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of Hypoxic Protein Synthesis in Human Cancer Cells
Project Description: Dr. Uniacke’s research program is focused on how the protein synthesis machinery in humans changes in response to oxygen deprivation (hypoxia) and how cancer cells exploit this to adapt to the hypoxic cores of tumors. This will benefit future initiatives in the pharmaceutical industries targeted at drug design in cancer therapy.

Project Title: Experimental Facility for Smart Infrastructure Research
Project Description: The equipment being requested will enable the applicant to undertake cutting-edge research on monitoring and predicting catastrophic failures of civil infrastructure through the use of control and measurement hardware and statistical signal processing algorithms.

Project Title: Laboratory for Fundamental and Applied Ecology
Project Description: Creating a more sustainable world is a provincial, national and international priority. This project will advance the scientific understanding of the ecological basis of sustainability by examining biodiversity conservation, disease transmission, aquaculture production, and fisheries collapse.

Project Title: Diagnostic and Biomechanical Surrogate Development for Head Injury Reduction using High-speed X-ray Fluoroscopy
Project Description: The prevalence of concussion among athletes suggests a need to reassess acceleration-based helmet performance criteria. A diagnostic that can instrument a tissue-simulating headform will be developed to provide this alternate performance metric, a measure of impact-induced brain deformation.

Project Title: The Plant Metabolic Biochemistry Laboratory
Project Description: Plants make a splendid array of compounds that impact our everyday lives, however we still know very little about how plants actually make them. The focus of this proposal is to create a world class plant metabolic biochemistry laboratory with the ultimate goal of discovering these processes.

Project Title:
The Nature of Neotyphodium-Poöideae Symbioses: 
Biology, Agronomy, Ecological Invasions, and Climate Change
Project Description: Commonly used pasture and turfgrasses are introduced to Canada from Europe. They are often found in association with fungus that grows inside the plant and brings many benefits to its host. Unfortunately these same beneficial traits also make these plants problematic when they escape cultivation.

Project Title: The Neurodevelopment and Degeneration Laboratory (NDL)
Project Description: The Neurodevelopment and Degeneration Laboratory (NDL) will strive to answer fundamental questions in neuroscience, develop new tools for collaborative investigation into the mechanisms underlying neurological disorders and train scientists in the areas of molecular neuroscience and stem cell biology.

Project Title: Laboratory for Micro-Robotics Research
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure supports research in the design and control of groups of micro-scale robots for biotechnology, micro-manufacturing and medical applications. Controlled by magnetic fields, these sub-millimeter robots provide unprecedented access to small confined spaces in a non-invasive manner.

Project Title: Hearing Technology Research Laboratory
Project Description: The proposed Hearing Technology Research Laboratory will allow the research team to develop 1) better methodologies and tools for assessing hearing disorders, 2) improved computational models of hearing loss and tinnitus, and 3) improved biomedical devices for treating hearing disorders and tinnitus.

Project Title: Laboratory for Prototyping Energy and Water Systems
Project Description: The goal of this research program is to develop innovative and cost-effective energy and water system solutions for both remote locations and larger communities. This work will develop innovative system prototypes and formulate computational methods to aid in system design.

Project Title: Infrastructure for a Translational Oncology Research Laboratory
Project Description: Effective clinical application of new cancer drug discoveries has been historically challenging. This proposal aims to improve cancer drug development by incorporating the study of naturally occurring cancers in pet dogs that accurately reflect the biology of human cancer, to the benefit of both species.

Project Title: Indoor/Outdoor Testbed for Aerial and Ground Multi-Robot Research
Project Description: The goal of the proposed research is to develop learning and adaptation capabilities for mobile robots to facilitate reliable, long-term service applications. These will be validated on a state-of-the-art, multi-robot testbed. The work will strengthen Ontario’s reputation for excellence in space and aerial robotics.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Search for GeV Dark Matter
Project Description: For many years researchers have sought the elusive Dark Matter of our universe. The proposed research project will increase the sensitivity and widen the search window for dark matter particles with an innovative spherical gaseous detector at Ontario’s premier astroparticle physics lab, SNOLAB.

Project Title: Super Resolution Optical Imaging of Mitochondrial Dynamics in Human Diseases
Project Description: Rapid cell proliferation and apoptosis resistance are hallmarks of pulmonary hypertension and cancer. Disordered mitochondrial dynamics contribute to these abnormalities. Dr. Archer proposing using a new super-resolution microscope to image mitochondrial structure and develop mitochondrial-targeted therapies.

Project Title: Laboratory for Information Visualization
Project Description: n order to create new ways to gain useful insight from large volumes of language data, new ways of seeing the data are needed.  The requested infrastructure will provide computing capacity for language analysis and new interactive technologies to support engaging exploration of data.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Magnetic Control of Microstructure Morphology: Means for Control of Material Properties in Nanocomposites
Project Description: 3D printing is the future of manufacturing. However, current technology can only print objects with homogeneous material properties. This limits its applicability as complex objects comprise multiple parts having different properties. The research will enable printers that control material properties on demand.

Project Title: An Expanded Integrated Cancer Research Biomatrix
Project Description: The expanded cancer research Biomatrix is a data warehouse which will contain clinical information collected from patients in our cancer programs.  Scientists will use this data to develop new cancer treatments, design better methods for detecting cancer earlier and to find ways of preventing cancer

Project Title: High Voltage Energy Conversion Laboratory
Project Description: The research will demonstrate the feasibility of a new electric generator technology that can operate at very high DC voltage. The new generator concept has a power density 10 times higher that of current state-of-the-art generators, while being more energy efficient.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Genetic and Molecular Epidemiology
Project Description: Heart disease and cerebrovascular disease are the second and third leading causes of death in Canada, respectively.  The proposed research aims to reduce the burden of cardiovascular diseases in Ontario by discovering their genetic causes and creating novel preventive strategies.

Project Title: The EvoHealth Physiology Laboratory: Testing the evolved function of depression
Project Description: Depressive cognition is resistant to distraction, and there is debate as to whether this is an adaptive or maladaptive feature. This proposal seeks equipment to resolve this debate by examining how 3 systems involved in distraction-resistance (brain, visual, cardiovascular) are regulated by depressive symptoms.

Project Title: Establishing a Facility for Cognitive Neuroscience in Acquired Brain Injury
Project Description: This research will examine some of the most important aspects of our lives, namely our ability to communicate and remember information about our pasts, our thoughts, and our emotions, and to inform diagnostic and treatment development for a range of conditions in which these processes are disrupted.

Project Title: Quantitative Methods and Infrastructure for Rapid, Evidence-Based Decision-Support in Public Health
Project Description: The principal objective of this proposal is to develop decision-support tools, using computational infrastructure to assess the risk of impending events, provide population health indicators based on the latest available data and information, and identify optimal management strategies for informing health policies and effective responses.

Project Title: Experimental Techniques to Determine the Rheological Properties of Polymeric Liquids
Project Description: I propose to create a world-class laboratory at Queen’s University for research on the flow properties of polymeric liquids, and specifically, for measuring the elasticity of these liquids. The Ontario plastics industry, and its continued growth, will revolve around how well we can understand elastic liquids.

Project Title: Advanced Materials Research Consortium
Project Description: The Advanced Materials Research Consortium aims at developing new, competitive, and sustainable technologies for resource recovery and processing, waste abatement and treatment to improve sustainability of industrial activities and to train a highly skilled and educated workforce for the Ontario mining and manufacturing sectors.

Project Title: Investigating Cognition in Parkinson's Disease: Identifying Clinical and Cognitive Features That Predict Functional Impairment
Project Description: Using tests of cognition, modern neuroimaging, driving simulation, and virtual reality technology, the aim is to clarify cognitive deficits in Parkinson’s disease (PD) and to understand how they affect real-world functions (e.g., driving).  The overarching aim is to identify patients at risk and to improve management.

Project Title: Biodiversity and Conservation of Freshwater Fishes Laboratory
Project Description: A Biodiversity and Conservation of Freshwater Fishes Laboratory will be developed using the requested infrastructure of fish and water quality sampling equipment. The lab will be used to identify the threats to fish biodiversity in Ontario in order to inform conservation efforts to protect this biodiversity.

Project Title: Advanced Live-cell Microscopy to Study Membrane Dynamics, Identity and Function
Project Description: We aim to understand the molecular signals and processes that dynamically control the properties and functions of membrane organelles.  Organelle dysfunction underpins disease development like cancer and infection.  To do this, we require advanced imaging instruments to directly observe cell behaviour.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Continuous, Privacy Preserving, Data Cleaning at the McMaster Data Science Lab
Project Description: The proposed computing infrastructure will be used to develop and test automated data cleaning tools that will enable users and organizations to reap value from their data faster.  These tools will enable fast cleaning of dynamic data, while ensuring the non-disclosure of sensitive information.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Equipment For Organic Materials Synthesis, Purification and Characterization
Project Description: This infrastructure investment will enable the development of novel synthetic methods that allow efficient access to important conjugated materials. Ultimately, these materials will be sought in applications such as organic photovoltaics, light emitting diodes and field-effect transistors.

Project Title: CRC Tier II in Ecotoxicogenomics and Endocrine Disruption
Project Description: The CRC tier II in Ecotoxicogenomics and Endocrine Disruption will study how hormone-mimicking chemicals that are present in the environment operate and interact with the physiological functions of animals and will develop new diagnostic tools to measure these environmental health stressors.

Project Title: Advanced Chemical Vapour Deposition System for Nanostructured Clean Energy Materials Development
Project Description: An advanced chemical vapour deposition system with x-ray diffraction will be used to develop novel nanostructured materials for clean energy technologies. Results will lead to material breakthroughs in fuel cells and metal-air batteries that will be of significance to the Ontario fuel cells and battery industry.

Project Title: Ultrafast Electron Sources for Atomically-Resolved Dynamics and High-Resolution Imaging
Project Description: A state-of-the-art ultrafast electron diffraction setup will be developed to allow the investigation of molecular structure and photoinduced dynamical processes with atomic spatial resolution. It will bring new vistas in the characterization of novel materials and the determination of protein structures.

Project Title: Gas Chromatograph and Ultraportable Sensor for Determination of Peatland Greenhouse Gas Exchange
Project Description: A gas chromatograph and ultraportable greenhouse gas (GHG) sensor will be used to measure peatland GHG flux under various land uses. Results will improve understanding of the interaction between peatlands and climate. Restoration practices to minimize peatland GHG emission will be identified.

Project Title: Isotopic and Geochemical Investigations of Planetary Materials
Project Description: The aim of this application is to establish state of the art infrastructure dedicated to the geochemical study of planetary materials in Ontario. This infrastructure will be used for the development of innovative methods for the analysis of geological and extra-terrestrial materials to constrain their formation history.

Project Title: A State-of-the-Art Optical Towing Tank for the 21st Century
Project Description: The new optical towing-tank facility, along with state-of-the-art imaging techniques, will allow for complete characterization of unsteady aerodynamic and hydrodynamic problems ranging from small flying sensors and underwater vehicles up to large-scale wind and water turbines.

Project Title: Creation of a Laboratory to Study Signal Transduction and Gene Regulation in Cancer
Project Description: Dr. Salmena’s research proposal aims to build a laboratory dedicated to the investigation of disrupted phosphoinositide signal transduction and microRNA-mediated gene regulation in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).  These efforts will help clinicians to choose more effective strategies and therapies to improve the outcome of patients with AML.

Project Title: Human Origins Laboratory at Lakehead University
Project Description: Dr. Tocheri's research program aims to increase understanding of human groups and societies through time. He will create a specialized, state-of-the-art laboratory at Lakehead University dedicated to the study of human origins, and will provide Canadian students with specialized research training and skills.

Project Title: Facility for Research on Structural Behaviour of Wrinkled Energy Pipelines
Project Description: Buried oil and gas pipelines develop various defects and one such defects is wrinkle. This research will investigate the structural behaviour and failure mode for pipelines with small wrinkle defect subject to cyclic deformations resulting from pressure fluctuations of fluid and seasonal temperature variations.

Project Title: Establishment of the Nipissing University Youth Development Through Sport and Physical Activity Laboratory
Project Description: The CFI infrastructure will lead to the development of a Youth Development through Sport and Physical Activity Laboratory, provide critical support for Dr. Bruner’s Canada Research Chair research program, and will enable capacity for inquiry that is unique within Ontario and Canada.

Project Title: Freshwater Ecology and Fisheries
Project Description: This project will demonstrate how environmental changes (e.g. climate change, pollution, species invasion) alter fish behaviour, and how behavioural change can affect populations, ecosystems and capture rates. The goal of this research is to improve fisheries management strategies in Canada.

Project Title: Mechanisms and Features of Social Networks in Drosophila
Project Description: This research will identify behavioural and cellular mechanisms of social behaviour. Using Drosophila as a model system we will characterize genes underlying social network interactions, the evolution of sociality, and the use of artificial intelligence to define features of sociality.

Project Title: Green Chemicals and Processes
Project Description: In this program, novel processes for extracting lignocelluloses from wasted spent liquors of pulping processes and for converting the extracted lignocelluloses to flocculants, dispersants, depressants and collectors, which have an extensive application in the mining and oil industries, will be developed.

Project Title: Equipment for Electrophysiological Recording and Functional Imaging of Brain Plasticity
Project Description: The objective of the proposal is to expand our work in hearing restoration into studies of functional brain imaging and into non-human primates.  This work will examine how the brain of hearing subjects processes sound and how the brain processes sound in deaf subjects following hearing restoration.

Project Title: Long-term Environmental Change Facility
Project Description: Long-term environmental trends in aquatic ecosystems will be studied using information preserved in lake sediments, and used to assess the impacts of various multiple stressors associated with industrial activities, land-use development and climate change.

Project Title: Toronto Social Psychophysiology Lab: Multi-method Observation of Dyads and Groups
Project Description: The proposed research examines the physiological underpinnings of successful social interactions in multicultural societies like Canada. The research infrastructure will be the first of its kind in Canada to simultaneously collect subjective, behavioural, and physiological data in small groups.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Infrastructure for Studying Self-Propagating Protein Aggregates
Project Description: Self-propagating protein aggregates play a key role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease. We intend to identify and characterize self-propagating protein aggregates using cell and animal models of neurodegenerative diseases. This research may lead to new therapeutic targets.

Project Title: A Portable Eye Tracking-EEG System
Project Description: The purchase of a portable eye tracker-EEG system will allow conducting world-class investigations in the neural bases of face perception and social cognition directly in schools and community settings to test clinical populations and will also enable the study of live dyadic social interactions at the brain level.

Project Title: Nonlinear Integrated Optical Devices Based on III-V Semiconductors for Quantum and Classical Communications
Project Description: The goal is to develop integrated photonic circuits for optical communication networks. Such circuits will implement all-optical signal processing that will overcome fundamental limitations of electronics. Another goal is to produce on-chip sources for quantum communications that enable secure information transfer.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: CRC Tier II in Self-Assembly and Nanomaterials
Project Description: The research proposal is aimed at the characterization of confined environment for the development of tailored nanoreactors. The dispersed and active catalytic center is photosensitive, it possesses a very high surface area and will be provide optimal light absorption capability for photosynthesis and fuel cell applications.

Project Title: Extraction, Processing, and Recycling of Strategic Materials
Project Description: The goal of our research is to address the sustainability challenges and criticality concerns associated with increasingly important strategic materials (primarily rare-earth elements), through developing advanced electrochemical and hydrometallurgical processes for their extraction and recycling.

Project Title: Stable Isotope Facility for Improved Understanding of the Fate and Removal of Emerging Contaminants in Water
Project Description: This research will use Compound Specific Isotope Analysis (CSIA) to advance the understanding of the transformation, transfer, and removal of emerging contaminants from surface water. Cost-effective water treatment solutions will be evaluated using CSIA to protect human and ecosystem health.

Project Title: Enhancement of Low Background Counting and Assay Technologies at LU for SNO+
Project Description: SNO+ will study neutrinos from the sun at low energies, and by adding Tellurium it is also possible to look for a very rare decay. This project proposes to enhance the technologies and processing to ensure low backgrounds and improve the sensitivity of measuring these very small numbers and training HQP’s.

Project Title: Connecting Genes to Molecules in Marine Proteobacteria to Discover New Compounds and Biosynthetic Pathways
Project Description: We aim to discover therapeutically useful molecules and their biosynthetic pathways in marine bacteria. Transformation-Associated Recombination is a ground breaking new technique that will be used to capture and study the genes responsible for producing these important natural product molecules.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support Human Colon Function Assessment
Project Description: The objective is to provide better diagnosis and evaluation of treatment options for chronic constipation. An innovative 84-sensor acquisition and analysis system is requested that will allow unprecedented analysis of colonic motility patterns and research into the causes of chronic constipation.

Project Title: Nextgen Sequencing Laboratory for Methods Development and Deciphering Genomic and Epigenetic Causes of Complex Disease
Project Description: Taking advantage of high-throughput sequencing, we will establish improved approaches for interrogating biological information contained in DNA and RNA. In conjunction with established expression genetics methodologies, these methods will yield new insights into heritable causes of complex human diseases.

Project Title: Development of Environmentally Responsible Hydrometallurgical Processes
Project Description: The goals of the proposed research projects are: (1) to develop effective processes for copper and gold extraction, and (2) to lower the negative impact of metal extraction processes on the environment. The results of the proposed research will advance our understanding of hydrometallurgical metal extraction processes.

Project Title: Neurocognitive Aging: Bridging the Gap Between Neuroscience and Neurointervention
Project Description: The overarching goal of this proposal is to enhance the cognitive health of older Ontarians. A combination of state-of-the-art brain imaging and brain-stimulation techniques will be used to identify age-related brain changes and guide therapies to slow the trajectory of age-related cognitive decline.

Project Title: Exploration of a Rectifying Antenna Solar Cell Technology
Project Description: The objective of the proposed research is to study optical rectification plasmonic antenna technology to overcome the theoretical 32% efficiency limit of single junction solar cells. State of the art instrumentation will permit us to investigate the individual steps of the process towards the goal of developing an innovative Ontario-owned photovoltaic solar cell technology.

Project Title: The Role of Emotions and Heuristics on Individual Behavior and Strategic Interactions
Project Description: Researchers will use simple computerized games to evaluate the influence of emotions and suboptimal problem solving on decision-making. Research conducted in this laboratory will impact economic modelling, as well have implications for education, health, and regulatory policy.

Project Title: Advanced Human Computer Interaction Laboratory
Project Description: Supported by the proposed advanced Human Computer Interaction Lab, this research seeks to improve online experiences for older adults, as well as identify ways to keep the Millennial generation engaged and motivated during learning and work processes.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: The Songbird Project: An Integrative Examination of Social Behaviour
Project Description: The project develops a new preparation for studying social environments’ effects on individuals’ health, reproduction, neurobiology, and even evolution. New automated monitoring and recording technologies will be implemented to experiment on groups, providing a profoundly new window into sociality.

Project Title: Virtual Electric and Hybrid Electric Vehicle Power Integration Lab (HEPIL)
Project Description: This project will include a globally unique axle-mounted all-wheel drive chassis dynamometer system with vehicle-to-grid capabilities for advanced research on the next generation of vehicles with electrified powertrains. It will position Ontario as an international leader in electrified vehicle research and testing.

Project Title: Canadian Additive Manufacturing Network (Can-AMN)
Project Description: The Canadian Additive Manufacturing Network (Can-AMN) will foster transformative research on additive manufacturing with broad impact on critical issues related to Ontario’s aging population and manufacturing sectors. It will promote collaborative multidisciplinary research on system integration, processes and materials.

Project Title: Evaluating Soil Health and Soil Ecosystem Services for Improved Performance of Agroecosystems Under Climate Change
Project Description: Using 18 fully instrumented soil mesocosms, unique to North America, we will investigate soil health and its role in agricultural productivity and ecosystem services, including carbon sequestration and improved water quality, as affected by climate change.  Management practices that improve soil ecosystem services will be developed.

Project Title: Dynamic Complexes and Large-Scale Assemblies in Neurobiology and Disease
Project Description: To therapeutically target neurological disease, we will characterize novel dynamic complexes and large-scale assemblies of intrinsically disordered proteins that control neuronal function. Equipment that enables detailed structural and dynamic information on these states, distinct from standard tools for static systems, is required.

Project Title: Facility for Fully Interactive Physio-Digital Spaces
Project Description: We propose a facility to invent Fully Interactive Physio-digital Spaces (FIPS) where every physical thing can display digital information and sense interaction. Our research will shape the next paradigm of digital media by developing FIPS toolkits and infrastructure, interaction vocabularies, applications, and new media artworks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Research Facility for Integrated Building Energy Harvesting Systems
Project Description: REFIBES, a one-of-a-kind research facility, will integrate the latest and most exciting energy technologies in a way that will address the world’s sustainable energy challenge by integrating electricity, thermal, transportation and fuel systems into smart community energy nodes.

Project Title: The Robohub: A Robotic Test Facility for Multi-Robot Teams
Project Description: The Robohub will create a dynamic centre for multi-disciplinary research into robotic solutions for hazardous environment operation, assistance for the elderly and disabled, human-machine interaction, and clean manufacturing. It will develop and deploy aerial, humanoid and magnetic levitation vehicles, as well as heterogeneous robot teams.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Biomaterials Nanoscale Imaging and Characterization (BIONIC)
Project Description: BIONIC will establish a facility enabling biomaterials and their interactions with cells to be studied in 3-D through an integrated combination of nanofabrication, electron and optical microscopies, and in situ characterization techniques. This will advance transformative materials-based strategies for studying, preventing, and treating disease.

Project Title: Enhancing the Resilience and Sustainability of Critical Geotechnical Infrastructure
Project Description: This proposal will create a unique laboratory drum centrifuge facility for conducting scaled physical modeling of geotechnical problems of great significance to Ontario, involving the resilience and sustainability of critical societal infrastructure for the built environment, energy resources and natural hazard mitigation.

Project Title: Advanced Disaster, Emergency, Rapid Response Simulation (ADERSIM) Program
Project Description: The ADERSIM research infrastructure and program team expertise will develop state-of-the-art modelling and simulation technology to evaluate and enhance disaster and emergency planning and rapid emergency response strategies by governmental, non-governmental, private and public sector companies and businesses in Ontario.

Project Title: Responsive Ecologies Lab -  RE/Lab
Project Description: The Responsive Ecologies Lab investigates how technologies can improve our quality of life, social communication, wellbeing, and learning and creativity. By developing novel tools and multisensory interfaces, we will provide solutions to environmental, health, and social challenges while creating innovative economic opportunities.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Organ Repair Laboratory
Project Description: The Organ Repair Laboratory (ORL) will provide new ways to assess and repair donor lungs and livers before transplantation. This will help to address the shortage of donor organs in Ontario and provide a higher patient quality of life. The ORL will provide a foundation to expand repair innovations to other transplantable organs in the future.

Project Title: ARIEL-II: Driving Scientific Discovery and Health Science with TRIUMF’s Advanced Rare Isotope Laboratory
Project Description: ARIEL-II will dramatically expand Canada’s novel isotope production capabilities for discovery and health science and will generate societal and economic benefits by advancing medical imaging and targeted tumour therapy, attracting world-class talent to Ontario, expanding commercialization of accelerator technologies, and creating high-paying jobs.

Project Title: A Molecular Approach to Surface Functionalization: From Automotive to Biomedical Applications
Project Description: Innovative coatings that repel water- and oil-borne contaminants, and protect metals from acid, heat, and oxidation will be developed. Significant automotive applications include high-tech lubricants and corrosion-preventing coatings.  Coatings for metal nanoparticles will provide high efficiency solar cells, and low-toxicity chemotherapy.

Project Title: Engineered Biologics - Targeted Diagnostics and Therapy
Project Description: TRAC and CPO have established a program to develop synthetic antibody (Ab)-based diagnostics and therapeutics for cancer. The requested infrastructure will increase output allowing for generation of Abs against diverse antigens, rapid translation into therapeutic or diagnostic agents and increased collaborations.

Project Title: The Centre of Immune Profiling – A Next-Generation Paradigm for Understanding and Treating Immune Disease
Project Description: The Centre for Immune Profiling will provide a state-of-the-art technology platform for comprehensively characterizing the immunologic pathways underpinning autoimmune disease and translating this knowledge into more effective treatments and biomarkers enabling prevention of disease and/or its progression so as to transform health outcomes.

Project Title: Integrated Systems-Level Imaging (ISLI)
Project Description: To continue to expand our world leading and highly translational imaging research program we require new development laboratories, prototyping equipment and computing resources. With these facilities we will advance image guidance and  radiomics technologies to direct interventions and personalize medicine.

Project Title: Canadian Planetary Simulator (CAPS)
Project Description: The project will enable innovative research on planetary surface environments- including extreme terrestrial environments. The inclusion of state-of-the-arts instruments will enable mult-disciplinary investigations, new instrumentation, new instrumentation techniques and the training of HQP in the analytical sciences.

Project Title: CRESS - Suborbital Payload Research Center (SPaRC)
Project Description: Intended to centralize Canada’s atmospheric and Earth-surface research programs, the proposed state-of-the-art research facility will rely on the demonstrated capability of the science and engineering team to design, build, characterize and operate instruments and payloads for sub-orbital missions for environmental monitoring.

Project Title: Food Security in a Changing World: Centre for Plant-Microbe Chemical Genomics
Project Description: Our goal is to provide farmers with novel, environmentally benign alternatives to agrochemicals to control pathogens of both field and greenhouse crops, and thereby ensure the continued production of crops of high quality and value in the face of intensified environmental challenges.

Project Title: The Stem Cell Epigenetics and Therapeutics
Project Description: This proposal requests critical infrastructure for OHRI's Sprott Centre for Stem Cell Research, which will augment and accelerate our research pipeline for cellular and molecular analyses, epigenetic and genomic analyses, preclinical development, and clinical translation of novel regenerative medicine therapeutics.

Project Title: Canada's Genomics Enterprise (CGEn): A National Genomic Tools Network for Transforming Life Science Research
Project Description: This project will create a pan-Canadian infrastructure for production-scale, whole-genome sequencing, with transformational impact on biomedical and other life science research. The Ontario node will be implemented at The Centre for Applied Genomics at The Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto.

Project Title: Smart Grid: Cyber-Physical Operation, Security and Quantum Technology
Project Description: Our goal is to make our critical infrastructure, namely, power distribution systems, smart andsecure in the Internet Age. We will perform a large-scale co-simulation and study the cyberphysicaloperation and security of a large-scale Smart Grid. We will exploit quantumcommunication to achieve low latency and high security.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Interventional Device Development and Testing Platform
Project Description: Building on the Centre for Research in Image-Guided Therapeutics, SRI is extending its capabilities in thedevelopment and testing of new medical technologies with the addition of a fully equipped catheterizationlab for preclinical studies, and new micro-machining capabilities in its Device Development Lab.

Project Title: High-Resolution Discovery Tools to Enable Personalized Cancer Medicine
Project Description: This initiative will establish state-of-the-art proteomics, structural biology and optical micro-imaging capabilities for multi-dimensional tumour phenotype analysis to enable an innovative research program that will realize personalized cancer medicine.

Project Title: Toward Cutting Edge Science: Establishing Advanced Micro-beam Capability for Macromolecular Crystallography at the CLS
Project Description: The study of challenging research objects, e.g. membrane proteins and protein:protein complexes, require the use of ever smaller crystals for diffraction analysis. This requires upgrades (source, optics, alignment, detector) to Canada’s only insertion station, beamline 08ID-1 at the CLS.

Project Title: Centre for Original Medical Target Evaluation and Translation - Accelerating a First In Human Innovation Strategy (COMET-Alpha)
Project Description: Building on previous investments from CFI, ORF and CIHR, our COMET-alpha team is assembling a world class centre in fast tracking the translation of genomic and proteomic targets into patients, through diagnostic biomarker development, and novel light or radioactive labelling to track movements in patients using PET-MR.

Project Title: Advanced Aging ResearCH (ARCH) to Transform Health and Well-Being of Older Adults
Project Description: The ARCH centre at Waterloo comprises comprehensive health sensors, wireless and assessment equipment supporting a distinct health/engineering sciences research hub. Research will drive early detection of chronic conditions and individualized treatment/prevention, leading to advanced technology development for healthy aging.

Project Title: Multi-Hazard Test Facility for Built Infrastructure Protection and Resilience
Project Description: The aim of the proposed unique world-class facility is to enhance the resilience of Canada's built infrastructure against the multi-hazard effects of earthquake, fire, cold region, climate change, blast, wind, and their combinations and reduce their cost by exploiting new breakthrough technologies in networked hybrid laboratory testing.

Project Title: Coherent X-Ray Photonics: A Technology Unifying Materials, Imaging and Ultrafast Science
Project Description: We will construct a laser source of coherent soft X-rays, enabling X-ray probing of materials with unrivaled time resolution and very high spatial resolution. This high power laser system, unique in the world, will bring advanced laser processing and characterization modalities, required for next generation materials, to the Manufacturing sector.

Project Title: Deciphering Brain Network Disruptions in Neurological Disorders: A Pivotal Step in Therapeutic Intervention
Project Description: The proposed project is to undertake cutting-edge neural network dynamics research on stroke, Parkinson’s disease, and depression, and create a competitive environment that will rival the most advanced international efforts, and will ultimately elucidate how/which therapies may have the best (or least) chances of success in the clinical setting.

Project Title: Probing Cellular Networks by Next-Generation Proteomics and Single-Cellgenomics
Project Description: This proposal aims to establish a continuum of platforms that will enable us to carry out quantitative and analytical proteomics, cell biology and genomics of single cells. The overarching objective of this infrastructure request is to advance the understanding and treatment of human disease.

Project Title: CERES: CEntre for Reconfigurable Electromagnetic Surfaces
Project Description: The proposed laboratory facilities will be used for the research and development of novel types of thin and lightweight electromagnetic surfaces ranging from radio frequencies to optical frequencies.  They will serve applications in communications, sensors and security, and medical imaging and diagnostics.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Rapid Prototyping of Patient Specific Models, Dexterous Tools and Implants
Project Description: This infrastructure project will create a unique hub of imaging and prototyping expertise spanning across southern Ontario with facilities to perform medical imaging processing and segmentation, realistic patient specific models and 3D printing technology for medical device and implants.

Project Title: Centre for Developmental Brain Plasticity & Repair (CDBPR)
Project Description: We will undertake ground-breaking research into developmental neuroplasticity using a range of advanced neuroimaging approaches that span from individual neuronal synapses to the entire brain.  These diverse approaches will lead to the discovery of new therapies for disorders such as autism, brain injury and cognitive dysfunction.

Project Title: GRIFFIN Compton and Background Suppression Shields
Project Description: The GRIFFIN Compton and Background Suppression Shields will establish a facility for decay spectroscopy research with rare isotope beams that will be unrivalled worldwide and will have a transformative impact on our understanding of the fundamental properties of atomic nuclei and the astrophysical origins of the heavy chemical elements.

Project Title: Platform for Advanced Design Leading to Manufacturing in Micro-Nano Technologies
Project Description: ADEPT provides Ontario researchers and their industrial partners with access to $20M in advanced design tools, enabling collaborative research and engineering in micro-nano technologies linked to manufacturing.  Benefits include highly skilled jobs, spinoff companies, and highly qualified innovators.

Project Title: Queen's CardioPulmonary Unit (Q-CPU) – Centre for Translational Research in Pulmonary Hypertension
Project Description: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a devastating disease of the lung’s blood vessels that causes shortness of breath on exertion and ultimately leads to fatal right ventricular failure. The Queen’s CardioPulmonary Unit (Q-CPU) will be a leading research group in the development, preclinical testing and commercialization of new therapies.

Project Title: Canadian Entangled Photon Source
Project Description: This project aims at utilizing the unique quantum capabilities of photons to break new grounds in the field of material spectroscopy to benefit sustainable energy, the field of quantum imaging to enable new healthcare imaging modalities, the field of space communications to usher in a new era of fundamentally secure satellite information transfer

Project Title: Centre for Cancer Stem Cell Therapeutics
Project Description: The Centre for Cancer Stem Cell Therapeutics at the University of Toronto Mississauga will bring together top researchers to develop new anti-cancer compounds for the benefit of Ontarians and Canadians. The chemistry, cell biology and computational infrastructure will allow researchers to target destruction of cancer stem cells.

Project Title: DriverLab: Developing Advanced Driving Simulation Technologies to Support Safe Driving in Older and At-risk Drivers
Project Description: DriverLab is a state-of-the-art, high-fidelity, driving simulator capable of introducing challenging conditions such as real rain and glare. It will be used to develop sensitive methods of driver assessment/training and provide careful evaluations of the safety of in-car technologies across different populations (eg, older and at-risk drivers).

Project Title: Advanced Materials: From Designer Molecules to Transformative Devices
Project Description: We propose to create a Centre for Advanced Materials Research (CAMR) that brings together scientists from the Faculties of Science, Engineering and Medicine. The proposed 16,700 sq. ft. of new space would be equipped for the invention, study and applications of materials with emphasis on optical and biomaterials.

Project Title: Next generation genome editing and functional evaluation of pre-clinical models of human disease
Project Description: Abnormal changes in genes, called mutations, cause disease. This project uses the latest technology, genome editing, to make mice with exactly the same mutations as patients. By studying mouse models with the kind of clinical tests used on humans, scientists can learn how mutations cause diseases and companies can develop better treatments.

Project Title: Centre for Islet Research and Therapeutics (CIRT)
Project Description: This project will create a Centre for Islet Research with the infrastructure needed to obtain a reliable source of high-quality human pancreatic cells (islets) and the ability with which to analyze them. The centre will serve to increase the research capacity of Ontario's diabetes researchers and accelerate development of new diabetes therapies.

Project Title: Research Program for Rare Pediatric Diseases (RaPiD)
Project Description: RaPiD is a collaborative research program uniting world-class clinicians and basic scientists to: 1) Identify the genomic causes of rare diseases (RDs) and develop efficient diagnoses of RD patients; 2) Explore RD pathogenic mechanisms in relevant cell and animal models; and, 3) Develop effective therapeutic avenues for RDs.
Lead Research Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.

Project Title: A Platform for CMOS-MEMS Integration and Characterization
Project Description: This proposal will enable research, discovery and technology development in the area of “nano- and micro-technologies”. The infrastructure will yield an open-source platform technology that integrates actuators, sensors and electronics on-a-chip.  Application areas include nanotechnology, communication, and chemical and physical sensors.

Project Title: Enhanced Tellurium Purification and Double Beta Sensitivity for the SNO+ Experiment
Project Description: By developing and installing advanced purification equipment for tellurium, water and an amine-based surfactant for the SNO+ detector in the underground lab near Sudbury, this project will enable SNO+ to achieve the world's best sensitivity to detect neutrinoless double beta decay -- a potential landmark discovery in particle and nuclear physics.

Project Title: Measuring Low Frequency Genetic Markers for Cancer Management
Project Description: This project includes the study of three priority areas:1. mosaic germline non-hereditary cancer predisposing mutations;2. circulating tumour DNA (ctDNA) and early cancer diagnosis; and3. gene expression profile (GEP) signature and personalized cancer treatment.

Project Title: ALPHA-g: An Apparatus to Explore Antimatter Gravity With Cold Trapped Antihydrogen
Project Description: ALPHA-g, a Canadian/Danish-led multinational collaborative experiment at CERN, will pursue the answer to the gravitational question “does antimatter fall up or down?”, making the proposed apparatus the 21st Century version of Newton’s apple tree.  ALPHA-g

Project Title: Interdisciplinary Research Laboratory and Remote Collaborations Unit in Global Health and Human Rights
Project Description: This proposal’s objective is to fund a research and training hub on global health and human rights at the Dalla Lana School of Public Health (DLSPH) at the University of Toronto. This hub will train future researchers and carry out the international research collaborations central to global health research.

Project Title: Intelligent Home Sensor Networks for the Elderly
Project Description: This project will build a custom-designed, simulated, single-house-based research platform to develop and evaluate novel sensor technologies and systems, which will be used for continuous monitoring of physical activities and physiological parameters of elderly patients with chronic diseases.

Project Title: Integrated Platform for High-Throughput Protein/Protein and Drug/Target Interaction Analysis
Project Description: Dr. Taipale’s research uses cutting-edge functional genomics tools to characterize how the protein quality control machinery is organized in the cell. The generated knowledge is exploited to characterize how this network is disrupted in rare human diseases and to identify potential drugs for these diseases.

Project Title: Advanced Characterization for Production and Applications of Functional Materials Based on Nanoscale Building Blocks
Project Description: The objective is to support the expansion of the research program based on the established PI’s expertise in the synthesis of novel well-defined size- and shape-controlled nanoscale building blocks (NBBs). The main outcomes are the development and implementation of NBB functional applications.

Project Title: Ultra-High Performance Mass Spectrometry Facility for Studies in Analytical Toxicology and Molecular Genetics
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure is an ultrahigh performance liquid chromatograph triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (UHPLC-TQMS) for extremely sensitive quantitative analysis of complex biological samples in analytical toxicology and molecular genetic studies.

Project Title: Molecular Imaging of Lipids in Rodent Models Brain Co-Morbidities
Project Description: The infrastructure requested in this proposal will lead to an innovative molecular imaging research facility that will enable the PI and collaborators to identify the role that membrane lipids play in conferring vulnerability to cell death of brain cells.

Project Title: Four-Dimensional Structure Elucidation of Cancer-Associated Proteins in Action
Project Description: This innovative program will establish state-of-the-art NMR and protein crystallization methodologies to study the conformational changes and dynamic motion of key proteins implicated in cancer development and progression leading to novel targets and strategies for therapeutic modulation.

Project Title: Center for Integrative Laboratory and Field Physiology
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will establish a unique center in Ontario where the focus is on the effects of digestion on the physiology of native Ontarian fish as well as those species used in aquaculture from the perspectives of integrative, developmental, and field physiology.

Project Title: Biomaterial Host Response Analysis and Engineering Laboratory
Project Description: The proposed research will study biomaterial-induced inflammation to identify novel strategies for improving biological responses to implanted materials and developing inflammation-modulating materials. A rapid in vivo biomaterial-screening platform will also be developed in support of these goals.

Project Title: Superconducting Magnet Platform for Magnetic Resonance Imaging Systems Development
Project Description: We believe that through the design and development of smaller, customized MRI systems that can be installed within the emergency room for the diagnosis of stroke, we have the potential to save lives and to reduce the overall economic burden of managing stroke in Ontario.

Project Title: Elucidating the Structure and Function of Zebrafish Sensorimotor Circuits Using Optogenetic and Behavioural Approaches
Project Description: Dr. Thiele's research will uncover some of the fundamental principles by which neural circuits combine sensory information with motor output using a unique and multidisciplinary approach that combines the larval zebrafish model system with modern neuroscience technologies.

Project Title: Structure and Oligomerizing Function of Calcium Signaling Proteins in Health and Disease
Project Description: This research will link the atomic resolution structures and oligomerizing properties of stromal interaction molecule and mitochondrial uniporter calcium signaling proteins to cellular functions associated with health and disease, information required for the development of new therapeutic and diagnostic tools.

Project Title: A Laboratory for Autonomous Driving
Project Description: The end goal of this proposal is to provide the computational resources necessary to develop cost effective solutions to autonomous driving. This can lower the risk of accidents, provide mobility for the elderly and people with disabilities, and decrease the pollution, for a healthier environment.
Keyword: Artificial Intelligence

Project Title: Non-Invasive Stimulation of the Human Visual Cortex
Project Description: Non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) is an emerging technology that has enormous potential as a tool for rehabilitating the brain. This proposal aims to understand the effects of NIBS on visual brain areas and to use NIBS to treat brain-based visual disorders such as amblyopia.

Project Title: CryoLab for Arctic, Antarctic and Planetary Studies
Project Description: Cryolab for Arctic, Antarctic and Planetary Studies will provide the infrastructure necessary for innovative studies on the impacts of climate change and disturbances on permafrost in northern Canada and Antarctica and prepare for future missions to Mars.

Project Title: Advanced Characterization of Biomaterials
Project Description: The improvement of orthopaedic and dental implant technologies is one of the central concerns of our aging society. This infrastructure will enable researchers to uncover the nanoscale mechanisms that govern how bone bonds to implant devices and enable improved design of implant materials.

Project Title: Bats as Models for the Study of Multisensory Integration
Project Description: The Multisensory Integration Laboratory (MIL) will improve our understanding of visual and auditory information integration in vertebrates, including humans. The lab’s primary foci will be visual capture and cross-modal recognition, using an interdisciplinary, multi-level approach. MIL will be unique to Canada.

Project Title: Computer-Intensive High-Dimensional Models for Option Pricing and Risk-Management
Project Description: This research program develops innovative modelling methods and fast pricing formulas for financial assets. It provides the tools needed to speed financial innovation, improve market liquidity, and allow financial markets to bear risk more efficiently decreasing the likelihood of future market crashes.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Purification and Chemical Biological Investigation of Antibacterial and Antifungal Compounds
Project Description: The research supported by this infrastructure will lead to new therapeutics for treating antibiotic resistant pathogens. It will also provide unique training opportunities for students and postdoctoral fellows interested in careers in the private sector or academia.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: A Laboratory for the Discovery of Energy-Purpose Functional Metallopolymers
Project Description: This ORF investment will allow for the acquisition of essential infrastructure for the synthesis and characterization of energy-purpose functional metallopolymers. The metallopolymers will be used to produce next-generation lithium-ion batteries and inverted bulk-heterojunction solar cells.

Project Title: Quantitative MR Imaging Laboratory for Cell and Tissue Engineering
Project Description: Our research program strives to bring engineered tissue and organs as a treatment option to Ontarians, through the development of new magnetic resonance imaging technology to accelerate tissue engineering research and to eventually enable non-invasive monitoring in patients.

Project Title: Pharmaceutical Therapies for Alzheimer's Disease
Project Description: This proposal aims to acquire a state-of-the-art nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) system that will be used to understand the mechanisms of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) by designing novel therapeutic agents which will provide health, social and economic benefits to Ontarians.

Project Title: Profiling the Metabolic and Immune Exosomal Secretome
Project Description: The proposed research strives to uncover novel cellular mechanisms and unique aspects of cardiovascular and metabolic diseases by profiling small secreted molecules called exosomes. This research will lead to biomarker discovery and innovative therapies for heart disease and type 2 diabetes.

Project Title: Reservoir Monitoring Using Time-Lapse Superconducting Gravimetry
Project Description: Monitoring oil, gas, and water reservoirs and their dynamics is important for Canada’s economy and environmental sustainability. Superconducting gravimeters enable an innovative approach to monitoring fluid migration in reservoirs by sensing mass change during injection/extraction processes

Project Title: Infrastructure to Establish a Human Cardiovascular Physiology Laboratory
Project Description: Dr. Millar’s research program will study, in healthy and diseased humans, 1) neural regulation and control of the circulation and 2) novel interventions designed to improve cardiovascular regulation. These findings will be ready for rapid translation to assist with the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease.

Project Title: Women’s Cardiovascular Health: Sexually Dimorphic Cardiovascular and Autonomic Responses to Stressors
Project Description: This application is for funds to develop a Women's Cardiovascular Health Lab at York University, Toronto, Ontario. The proposed infrastructure will facilitate improvements in the standard of care and quality of life of women in Ontario and around the world that are suffering from cardiovascular disease.

Project Title: Exploring the Neurocognitive Bases of Social Behaviour
Project Description: This research will produce a deeper understanding of the neurocognitive bases of social mimicry, determine whether digital media that recruits the human mirror system promotes superior engagement and memory for information, and assess the effects of power on social perception and behaviour.

Project Title: Molecular Analysis of Cell Migration Control by Physical Microenvironment and Its Role in a Disease State
Project Description: This project seeks to reveal the molecular mechanisms utilized by mammalian cells to sense physical properties of their microenvironment and to guide cell migration towards areas of stiffer extracellular matrix. This type of cell migration is known to contribute to cancer metastasis.

Project Title: Discovery and Investigation into Novel, Emerging and Re-emerging Viral Pathogens in Birds
Project Description: Wild birds can transmit numerous high-impact viruses, including avian influenza and West Nile viruses. This research will explore the use of digital droplet PCR technology to perform surveillance on novel or emerging virus pathogens in birds, and conduct pathogenesis studies to better understand the ecology of these diseases.

Project Title: A Novel Role for Histone Variant H2A.Z in Learning and Memory
Project Description: This project will identify the mechanism by which a novel histone protein regulates memory. We will build on our prior evidence of memory-enhancing effects of histone H2A.Z depletion to identify new regulators of H2A.Z function and explore its contribution to promoting age-related cognitive decline.

Project Title: Extracellular Vesicles in Vascular and Renal Health and Disease
Project Description: Extracellular vesicles are important biological markers of damage that also cause injury in cardiovascular and kidney disease. Proposed research will increase knowledge of extracellular vesicles in kidney/cardiovascular disease leading to better detection and development of novel therapies.

Project Title: Distributed Digital Performance Laboratory
Project Description: The Distributed Digital Performance Laboratory (D2PL) is dedicated to the application of intelligent digital media to new forms of cultural expression, and to gaining new insights into how we sense, process and interact with the performing arts in the digital age.

Project Title: New Tools for Applied Wheat Genetics and Breeding
Project Description: The University of Guelph Wheat Breeding Program will attempt to improve the genetics of wheat for improved yield, disease resistance, adaptation to climate changes and end-use quality, through a better understanding of the genetics of important traits and by developing novel breeding strategies and tools.

Project Title: Participatory Media Lab
Project Description: Through fieldwork, computational data, and spatial analysis, this project will offer an in-depth understanding of the relationship between social movements, urban space and digital media. The project will also develop new research tools to clean/parse, analyze and visualize the interactions between social media data and contemporary protest movements around the world.

Project Title: Design and Synthesis of Novel Organic Conductors
Project Description: The proposed research seeks to discover and develop novel conductive organic materials with unique electronic, optical, and magnetic properties. New materials with optimal properties can be used in next-generation organic electronic devices as well as biomedical imaging/therapeutic applications.

Project Title: Development of Improved Ion Channel Drugs and Engineering Ion Channels as Biosensors
Project Description: Fifteen percent of all drugs target a class of medically relevant proteins called ion channels. Dr. daCosta aims to develop new and improved ion channel pharmaceuticals, and to engineer ion channels for novel diagnostic and therapeutic applications.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Integrative Responses of Fish to Environmental Stressors
Project Description: Global climate change and increased aquatic contamination have led to environmental stressors that impact fish populations in Ontario and Canada. This research will examine the effects of mixed environmental stressors on fish species by assessing epigenetic, cellular and phenotypic changes.

Project Title: Dynamic Memory Systems in the Human Brain
Project Description: The requested funding will be used to establish a cognitive neuroscience lab that uses the converging techniques of brain imaging (fMRI), pharmacological manipulations, and behavioural modeling to understand how changing chemical states in the human brain relate to memory behaviours and disease.

Project Title: Biophysical and Structural Platform to Advance the Study of B cell Glycoproteins in Vaccine and Disease
Project Description: The proposed innovative technology and corresponding infrastructure will enable scientists to determine the atomic structure and function of critical molecules on the surface of immune cells, leading to better vaccines and therapeutics.

Project Title: Understanding Climate Shifts, Foodways, and Societal Resilience through Ancient Plant Residues
Project Description: This project will use innovative techniques to investigate transformations in past environments, human causes of these shifts, and societal responses to ecological change. Changes in human-environmental relationships will be mapped through patterns of plant residues extracted from sediments and artifacts.

Project Title: Laboratory for Generative Responsive Realities
Project Description: The laboratory for Generative Responsive Realities will develop transferable knowledge, technology, creative practice and training in the creation of responsive artificial worlds experienced through rapidly emerging mixed reality technologies, including both Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR).

Project Title: Laboratory of Ecology and Macroevolution
Project Description: With the requested infrastructure, I will establish a world-leading research program that links ecology and macroevolution to explain the origins of biodiversity and the factors that shape it in a changing world. My research on Anolis lizards will both advance basic knowledge and inform invasive species management policy.

Project Title: Scanning Electron Microscope for Life Science Imaging
Project Description: The principal applicants request a scanning electron microscope and accessory equipment to investigate the architecture of pathogenic bacterial biofilms. Their research programs are targeted at identifying the mechanisms of antibiotic resistance and to develop novel antimicrobial therapies.

Project Title: A New Bioinformatics Laboratory to Integrate Functional Genomics, Biocuration, and Analytics in Biomedical Research
Project Description: This is a proposal to establish a new Bioinformatics Laboratory to support an innovative computational research and training program focused on antibiotic resistance in bacterial pathogens, environmental toxicity of industrial and biomedical compounds, and integration of clinical and genomic data.

Project Title: Infrastructure for 5G Wireless Cellular Networks and Internet of Things
Project Description: This proposal will investigate new and innovative techniques to enhance spectral efficiency, reliability, range and security of wireless networks. These could be applied in areas such as Backhaul Connectivity for Small Cells, Cloud Radio Access Networks, and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Project Title: A Human/Mouse Translational Drug Development Program for Major Depression
Project Description: By investigating cellular and molecular pathologies and the interaction between age and risk for neuropsychiatric disorders, the proposed research program aims to acquire an in-depth understanding of the molecular bases of depression, and develop therapeutic approaches for depression.
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: Platform for Antibiotic Discovery
Project Description: Antibiotic resistance is the health care challenge that threatens to roll back over a Century of advances in medicine. This research strives to overcome the resistance crisis by exploring the mechanisms of drug resistance and discovering new molecules and strategies that can inform new drug development.

Project Title: In Vitro Technologies for Plant Propagation and Conservation
Project Description: Plant tissue culture has revolutionized our ability to propagate plants, conserve endangered species, and improve crops. However, many species remain recalcitrant to these techniques. This project will provide help better understand and overcome this problem in a wider range of plant species.

Project Title: Development of Antiviral Therapies for Emerging Viruses
Project Description: The objective of the proposed project is the discovery of cellular host factors essential for viral infection and their use for the development of novel antiviral therapies. To that aim, state-of-the-art platforms will be established to monitor viral infection and develop small molecule inhibitors of infection.

Project Title: Smart Polymers for Organic Electronics
Project Description: The focus of the project is to explore the use of smart polymers in the design and fabrication of novel flexible printable electronic sensors. These next generation sensors would represent a significant contribution to industrial economic growth, healthcare, environmental surveying and personal safety.

Project Title: New Tools for Behaviour and Health Monitoring of Dairy Cattle
Project Description: Research infrastructure, including automated technologies for behavioural assessment and health monitoring, is required to establish a research program that will provide novel biological insights into factors affecting the expression of feeding behaviour in dairy cattle.

Project Title: Nipissing University Branch Research Data Centre
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will establish a Statistics Canada Branch Research Data Centre at Nipissing University to support the Tier II Canada Research Chair (CRC) appointment of Dr. David Zarifa. This Data Centre will provide Dr. Zarifa and his team secured access to Statistics Canada micro data files.

Project Title: Developing Biomaterials to Manipulate and Study Cell-Matrix Interactions
Project Description: This research will develop materials to mimic and control the natural chemical environment surrounding cells. This will make it possible to accurately probe cell-material interactions which, ultimately, will lead to the development of material based therapeutics for cancer and stem cell therapies.

Project Title: Self-Knowledge and Interpersonal Perception
Project Description: The main objectives are to identify blind spots and bright spots in self-knowledge and interpersonal perception, identify consequences of self-knowledge and interpersonal accuracy, and identify methods that can improve self-knowledge and interpersonal accuracy. This line of inquiry has the potential to improve decision-making, relationships, and well-being.

Project Title: STEAM 3D Lab: Discover, Design, Develop
Project Description: “STEAM-3D: Discover, Design, Develop” investigates uses of digital media and interactive tools in education. The program's objectives are to develop, observe and evaluate constructionist pedagogies in the context of a “maker-space” and to build capacity for affecting change in various education settings.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Bioinformatics for Regulatory Sequences and Systems
Project Description: We aim to develop (and apply) techniques from statistics and computer science to understand how molecules create the complex behaviours of the cell.  This will help predict which mutations will lead to cellular malfunctions and disease, and understand how complex organisms can appear during evolution.

Project Title: Chronic Disease Prevention
Project Description: The goal of this research program is to inform chronic disease prevention strategies; an evidence informed approach that emphasizes population impact, health care sustainability and equity. This research will create methodological innovations that can be applied to novel population data.

Project Title: Flow Visualization Platform for Physical Modeling of Fluid Flows in Steelmaking and Casting
Project Description: This research project will focus on the development of a state-of-the-art flow visualization platform for physical modeling of fluid flows, to design, optimize, enhance, and debottleneck  steelmaking and casting processes, and develop new and innovative technologies, in the field of ferrous metallurgy.

Project Title: The Origins of Life Laboratory
Project Description: The Origins of Life Laboratory will develop and test hypotheses of how first life on Earth emerged and under what conditions Earth-like life on early Mars or habitable, Earth-mass exoplanets could arise.

Project Title: Advanced Storage Systems and Electric Transportation (ASSET) Lab
Project Description: The Advanced Storage Systems and Electric Transportation (ASSET) Lab will test and validate leadingedge electric energy storage systems equipment for electric vehicles (EVs), thus accelerating the commercialization and wide-spread adoption of electric transportation in Canada and abroad.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Ecological Genomics of Plant Adaptation in Novel Environments
Project Description: The proposed research combines field experiments with ‘next-generation’ sequencing to examine the ecological and genetic basis of invasion success in novel and changing environments in two of Ontario’s more notorious weeds: purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria) and garlic mustard (Alliaria petiolata).

Project Title: Neural Basis of Reaching, Grasping and Object Manipulation
Project Description: Using a host of neurophysiological, robotic and computational tools, the proposed research aims to explain how the brain and body interact to make reaching and grasping seem so easy, how trauma and disease modify these interactions to impair movement and how best to fix them to optimize recovery.

Project Title: Data-Intensive Approaches to Digital Curation and Preservation
Project Description: Digital curation, the active management and preservation of digital resources for future use, is an indispensable element of data-intensive research and sustainable society. This project will develop novel, data-intensive approaches and effective, scalable methods for digital curation and preservation.

Project Title: Data, Equity and Policy in Education Lab
Project Description: Data for educational policy-making are currently greatly under-utilized and highly fragmented in Canada. The Data, Equity, and Policy in Education Lab will amass a range of data on a comprehensive set of educational topics and will facilitate knowledge exchange among a variety of educational stakeholders.

Project Title: Quantitative Tissue Imaging for Physiological and Genetic Analysis
Project Description: We propose to establish a facility for imaging biological samples, and measuring the detailed differences between them. This facility will enable researchers to construct digital tissue archives suitable for image-based studies in many emerging areas of both the biomedical and environmental sciences.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Developing Novel Cell Therapies and Manufacturing Methods
Project Description: The goal of this research project is the development of a novel treatment for cancer based on white blood cells.  The outcomes of this project will benefit Ontario through the creation of improved cancer treatments and by enabling economic growth in the Life Sciences and Advanced Manufacturing sectors.

Project Title: C. elegans as a Model to Study Environment-Genotype Interactions
Project Description: Two fundamental determinants of human health are genetics and environment. The proposed research seeks to understand how environment, specifically diet and microbiota, influence health, development, and disease susceptibility and progression, using C. elegans as a model system.
