Project Title: Linking Lake Nipissing and its Watershed: High Frequency Monitoring of Hydrology and Nutrient Fluxes
Project Description: The Lake Nipissing Bays project will use CFI –MRI funds to conduct high frequency monitoring of river inflow, water quality and weather conditions to improve understanding of potential sources of phosphorus from upstream watersheds and within-bay sources, and the influence of weather on water conditions in Lake Nipissing.

Project Title: Arts Research Collaboratory
Project Description: This research into collaborative digital research tools and interfaces innovates in the text technologies that are shaping the production and dissemination of information about textual and cultural artifacts in a digital environment, engages citizen scholars, and enriches the global web with scholarly knowledge.

Project Title: Advanced Core Logging Laboratory
Project Description: An advanced portable laboratory will be developed for geotechnical core logging in mining. The novel technology will enable faster and more accurate field data collection and elimination of conventional errors. This will help more efficient planning and design and better management of mining risks.

Project Title: Targeting the Translatome in Disease
Project Description: Drs. Alain and Rayner’s research aims to determine the underpinnings of gene regulation by microRNAs and translation control in cancer and cardiovascular disease. Their studies will lead to innovative therapeutics to counter the significant human and economic impact of these diseases in Ontario.

Project Title: Activatable Contrast Agents and Advanced Materials For Molecular Imaging
Project Description: Personalized medicine through molecular imaging is difficult to implement, but may be achieved with novel tracers for molecular magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). A small animal MRI instrument that can operate at both clinical magnetic field strengths is requested, which would accelerate tracer development and clinical translation.

Project Title: Nipissing’s Mobile Digitization and Repatriation Lab: A Facility for Global Environmental Histories and Geographies
Project Description: Nipissing’s Mobile Digitization and Repatriation Lab, will support the Canada Research Chair in Global Environmental Histories and Geographies. Using archival materials and natural history collections Nipissing’s Global Semi-Periphery Institute will provide a humanities-based approach to understanding environmental change over time of semi-peripheries.

Project Title: Data and Laboratory Development to Study Migration and Industrial Change
Project Description: Ontario has recently ceded its position as Canada’s economic powerhouse, due largely to declines in its manufacturing sector. My research program will develop and use new big administrative data sources to identify the migratory implications of this profound demographic and economic change.

Project Title: Hybrid PVD Coating System
Project Description: Ontario’s manufacturing sector relies on advanced technologies to remain globally competitive. Innovative tool designs, materials and coatings can directly enhance productivity, quality and cost competitiveness. Investigations into novel materials are needed to fully attain this potential.

Project Title: Practice Changing Research: Improving Diagnosis and Management for Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphomas (CTCL)
Project Description: Dr. Litvinov’s research program will develop innovative approaches to study and treat Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphomas, the most common lymphoma of the skin. The proposed research aims to develop effective diagnostic/prognostic tests and immunotherapeutic approaches for the treatment of this malignancy.

Project Title: Cryo-electron Microscope for Structural Analysis of Cellular Complexes
Project Description: This research aims to have an impact on our ability to treat infectious diseases and cancer by elucidating new mechanisms to overcome antibiotic resistance and to develop effective therapies for cancer. Treatment to paliate these diseases costs over $12 billion annually to Ontario.

Project Title: The Role of Oxygen in Autophagy Regulation and Metabolic Homeostasis
Project Description: The proposed research seeks to discover novel oxygen-dependent cell signalling that links nutrient/stress sensing to the regulation of the autophagy pathway.  Additionally, the dysregulation of autophagy in disease will be studied under tissue specific physiological oxygen levels.

Project Title: Platelet Biology to Improve Patient Outcomes – from Bedside to Bench and Back
Project Description: The proposed research aims to better understand how blood cells interact with vessel walls to cause heart attacks and strokes. Secondarily the goal is to identify strategies to improve patient’s response to therapy and will lead to optimization of medical treatment for these conditions.

Project Title: Environmental Processes and Change in Northern Canadian Ecosystems
Project Description: The objective of the proposed research program is to understand how northern ecosystems in Ontario and Canada are impacted by environmental change, including long-term climate change, exposure to contaminants, and changes to freshwater ecosystems such as productivity, and snow and ice cover.

Project Title: High-throughput Sampling of the ‘Fire of life’ in Diverse Organisms, Substrates and Conditions
Project Description: This proposal will develop an assemblage of respirometry equipment to yield the most flexible and productive metabolic sampling ability currently existing, substantially impacting our ability to study how metabolic rate evolves, and prepare students for jobs in biology, health and veterinary sciences.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Development of Bioresponsive and Interactive Ophthalmic Biomaterials
Project Description: To develop better treatments for ocular diseases, Dr. Wells will develop bioresponsive polymer biomaterials to deliver drugs and photoswitchable surface treatments to modulate host interactions.  These technologies will personalize biomaterials and improve their integration and function.

Project Title: Neuroimmune Interactions in Pain
Project Description: My research team will use an integrated approach spanning genomic, proteomic, molecular, cellular and behavioural neurobiology to dissect the role of the immune response in pain. Using the post-surgical wound and spinal cord injury models, we will identify novel immune targets that control the initiation, development and/or maintenance of inflammatory and neuropathic pain. Understanding the interactions between the nervous and immune systems will be critical to the development of new and efficacious treatments for acute and chronic pain disorders.

Project Title: Shallow-Water Earth Observation Lab
Project Description: The proposed research will develop methods to map the depth of shallow waters using satellite data. Algorithms will be developed for optical and radar data. Canadian industry collaborators will commercialize findings. Canadian government and military will benefit from coastal bathymetry data.

Project Title: High-Speed Skeletal Imaging Laboratory
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to establish a High-Speed Skeletal Imaging Research Laboratory in an ambulatory patient care centre. The laboratory will have the capability to precisely measure the motion of musculoskeletal joints during high-demand activities of daily living. These measurements are crucial for Dr. Rainbow’s research program focused on determining mechanical factors associated with the onset and progression of musculoskeletal diseases.

Project Title: Learning in the Developing Mind and Brain
Project Description: The requested funding will be used to establish a new laboratory that uses cutting edge neuroimaging methods and analyses to discover how neural structure and function change across the early life span and how this influences memory function and real world learning outcomes for language and education.

Project Title: Translating New Models of Cardiac Disease into Therapy
Project Description: Heart failure is responsible for over one-third of deaths in Canada. We have created tools to personalize heart medication treatment, finding the correct drug for the right patient. Our methods can be used to discover novel heart failure therapies, reducing health care costs and socioeconomic burden.

Project Title: MRS Spectroscopy for Addiction and Psychiatry
Project Description: MRS can identify differences in basic brain biochemistry in people with and without disorders, and can rule out conditions such as Alzheimer's disease. However, brain dysfunction in mental disorders almost always involves changes in brain chemical processes that are best determined using advanced MRS methods. The requested infrastructure will take full advantage of recently installed advanced MRS equipment and develop new technologies, hardware and software to uncover abnormalities in neuronal and glia processes at the molecular level in addictions and psychiatric disorders.
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: Conversion Facility for Value-Added Products from Boreal Forest
Project Description: This proposal aims at developing novel transformative, cost-effective and environmentally-sound technologies and products from renewable resources that can replace imported fossil-based fuels and petrochemicals and create new opportunities for the emerging Bioeconomy.

Project Title: Real-time Navigated iKnife System for Breast Cancer Surgery
Project Description: Surgical intervention in breast cancer is common, but a key challenge that undermines this intervention is the inability for the surgeon to remove the entire tumour, which results in repeated surgeries and increased burden to patients and the healthcare system.  In this application, we are combining two technologies that will effectively map the position of the surgical tool relative to the tumour with real-time molecular information generating by mass spectrometry to accurately define the resection margin with minimal disruption to healthy tissue.  This surgical platform will significantly reduce the need for repeat breast cancer surgeries, as well as additional systemic cancer therapies.

Project Title: Colibri: an Ultra-Fast Telescope Array for Astronomy and Space Science
Project Description: The project will meld emerging ultra-fast low-light imaging technology with commercial astronomical telescopes.  The resulting sensitive rapid-imaging telescope array will have unprecedented capabilities.  Applications include solar system science, extrasolar planets, and space science.

Project Title: Workplace Simulation Equipment for Improving Occupational Health and Safety Outcomes in the Mining Industry
Project Description: This project will integrate a robotic platform (vibration and motion), eye-tracking system and an environmental chamber (temperature; humidity) into the existing CROSH lab. CROSH will become the first lab in Canada with the infrastructure to simulate workplace environment conditions associated with underground mining and equipment operation.

Project Title: Evidence-based Decision Making Centre
Project Description: Supported by the proposed Evidence-based Decision Making Centre, this research program will combine traditional and innovative neurophysiological techniques to understand and enhance individual/ group managerial decision-making promising significant productivity gains for Ontario organizations.

Project Title: Applying Biomarkers of Present Moment Awareness to Promote Mental Health
Project Description: Depression is the leading cause of disability in Ontario, Canada, and around the world. The goal of the proposed research is to develop new techniques of assessing a person's current state of depression vulnerability. If successful, the project could revolutionize the use of preventative medicine in combatting depression.

Project Title: Nutrient-Neural Signaling in the Colon: A Role in IBS
Project Description: Meal induced symptoms in patients with irritable bowel syndrome has been well recognized for many years but the mechanisms producing these symptoms are unknown.  This proposal will examine the mechanisms of how specific nutrients in the gastrointestinal tract can produce symptoms of abdominal discomfort and altered motility (e.g. diarrhea) in irritable bowel syndrome.

Project Title: Systems biology infrastructure to explore protein misfolding and cellular protein quality control in human diseases
Project Description: Our research using the model organism yeast with its unparalleled capacity to explore genetic and cellular networks seeks to decipher the role of protein misfolding, cellular protein quality control, and aging in neurodegenerative diseases at a systems biology level.

Project Title: Understanding and Harnessing Human Memory Retrieval
Project Description: This project aims to better understand how memory retrieval can weaken our retrieved memories, to investigate how memory retrieval differs across people, and how these effects can be harnessed to enhance practices in mental health, education, interrogation and human resources.

Project Title: Facility for In Situ Characterization of Next-generation Electrochemical Devices
Project Description: Work with the requested In Situ Characterization System will lead to improved energy storage technologies by enabling a critical assessment of novel materials and approaches to improve their energy density and stability for use in current and future clean energy technologies.

Project Title: Exploring Neuroprotective Mechanisms Against Low Oxygen Stress in Hypoxia-tolerant Vertebrate Brain
Project Description: Our goal is to understand how hypoxia-tolerant brain maintains energetic homeostasis during low O2 stress. This will provide key insights into: (1) natural neuroprotective mechanisms against hypoxia, (2) the evolution of hypoxia-tolerance at the cellular level, and (3) treatments against hypoxic stress in brain.

Project Title: Dissecting Oncogenic Networks by Functional Genomics Using Multiplexed Genome Editing in Vivo
Project Description: Dr. Schramek has developed cutting-edge in vivo screening methodologies that integrate human cancer genomics and mouse modeling to enable (1) simultaneous screening of hundreds of putative cancer genes, (2) rapid characterization of cancer driver mutations and (3) screening for specific cancer vulnerabilities.

Project Title: HIV-1 pathogenesis and viral control
Project Description: Dr. Arts will establish one of the most advanced molecular virology laboratories in the world to study HIV-1 pathogenesis, treatment, and vaccine development.  His research program has defined the HIV-1 attributes related to transmission between humans and the rate of disease progression.

Project Title: High Throughput Genetic Sreening Technology for the Identification of Novel Targets for Treating Human Disease
Project Description: Dr. Screaton’s research will utilize new cutting edge approaches to understand at the cellular level the mechanisms that lead to both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes.  His research will also allow the identification of specific molecules and genes to target novel therapies for treating Type 1 and 2 diabetes.

Project Title: Mechanisms Regulating GPCRs in Disease
Project Description: Dr. Ferguson’s research program will develop novel avenues of drug treatment for hypertension, Alzheimer’s disease, Huntington’s disease, stress, anxiety and depression by repurposing drugs that are in current clinical trials for other disorders and creating unique platforms for novel drug discovery.

Project Title: Molecular Mechanisms Underlying Learning and Memory in Health and Disease
Project Description: We propose to develop and adapt novel tools (light, electrical signals, and molecules) for the purpose of understanding biological processes in brain health and disease.  We aim to find new treatments for debilitating medical disorders.  The work and discoveries will have significant socio-economic impacts.

Project Title: Molecular Mechanisms Driving Osteoarthritis
Project Description: Osteoarthritis affects more than 3 million people in Canada and causes annual costs of almost $30 billion, with proportional numbers for Ontario. The objective of this proposal is to identify underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms, with the long-term goal to develop novel therapies for this disease.

Project Title: Center for Advanced Dynamic Imaging of Tissue Barriers: Cellular Processes and Molecular Interactions.
Project Description: Diabetes and heart disease are two of the most common ailments afflicting Canadians. Breakdown of tissue barriers are known to contribute to the progression of these diseases. We propose to establish an advanced microscope imaging center to study why these barriers fail in order to test novel therapies.

Project Title: Advanced Power Electronics Laboratory for Sustainable Energy Research (PELSER)
Project Description: This project will establish an "Advanced Power Electronics Laboratory for Sustainable Energy Research” for cutting edge power electronics research in developing highly power efficient and cost effective power converter technologies that will provide Canadians with a clean, reliable and affordable energy future.

Project Title: Regenerative Cardiovascular Medicine Laboratory
Project Description: The proposed work will study the role of immune dysfunction in the pathogenesis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Stem cells from PAH patients will be used for proof-of-concept testing of new cell-based immunotherapies for PAH and other diseases of pathological vascular remodeling.

Project Title: Sustainability Policy Research on Urban Transformations (SPROUT) Lab
Project Description: The requested Sustainability Policy Research on Urban Transformations (SPROUT) Lab will explore innovative partnerships among governments, small businesses and civil society to create policy-relevant insights into pathways toward sustainable urban communities.

Project Title: SleepdB: A Sound-proof Laboratory to Examine Sleep-disordered Breathing
Project Description: SleepdB is a sound-proof sleep laboratory that will leverage novel acoustic-based methods to uncover the mechanisms underlying sleep-related respiratory diseases like sleep apnea and asthma. The infrastructure will also be used to develop new non-invasive technologies to monitor these diseases.

Project Title: Small Molecule Interrogation of G Protein-coupled Receptor
Project Description: Dr. Giguère’s research seeks to screen and develop pharmacologically distinct drugs with enhanced therapeutic potential and reduced side effects. To this end, he aims to target a newly discovered sodium modulation site found to control a signaling pathway triggering most deleterious effects of opioid receptor signaling.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Facility for Advancing Great Lakes Science
Project Description: The Great Lakes are an invaluable resource to Ontario’s economy, but are stressed by numerous interacting factors. This research will investigate how species respond to biological, chemical and thermal stressors, and help us better understand and protect Great Lakes' ecosystems.

Project Title: Clustering for Ultra High-Dimensional Data
Project Description: The ‘big data’ era presents many challenges to scientists in a wide range of endeavours, from management science to medical informatics. This research will develop statistical techniques for the analysis of very large data sets that cannot be analyzed with existing approaches.

Project Title: Innovation in Structured Light
Project Description: This research program will be aimed at the design and fabrication of novel optical and plasmonic devices suitable for “structuring” single photons and optical beams, and their applications to quantum computation, quantum information and secure quantum communication.

Project Title: Elucidating the Role of Macrophages in Cardiovascular Disease
Project Description: This innovative research program will elucidate the role of macrophages in cardiovascular diseases, including atherosclerosis, myocardial infarction and viral myocarditis. Its findings will contribute to the development of new diagnostic, prognostic and treatment strategies for these diseases.

Project Title: Innovative Dental Restorative System with Enhanced Biostability, Antidegradative and Antimicrobial Properties
Project Description: Recurrent tooth decay around resin composites is a major reason for dental restoration failure, which costs Canadians $3 billion per year. The project will establish strategies to develop materials that are resistant against degradation and bacteria in order to increase the longevity of dental restorations.

Project Title: Digital Storytelling and Mobile Media Lab
Project Description: This proposed Digital Storytelling and Multi-Media Lab will support the integration of innovative digital and new media in health and human rights research based at the University of Toronto. Digital storytelling will be used as a tool in HIV and sexually transmitted infections (STI) prevention strategies.

Project Title: The Design and Fabrication of Performance-driven Architecture: Non-standard Surfaces for Customised Acoustic Quality
Project Description: Innovative architectural research into the development and testing of novel surfaces for acoustic performance will benefit the design of indoors spaces such as classrooms, meeting rooms, and open concept offices, thus improving Ontarians’ health, built environment, and learning potential.

Project Title: Integrative Systems Biology Investigation of Chronic Respiratory Diseases
Project Description: The primary objective of my research program is to identify novel biological networks regulating drug response and susceptibility to diseases such as those affecting the airways. My team will integrate environmental exposures with biological information spanning genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics and metabolomics from human populations to uncover complex relationships among genes and characterise their interactions with environmental mediators. My translational research program will improve patient care through better prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of chronic diseases as well as train highly-qualified personnel in high-throughput computational biology at Queen’s University.

Project Title: Preventing Falls in Vulnerable Populations
Project Description: The research programs aim to prevent fall-related injuries in vulnerable populations by developing a new rehabilitation program to improve walking balance in people with spinal cord injury and by modifying the design of challenging environments (ie, stairs and inclined ramps) to prevent falls in older adults.

Project Title: The C. elegans motor system: A Development, Operation and Disease Model
Project Description: The objective is to gain a comprehensive understanding on how an animal’s motor behavior is encoded at the cellular, molecular and physiological level. We will achieve the goal by structure of the C. elegans nervous system via high-throughput electron microscopy and optogenetics. Its motor circuit output has been successfully used to model neurological disorders.

Project Title: In vivo Fluorescence Miscroscopic Analysis of the Developmental Evolution of the Amphibian Skull
Project Description: The objective of the current proposal is to create an innovative facility to gather novel data pertaining to the development and evolution of the skull, using cutting-edge in vivo fluorescence technology.

Project Title: Laboratory of Quantitative Global Change Ecology
Project Description: The proposed interdisciplinary Laboratory of Quantitative Global Change Ecology combines theoretical, computational, experimental, and field-based approaches to document, understand, and forecast ecological and epidemiological impacts of climate change and land-use change.

Project Title: Specialized Tools for In-situ and Online Analysis of Volatile Organic Compounds Relevant to Environmental Systems
Project Description: The objective of the project is to investigate the surface chemistry of atmospheric aerosols and their contribution to climate change, and newly synthesized nanomaterials and their role in remediating indoor pollution and wastewater treatment.

Project Title: Facilities for Development of Multifunctional Miniature Devices
Project Description: This project will establish the Facilities for Development of Multifunctional Miniature Devices for developing novel manufacturing and characterization technologies aimed at creating unconventional miniature devices for applications in bio-sensing, biomedical diagnosis, and new materials.

Project Title: Structure of GPCR membrane proteins
Project Description: The applicant will contribute to the revolution in membrane protein structural biology by studying G-protein-coupled receptors in order to understand the receptors' inner workings and enable structure-based drug design.

Project Title: Green Methods for the Preparation of New Materials
Project Description: The research programs of Dawe and Maly focus on the design and synthesis of new materials with a wide range of potential applications, including gas storage and separation as well as catalysis of chemical reactions.

Project Title: Evolution and Diversity of the Synapse: Roles for Voltage-gated Calcium Channels and PDZ Mediated Protein Interactions
Project Description: I compare synaptic structure and physiology between highly divergent animals, with a focus on calcium channels that mediate pre-synaptic neurotransmitter release, and synaptic protein complexing. These studies are aimed at expanding our understanding of synaptic diversity and evolution.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Maturation of Sensitive Circuits Underlying Early Life Stress
Project Description: Early life experiences crucially define cognition and mental health throughout life. To understand how early life experiences affect mental function, Dr. Arruda-Carvalho’s research examines how changes in functional connectivity within sensitive brain circuits underlie behaviour and sensitivity to stress.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title:
Development of Advanced Nanostructured Graphene Materials for Clean
Energy Storage
Project Description: Dr. Aiping Yu will establish a production and testing system to carry out her research on the advanced graphene materials for clean energy storage and utilization. This system will carry out state-of-the-art research on graphene materials and significantly improve the energy efficiency of the storage devices.

Project Title: High-frame Rate and High-frequency Ultrasound in Pediatric Cardiovascular Disease
Project Description: Ultrafast, and high frequency ultrasound equipment are innovative techniques that can be used to visualize the pediatric heart. This equipment is essential to allow SickKids researchers to develop imaging tools that will provide important new insights into the mechanisms of pediatric heart disease, culminating in new therapeutic strategies and better outcomes for patients.

Project Title: Targeting Wnt Signaling in Heart Disease
Project Description: This proposal aims to address the clinical problem of arrhythmogenic cardiac death, first through the elucidation of the novel role of Wnt signaling in the dysregulation of ion channel expression and abnormal rhythm (arrhythmia) of the diseased heart, and then to develop new therapeutic avenues.

Project Title: A Versatile Multi-physics Device and Circuit Characterization and Testing Platform
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure provides essential characterizing and testing capabilities to achieve innovative design and comprehensive hardware solutions to overcome the challenges facing next generation communication and data storage technologies, paving the path to high performance, reliable, cost-effective Internet of Things applications.

Project Title: Scaling the Cluster Computing Infrastructure for Scalable Big Data Management and Analysis
Project Description: People’s everyday economic and social activities have generated massive amounts of data, which has given rise to the “Big Data problem.” This research focuses on foundational issues in Big Data management and analysis using a large-scale, state-of-the-art cluster infrastructure.

Project Title: The Wearable Biomechatronics Laboratory
Project Description: Dr. Trejos is requesting essential items that will enable the development of nonintrusive, patient-centred, wearable mechatronic devices for rehabilitation. The items requested include a multimaterial 3D Printer, a lightweight, safe robotic system and renovations to the Wearable Biomechatronics Laboratory.

Project Title: Vision: Two-photon Imaging System for Research in Retinal Development, Injury and Repair
Project Description: This proposal will provide a state-of-the-art two-photon microscope to support the research of three vision scientists who aim to explore the mechanisms that influence retinal development, injury and repair, in order to develop new strategies for treating vision loss.

Project Title: Imaging Progressive Cartilage Degeneration: Unravelling the Mechanisms Associated with Joint Damage in Osteoarthritis
Project Description: This project will reveal the mechanisms underlying the development of osteoarthritis—the most common form of arthritis. The research will leverage experimental models of disease as well as a unique large-scale collection of precious human samples collected from knee and spine surgery patients.

Project Title: NSERC/UNENE Senior Industrial Research Chair in High Temperature Aqueous Chemistry
Project Description: The infrastructure will support a Senior NSERC Industrial Research Chair in High Temperature Aqueous Chemistry to provide research on the primary coolant chemistry, moderator chemistry, steam-generator chemistry and nuclear waste management of Ontario’s nuclear reactors.

Project Title: Neurobiology of Stress in Health and Disease
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will enable us to map out the complex neural circuits that underlie the stress response and how they become dysregulated in stress-related disorders. This research could lead to the identification of novel targets for treating the core symptoms of stress-related disorders.

Project Title: Novel in situ Remediation Technologies for Treatment of Contaminated Soil and Groundwater
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to acquire a key piece of instrumentation needed for research and technology development activities related to remediation of contaminated soil and groundwater.

Project Title: An Advanced Precision Medicine Technology Centre: Molecular Profiling in Kidney Cancer
Project Description: There are very few molecular markers that are effective in the diagnosis and treatment of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). We propose to acquire innovative screening platforms to discover (and apply diagnostically) novel “biomarkers” in RCC, specifically those that identify small renal masses.

Project Title: Biomechanical Determinants of Occupational Performance
Project Description: Millions of Canadians push, pull and lift at work every day. Dr. Fischer's research program explores why we choose to move the way we do at work, helping us to design safer workplaces and ensure Canadians remain healthy at work.

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Development and Application of Nickel Catalysts for Sustainable Chemistry
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will enable the development of nickel-catalyzed transformations for the production of value-added materials, such as medicines, from renewable chemical feedstocks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Ultrafast Terahertz Spectroscopy of Quantum Phase Transitions
Project Description: Cutting-edge optical tools based on a new type of laser system and a high-stability optical platform will be used to deepen our understanding of quantum interactions in solids and develop optical methods to control quantum states for future technologies.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Physical Activity Assessment and Analysis Suite
Project Description: The proposed research will develop new techniques to assess physical activity behaviour so as to examine the effectiveness of physical activity promotion programs. It will also help to explain the physical activity-to-health connection in healthy youth and those living with chronic disease.

Project Title: Constraining Canada’s Regional and Urban Carbon Cycle using Atmospheric Greenhouse Gas Measurements
Project Description: Through atmospheric measurements of greenhouse gases, this project will better constrain Canada’s greenhouse gas emissions and will determine the impacts a changing climate will have on ability of the Canadian Boreal forest to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

Project Title: Targeting Mitochondrial Dysfunction in Leukemia
Project Description: Dr. Steven Chan’s innovative research will shed light on differences between cancer and normal cells by deciphering the underlying mechanisms that lead to mitochondrial dysfunction and cancer pathogenesis. His findings will identify cancer-specific vulnerabilities that can be targeted to create new therapeutics.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Translation of Radiolabeled Monoclonal Antibodies to First-in-Humans Clinical Trials
Project Description: This project will establish the first-ever capability at the University of Toronto to prepare radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) under Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) conditions for advancement to first-in-humans clinical trials for molecular imaging (MI) and radioimmunotherapy (RIT) of cancer.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Harnessing the Power of Light: Discovering New Materials for Optoelectronics, Solar Energy Harvesting, and Biomedicine
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure is for the core instrumentation for developing a state of the art photonics materials research program that will attract/cultivate collaborators from Ontario, and abroad. The instrumentation is essential to engineering new, high performance, photonic materials.

Project Title: Defining and Overcoming Immunosuppression to Fight Persistent Viral Infection and Cancer
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will establish the foundation of Dr. Brooks’ laboratory; it will enable his innovative program focused on understanding how the immune system functions in response to persistent virus infections, and how this knowledge can contribute to developing anti-tumour therapies.

Project Title: Amélioration des infrastructures des equipments du Centre de recherche appliquée en biovalorisation.
Project Description: Ce projet a pour objectifs de permettre l'acquisition de trois nouveaux equipements et de proceder a la modification de certaines infrastructures pour accueillir ces equipements. Ce projet contribuera a accroitre le soutien deja offert aux entreprises. Les projets realises auront un impact significatif sur l'augmentation de la capacite des entreprises, leur competitivite et la creation d'emplois.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 001 - Stream 1
Keyword: Biotechnologie, biovalorisation, biofermentation, amelioration genetique, marqueurs, biogaz, ,produits naturels, extractions, analyses, cultures cellulaires.

Project Title: Establishing the Centre for Healthcare Interoperability and Emerging Technologies
Project Description: We propose to establish a Centre for Healthcare Interoperability and Emerging Technologies, which will serve two core functions. The Centre will facilitate systems integration and interoperability between healthcare systems and software within a provincial Electronic Health Records System (EHRS). The environment will also function as an evaluation and demonstration lab for enabling the use of leading edge software and natural user interface devices within a healthcare enterprise.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 001 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Mohawk College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Services Oriented, Enterprise Architecture, Interoperability, Mobile, Standards, Healthcare, eHealth Technologies, Integration, Testing

Project Title: Applied Technologies for Removal of Trace Elements
Project Description: This infrastructure will facilitate the development and advancement of biologically based treatment systems for the immobilization and removal of toxic trace elements in water.  The optimization and commercialization of this technology will allow for a low-cost, high efficiency, and practical means of removing hazardous contaminants from water.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 001 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Fleming College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Water treatment technology, anaerobic bioreactors, trace elements removal, bioremediation, metals, biological treatment systems, analytical laboratory equipment

Project Title: Canadian Food and Wine Institute: Niagara Food, Culinary and Beverage Innovation Centre
Project Description: Ontario is one of the largest food and beverage processing jurisdictions in North America (>$32 billion/yr in sales, 114,000 jobs).  Niagara College will support innovation in this field by pairing researchers and students with industry, giving them the tools and equipment to stimulate commercialization in this critical sector of the economy.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 001 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Niagara College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Food Safety, Sustainability, Competitiveness, Productivity, Culinary Innovation, Consumer Research, Entrepreneurship, Nutrition, Economic Revitalization.

Project Title: Green Homes
Project Description: Access to proven technologies is a competitive advantage to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which require technologies to be evaluated, prototyped, and tested, both in laboratory and field settings, before they can be brought to market. George Brown College (GBC) seeks ORF funding to establish the Green Homes Lab, to facilitate an applied research and technology development initiative focusing on addressing this innovation gap and catalyzing the economic development of SMEs in the residential construction/renovation sector in Ontario. This initiative comprises two themes; 1) Development of Novel Building Retrofit Materials and Methods, and 2) Development of "Smart" Building Automation, Sensor and Control System Technologies.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 001 - Stream 2
Lead Research Institution: George Brown College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Construction Materials, Engineering, Environmental Protection Planning, Green Technology, Prototyping and Testing, Sustainable Buildings

Project Title: Open Solar Inverter Test Facility
Project Description: St. Lawrence College will develop an outdoor solar inverter test facility for product improvement and performance verification. The facility will engage college students and faculty in industry led projects and support increase in the productivity and competitiveness of local and regional companies.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: St. Lawrence River Institute of Environmental Sciences
Keyword: Energy , Renewable, Sustainable, Integration, Electric, Inverter, Testing, Solar, Grid, Capacity

Project Title: Centre for Rapid Prototyping and Additive Manufacturing
Project Description: The proposed Centre for Rapid Prototyping and Additive Manufacturing will investigate the use of laser sintering of powdered metals in manufacturing applications. Consortium partners will work with Mohawk College to evaluate the competitive design and manufacturing advantages offered by the technology.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Mohawk College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: building sciences, building analytics, building operations, business collaboration, business innovation, construction engineering, architecture, applied research, sustainability, energy efficiency,

Project Title: Integrated 2D/3D Production Workflow for the Screen-based Industries
Project Description: Academic researchers working together with industry partners at Sheridan College’s Screen Industries Research and Training Centre will gain access to infrastructure to enable collaborative innovation technology development within the province’s screen-based cluster.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Sheridan College Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning
Keyword: Workflow, media, collaboration, metadata, cinema, interactive media, stereoscopic, visualization

Project Title: GBC Research Labs: Interprofessional Health Technology Development and Assessment
Project Description: The health care system faces increaded demands from an aging population, technological advancement, new patient-centred distributed care models and fiscal restraints. A strategic priority of George Brown College's (GBC) Strategy 2020 vision is to take a leadership role in Canada's interprofessional healthcare innovation agenda acorss all continuums, through training, partnership development and applied research. GBC Research Labs in Interprofessional Health Techonology Development and Assessment (GBC Research Labs) will meet this need through a program of research-driven technology development that supports innovation in Ontario across the continuum of care from clinic to hospital to the home. Research outcomes will include designing and prototyping products, processes and services for use in both clinical and home care settings, reducing the risk of infection while increasing system efficiency and patient mobility, safety, independence and healthy living. The research will support Ontario SMEs at all stages of technology development to enable industry to produce products that increase competitiveness, market penetration, economic development, and innovation capacity.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: George Brown College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Interprofessional Healthcare, Healthcare Devices, Health Information Systems, Health Technology Development, Assistive Devices, Orthotics, Prosthetics, Prototype Development

Project Title: Amélioration des infrastructures de recherche du Centre de recherche appliquée en biovalorisation
Project Description: Ce projet vise à accroître le soutien déjà offert aux entreprises en permettant  l’acquisition de neuf nouveaux équipements et la modification de certaines infrastructures pour accueillir ces équipements. Les projets réalisés grâce à l’amélioration des infrastructures auront un impact significatif sur l’augmentation de la capacité des entreprises, leur compétitivité et la création d’emplois.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 1
Keyword: Biotechnologie, bio fermentation, aliments, microbiologie, oxydation des lipides, biovalorisation

Project Title: Enhancing the Building Industry through Analytics and Next Generation Collaboration
Project Description: Algonquin College, in collaboration with the Construction sector, will research, develop and implement industry-specific digital and virtual technologies to enhance the design, build, operate and renew phases of the construction industry and to train Highly Qualified Personnel (HQP) to address current shortages.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 1
Keyword: Energy , Renewable, Sustainable, Integration, Electric, Inverter, Testing, Solar, Grid, Capacity
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Centre for Smart Manufacturing
Project Description: The Centre for Smart Manufacturing will be equipped with integral technologies to enable applied research opportunities for manufacturers seeking to innovate products and processes in areas of High-Performance Manufacturing and Information & Computer Technology Enabled Technologies.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 002 - Stream 2
Lead Research Institution: Conestoga College Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning
Keyword: Additive Manufacturing, raid Prototyping, eManufacturing, Powder Metallurgy, Laser Sintering, Clean Technology, Digital manufacturing

Project Title: Advanced Multi-material Additive Manufacturing: Product and Process Innovation
Project Description: Specialized equipment for multi-mal erial additive manufacturing research complementing Sheridan's world-class Centre for Advanced Manufacturing and Design Technologies will offer unprecedenled opportunity to Ontario's manufacturing sector resulting in increased know-how and economic benefit.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 003 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Sheridan College Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning
Keyword: Building Information Modelling (BIM), Construction, BIM Adoption, BIM Protocols, LiDAR Technology, Visualization, Energy Modelling, Mobile Technologies, Architecture, Design

Project Title: Centre for Industrial Material Development (CIMD)
Project Description: Through this ORF request, Lambton College will increase its advanced material research capacity by establishing the “Centre for Industrial Material Development (CIMD)” to become a regional and provincial hub for industrial material and biomaterial development projects.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 003 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Lambton College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Food processing innovation & technology, equipment manufacturing, food safety & authenticity

Project Title: Food Innovation & Technology
Project Description: Our initiative is strategically designed to strengthen Conestoga’s applied research capacity to serve  Ontario’s multi-billion dollar Food and Beverage Processing sector with a specific focus on Automation in Food Processing and Packaging, and Food Safety in Processing and Packaging Technology.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 003 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Conestoga College Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning
Keyword: Product Development, Process Validation, Sensory Evaluation, Product Optimization, Recipe Standardization, Shelf-Life, Regulatory Compliance, Beverage Formulation, Food Safety, Packaging Material Evaluation

Project Title: Supporting Food and Beverage SME Product Innovation: GBC Food Science and Culinary Arts Applied Research Infrastructure
Project Description: ORF investment in expanding GBC’s Food Innovation and Research Studio will enable Toronto’s 20,000+ food and beverage industry SMEs to overcome multiple technical challenges currently preventing products from moving speedily, and successfully, to national and international markets.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 003 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: George Brown College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Material Design, Novel Synthetic Materials, Bio-Material, Material Characterization, Material Processing, Membrane Development, Nano-composite & Nano-Engineered Material, Extrusion, Particle Analysis, Recyclable Material

Project Title: Building Information Modelling Research Initiative
Project Description: George Brown College (GBC) is committed to becoming the leading institution in Canada for BIM applied research, innovation and training. GBC will support SMEs in adopting BIM approaches and adapting BIM tools into their business models. The proposed initiative will actively transfer BIM technology and processes Ontario's construction sector SMEs, increasing SME productivity and efficiency throughout the whole building to Ontario's construction sector SMEs, increasing SME productivity and efficiency throughout the whole building lifecycle. GBC will provide training to recent graduates as well as to seasoned industry professionals so that they can facilitate BIM implementation in the workforce. This initiative will enable GBC to take a leadership role and partner with industry to address the BIM innovation gap and catalyze economic development in the construction sector in Ontario.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 003 - Stream 2
Lead Research Institution: George Brown College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Additive manufacturing, e-manufacturing, product innovation, re-engineering, biomedical devices, aerospace parts, raid prototyping

Project Title: Development and Application of Synthetic Biology Devices for Human Health
Project Description: The Pardee lab is merging cell-free synthetic biology with engineered materials and electronics to create new programmable diagnostics, a portable therapeutics manufacturing platform, and advanced research tools. These low-cost devices hold great potential for research, medicine, agriculture, industry, environmental monitoring, and education.

Project Title: Epigenetic Regulation of Learning and Memory
Project Description: The field of neuroepigenetics seeks to understand how cells interpret the genetic information to mediate neuronal development and function. This research program focuses on understanding the neurobiology of two key epigenetic regulatory complexes that are important factors in the etiology of Intellectual Disability.

Project Title: Understanding Cardiovascular Response and Influence to Physical Exercise
Project Description: This project aims to understand the reactive and adaptive human response to physical stressors. The research focus is on the human vasculature and how changing vascular stimuli and blood flow can alter the vasculature itself as well as adaptive responses of downstream targets like skeletal muscle.

Project Title: Integrated Lab for the Development of Catalysts for Sustainable Synthesis
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will support cutting-edge research in catalyst design, testing, and mechanisms to improve the sustainability of the fine chemical industries, such as pharmaceuticals. The proposed catalysts have the capacity to reduce the number of required synthetic steps, reducing both monetary costs and generated waste.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma through Combined Mass Spectrometry Imaging, Metabolomics and Multivariate Analysis
Project Description: This project will develop and apply new analytical techniques based on mass spectrometry to identify and monitor biomolecules associated with cancer. The project will initiate with squamous-cell carcinoma patient samples since it has high clinical relevance; 30 percent of the head and neck region cancers occur in the oral cavity.

Project Title: Molecular Imaging Probe Discovery Laboratory
Project Description: Molecular imaging probes are used to diagnose, monitor and guide treatments for diseases such as cancer. The equipment requested will enable probe development efforts that will result in earlier disease detection, more accurate diagnosis, tailored treatments, and commercialization opportunities in Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Deep Learning Facilities
Project Description: A theory of big data will be developed using a GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) cluster to train neural networks to approximate semantic distance and bioinformatics deep learning involving proteomics data. The system will have applications to a Question Answering system, as well as systems in bioinformatics.

Project Title: Role of Intestinal Microbiota in Food Sensitivity
Project Description: The primary objective of the proposed research is to characterize the role of human intestinal microbiota in the digestion of food proteins, such as gluten, that cause inflammation and sensitivities to humans. Their increasing prevalence requires identification of preventative and therapeutic strategies.

Project Title: Laboratory for Mechanistic Studies of Myeloid-Driven Immune Suppression
Project Description: The proposed research seeks to improve our understanding of the mechanisms used by the immune system to identify targets, which will have applications in the treatment of autoimmune disease as well as cancer immunotherapies.

Project Title: Computing Infrastructure to support the Canada Research Chair in Environmental Modelling and Analysis
Project Description: High performance computing resources will be used to identify novel methods for improving the reliability of environmental models. The resultant models will help decision makers to make informed decisions about Canada’s water and energy resources, protecting the environment and public health.

Project Title: Networked Imagination: A Laboratory for Network Music and Live Coding
Project Description: The Networked Imagination Laboratory will create software interfaces and practices in which the collaborative potentials of networking are unfolded into new models. What might work look and sound like if it were taken as axiomatic that human productivity is unavoidably networked and conversational?

Project Title: Creation of a Laboratory to Study Redox Modulations in Mood Disorders
Project Description: Dr. Andreazza’s research program aims to identify the role of energy metabolism and oxidative changes to biomolecules in mood disorders to, ultimately, find affordable, easy-to-use biological markers to prevent disease progression and guide development of novel and effective treatments.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Establish an Interactive Data Exploration and Analytics (IDEA) System Laboratory
Project Description: This research project will create an Interactive Data Exploration and Analytics (IDEA) system to develop analysis, interpretation, and decision-making tools for the healthcare industry. The IDEA system will be developed and ecologically validated in collaboration with local industry and healthcare providers.

Project Title: Functional Proteomics
Project Description: Dr. Gingras is requesting instrumentation to further develop a new kind of mass spectrometry method called Data Independent Acquisition.  This method will be used to quantify peptides derived from alternative splicing events and peptides which are modified by phosphorylation.

Project Title: Tissue Culture Facility of Bioanalytical Sensors
Project Description: Dr. Kerman's cutting edge research, aimed at understanding Alzheimer’s disease (AD), will contribute significantly to the development of novel techniques and tools that utilize neurons for rapid and cost-effective screening of next-generation AD therapeutics.

Project Title: Preventing Risk and Promoting Well-Being in Emerging Adulthood
Project Description: Emerging adulthood (ages 18-25) is a unique and critical period of psychological and cognitive development. The requested infrastructure supports ground-breaking research to ensure healthy adjustment in emerging adulthood, setting the stage for a productive and fulfilling adulthood.

Project Title: Custom Low-Dimensional Material Systems Explored from Atom to Bulk
Project Description: With the prospect of innovation in the area of new materials for energy and next generation electronics, Dr. Luican-Mayer’s research program combines scanning tunneling microscopy, to visualize and control matter at the atomic scale, with a newly discovered platform for constructing atomically thin custom-made material systems.

Project Title: Project Re•Vision: Mobilizing New Meanings of Difference
Project Description: Project Re•Vision develops and evaluates innovative arts-based methods to transform misperceptions of those with disabilities and bodily differences as well as members of other marginalized communities, including Indigenous and racialized people in health, business, education, the arts sectors.

Project Title: Quantum Dynamics of Confined Molecules
Project Description: This research will probe the nature of molecular motion in quantum matter and will lead to innovative software tools for the simulation and design of novel materials. Applications in the areas of nanoelectronics, storage of clean energy, and quantum information are outcomes of the research.

Project Title: Simulating Digestion for Food Nanotechnology Assessment
Project Description: Developing food nanotechnologies presents tremendous opportunities, as well as risks, to alter the ‘healthiness’ of processed foods. In developing these technologies, we are in dire need of state-of-theart technologies to assess their behaviour in model gastrointestinal tracks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Spatially-resolved Biochemistry
Project Description: This proposal seeks funding to establish the Centre for Single Cell Analysis at University of Toronto, Scarborough, to resolve, in both time and space, the mechanisms of immune cell activation in individual cells through the application of cutting-edge microscopy techniques.

Project Title: Precision Physics with Atoms and Molecules
Project Description: The research program will use atoms and molecules as the building blocks of precision technologies. The objectives are to develop portable high-performance clocks using atoms cooled by lasers, and to develop molecular devices for controlling the quantum properties of light at terahertz frequencies.

Project Title: Coupled Human and Natural Systems Laboratory (CHANS-lab)
Project Description: This research will help us to better understand and predict how public sentiment regarding vaccines and climate change spreads through social networks. This will be accomplished by developing a computational laboratory and digital database to analyze data from Twitter and other “Big Data” sources.

Project Title:
Establishment of a Sensory Neuroplasticity Platform at the Faculty of Pharmacy of the
University of Toronto
Project Description: Intractable pain is the single most common cause of disability world-wide. This project will use advanced experimental approaches to reveal how cellular changes in the spinal cord contribute to pathological pain, and to identify cellular processes that reverse pathological pain or counter its development.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Neural Mechanisms Underlying Cognitive Transformations for Human Goal-Directed Action
Project Description: Using an integrated, multi-disciplinary neuroscience approach the main objective of this proposal is to develop a better understanding of the perceptual, cognitive and motor-related brain mechanisms in humans that support the selection, planning and control of goal-directed behaviour.

Project Title: The Sport & Physical Activity Research Collaborative (SPARC) Facility at UOIT
Project Description: Over 90% of Canadians are physically inactive; and yet many athletes aim for excellence in high performance sport. Drs. Wattie and Lloyd address these challenges at the UOIT Sport & Physical Activity Research Collaborative (SPARC), studying and designing ways to increase physical activity and sport performance.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Infrastructure for WaterlooBCI Laboratory
Project Description: This project will establish the WaterlooBCI laboratory, the objective of which is to develop non-invasive brain computer interfaces (BCI) to help the rehabilitation process for stroke patients, as well as those with spinal cord injury, Parkinson’s disease, and other motor function disabilities.

Project Title: Reservoir Monitoring Using Superconducting Gravimetry
Project Description: Monitoring oil, gas, and water reservoirs and their dynamics is important for Canada’s economy and environmental sustainability. Superconducting gravimeters enable an innovative approach to monitoring fluid migration in reservoirs by sensing mass change during injection/extraction processes.

Project Title: Remuscularization of Injured Hearts Using Stem Cells
Project Description: Dr. Laflamme's innovative research is aimed at developing methods to generate functional heart tissue from stem cells. He plans to utilize these tissues to develop a safe and efficacious stem cell-based therapy for heart failure.

Project Title: Facility for Women’s Reproductive Health Research
Project Description: Epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) is the most deadly women’s cancer, and preeclampsia (PE) is a serious pregnancy complication. This project aims to investigate the molecular mechanisms contributing to the development of EOC and PE, and to develop diagnostic and therapeutic tools for these diseases.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Support the Nipissing University Social Neuroendocrinology Laboratory
Project Description: By combining theory and methodology from social, experimental, and personality psychology, endocrinology, and pharmacology, the proposed research will examine the psychological, hormonal, and situational factors that give rise to individual differences in human aggressive behaviour.

Project Title: Fast Two-Photon Resonance Microscope System for Advanced in vivo Imaging of Brain Plasticity in Awake and Behaving Mice
Project Description: This research will uncover how the dynamics of neural network activity evolve during motor learning, which will inform the development of therapeutic strategies for counteracting neural circuit dysfunctions in stroke, neurodegenerative disease, and traumatic brain injury.

Project Title: Rehabilitation Aimed at Muscle Performance (RAMP)
Project Description: The Rehabilitation Aimed at Muscle Performance research lab, led by Dr. Reid, aims to determine the causes of muscle dysfunction resulting from disease, hospitalization and inactivity with the ultimate goal of preventing weakness, improving strength and maintaining independent living in Ontarians.

Project Title: Germanium Detectors to Understand Neutrinos and Dark Matter
Project Description: This project supports Ontario’s continued international leadership in the quest to understand the nature of matter. Germanium-based technologies will be developed for next generation experiments to search for dark matter and to understand neutrinos in deep underground laboratories such as SNOLAB.

Project Title: Computational Infrastructure for Simulating Lake, Atmosphere and Ocean Dynamics
Project Description: Our research will develop mathematical and computational techniques for modelling motions in naturally occurring fluids such as the Great Lakes, the coastal oceans and the overlying atmosphere with implications for science-based management practices (e.g. water quality) and climate change adaptation.

Project Title: Nanotopography Platform for Stem Cell
Project Description: Stem cells are crucial to cell therapy, regenerative medicine and disease modeling; however, the growth of undifferentiated stem cells is challenging and expensive.  This project will develop a nano-structured stem cell culture system, providing a cost-efficient and reliable cell culture platform.

Project Title: Investigating Neuromuscular Control Strategies Using Haptic Robotics
Project Description: To complete activities of daily living we coordinate limb movements through the neural control of muscles in the upper extremity. This work integrates biomechanics and neurophysiology with haptic robotics to investigate how muscle recruitment and control strategies influence workplace injury risk.

Project Title: Disentangling the Climatic Mechanisms that Structure Species’ Distributions and Interactions
Project Description: This research program will aim to advance our understanding of how climate structures species’ distributions and how species interactions influence how species respond to climate change. This research will improve our knowledge about the overall responses of species to climate change.

Project Title: Discovery and Synthesis of Nanomaterials for Ubiquitous Electronics
Project Description: Dr. Musselman’s research program will develop a new type of thin film deposition system that can rapidly discover new nanoscale materials to accelerate product development cycles. Discovered materials will be used to improve next-generation ubiquitous electronic devices and functional coatings.

Project Title: New Discoveries through Activity-Based Protein Profiling
Project Description: We will develop new biotechnologies to detect and study human pathogens. These tools will be used to identify enzymatic activity in complex proteomes for biomarker and therapeutic discovery, to metabolically label pathogens for manipulation and to track, image and probe host-pathogen interactions.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Proteomics Laboratory to Investigate Alternative Splicing Regulation in Stem Cell Differentiation
Project Description: The proposed research aims to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of stem cell differentiation using proteomics. It will bring crucial knowledge necessary for development of stem cell therapy, which is promising to treat various human diseases including cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases.

Project Title: Advanced Optical Instrumentation Laboratory For Large Astronomical Telescope Instrument Development
Project Description: This project seeks to establish an advanced optical and infrared instrumentation research lab in order to develop next-generation astronomical cameras and spectrographs for existing large telescopes and soon-to-be-built extremely large telescopes, such as the Thirty Meter Telescope.

Project Title: Remodeling of the Cerebral Vasculature in Health and Disease
Project Description: The brain is particularly vulnerable to vascular failures. Indeed, neurological disorders that comprise vascular dysfunctions are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. The proposed research will identify novel therapeutic targets to counter cerebrovascular diseases and to promote brain and mind health.

Project Title: High Content Screening to Identify and Validate Potential Therapeutic Targets
Project Description: Dr. Andrews’ research utilizes innovative high-throughput approaches to measure protein interactions in live cells. In particular, his lab will identify and validate new potential therapeutic targets in the context of understanding cell survival programs to translate this essential knowledge to advance health benefits.

Project Title: Laboratory for Ultrafast Thermo-Magnetics
Project Description: The laboratory for ultrafast thermo-magnetics is needed to study magnetic phenomena at high temperature and extremely short time scales. The research will enable the development of high-density data storage and advance our knowledge of nanoscale interactions between light, magnetism and heat.

Project Title: Electron Microscopy for the Engineering of Novel Bactericidal Nanomachines Derived from Bacteriophages
Project Description: We will develop novel bacterial killing agents, called tailocins, that will be used to specifically eliminate any bacterial strain. The pursuit of this project requires a new electron microscope, which will be purchased through this application. Our work will have impact in treating infections by antibiotic-resistant bacteria, and in investigating the role of the microbiome in human health.

Project Title: Multiscale Functional Material Modelling for Energy Applications
Project Description: The requested high-performance computer CLUSTER will contribute to the advancement of ecologically-sustainable energy systems by developing new energy materials that can be utilised in cost-competitive photovoltaic devices and also improve the efficiency of light-emitting devices.

Project Title: Electro-Functional Membranes: Selective Separations and Catalytic Degradations of Environmental Contaminants
Project Description: Pollutants of human health and environmental concern are continually infiltrating Canadian waters. This project aims to develop novel nano-composite devices that can efficiently clean our drinking water and decontaminate natural environments, while also destroying many of the most recalcitrant environmental pollutants.

Project Title: Real-time Aquatic Ecosystem Observation Network
Project Description: "This multi-institutional proposal will develop a freshwater observation network that will be comprehensive in time (continuous, year-round, real-time data), space (linking researchers, projects, networks and agencies), and level of biological organization (characteristics of water, biota, etc.)."
Keyword: freshwater ecosystems, nutrient dynamics, water quality, biogeochemistry, spatial ecology, community ecology, ecosystem management, biodiversity, ecosystem services

Project Title: Lab-in-Fibre: Smart glass probing and distributed sensing microsystems
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure will establish critical 3D-laser fabrication and diagnostic tools with which a multidisciplinary team of researchers can drive open a new field of lab-in-fibre sensing and underpin new approaches in non-invasive surgery, environmental sensing and the Internet of Things.
Keyword: "distributed sensing, lab-in-fibre, lab-on-a-chip, smart glass, ultrafast laser, laser-matter interaction physics, smart catheter, plasmonic sensor, optofluidics, biomass, safe water, cellular mechanics, cytometer"

Project Title: Unlocking the Radio Sky with Next-Generation Survey Astronomy
Project Description: We propose to build advanced research databases for new radio telescopes, which we will use to understand cosmic magnetism, galaxy evolution, and cosmic explosions. This work will also let us prepare for the forthcoming data challenges of the billion-dollar Square Kilometre Array.
Keyword: radio astronomy; time-domain astrophysics; cosmic magnetism; galaxy evolution; cosmology; data mining; high-performance computing; public data archives; software stacks; digital infrastructure
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Mega-Scale Multi-Dimensional Experimental Facility for Enhancing Canada’s Infrastructure Resilience
Project Description: The project aims to establish a laboratory that will enable a new level of accuracy in large-scale multi-dimensional civil infrastructure testing and modelling. The research enabled by the laboratory will ultimately enhance the safety and resilience of Ontario’s critical civil infrastructure.
Keyword: Infrastructure, Multi-Hazard, Safety, Resilience, Hybrid Testing, Large-Scale, Multi-Axial, Dynamic Loading.

Project Title: Preclinical Platform Expansion for Cardiovascular Interventions: Electrophysiology and Regenerative Medicine
Project Description: The proposal seeks to expand our preclinical catheterization laboratory to support a new electrophysiology (EP) suite for interventions and enable arrhythmia monitoring in pigs with cardiac stem cells; it will also upgrade the facility with wireless EP monitoring and housing of immunosuppressed pigs
Keyword: Electrophysiology, Arrhythmia, Heart Attack, Heart Failure; Regenerative Medicine, Stem Cells; Interventional Cardiology; Medical Devices; Sudden Cardiac Death

Project Title: Advanced Neurotherapeutics involving MRI Guidance of Transcranial Focused Ultrasound
Project Description: Transcranial magnetic resonance guided focused ultrasound enables noninvasive treatment of brain diseases through the intact skull. SRI will continue its pioneering development of this world-leading technology by translating the next generation of FUS & MRI systems for clinical applications.
Keyword: Transcranial focused ultrasound, Noninvasive brain therapy, Thermal ablation, Localized drug delivery, Blood brain barrier disruption, Microbubbles

Project Title: The CRDCN Transition to High Performance Computing: Liberating Data for Research and Policy

Project Title: Advanced Infrastructure for Dynamic Imaging and Control of Complex Systems -ALLS+

Project Description: The  requested TRIUMF infrastructure will provide Canadian and international users with unique muon research capabilities for the study of quantum systems under normal and extreme conditions, and advance quantum information, communications, batteries, green chemistry and CANDU reactor design.
