Project Title: Functional Near-infrared Spectroscopy for Multi-modal Neuroimaging
Project Description: The goal of the research is to understand how cardiovascular fitness changes neural activity in the human brain and spinal cord. The requested functional near-infrared spectroscopy system will provide essential information that identifies brain activity that differentiates fit versus sedentary individuals.
Keyword: neuroimaging, fNIRS, optode, EMG, analog to digital, constant current

Project Title: GPU Hardware Acceleration Technology for Machine Learning Systems
Project Description: A high-performance computing cluster is requested in order to support a well-established research program in the field of machine learning and artificial intelligence. With new infrastructure, the lab will be able to increase the scope of collaboration and gain the ability to tackle larger projects.
Keyword: Machine learning, computer science, Algorithms, hardware accelerators

Project Title: Leveraging Essential Genes and Genetic Networks to Cripple Human Fungal Pathogens
Project Description: Fungal pathogens have a devastating impact on human health. To address this clinical need, this proposal aims to acquire the infrastructure necessary to discover genes that are required for fungal pathogens to survive and cause disease. This will permit the development of new therapeutic strategies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Molecular Genetic and Mutation Signature Analyses of High Priority Carcinogens
Project Description: This project will determine diagnostic signatures of DNA damage from exposure to known or suspected carcinogens, and genetically engineer advanced next generation systems to model DNA damage in humans. This work will lead to better cancer prevention, diagnosis, and treatment strategies.

Project Title: Cold Climate Agri-food and Small Community Mobile Wastewater Research Facility
Project Description: The objective of this project is to develop low-cost, low-energy treatment technologies to remove and recover nutrients from agri-food and small community wastewaters. A unique research facility will be developed consisting of mobile cold-climate wastewater test units and field data acquisition equipment.

Project Title: Biophysical and Structural Biology Resources to Understand Host-pathogen Interactions
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will establish a state-of-the-art biophysics and structural biology facility specialized to study human and viral proteins and protein complexes. This facility is unique to Canada and will positively impact the academic and biotech sectors in Ontario.

Project Title: Functional Proteomics to Uncover the Mechanism of Therapeutic Resistance in Cancer Treatment
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will allow Dr. Li and his team to develop an innovative approach for profiling key signalling events underlying tumorigenesis, for improving existing cancer therapies, and for the development of novel strategies to overcome resistance to existing or emerging therapies.

Project Title: Wild Animal Facility for the Study of Host-microbiota Interactions
Project Description: Mammals are naturally colonized by complex microbial communities that provide essential biological functions and influence disease susceptibility. This project will explore how this “microbiota” affects the immune system and its ability to fight infection and prevent the development of intestinal inflammation.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: Actomyosin Cytoskeleton Dynamics in Cell and Tissue Homeostasis
Project Description: The shape of all cells in the human body is determined by an internal structure called the cytoskeleton. Prof. Olson investigates cytoskeleton function and regulation to understand its contribution to human health, and to identify novel drug targets for cancer and cardiovascular disease therapy.

Project Title: NeuroHealth and Rehabilitation Research Centre (NHR2C)
Project Description: The goal of the proposal is to develop effective exercise approaches for managing disability and improving health in people with neurological conditions (e.g., multiple sclerosis and Alzheimer’s disease). Research support will enable the acquisition of adapted exercise modalities and imaging systems.

Project Title: Enhanced Assessment of Multiple Stressors
Project Description: The project will bring Ontario to the forefront of research on the effects of multiple stressors on aquatic ecosystems by supporting water managers across Ontario to make informed decisions to protect aquatic resources threatened by human activities, including climate change.
Keyword: Ecotoxicology, emerging contaminants, multiple stressors, wastewater, fish biology, risk assesment, risk management, watershed processes, cumulative effects, integrated imaging plate reader, aquatic bioenergetics systems

Project Title: The Decision Neuroscience Laboratory: Tracking the Computational Dynamics of Decision Making and Self-control
Project Description: This proposal uses innovative computational and brain imaging approaches to reveal the dynamics of decision making and self-control. It will yield novel insights into why people fail to achieve their goals, and allow us to develop new approaches to helping them make healthier, more adaptive choices.

Project Title: An Enhanced Protein Preparation and Structure-Function Characterization Facility
Project Description: Protein phosphorylation catalyzed by kinase plays a key role in health and disease conditions. Using a combination of protein structural and biochemical characterization approaches, we aim to study atypical kinases from both prokaryotes and eukaryotes to future development of new antibiotic strategies and other therapeutic applications.
Keyword: protein phosphorylation, atypical kinase, structure-function studies, crystallography, enzyme, regulation, membrane protein, purification, crystallization, shake incubator, FPLC, OD scanner, LCP, microscope, rotating anode, UPS

Project Title: A Pipeline for Integrative Analysis of Chromatin Dynamics & Genome Architecture
Project Description: Dr. D’Amours’ research aims to understand how chromosomes are separated equally in dividing cells, and how cancer cells corrupt this process to promote tumorigenesis. The proposed research will use cutting-edge equipment to study the mode of action of proteins responsible for chromosome separation in live cells.

Project Title: Sustainable Water Treatment Lab - Research Equipment Infrastructure Request
Project Description: This proposed research will investigate biofiltration for treating drinking water in a sustainable and cost-effective manner. When used in conjunction with membrane technology biofiltration will significantly reduce chemical and electricity needs at water treatment plants and reduce disinfection by-products.

Project Title: Neurobiology of Energy Balance
Project Description: The goal of this project is to understand the neurobiological mechanisms in obesity. We will use high resolution imaging and electrophysiology techniques to visualize and obtain live recordings of electrical activity from single brain cells.

Project Title: Grid Edge Transactive Energy Management System
Project Description: The project is to develop and demonstrate a demand response system between the electric power distribution systems and customer home energy management system to reduce potential capital investments of electric power distribution companies and electricity costs of home customers.

Project Title: Advanced Camera Imaging Lab at York University
Project Description: This application is for funds to establish an Advanced Camera Imaging Lab at York University, Ontario. The proposed infrastructure will facilitate advancements in digital imaging technology and contribute to Ontario’s growth as a leader in technology within Canada and the world.

Project Title: Integration and Co-existence of Emerging Wireless Architectures
Project Description: The objective of the proposed program is to establish the measurement and verification infrastructure necessary to investigate co-existence between key wireless technologies, e.g., Wi-Fi and LTE, leading to effective spectral usage within their areas of deployment in Ontario, Canada.

Project Title: Diffraction Engineered next Generation mm-wave Wireless Networks using Smart Electromagnetic Metasurfaces
Project Description: This proposal aims at inventing a new mm-wave technology exploiting electromagnetic metamaterials as smart wave scatterers to engineer RF environments, to achieve ultra-high speed wireless communication between multiple electronic devices located in strategic areas of typical dense urban environments.

Project Title: Enabling Biomarker Identification and Treatment Optimization for Prevalent Neurological Disorders
Project Description: The proposed research will enhance our understanding of Parkinson’s disease, major depression and epilepsy, and how different components of the affected brain networks interact in health and disease. The researchers will deliver improved and expanded treatment options for these neurological disorders.
Keyword: Movement disorders, major depression, epilepsy, EEG, MRI, rTMS, biomarkers, personalized therapeutics, MRI-compatible EEG system and components, acquisition and stimulus computers

Project Title: Tracking Trajectories for Vulnerable Children: Using Data to Understand Outcomes
Project Description: Child maltreatment can contribute to devastating, long-lasting outcomes. The Ontario Child Abuse and Neglect Data System’s (OCANDS 2.0) expansion will enable researchers, administrators, and policy-makers to study child welfare trends over time to better understand effective policies and practices.
Keyword: child maltreatment, longitudinal research design, research-ready datasets, child welfare indicators,

Project Title: Genome-Driven Discovery of Next-Generation Natural Biotherapeutics
Project Description: Microbial small molecules are a resource from which new biotherapeutics can be developed. This research will leverage microbial genome data to guide the discovery of novel natural products, which will help to uncover new treatment strategies to combat human diseases.
Keyword: bioactive small molecules, natural products, human microbiome, drug discovery, bioinformatics, genomics, single molecule real time DNA sequencer, automated DNA size selector
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project Title: A Testbed for Modern Cloud Storage Research
Project Description: This research aims to solve a key problem in modern data centres: data storage system inefficiency and low performance. This research will explore three radical designs that can leverage recent advances in hardware technology, and employ storage-specific optimizations to build a more efficient system.
Keyword:
Cloud Computing, Storage systems, low latency computing, software-defined
networks, highly-efficient data center.
Specific infrastructure software-defined networks, non-volatile memory, network-attached cards

Project Title: Functional and Metabolic Assessment of Small Animal Models of Disease with MRI
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to develop non-invasive anatomical, metabolic and functional magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods and apply them to novel rodent and primate models of human brain disorders. The use of MRI allows our approaches to be directly translated to human patients.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Develop Solid State Detectors for High Luminosity LHC
Project Description: The funds requested are for infrastructure to develop and construct a state-of-the-art silicon particle detector. It will be installed to the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider in CERN, Switzerland and will be used by Canadian physicists to explore the fundamental nature of the universe in 2026-2036.

Project Title: Building Open and Interoperable User-oriented Internet of Things
Project Description: The objective of this project is to develop new technologies required to build an open IoT-infrastructure that better connects people with their environments. This includes the development of core functionality needed to create, maintain and run IoT applications without requiring substantial integration upfront.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Improving Outcomes for Organ Transplantation: A Live Imaging Platform to Target Immunologic and Fibrotic Events
Project Description: This program will reveal the underlying processes that result in the premature failure of transplanted organs. Leveraging unique access to living human tissues, the researchers will deliver new drug targets, therapeutic strategies and decision-making tools to improve outcomes for organ transplant recipients.
Keyword: ischemia-reperfusion injury, fibrosis, antibody-mediated graft rejection, inflammation, angiotensin signaling, nanoparticles, immunotherapy, graft loss, intravital microscope upgrade, 3D microscope, vibratome, tissue dissociator

Project Title: Ultrasound Technology for Image-guided Interventions in the Spine
Project Description: Dr. O’Reilly’s research innovates ultrasound technologies to permit non-invasive, non-ionizing therapies for the spine. In particular, her lab will investigate how ultrasound interacts with the spinal anatomy and develop new ultrasonic devices for delivering healthcare treatments for a range of spinal pathologies.
Keyword: ultrasound therapy, non-invasive surgery, spine, ultrasound phased array, multi-channel beamformer, acoustic field measurement apparatus

Project Title: Development of Reasoning about the Self
Project Description: This project will investigate early social cognition and its development across the lifespan, focusing specifically on children’s developing understanding of the self, the connection of these theories of the self to social and moral judgment, and how they effect decision-making for the self across the lifespan.
Keyword: social cognitive development, development of self, moral development, personal identity, intuitive dualism, ownership reasoning, fairness, folk theories, lab space, computing systems, data backup, experiment software

Project Title: Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms Underpinning the Initiation, Progression and Metastasis of Pancreatic Cancer
Project Description: Dr. Faiyaz Notta will elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underpinning the pathogenesis of pancreatic cancer. Fundamental and cutting-edge lab equipment is requested to establish his innovative research program, which will be located at the Princess Margaret Cancer Centre in Toronto.
Keyword: pancreatic cancer, chromothripsis, polyploidy, metastasis, precancer, gene expression profile, single-cell genomics, clonal heterogeneity and evolution, single-cell/low cell input DNA/RNA sequencing, general lab equipment

Project Title: Contribution of Environmental Chemicals to Beta Cell Dysfunction and Death in Diabetes
Project Description: The Bruin lab investigates the mechanisms underlying pancreatic β-cell loss and dysfunction in patients with diabetes, a growing health crisis in Ontario. The fully automated live-cell, high-content imaging suite is essential for high resolution imaging of fixed tissues, and screening studies to identify β-cell toxins.

Project Title: Novel Mechanisms of Heart Failure: Discovery to Translation
Project Description: Drs. Fish and Billia will use the requested equipment to identify new blood biomarkers for heart failure that will enable early detection of the disease. They will also develop innovative therapeutic approaches to repair damaged heart muscle cells and prevent harmful inflammation involved in the disease.
Keyword: cardiovascular disease, heart failure, endothelium, gene expression, microRNA, cell cycle control, cancer, regenerative medicine, biomarkers, live-cell imaging, qPCR, particle characterization, cardiovascular physiology

Project Title: Microultrasound for Diagnosis and Image-Guided Intervention
Project Description: The goal of the proposed research is to develop new miniature ultrasound (US) probes and advance US beamforming technologies to achieve optimal high-resolution imaging that would enhance image guidance and thus diagnosis and intervention of diseases such as esophageal cancer.
Keyword: Ultrasound, Imaging, Miniaturisation, Transducer Array, Imaging systems, transducer fabrication equipment, device characterisation

Project Title: Pedestrian Behaviour Lab: Street-crossing Simulator to Study Risk Factors and Training System for Injury Prevention
Project Description: Unintentional injury is the leading cause of death for Canadian children and motor-vehicle pedestrian injury is the single greatest issue for school children. Using virtual reality technology the PI will study risk factors for injury and test a behavioural intervention program to improve children's crossing skills.

Project Title: Nanotechnology Enhanced Multifunctional Carbon Fiber Reinforced Polymer Space Structures
Project Description: This project will develop a new cost-effective manufacturing technology to make multifunctional carbon fiber reinforced polymer composites that posses non-structural properties by adding carbon nanotubes for spacecraft structure. It will be highly adaptive to existing manufacturing processes and infrastructure.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Investigate How to Make Children Critical Consumers of Information
Project Description: This research program will deliver critical insights into how children evaluate and acquire knowledge from digital and online information sources. It investigates how and why children integrate reliable and non-reliable sources to make intelligent decisions about online content.

Project Title: Materials Characterization System for Developing and Testing Self-sensing Cementitious Composites
Project Description: This research focuses on developing self-sensing cementitious materials used as sensors for monitoring concrete structures. The sensors developed in this research can be embedded in the structure for local sensing or applied as an overlay or "sensing skin" to spatially map strains and defects.
Keyword: Structural Health Monitoring, Sensors, Cementitious Composites, Self-sensing, Damage Detection, Multifunctional Materials, Nanocomposite, Mixing, Loading, Environmental Conditions, Corrosion, Strain, Resistivity

Project Title: Translational Emotion Science and Youth Well-being
Project Description: Dr. Thomassin studies youth emotion skills and applies rigorous, multi-method approaches to understanding the emotion-physiology-behaviour dynamics present in family interactions and psychotherapy. She aims to personalize youth psychotherapies to enhance their effectiveness.

Project Title: Preclinical Investigation of Novel Therapies for Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia
Project Description: Advanced technologies to measure lung structure (known as “unbiased stereology”) are essential to characterize abnormalities of the lung and to quantify effects of therapies. The objective of this application is to create the only Canadian stereology facility dedicated to study of the developing lung.

Project Title: Neural Control of Reward Seeking and Behavioural Control
Project Description: This project will investigate the neural mechanisms that underlie the detection and encoding of predictive information. This work will improve understanding of both the neural circuits that control normal decision-making and the ways in which these circuits are altered in mental health disorders.
Keyword:
animal behaviour, instrumental learning, Pavlovian learning, decision-making,
behavioural control, behavioural testing, optogenetics, electrophysiology, histology

Project Title: Cell Therapy for Organ Repair, Restore, Regenerate and Support (COR3S)
Project Description: Through a vital upgrade of the Krembil Regenerative Cell Facility (KRCF), we will study regenerative cell therapies for important, costly, and morbid conditions, like diabetes, myocardial infarction and sepsis. We aim to develop novel therapeutic options for patients by conducting “first-in-human” trials.
Keyword: regenerative therapy, cardiovascular disease, cell manufacturing, complications of diabetes mellitus, sepsis, diabetic nephropathy, clean room technology, good manufacturing practice, cell production facility

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Unbiased Identification of Environmental Chemicals and their Protein Targets
Project Description: Prof. Peng seeks to deconvolute the chemical components of environmental mixtures and their toxic pathways, by developing untargeted chemical analysis and chemical proteomics assays. This knowledge will enable to manage health risks of environmental pollutants in an unbiased fashion.
Keyword: untargeted chemical analysis, chemical proteomics, toxic mechanism, database, mass spectrometry, High-resolution mas spectrometry, HPLC, n-LC, Oribitrap

Project Title: Microbial Interactions with Food Components and the Gut Microbiota During Digestion
Project Description: This platform for microbial community modelling in food and the gut will lead to the design of new functional foods and provide evidence-based support for modulation of the gut microbiota through food components, aiming towards improved health and food safety outcomes as well as reduced food waste.

Project Title: Surface Characterization Laboratory
Project Description: This proposal aims to create the Surface Characterization Laboratory (SCL) - a core research platform to collaborate and develop novel innovative "smart" materials with advanced performance and reduced cost for environmental sensing, catalysis, energy applications, and molecular electronics.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: The CardioLink Research Platform: Innovations in Cardiovascular Surgery & Cardiometabolic Care
Project Description: CardioLink is a research platform in Cardiovascular medicine whose mission is to improve the lives of patients who undergo or are at risk of requiring heart or vascular surgery through rigorous clinical trials. To enable high quality a trial, we request an advanced electronic data capture system to collect, manage, validate and process clinical trial data.
Keyword: Cardiovascular disease, Surgery, Vascular disease, Diabetes, Clinical Trials, Electronic Data Capture solution (software/hardware), Data Management

Project Title: Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting for Muscle Cell Characterization and Purification
Project Description: The proposal will investigate the fundamental molecular and cellular mechanisms that control muscle development and differentiation, and changes associated with disease (aging, cancer, heart disease).  The research will focus on the roles of transcription factors in regulating muscle growth and development.

Project Title: Investigation of Mechanisms Responsible for Diabetes and Heart Failure
Project Description: Our studies will provide new knowledge on mechanisms of obesity-related immunometabolic dysfunction, known to cause diabetes and heart failure. This new knowledge will advance both diagnostic and therapeutic opportunities.

Project Title: Immersive Storytelling Lab
Project Description: The Immersive Storytelling Lab at York University supports globally relevant content creation and technology innovation at the intersection of augmented reality and the moving image, enhancing Ontario's global presence in the area of immersive digital storytelling and AR.

Project Title: Establishment of the Functional Organic Materials Research Centre
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will create a world-class interdisciplinary Functional Organic Materials Research Center, leading to new innovative materials for use in wearable electronics, "smart" drug-delivery technologies, for the consumer goods market, and biomedicine.

Project Title: A Molecular Immunology Laboratory to Elucidate the Mechanisms of Immune Regulation Following Exercise
Project Description: Dr. Abdul Sater’s research program is focused on understanding the mechanisms through which various physical activity patterns shape the inflammatory response, the identification of novel biomarkers of effective training, and the prevention of autoimmune diseases in genetically susceptible individuals.

Project Title: Developmental Epigenetics
Project Description: Dr. Ramalho-Santos is a world recognized expert in Developmental Epigenetics & will create new means to assess how the environment shapes embryonic development to impact health in later life. His findings hold great promise for improving fertility, pregnancy outcomes & health in Ontario & beyond.
Keyword: Embryonic development, epigenomics, genomics, reproductive health,pluripotency, stem cells, chromatin biology, gene regulation, regenerativemedicine, Ultra-long read DNA and RNA sequencing, transposons, single-cell analyses

Project Title: Loyalist College Equipped to Support Business Innovation in the Natural Product and Cannabis Industry
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to expand the Applied Research Centre for Natural Products and Medical Cannabis at Loyalist College with industry-relevant infrastructure, providing a hub for college-industry partnerships, experiential learning opportunities and business innovation.

Project Title: Sustainable Chemicals and Processes Research
Project Description: Through this ORF request, Lambton College will expand its laboratory capacity for sustainable chemicals and process research in its three research centres to increase its ability to support the development and commercialization of sustainable materials, chemicals and processes.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 006 - Stream 1

Project Title: Mining Centric Research Innovation Hub
Project Description: To enhance Northern College’s capacity of performing mining centric applied research through the establishment of the Innovation Hub to support the needs of our communities by providing research and development opportunities for the betterment of Northern Ontario’s economy and beyond.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 006 - Stream 1
Lead Research Institution: Northern College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: Mining, Mineral Exploration, Metallurgy, Technology Development, Mining Supply, Northern Ontario Economic Development, HQP Training, Business Improvement

Project Description: Investment in the Centre for Advanced Research and Innovation in Biotechnology (CARIB) will increase industrial applied research and innovation activities and bridge critical gaps in the agri-food production sector. Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 006 - Stream 1

Project Title: Advanced Recycling Technologies Research Lab for Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE): The WEEE Pilot Plant
Project Description: Conestoga College is a national leader of research and innovation in advanced recycling technologies for waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) - a strategic area of research focus for Waterloo Region, which is recognized as Canada’s innovation capital for technology and advanced manufacturing.

Project Title: Creation of the Centre of Expertise in Smart Prototyping (CEPI)
Project Description: La Cité désire développer de nouvelles installations de recherche pour soutenir les entreprises privées de l’Ontario à développer des prototypes de produits en mobilité, en villes intelligentes et en santé par l’aménagement de laboratoire de recherche en usinage, en prototypage, et en intelligence artificielle.

Project Title: Canadian Extrustion Research Laboratory (CERL)
Project Description: Through this ORF request, Lambton College will increase its material development capacity establishing the “Canadian Extrusion Research Laboratory” to become a provincial and national hub for material development projects.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 007 Stream 1

Project Title: Virtual Humans and the Creative Industries
Project Description: The integrated infrastructure will enable innovation support focused on believable computer-generated characters within all types of screen-based entertainment, providing a global competitive advantage for Ontario companies within significant existing and emerging markets.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 007 Stream 1
Keyword: virtual humans, cinema, virtual production, virtual/augmented reality, entertainment applications, user experience, artificial intelligence

Project Title: Secure Digital Supply Chain
Project Description: As businesses digitize and become increasingly data-driven, a secure digital supply chain is critical to maintaining Ontario’s competitiveness.  Industry-driven research enabled by this proposal will result in technology enhancements leading to improved productivity, security, and market expansion.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 007 Stream 2
Lead Research Institution: Conestoga College Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning
Keyword: Supply chain technology, digitization, cybersecurity, logistics, transportation, digital warehouse, visualization, information systems, movement of goods

Project Title: Sensors and Communication Technologies for Industrial Internet of Things Applications
Project Description: Fleming College will create an Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) deployment lab, retrofitting two existing spaces to create a clean room and a lab solely dedicated to sensors and IIoT applied research to develop innovative communication technologies and sensors for multiple sectors and industries.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 007 Stream 2
Keyword: Wireless communications, networking, telegram splitting, Industrial Internet of Things, sensors, data analytics, smart devices, edge computing, low-power wide-area network, technology integration

Project Title: Centre for Innovative Aquaculture Production
Project Description: Fleming College will create a Centre for Innovative Aquaculture Production on our Frost Campus in Lindsay. The new dedicated research facility will expand our capacity to engage in exceptional applied research that better meets the needs of the provincial and national aquaculture sectors.
Round: College Industry Innovation Fund - Round 007 Stream 2
Keyword: Aquaculture, fish production, shrimp production, nutrition, food additives, feed conversion ratio, hatchery technology, feeding strategy, fish health, aquaponics

Project Title: Infrastructure for the Study of Microsporidia and the Co-Evolution of Host-Pathogen Interactions
Project Description:
My research will investigate the molecular basis of host-pathogen interactions. Using the simple
roundworm, we will study how the ubiquitous intracellular pathogen microsporidia is able to infect and
proliferate inside of hosts, which will reveal mechanisms of parasite pathogenesis.

Project Title: Multimodal Stimulated Raman Microscopy Laboratory
Project Description: There is a world-wide need for optical microscopies having no added labels or stains. We propose to build a Multimodal Stimulated Raman Microscopy lab to lead the world in next-generation label-free, chemical-specific optical imaging. We strategically target applications in Brain Health and Mineralogy.

Project Title: Ambient Intelligence and Interaction: Sensing, Analysis, and Actuation
Project Description: The Ambient Intelligence and Interaction Lab will develop methods for smart homes and smart vehicles to ambiently monitor users via sensing and wearable technologies, understand the physical and mental states of users, and respond through dynamic actuation of elements within the smart environment.

Project Title: Liquid Metal Engineering of Lightweight High Strength Low Alloy Steels and Aluminum-Zinc Alloys
Project Description: The casting of engineering metals forms the base of Ontario’s manufacturing economy. The requested infrastructure will enable the research team to examine the formation of structure and defects in high-strength Al and steel castings at the microscale and develop simulations to improve their castability.

Project Title: Synaptic, Cellular and Circuit Mechanisms Underlying the Cortical Control of the Optokinetic Reflex
Project Description: The neocortex of mammals has an amazing capability of adaptively modulating brainstem-mediated innate reflexes. I will combine functional imaging, electrophysiology, circuit manipulation and behavioral assay to uncover synaptic, cellular and circuit mechanisms underlying the cortical control of reflexes.

Project Title: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss and Brain Plasticity
Project Description: Using a state-of-the-art brain imaging system coupled with complex behavioural testing in genetically-modified mice, the requested infrastructure will enable us to uncover the cellular mechanisms that cause altered sensory-perception following loud noise exposure and hearing loss.

Project Title: A Viral Pathogenesis Laboratory for the Study of HIV Disease and Host Immunity
Project Description: Using a combination of cellular analysis and virus infection assays, Dr. Guzzo’s research will identify novel interactions between immune cell proteins and the outer HIV virus coat, discovering new vulnerabilities on the virus that can lead to the development of novel HIV therapeutics.

Project Title: Terahertz Technologies for the Detection of Microbes, Allergens, and Foreign Objects in Food Products
Project Description: The requested equipment will enable University of Guelph researchers to introduce key innovations in terahertz spectral imaging that will significantly improve microbe/allergen and foreign object detection in foods compared to available methods, reducing the number of Ontarians affected by foodborne illness.

Project Title: Linked Culture Lab
Project Description: The Linked Culture Lab will be a world-class facility for the production of Humanities and Social Science linked data. As the Web grows users need linked data, the connective tissue between digitized resources, in order to readily sort and synthesize vast amounts of authoritative information.

Project Title: Adaptable Liquid Chromatography System for Online and Offline Analysis of Trace Atmospheric Water-Soluble Compounds
Project Description: Dr. Young’s research program uses and develops novel analytical techniques targeting critical issues in environmental chemistry. A unique, state-of-the-science adaptable liquid chromatography will allow diverse innovative approaches to problems in pollutant fate, urban air quality, and climate change.

Project Title: High Dimensional Single Cell Immuno-Analytic Platforms for Deciphering Immune Complexity in Health and Disease
Project Description: Immune-mediated diseases such as asthma, rheumatoid arthritis and Type 1 diabetes collectively affect 10% of Ontarians. We will use the requested infrastructure to identify new biomarkers to enable early detection and novel individualized treatments for these diseases.

Project Title: Understanding the Role of Dipeptidyl Peptidase 4 in Type 2 Diabetes and Cardiovascular Disease
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to address the clinical problem of type 2 diabetes and the underlying accelerated risk for death and complications from cardiovascular disease. Identification of novel dipeptidyl peptidase 4 substrates will lead to new therapeutic targets or biomarkers for patients at risk.

Project Title: A Smart Big Data Analytics and Knowledge Management Framework
Project Description: The BAM lab will build a smart framework to address real-time processing and storage of multi-modal big data.  The framework will learn to create data profiles, select and execute workflows to extract knowledge, and create hierarchical knowledge graphs with indexing for efficient knowledge retrieval.

Project Title: The Biological Signatures of Clinical Progression in Bipolar Disorder
Project Description: The aim of this project is to develop a multimodal predictive signature of mood episode relapse using machine learning algorithms coupled with blood biomarkers and clinical data.

Project Title: Recording and Manipulating Brain Circuits with Light
Project Description: During a stroke, the ability of brain cells to function normally is impaired by a blockage or a rupture of a blood vessel within the brain. This project will bring together technologies that will allow us to measure the impact of small strokes, called microinfarcts on blood flow and brain function.

Project Title: Social Interaction, Language and Culture Laboratory (SILC Lab)
Project Description: The proposed Social Interaction, Language and Culture Laboratory (SILC Lab) supports research on how multilinguals navigate intercultural encounters. High-quality video recording, storage, and analysis of interaction, will further our understanding of the interactional skills migrants need to thrive in advanced economies.

Project Title: High Resolution Mass Spectrometry for Longitudinal Personalized Metabolomics Profiling
Project Description: This proposal aims to create a novel method based on mass spectrometry to measure thousands of molecules in human blood plasma within a single experiment. The project will use a next-generation instrument to support research in personalized medicine and will help to devise tailored therapies.

Project Title: High-Resolution Mapping of Functional Genomic Elements in Spinal Motor Neurons
Project Description: This project aims to understand how genes in embryonic stem cells are regulated during neuronal development associated with human health and disease. This research will benefit Ontarians by leading to more efficient stem cell programming strategies for regenerative medicine and disease modelling.

Project Title: The Tissue Engineering for Advanced Medicine (TEAM) Lab: A Platform for Precision Prevention, Diagnosis, and Medicine
Project Description: We propose to create the Tissue Engineering for Advanced Medicine (TEAM) Lab to push forward a precision prevention, diagnosis, and medicine approach that could directly impact the lives of 3 million Canadians with respiratory disease by optimizing therapeutic management.

Project Title: Facility for Assessing the Fire Resiliency of Building Materials
Project Description: This proposal outlines the equipment necessary to establish a novel, and unique to Ontario, laboratory at York University that will focus on developing fire safe, innovative and sustainable materials for use in our built infrastructure.

Project Title: Knowledge Syntheses and Clinical Trials of Important Food Sources of Sugars and Cardiometabolic Health
Project Description: There is an urgent need to develop prevention strategies for obesity and diabetes in Ontario. We propose to conduct a series of high quality systematic reviews and meta-analyses of the role of food sources of sugars and randomized controlled trials of sugar reduction strategies targeting sugar-sweetened beverages in the prevention of obesity, diabetes, and their complications.

Project Title: Metabolic Vulnerabilities in Cancer
Project Description: Cancer cells generate energy differently than normal cells. Dr. St-Pierre’s research is focused on identifying metabolic networks that drive the progression of poor outcome cancers, particularly breast cancers, to develop novel metabolic therapies to be used either alone or in combination with other anti-cancer drugs.

Project Title: Developing Integrative Simulation-Based Research on Social Work Education & Practice
Project Description: This project will be the first in Ontario to explore the effectiveness of both face-to-face and technology-enhanced (e.g., AI) simulation for social work education while also using simulation as a research methodology to explore complex elements of social work practice.

Project Title: Digital Participatory Research and Physical Cultures Lab
Project Description: This application is for funds to obtain equipment for a Digital Participatory Research and Physical Cultures Lab (DPRPCL) at York University, and presents an opportunity to engage and coordinate stakeholders in DPR around physical cultural studies, sport for social justice, health and human rights.

Project Title: Biofilm Engineering and Resource Recovery Laboratory
Project Description: The objectives of this research are to develop new processes and technologies to: (1) make wastewater treatment plants energy efficient; (2) enhance energy recovery from wastewater; and (3) develop dynamic process and energy models of such systems.

Project Title: The Centre for Multimodal Sensorimotor and Pain Research
Project Description: The Centre for Multimodal Sensorimotor and Pain Research will bring together basic scientists and clinicians to investigate how pain is represented in the brains of healthy individuals and those with chronic pain to develop new targeted treatment strategies for chronic pain.

Project Title: Oxygen is Poison – How Incorrect Modelling of the Human Microenvironment Has Impeded Paediatric Research
Project Description:
By obtaining the latest infrastructure for hypoxic cell culture, and cell and tumour imaging, researchers
throughout Ontario will be able to generate innovative research models, make important disease
discoveries, and develop novel therapies that provide better outcomes for Ontarians and their families.

Project Title: Neural and Physiological Correlates of Bilingual Development Across the Life-Span
Project Description: The overarching goal of the proposed research program is to understand the typical brain and physiological patterns of monolingual and bilingual acquisition and to understand which patterns are associated with atypical language acquisition in infants, children, and adults.

Project Title: Digital Design Research Hub- Landscape Architecture-Innovations in Landscape Architecture
Project Description: The Digital Design Research Hub (DDRH), led by Dr. Nadia Amoroso at the University of Guelph, will develop new “modes” of 3D data visualizations, as visual means to expose the ‘unseen elements’ of the landscape, and generate new instrumentations, as 3D frameworks, to guide the end-user’s design decisions, and increase productivity in planning development in Ontario.

Project Title:
Integration of Long-Term Data and Experimental Manipulation to Study Lifehistory
Evolution under Rapid Climate Warming
Project Description: Climate change has resulted in warmer environments and longer growing seasons. The effects of warming on cold-blooded vertebrates must be understood by integrating long-term monitoring with experiments. Understanding these impacts will help conserve and manage imperiled species in Ontario.

Project Title: Expanding the Chemistry of DNA
Project Description: The proposed project will develop high-throughput screening technologies based on DNA encoding, which will facilitate the rapid discovery of novel therapeutics and diagnostic for biomedical research. The technologies will also enable cleaner methods for screening of small-molecule catalysts for synthesis.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Advanced Structure and Spectroscopic Studies of G-Protein- Coupled Receptors
Project Description: 40% of drugs target a class of membrane protein receptors called GPCRs. The requested infrastructure will allow the Prosser lab to develop an integrated initiative using NMR and other biophysical methods to study the molecular underpinnings of drug action on the adenosine and dopamine GPCRs.

Project Title:
Facilitating the Resilience of Sexual and Gender Minority Youth: An Infrastructure to Leverage Research and Technology
Infrastructure to Leverage Research and Technology
Project Description:
This proposed Digital Resilience Multi-Media Laboratory will develop cutting-edge digital technology
tools for research and will innovate technologically-enhanced interventions designed to improve the
resilience of Gender and Sexual Minority Youth (GSMY) in Ontario and across Canada.

Project Title: Improving Sustainability of Urban Infrastructure Systems
Project Description: In order to guide urban infrastructure decisions, the PIs will use a systems approach to provide a detailed assessment of Toronto’s transport infrastructure and analyze the greenhouse gas emissions of the entire region. These models will investigate and incorporate uncertainty and indirect emissions.

Project Title: Imaging and Electrophysiology Equipment for Multi-Neuron Stimulation and Recording
Project Description: Dr. Prescott studies how pain signals are normally processed by the nervous system and how disrupted processing leads to chronic pain. The requested infrastructure will transform his research by enabling multi-neuron stimulation and recording. This research is crucial for the 1 in 10 Ontarians living with chronic pain.

Project Title: Collaborative Mobile Interaction Workshop
Project Description: The goal of this proposal is to create the Collaborative Mobile Interaction Workshop, an innovative space in which new mobile device technologies will be utilized to develop interactive collaborative experiences to support both marginalized communities and first-world tech-enabled environments.

Project Title: From Circuits to Behaviour in Health and Disease
Project Description: The aim of this research is to improve treatments and outcomes for Ontarians with neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric disease by using state-of-the-art tools to improve our understanding of how specific brain cells and circuits relate to specific aspects of cognition including memory, attention and motivation.

Project Title: Skin Immune Cells and Pathogens Facility (SPF)
Project Description: Our project will lead to novel insights on the roles of key immune cells present in the skin and mucosal surfaces called dendritic cells (DC). We will determine the role of DC in infections such as HIV-1 and skin diseases such as eczema and psoriasis, which will lead to novel therapeutic approaches.

Project Title: Bacteriophages & the Gut Microbiome
Project Description: The bacterial population in your gut keeps you healthy but, if disrupted, can lead to diseases such as colitis, obesity and depression. In the gut there are many viruses that infect bacteria, to unknown effect. This research aims to identify the roles these viruses play shaping microbial populations within humans.

Project Title: A Real-Time Digital Simulator to Develop Resilience-Oriented Protection Systems for Power Grids
Project Description: The frequency and diversity of large disturbances that can disrupt normal operation of power systems have increased. Protection systems of the grid play a major role in preventing disruptions. The proposed research will develop next-generation protection systems to improve the resilience to disruptive events.

Project Title: Computational Neuroimaging
Project Description: Major challenges in neurosurgery are precisely localizing the region of the brain to target and determining who will benefit from surgery.  Dr. Khan’s research program in computational neuroimaging is investigating new ways to analyze brain images to aid planning and guidance of surgical interventions.

Project Title: Elucidating the Role of Effector Proteins in Promoting Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Symbiosis
Project Description: The objective of this project is to identify novel fungal proteins that play important roles in regulating the colonization of roots during the beneficial symbiosis that occurs between plants and mycorrhizal fungi. This project seeks to enhance the productivity of crops while reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.

Project Title: Chemical Strategies to Modulate Ternary Complex Protein Assembly
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to develop synthetic small molecule approaches to cancer immunotherapy. It specifically describes the development of new chemically reactive small molecules that link antibodies and immune effector cells to cancer cells through irreversible covalent bonds.

Project Title: Advanced Flow Management System for Development of Smart Sensor Systems and E-nose Mapping
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will create a world-class multi-disciplinary research program that facilitates the move toward early stage detection of biomarkers by developing next-gen smart sensor systems that revolutionize clinical routine practices, environmental monitoring and greenhouse product protections.

Project Title: Nanophotonic Neuromorphic Computing
Project Description: The proposed brain-inspired processors will fundamentally leverage the strengths of nanophotonic devices with neuromorphic architectures, to outperform current microelectronics in energy efficiency and computational speeds, which currently limit hardware scaling in digital electronics.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Study of DNA Repair: Biology, Target Validation and Drug Development
Project Description: The primary objective of this proposal is to perform synthetic lethality screens in human cell lines to identify cancer vulnerabilities that can be pursued in target validation and in early stage drug discovery studies.

Project Title: Interdisciplinary Research Centre for Sexual and Gender Minority Health
Project Description: The objective is to develop a research and training Centre at the Dalla Lana School of Public Health, UofT, to conduct community-based research with sexual minority and gender diverse populations (SMGDP). The Centre’s research will address sexual and mental health inequities among SMGDP.

Project Title: Canada Research Chair in Creative Innovation and Leadership
Project Description: Creativity is vital for individuals, business and economic success, and innovation. This research will explore how creativity can be fostered through work across three core themes: (1) Platforms for creativity; (2) Creative identities and leadership; and (3) Public understanding of creative practice.

Project Title: TI-STAR: A Tracking Detector for Experiments with Exotic Nuclei at TRIUMF
Project Description: Dr. Dennis Muecher requires the requested infrastructure to assemble a state-of-the-art silicon detector, which will be merged with equipment at Canada’s premier physics lab. It will enable him to answer long-standing questions in nuclear physics, including: how elements on Earth heavier than iron are formed.

Project Title: Catalyst Nanomaterial Synthesis, Characterization and Device Integration Suite for Sustainable Energy Technologies
Project Description: This research develops nanomaterial catalysts and electrochemical devices that use renewable electricity (wind, solar, hydro) to convert CO2 into fuels and chemicals (artificial photosynthesis), or use hydrogen for zero-emission vehicles (fuel cells) to achieve sustainability of our energy economy.

Project Title: Mass Spectrometry for Dissecting Phosphonate Tailoring of Bacterial Cell Surfaces
Project Description: Mass spectrometry sensitively detects molecules and measures their mass. This will allow us to understand how bacteria make phosphonates (molecules with a carbon-phosphorus bond), which will enable discovery of new biocatalysts for green chemistry as well as new antivirulence strategies.

Project Title: Impact Earth Laboratory
Project Description: This project aims to use portable instrumentation to gather chemical and mineralogical data to help us understand how rocks are melted during impact cratering events, how impact generated hydrothermal systems form, and how ore deposits form at impact craters.

Project Title: Laboratory for Epithelial Ecophysiology and Molecular Biology
Project Description: The goal of the Laboratory for Epithelial Ecophysiology and Molecular Biology is to build a clear and detailed understanding of the molecular causes of cold injury in insects, and to understand the ability of insects to drastically alter their thermal tolerance and survive extreme temperatures.

Project Title: Synthetic Medicinal Chemistry Platform for Antimicrobial Drug Discovery
Project Description: This research aims to develop new antibiotics to treat life-threatening drug-resistant microbial infections by conducting medicinal chemistry projects consisting of the design, synthesis, and evaluation of new antimicrobial drug-candidate compounds based on leads identified by McMaster’s microbiologists.

Project Title: Laboratory for the Study of Neuronal Development and Plasticity in Health and Disease
Project Description: Brain disorders pose a heavy burden on society. Current therapies largely target symptoms and not the underlying disease mechanisms. This project will elucidate the fundamental pathways regulating neuronal growth and plasticity in order to identify novel targets for the development of better therapies.

Project Title: Laboratory for Experimental X-ray Imaging (LEXI)
Project Description: Dr. Tanguay’s objective is to develop innovative X-ray imaging techniques for visualizing respiratory and cardiovascular disease. The results of his research will increase the sensitivity of X-ray imaging, reducing its negative effects and extending its application to new diagnostic applications.

Project Title: Canada Research Chair in Health Design
Project Description: This research program addresses designing effective information tools, particularly in the representation of information in specific medical contexts, how users interact with data for complex tasks, and how to present information for dynamic situations.
Lead Research Institution: Ontario College of Art and Design University

Project Title: Deciphering Metabolic Plasticity and Remodelling in the Normal and Diseased Heart
Project Description: This project will enable the understanding of how the heart regulates its metabolic function and utilizes energy substrates in normal and diseased conditions. This finding will be further tested using a lifestyle and dietary metabolic intervention in order to prevent or treat heart diseases.

Project Title: Predictive Immune Monitoring Approaches for Precision Cancer Chemo-Immunotherapy
Project Description: We aim to improve cancer immunotherapy outcomes by examining genetic features of tumours that dictate anti-tumour immune response, for the optimal design of patient specific treatment combinations and biomarkers for clinical monitoring of response to chemo-immunotherapy.

Project Title: Personalized Genomics of Neurodegeneration
Project Description: Neurodegenerative disorders pose a devastating medical, emotional and economic burden to Ontarians. The Rousseaux lab strives to overcome such hurdles by using new genome editing and genome-wide screening technologies to develop new therapeutic avenues.

Project Title: Establishment Of The Memory, Action, & Cognition Laboratory for the Study of Human Sensorimotor Neuroscience
Project Description: The goal of the proposed research program, which combines behavioural, neurophysiological, and computational approaches, is to develop a better understanding of how information about motor errors shape our decisions during human sensorimotor learning.

Project Title: Centre for the Study of Brain, Performance, & Music Creation (Centre BPMC)
Project Description: Thaut, Huang, and Britton propose a collaborative research-creation program that will examine the motor, cognitive, and creative mechanisms underlying performance practice in music. This project will integrate performance data with data on underlying brain mechanisms in performance and creation.

Project Title: Early Rehabilitation to Improve Patient-Centered Outcomes in Critical Care
Project Description: The proposed research focuses on effective and creative methods of physiotherapy to help patients in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) stay as strong as possible.  Infrastructure from this application will enable study of the impact of early physiotherapy in the ICU on function and quality of life in ICU survivors.

Project Title: Towards Personalizing Arthritis Medicine
Project Description: The University Health Network is requesting two new pieces of equipment to enable the proposed research programs of Drs. Nigil Haroon and Joan Wither. Both researchers will lead innovative research programs to improve the care and clinical management of two debilitating forms of arthritis.

Project Title: The Role and Fate of Inorganics in the Industrial Processing of Woody Biomass
Project Description: The requested infrastructure is needed to help the current and future pulping industry use energy and recover pulping chemicals more efficiently. It will be used to generate new knowledge on the chemistry of heat transfer fouling, including the impact of new technologies in the pulping industry.

Project Title: Multimodal Assessment of Human Cognition in Laboratory and Naturalistic Settings (Maclan)
Project Description: The goal of the MACLaN lab will be to explore mechanisms supporting successful learning and achievement of expertise. The facilities will be used to study linguistic expertise and deficits (Jouravlev), learning in STEM (Muldner), and effects of workload on performance (Herdman).

Project Title: NMR Project
Project Description: For the faculty and HQP at Lakehead University, a Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer is a valuable resource that facilitates a number of high-quality research projects, many of which have direct economic, environmental and/or health benefits to Ontario and Canada. With access to this infrastructure, Dr. Pedram Fatehi will study the fundamentals associated with lignin reactions and characterizations that are essential in developing processes for producing lignin-based dispersants and flocculants. Additionally, an NMR spectrometer will enable Dr. Stephen Kinrade to progress his studies into the fundamental chemistry and biochemistry of aqueous silicon, which has widespread applications in the fields of material science, health, agriculture, and the environment.

Project Title: Detecting Interstellar Meteoroids with Radar
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure is a modern, high power solid state radar transmitter for the Canadian Meteor Orbit Radar (CMOR). This will facilitate detection of interstellar meteoroids in addition to increasing CMOR’s sensitivity to weaker meteor showers and slower meteoroids.

Project Title: Super-Resolution Live-Cell Imaging System for Membrane Contact Site Dynamics
Project Description: Disrupted communication between organelles leads to diseases. The overall goal of this research is to understand the molecular mechanisms used by organelles to communicate with each other, using the requested highly sensitive super-resolution microscopy system for live-cell imaging.

Project Title: G-Protein Coupled Receptor Signalling in Health and Disease
Project Description: A suite of equipment that will enable us to monitor G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) signaling in cells, tissue and live animals is requested here. This work will have an impact on developing novel drugs for cardiovascular diseases, colitis, arthritis and cancer to benefit patients in Ontario and beyond.

Project Title: Spectroelectrochemical Analysis of Heterogeneous Electrocatalysts
Project Description: The direct use of electricity to drive chemical transformations can offset the intermittency issues inherent in renewable energy sources, maximizing the value of renewable infrastructure. This project will study catalysts for such reactions in an effort to expand the scope of electrochemical synthesis.

Project Title: Neurocognitive Development of Sensory Processing in Autism
Project Description: This project aims to (1) understand the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying the development of sensory perception, (2) explore how these processes differ in children with autism, and (3) leverage the plasticity of these underlying neural systems to improve cognition and clinical outcomes in autism.

Project Title: Using Systems Biology to Investigate Leukemic and Normal Stem Cells
Project Description: This work will investigate intra and extracellular signalling pathways within the bone marrow that control normal and cancer stem cell maintenance. Our work will both investigate normal healthy stem cells as they age, and how malfunctions in cell signalling events eventually contribute to leukaemogenesis.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Characterize Capillarity and Wetting for Under-Liquid Systems
Project Description: This project will advance methods to characterize the wetting properties of any material, in any environment. New understanding of under-liquid dynamics will drive materials development for myriad applications, from water repellant surfaces (e.g., for windshields) to anti-fouling coatings (e.g., for ships).

Project Title: Legal Text Mining
Project Description: This interdisciplinary project creates an infrastructure for collaborative research at the intersection of law and computer science. It sets up a lab, data hub and server system tailored to the automated analysis of legal texts. It thus facilitates research to make law more accessible and to develop new legal technology.

Project Title: Single-Cell Characterization of Drug Response in Human Cancer Stem Cell Populations
Project Description: Acquisition of the proposed state-of-the-art Spectral Flow Cytometer is essential for multi-parametric biomarker analysis. This instrument will provide unique solutions to gain fundamental understanding of drug response, at the single-cell level, in human cancer stem cells and other rare cell populations.

Project Title: Dark Stars and New Physics from Neutrinos
Project Description: Beyond the Standard Model: employing high precision simulation and statistical searches in astroparticle physics. The Queen’s Astroparticle Theory group will expand the search for dark matter in stars and at colliders, and uncover new physics from the neutrino sector.

Project Title: 3D Network for Immersive Simulation in Healthcare (3DNISH)
Project Description: The 3D Network for Immersive Simulation in Healthcare (3DNISH) lab will combine 3D printing and virtual reality to achieve a cost-effective, portable, highly realistic, multi-sensory learning environment for healthcare practitioners and trainees, resulting in fewer treatment and workplace errors.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Tandem Mass Spectrometry Unit for Examining Xenobiotic Changes to the Lipid Metabolome
Project Description: This proposal requests purchase of a liquid chromatograph tandem mass spectrometer (LC-MS/MS) that will be used to develop a state-of-the-art lipid metabolomics platform to assess the biochemical impact on cellular processes after exposure to environmental factors.

Project Title: Nanocatalyst Characterization and Performance Studies Platform
Project Description: Nanoelectrocatalysis can convert excess atmospheric carbon dioxide into useful chemicals such as feedstocks and pharmaceuticals using surpluses of green electrical energy. This research aims to create a framework for nanocatalyst design to obtain high performing, commercially viable systems.

Project Title: Mitigating Endocrine Metabolic Disease Risk After Spinal Cord Injury
Project Description: This research aims to improve how spinal cord survivors at increased risk of developing endocrine metabolic diseases—such as fractures, diabetes and heart disease—are diagnosed, monitored and treated in the clinic.

Project Title: Understanding the Genomic Architecture of Livestock using Precision Data
Project Description: By associating natural patterns in the genome with observable traits in livestock, Dr. Baes and her team will gain fundamental knowledge about how DNA regulates measurable phenotypes in animals. The goal is to understand how genetics influences health, activity, and metabolic efficiency of farm animals.

Project Title: Sub-diffraction Limit Imaging of Matrix Degradation Machines
Project Description: Using the requested sub-diffraction limit microscope, the applicants will examine how specific components of the molecular machine cooperate to control connective tissue degradation and how their dysregulation contribute to periodontal diseases, fibrosis, and arthritis.

Project Title: Investigating the Genetic and Biochemical Pathways that Regulate Hemostasis
Project Description: This research project will discover new genetic risk factors and biochemical mechanisms for cardiovascular disease. This information will be used to predict disease severity before symptoms occur. New targets will be identified for drug development.

Project Title: Model-Based Acquisitions for Quantitative Magnetic Resonance Imaging
Project Description: A magnetic field camera will be integrated with an ultra high field Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) system to measure field imperfections in real-time during scanning. This will improve accuracy, enabling completely new measurements that will improve the diagnosis and treatment of neurological disorders.

Project Title: Experimental Facility for Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics Research
Project Description: This research aims to develop robust and capable methods for designing and managing the next-generation of industrial robotics - innovations that will help to perform tasks faster, more accurately, and with greater adaptability to changing work assignments and conditions.

Project Title: Bioinformatics Computing Work Station Suite
Project Description: The objective of this research program is to identify unique biomolecules in fish which will be used to non-lethally monitor environmental pollution and other types of stress in Ontario freshwater ecosystems. An online database will be created to share our results with scientists, policy makers, and the public.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Infrastructure for Targeted Isolation of Microbes from the Human Gut Microbiota
Project Description: Modern lifestyles have dramatically reduced the biodiversity of our gut microbial ecosystem.  This project will utilize a high resolution cell sorter to isolate and characterize important microbes that are “missing” from the western microbiome to determine their biological function and guide the development of novel therapeutics.

Project Title: Immersive and Psychophysiological Testing Suite
Project Description: The requested funds will be used to set up an immersive and psychophysiological testing suite for the investigation of embodied and embedded cognition. This equipment will enable basic research investigating the decisional processes governing cognitive offloading and its cognitive consequences.

Project Title: Lung Imaging to Transform Patient Outcomes
Project Description: The overarching goal of this research program is to develop and validate techniques needed to provide a detailed in vivo understanding of COPD and asthma using pulmonary 129Xe MRI intermediate endpoints that can be used to test new treatments, as well as phenotype patients and personalize their care.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Elucidate the Roles and Regulation of Membraneless Organelles in Health and Disease
Project Description: Over a quarter million Ontario residents suffer from neurodegeneration. This proposal aims to develop new treatments by uncovering how membraneless organelles transform into toxic structures and drive neuron death with age. We will achieve this using quantitative microscopy on patient-derived neurons.

Project Title: Maritime Archaeology Research Infrastructure
Project Description: This research infrastructure provides Ontario university faculty and students world-class remote sensing instrumentation for underwater survey. This will assist in the mapping, characterization and protection of marine landscapes and underwater heritage in the Great Lakes and surrounding regions of Ontario.

Project Title: Investigating Mineralizing Processes in Layered Mafic Intrusions Using SEM-based Microtextural and Chemical Analysis
Project Description: The aim of this proposal is to acquire state-of-the-art micro-imaging equipment that will allow us to advance our understanding and improve targeting of exploration for mineralized layers in layered mafic intrusions, such as the chromite and nickel deposits of the Ring of Fire in Ontario.

Project Title: Triple Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer
Project Description: The innovations developed will provide a cost-effective alternative to currently used techniques for medical tests, reducing clinical analysis turnaround times, streamlining processing of biological samples analyses, and providing healthcare professionals with critical test results faster and more accurately.

Project Title: Mechanobiology-Inspired Regenerative Medicine
Project Description: This project aims to develop novel biomaterials to combat the pernicious effects of inflammation in arthritis. A Cell and Tissue Mechanobiology Facility will be established to discover inflammation-resolving molecules that can be incorporated in implants to stimulate cartilage repair.

Project Title: Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy for the Study of the Neural Mechanisms that Support Speech
Project Description: Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) will be used to evaluate brain activity while people speak. fNIRS is a cutting-edge brain imaging technology that will allow us to understand the neural mechanisms that control speech and devise new methods to earlier diagnose and treat speech disorders.

Project Title: INCUBATOR Lab: Advanced Bioart Laboratory and Multimedia Theatre.
Project Description: INCUBATOR Lab, in the School of Creative Arts at the University of Windsor, is a unique research/creation facility that functions as both a biotech laboratory and a multimedia theatre and public art venue where audiences can view living biological artworks through a glass wall.

Project Title: Unpacking the Transition from Suicide Ideation to Attempts in Adolescents
Project Description: Suicide is a devastating global health problem and is the 2nd leading cause of death among Ontarian youth. Determining why adolescents transition from suicidal thoughts to attempts is critical for suicide prevention. The proposed projects will identify novel cognitive and behavioral processes responsible for this in transition youth

Project Title: Infrastructure for a Neuroscience Laboratory Studying Co-occurring Addiction and Mental Illness
Project Description: Substance use occurs commonly in patients with schizophrenia and significantly worsens the disease. Dr. Khokhar’s research at University of Guelph aims to elucidate the neurobiological mechanisms underlying such substance use using rodent models, with an eye toward developing new treatments.

Project Title: Bioarchaeology and Forensics Portable 3D Osteology Scanning
Project Description: The infrastructure consists of 3D scanners and supporting facilities that will be used to create digital models of individual bones, graves, tombs and crime scenes. The infrastructure will be used to study past populations, and to develop best practices for forensic contexts.

Project Title: Astroparticle Theory Laboratory
Project Description: The Queen’s University Astroparticle Theory Laboratory will advance Ontario’s leadership in astroparticle theory and the search for dark matter by facilitating rapid exploration, computation, and international collaboration, as new physics models and search techniques are developed and refined.

Project Title: Driving Innovation: Establishing a Mobile Inclusive Music Theatre Makerspace
Project Description: The Mobile Music Theatre Makerspace will examine ways to bridge the access barrier evident in the arts, providing opportunity for music theatre creation and production in underserved communities. We will examine ways participation enhances artistic skills and well-being for participants and facilitators.

Project Title: Eye Movements and Electrophysiological Activity as Markers of Age-related Cognitive Change
Project Description: My research aims to further our understanding of the cognitive and neural changes that accompany normal human aging. I am requesting an electroencephalography system and eye-tracker that will allow my team to investigate age differences in attention and memory with very precise timing.

Project Title: Agricultural Soil Health Laboratory
Project Description:
This project will:
Characterize relationships between soil microbiomes and C and N cycling using innovative techniques.
Train HQP in advanced technical analysis, interdisciplinary methods, and critical thinking. 
Characterize impacts of East Central Ontario agri-food production systems on soil health indicators.

Project Title: Human Energy Balance and Metabolic Phenotyping Laboratory
Project Description: The acquisition of the requested infrastructure will enable us to move toward our fundamental goal to improve health by interrogating pathways leading to energy imbalance, evaluating their influence on health in adults and children, and developing interventions that lead to energy balance.

Project Title: Development of a Scintillating Bubble Chamber
Project Description: This project supports the ongoing, world-leading research at SNOLAB searching for the nature of dark matter in the universe.  The addition of the new method of detection increases the ability to distinguish signal from background and therefore increases the reach of the dark matter program.

Project Title: Genomic Portal for Polygenic Molecular Maps of the Brain
Project Description: The objective of this project is to build an online tool to show where and when certain genes are used in the brain. This will help us understand brain disease by highlighting specific parts of the brain and developmental times. This information can then be used to target experiments and treatments
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: Elucidating Ion Channel Function for Improved Drug Discovery
Project Description: Errors in protein function cause an array of human disorders. To correct such errors, one must understand protein function in detail. Supercomputers can predict protein motion and illustrate their precise function. The proposed research will use supercomputers to study protein function, leading to improved drug design.

Project Title: Decoding the Heterogeneity of Reactive Astrocytes
Project Description: Reactive astrocytes are a diverse group of cells found in all neurological diseases. This proposal aims to understand the heterogeneity of reactive astrocytes after injury. It will address how they are established, their function and how their diversity influences their response to novel strategies for brain repair.

Project Title: Fault Management Power Electronics Laboratory
Project Description: Ontario’s growing demand for electrical energy leads us to develop advanced technologies to integrate more renewable energy resources and improve system efficiencies. This research program focuses on development of novel reliable and fault-tolerant power converters for high-power applications.

Project Title: Mitochondrial Dynamics and Function in Stem Cells
Project Description: Muscle wasting during aging and in muscular diseases is a major cause of disability in Canada, with no effective treatment. Dr. Khacho aims to uncover the mechanisms regulating muscle stem cell function in order to identify pharmacological agents that enhance muscle stem cell function in aging and disease.

Project Title: Transport Phenomena in Multiphase Reacting Flows for Performance Improvement of Sustainable Energy Systems
Project Description: The proposed research provides insight into transport mechanisms in multiphase reactive flows due to diffusion, convection and conduction at both macroscopic and microscopic scales. Using the 2nd Law of Thermodynamics it identifies losses in systems which, when minimized improve their efficiency.

Project Title: Histological and Functional Photoacoustic Remote Sensing (HF-PARS) Microscopy
Project Description: The proposed program will address the essential needs for a non-contact, non-invasive, safe and accurate technique for imaging oxygen metabolic activity and multi-layered histology-like information for several clinical and pre-clinical applications in the field of oncology and ophthalmology.

Project Title: Visualizing Epigenomics in Real Time
Project Description: Uncovering how the epigenome regulates neural stem cells will be of critical importance for developing cell replacement therapies for neurological disease. This proposal will develop cutting edge technologies for tracking changes in the epigenome, as neural stem cells generate neurons and glia.

Project Title: Metabolic Phenotyping Using in Vivo Indirect Calorimetry
Project Description: My research program examines energy expenditure as it relates to obesity and associated diseases, in mammals, across their lifetime. I use in vivo (live) models and advanced technology to measure changes as they are happening in real time, allowing for non-invasive continuous quantification.

Project Title: New Genomic Technologies to Tackle Fungal Pathogens
Project Description: Pathogenic fungi are a growing health concern and the treatment infections is notoriously challenging. This project will develop CRISPR systems to create genetic mutants in order to explore the mechanisms by which Candida are able to tolerate treatment with antifungal drugs and cause disease.

Project Title: Measurements of Clouds, Aerosols, Forest Fire Smoke, and Volcanic Ash from a Network of Ceilometers
Project Description: The 3 primary objectives of this proposal for a network of 5 ceilometers (laser radars) are: 1) to improve our ability to track forest fire smoke and pollutants, 2) to better understand ozone trends by including profiling information, and 3) to improve our understanding of the formation of clouds and fog.

Project Title: Infrastructure to Elucidate the roles of Mitochondria in Germline and Stem Cell Biology
Project Description: My research uses both fruit flies and human systems to dissect the molecular mechanisms by which mitochondria, the powerhouse of the cell, function within living organisms. This research will help elucidate the role mitochondria play in key biological and disease-relevant processes

Project Title: Platform for Smart Biomaterials
Project Description: The proposed research focuses on developing smart, interactive biomaterials designed specifically to interact with desired biomolecules or cells in their environment, and simultaneously thwart attachment of non-desired entities. Applications include those in wearable devices, biosensing, and biomedical devices.

Project Title: Selective Laser Melting of Reactive/Sensitive Metals for Aerospace, Automotive and Medical Applications
Project Description: The metal 3D printing technology and processing know-how of reactive metals will be enhanced for higher thermal stability and less reactivity in the process. A robust SLM system will be designed and built for this program incorporating innovative laser/laser optics assemblies and build enclosure design.

Project Title: Primate Behavioral Endocrinology Lab
