Project Description: This application is to fund the development of the Primate Behavioral Endocrinology at York University’s Glendon College to contribute to the pressing need to understand how individuals respond to changing physical environments, and how these responses interact with the social environment.

Project Title: Research Innovation Laboratory for Integrated, Secure and Efficient Wireless Communications
Project Description: The proposed facility will provide an exceptional research innovation environment for the integrated design and orchestrated operation of 5th generation (5G) and Internet-of-Things (IoT) wireless networks. New technologies developed will support diverse IoT applications of connected industry and society.

Project Title: Multiscale Mechanics and Additive Manufacturing of New Metallic Materials for Aerospace and Biomedical Applications
Project Description: The proposed research program aims to use novel manufacturing and mechanical testing methods to create and evaluate new metallic materials with desired mechanical properties—especially for aerospace and biomedical applications—that cannot be obtained using conventional techniques.

Project Title: Laser Source for Label-Free Nonlinear Biomaterial Imaging
Project Description: Funding is sought to purchase a dual-output ultrafast laser system that will be used as the primary light source for the development of a new multimodal label-free nonlinear microscopy system. This platform will incorporate new vibrational imaging and multi-harmonic generation microscopy techniques.

Project Title: Ancient and Contemporary Environmental Bioindicators Laboratory (ACEBioLab)
Project Description: Establishment of the “Ancient and Contemporary Environmental Bioindicators Laboratory (ACEBioLab)” at the University of Waterloo (Anthropology) will facilitate innovative research using human teeth to retrospectively and prospectively study how environments impact health.

Project Title: Scalable Systems Software for Next Generation Architectures
Project Description:
The Scalable Systems Software for Next Generation Architectures program will explore systems
software including operating systems, compiler, runtime and application support for future data centers.
This encompasses both scalability and diversity of future computing environments.

Project Title: Study of Disease-Causing Mutations in NMDA Receptor Genes
Project Description: The infrastructure will enable the functional evaluation of mutations that cause neurodevelopmental disorders. This requires equipment to characterize neuron physiology, gene expression, and cognition and will improve treatment by determining the best pharmacotherapy among currently available drugs.

Project Title: Exploration of Pathophysiological Mechanisms Underlying Diabetes and its Related Complications
Project Description: Diabetic complication, including kidney and heart disease, remain extremely comment despite our ability to manage blood sugars through insulin, resulting in death and morbidity. We will explore the mechanism underlying diabetes and it complication to identify novel therapeutic targets.

Project Title: Gas-fluid-mineral Interactions: Implications for Element Cycles and CO2 Storage
Project Description: We will examine the impact of changes in CO2 content in air and the availability of water on reactions that release and take-up nutrients and contaminants. Results of the research will help to develop strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions using natural rock and waste products of mining operations.

Project Title: Investigating the Role of Intracellular Calcium Dynamics on Skeletal Muscle Function in Aged Muscle
Project Description: The proposal aims to identify novel mechanisms of aging-related muscle weakness and fatigue. Cellular and translational research approaches will be directed toward improving muscle function in the elderly by focusing on the role of altered intramuscular calcium handling on muscle strength and fatigability.

Project Title: Characterizing a Neural Basis for Crossmodal Plasticity Following Sensory Loss
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will establish a mechanistic understanding of how the brain is structurally and functionally reorganized following hearing loss. This will provide critical insights into the barriers to successful hearing restoration, and inform interventions that will translate innovation to clinical practice.

Project Title: Uncovering the Function of Glycans: Examining Interactions with their Biological Binding Partners at the Cellular Level
Project Description: Cell-surface carbohydrates (glycans) play a pivotal role in health and disease but understanding how they function is challenging. We will use novel techniques to examine how glycans interact with proteins in cells, providing crucial knowledge needed to uncover the specific biology of these vital biomolecules.

Project Title: Multiphase Processes for Sustainable Energy and Chemicals
Project Description: The project will optimize reaction pathways for converting renewable materials, advance the understanding of transport phenomena via a combined experimental and modeling approach, and design innovative sustainable technologies to convert existing waste streams to value-added products.

Project Title: Laboratory to Study and Combat Antibiotic Resistant Pathogenic Bacteria
Project Description: Antibiotic resistance is a major global health threat. By examining mechanisms of antibiotic efflux in bacteria, as well as the adhesion of bacteria to host cells during infection, Dr. Cox’s research program is exploring two important avenues to develop innovative approaches to combat this growing health crisis.

Project Title: Neuromuscular Genomics and Health Research
Project Description: The goal of this proposal is to understand the molecular mechanisms that cause neuromuscular diseases. This proposal uses a variety of clinical, molecular, and genomic approaches to deliver accurate diagnoses, better care, and targeted therapies for Ontarians with neuromuscular disease.

Project Title: Chemical Mapping of Complex Soft Matter
Project Description: This project aims at visualizing molecules in microstructures built by biopolymer-based nanoparticles and complex food matrices through Confocal Raman Microscopy to understand and steer quality and physicochemical properties, promoting product development and benefitting Ontario’s agri-food sector.

Project Title: Mechanisms Underlying the Optimization of Human Walking
Project Description: The main objective of this proposal is to advance our understanding of the optimization and control of human locomotion, and apply this knowledge to the design of novel rehabilitation strategies and robotic aids for those with mobility impairments.

Project Title: A Computing Patform for Discovery of Predictive Brain Dynamics
Project Description: The objective of this project is to provide a computing platform that enables researchers to fit complex models to measurements of human brain activity, with the goal to discover measures that can be used to predict neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders.

Project Title: Moral Psychology and Global Affairs
Project Description: At a time of constantly-changing social structures, this research investigates the psychology behind social conflict in order to pinpoint practical solutions. This involves: (1) detailing patterns in language and thought behind diverse moral values and judgements, and (2) applying findings with policy in mind.

Project Title: Establishing the Snow and Ice Research Laboratory at Queen’s University
Project Description: The new Snow and Ice Research Laboratory at Queen’s University uses state-of-the-art geophysical and remote sensing techniques to advance our ability to track the evolution of snow and ice in the environment, and assess the sensitivity, stability, and downstream consequences of glacier change in Canada’s North.

Project Title: Gravity of Fundamental Astrophysics Research (GoFAR) Collaboration Lab
Project Description: The proposed Gravity of Fundamental Astrophysics Research (GoFAR) Collaboration Lab will be a state-of-the-art virtual collaboration facility that will support the Canada Excellence Research Chair and the GoFAR team in establishing Toronto as a leading international centre for gravitational research.

Project Title: Establishing High Resolution Facility for Micro-component Dynamic Vibration Analysis
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will facilitate world class multidisciplinary research in developing micro- and nano-systems based ultra-sensitivity and highly-stable motion and orientation smart sensors to enable autonomous navigating in unknown environments.

Project Title: Creating a Living Lab for the Optimization of Green Building Performance
Project Description: This research program will deliver critical insights into the psychology of green building use by its occupants. It investigates how green buildings can meet their operational performance targets both in regard to the impact on the environment and on the wellbeing of the occupants.

Project Title: It’s All About Time: Optimising Infrastructure for Functional Brain Imaging in Children
Project Description: This proposal requests new advanced infrastructure and refurbishment of existing neuroimaging equipment to evolve our innovative studies of cognitive brain function, development, injury and intervention into core features of future therapeutics and precision medicine for children in Ontario.

Project Title: Sustainable Chemical Manufacturing
Project Description: This research proposal, based on catalysis and flow chemistry, will significantly enable chemical production through the development of new synthetic methodology and technology to dramatically reduce the negative environmental impact of the waste streams of the fine chemical manufacturing sector.

Project Title: Development of AML-Relapse Therapeutics (DART)
Project Description: We will develop novel therapies that are designed to treat blood cancers after they return based on specific molecular changes.  These molecular changes will also be used to identify patients who are at risk of having their cancer return after initial therapy.

Project Title: Automated Apparatus for PET Radiopharmaceuticals to Image the Living Human Brain
Project Description: This research program requires new infrastructure to develop cutting-edge radiopharmaceuticals, the enabling tools for medical imaging PET. These tools will allow us to study unexplored parts of the brain tied to psychiatric and neurological disorders with high socioeconomic burden in Ontario and worldwide.
Lead Research Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project Title: High-Throughput Facility for Design, Synthesis and Characterization of Novel Materials for Large-Scale Energy Storage
Project Description: The proposed research aims to find new materials for cathodes and electrolytes that improve lithium-ion battery performance while reducing costs. High-throughput combinatorial synthesis and materials characterization will be combined with machine learning to accelerate the search.

Project Title:
Intelligent Connectivity Lab: Software-Hardware Systems for the Internet of Things
Internet of Things
Project Description: Current wireless network designs cannot meet the future demands imposed by the advent of the Internet of Things (IoT). It is anticipated that 75 billion IoT devices will be installed by 2025. This research addresses the energy and throughput problems of today’s wireless networks for IoT applications.

Project Title: Integrative Physiology Laboratory to Study Sex-Differences During Exercise
Project Description: The aim of the project is to develop a laboratory to study sex-differences during exercise. With the requested equipment, Dr. Dominelli will be able to utilize both whole-body exercise and small muscle mass to comprehensively study sex-specific exercise physiology for improved exercise training.

Project Title: Discovery and Development of Crystalline Radiation Detection Materials
Project Description: We will discover novel crystalline inorganic materials for detecting X- and gamma-rays, and develop crystal growth methods to produce application-specific, environment-friendly radiation detectors based on these materials for applications in astroparticle physics, nuclear safety, security and medical imaging.

Project Title: Developing New Interventions for Breast and Lung Cancer
Project Description: The University of Toronto is requesting new equipment to enable the proposed research programs of Drs. Rama Khokha and Benjamin Lok. Dr. Khokha aims to develop novel medicines to prevent breast cancer, and Dr. Lok aims to develop better treatments for lung cancer.

Project Title: A Functional Approach to Stigmatization, Motivation, and Social Judgment
Project Description: This project supports infrastructure for an innovative line of research on how a person’s motivations (e.g., to protect oneself, to find a romantic relationship) and beliefs (e.g., stereotypes) shape who they stigmatize, as well as how people experience being stigmatized by others.

Project Title: Influence of Coupled Physical and Biogeochemical Processes on Metal Transport in Groundwater
Project Description: Ontario has an active mining industry that provides important economic benefits but also poses some risks to groundwater. This research will develop best practices for mining companies and regulators to ensure that these risks are minimized at operating mines and at legacy orphaned mines.

Project Title: Joint Motion Simulation Using Hybrid Experimental-Computational Techniques
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will enable studies focused on better understanding the biomechanics of ligaments in intact, injured, reconstructed and replacement knee joints. Our findings can help improve the outcomes of surgical procedures such as ACL reconstruction and knee replacement.

Project Title: Control and Protection of Next-Generation Power Electronically Enabled Hybrid AC-DC Power Systems
Project Description: This research program addresses significant technical challenges associated with the control and protection of the transforming electric network; specifically, a mixed alternating current (AC) direct current (DC) power system with large integration of renewable energy resources necessary to fight climate change.

Project Title: Harnessing Regulatory Immune Cells to Promote Transplantation Tolerance
Project Description: The University of Toronto is requesting support to set up Dr. Sarah Crome’s laboratory. Dr. Crome has discovered a new population of cells that regulate immunity. She will investigate their role in stem cell and organ transplants with the goal of developing new immunotherapies to prevent transplant rejection.

Project Title: Investigation of Organelle Dynamics and Remodeling Using Lattice Light-sheet Microscopy
Project Description: This application requests support for a novel imaging technology, called lattice light-sheet microscopy (LLSM). LLSM enables the observation of subcellular events in living organisms with extraordinary speed and resolution, and extremely low phototoxicity, offering unique new insights into the pathogenesis and treatment of disease.

Project Title: Industry 4.0 Smart Factory System
Project Description: The proposal is for a laboratory-scale Smart Factory to develop transformative technologies and train HQP to aid Ontario manufacturers in digitization, leading to the integration of production and maintenance scheduling in real time while enhancing efficiency and reducing costs and emissions.

Project Title: Characterization and Targeted Reversal of Synaptic Mechanisms Contributing to Autism
Project Description: This project will investigate how synapses, communication zones between brain cells, contribute to the cellular basis of autism spectrum disorder. This information will be used to drive the development of next-generation treatments designed to reduce or reverse symptoms of autism spectrum disorder.

Project Title: High Temperature Oxidation and Corrosion Laboratory
Project Description: A High Temperature Oxidation and Corrosion Laboratory is proposed for a research program investigating the degradation of materials used in nuclear power plants (NPP). The overall goal of the research program is to support the safety and reliability of NPPs in Ontario decades into the future.

Project Title: An Integrated Platform for Pre-clinical Testing of Melanoma Treatments
Project Description: e state-of-the-art live-cell and in vivo imaging equipment in this proposal will allow us to evaluate different melanoma treatments from the petri dish to in vivo models in a matter of weeks, using patient-derived samples to inform potential treatments before they are given to patients in the clinic.

Project Title: High Accuracy Gene Expression Quantification: Digital Droplet PCR
Project Description: The proposed infrastructure consists of a matched suite of instruments for the sensitive and accurate quantification of gene expression in a wide variety of biological samples with basic science, biomedical, and environmental applications.

Project Title: Microalgae Biomanufacturing Laboratory
Project Description: This program will develop novel processes for metabolic engineering of microalgae (composed of renewable chemicals made from carbon dioxide and sunlight) for product overproduction and develop comprehensive biorefining strategies for generating multiple chemical products from a single feedstock.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Advanced Microfluidic Nanobiosensing
Project Description: This proposal integrates functional nanomaterials into novel microfluidic biosensors and investigates the new biosensing technologies for applications to disease diagnostics and cell biology research. The leveraged infrastructure will enable nanomaterial synthesis, biosensor fabrication and experimentation.

Project Title: Seismic Behaviour of Retrofitted Continuous Concrete Slabs
Project Description: The project will examine experimentally the structural behaviour of full-scale retrofitted reinforced concrete slab-column connections under seismic loadings. The developed retrofitted techniques will reduce the treat of structural collapses while also maintain competitive retrofit construction costs.

Project Title: Design Observation Studio
Project Description: The Design Observation Studio will provide digital design and fabrication tools alongside behavioural observation equipment, enabling Dr. Olechowski to investigate underexplored challenges of modeling, prototyping and decision-making in the quickly evolving engineering design environment.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Research on Next Generation Wireless Networks
Project Description: This proposal will investigate new and innovative techniques to enhance performance, reliability, range and security of wireless networks. These could be applied in areas such as cellular networks, and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Project Title: Facility for Advanced Non-destructive Testing/Imaging Instrumentation Development
Project Description: We propose to develop three novel UofT-pioneered advanced non-destructive testing and imaging (NDT/NDI) instrumentation technologies for R&D and wide-ranging industrial inspection applications. The infrastructure will place Ontario at the forefront of NDI/NDT technology development worldwide.

Project Title: The Virtual Physiological Human Project
Project Description: This project will use computational models to obtain a more complete mechanistic under-standing of kidney function and blood pressure regulation in health and diseases, and will develop virtual reality technology to visualize and analyze high-dimensional data sets.

Project Title: Neurocomputational Approaches to Individual Differences in ‘Virtuous’ Decision-making
Project Description: People struggle to resist immediate temptation in favour of abstract or long-term benefits such as health or retirement savings. The Neuroeconomics Lab aims to understand the mechanisms that drive failures to make good choices, and develop effective strategies to improve health and financial decision-making.

Project Title: Decoding Cancer with Supercomputers
Project Description: The proposed research aims to identify causes of cancer progression - to find which extrinsic and intrinsic factors can contribute to cancer mutation occurrence in DNA - and to discover molecular mechanisms determining how these mutations can affect proteins, protein interactions and dynamic behavior of chromatin. This involves designing new computational methods that perform molecular modeling, molecular dynamics simulations and machine learning. These studies will offer key insights into the basis of mutagenesis and DNA repair and their contribution to cancer etiology - the knowledge of which is a prerequisite for developing novel targeted therapeutic strategies.

Project Title: Neuromechanics-based Assistive Robotics: Towards optimal personalized robotic assistance
Project Description: This research aims at modelling the core neuromechanical mechanisms of walking to support the design of personalized assistive robotic systems. This requires experimentation and data collection using the requested exoskeleton, instrumented treadmill, and motion capture system.

Project Title: Slide Scanner System to Study and Develop Novel Diagnostic Tools for Oral Fibrosis and Cancer
Project Description: With the requested Slide Scanning System, we will digitize and analyze histological slides from oral cancer biopsies to (a) understand how communication between inflammatory and repair cells transforms the oral epithelium into cancer and (b) use this information to predict cancer as a new diagnostic test.

Project Title: Materials Characterization Centre
Project Description: A novel X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy system is sought, which will enable detailed surface analysis of novel materials targeted for clean energy & “smart” device applications. The instrument will be the first of its kind in Canada & will be the marque instrument in our new Materials Characterization Centre.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Regulation of Whole-body Metabolism by Nuclear Hormone Receptors
Project Description: The goal of my research is to develop new therapeutics to treat diseases such as diabetes and obesity that affect millions of Ontarians, by uncovering novel regulatory mechanisms controlling the balance between energy intake and energy expenditure

Project Title: Craft of Intelligence Analysis Lab (CIAL)
Project Description: Access to police services to conduct in-situ studies on intelligence analysis is significantly restricted. This application requests infrastructure to establish the Craft of Intelligence Analysis Lab, to examine how intelligence analysts build intelligence products, and identify, select, categorize, and target risks.

Project Title: Connelly Research Laboratory Equipment Upgrades
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will enable the research team to examine the ongoing transformation of workplaces in Ontario and its impact on workers and organizational structures, through conducting workplace simulations and surveys for research on contingent work, disability in the workplace, knowledge hiding, and leader stress.

Project Title: Quantitative Proteomics to Study Microbial Systems
Project Description: This multidisciplinary research program will use leading-edge proteomics and advanced bioinformatics to investigate microbial-host interactions and antimicrobial resistance. By advancing our knowledge of the process of infection, this research will lead to improved treatment strategies for infectious diseases.

Project Title: Taking Superconducting Electronics to the Next Level of Integration
Project Description: The end of Moore’s law has made the semiconductor electronics industry ripe for disruption. Waterloo has a team of world-renowned researchers developing superconducting electronics, a possible disruptor. The proposed infrastructure will take their work to the next level.

Project Title: Neutron Detector Characterization Facility for Supernova Physics
Project Description: The objective of the project is to develop neutron detectors, of sufficiently low background noise, that open up new possibilities for a future large-scale supernova neutrino detector and other applications. The key element is a neutron detector characterization facility made from very pure lead and graphite.

Project Title: AI + Democracy Lab
Project Description: The AI + Democracy Lab will serve as a world class research centre for the development and application of Artificial Intelligence to social inquiry, including modelling social media data to measure public opinion, monitor interference in election campaigns, and identify human rights violations.

Project Title: Preclinical Studies in Aging Laboratory
Project Description: The Preclinical Studies on Aging Laboratory will facilitate studies of metabolic, immune and microbiome changes with age to discover non-genetic factors associated with healthy and unhealthy aging. It will also be used to test drugs and interventions to keep older adults healthier for longer.

Project Title: MAXimIzing MILk In A changing Food eNvironment (MAXIMILIAN)
Project Description: This grant will enable the purchase of equipment to investigate how milk and its nutritional and bioactive constituents, whether mother’s own, donor human milk or cow’s milk, can be leveraged to improve the health of Canadians. Promising strategies will be implemented.

Project Title: Observational Research Laboratory for Children and Families
Project Description: Evidence-based treatments for children’s mental health problems have focused on individual children and parents, to the exclusion of broader forces in the family. The requested infrastructure will remediate this shortcoming by supporting the development of evidence-based therapies for whole families.

Project Title: CogSim: An Interaction-aware Tri-simulator Facility for Research on Driver Behaviors and Cognitive Autonomous Driving
Project Description: This project will yield insight into driving behaviors and interaction mechanisms of mixed human-driven/automated vehicles using the innovative research facility, CogSim. It will include the development of safe and efficient decision-making algorithms for autonomous vehicles.

Project Title: Electrical Drive and Detection System
Project Description: This proposal will establish an electrical instrumentation system to enable ground-breaking research at the University of Waterloo on micro sensors and medical technology. It will enable training of HQP on cutting-edge instrumentation and development of novel technology.

Project Title: From the Sea to the Museum and Beyond: Maritime heritage at Marzamemi, Italy
Project Description: Using an innovative system of three-dimensional recording of ships and shipwrecks from antiquity to the present day, this project explores the physical markers of Mediterranean connectivity through colonization, trade, warfare, fishing, and forced migration, and their display for multiple audiences.

Project Title: Understanding Weld Cracking using In-situ Thermography and Simulation
Project Description: Liquid metal embrittlement (LME) crack propagation will be observed during resistance spot welding of steel. In-situ temperature and strain measurements of the weld will be made to understand the conditions required for LME to occur and develop techniques to avoid it.

Project Title: Advanced Microbicide Research and Analysis Facility (AMRAF)
Project Description: Establishment of the Advanced Microbicide Research and Analysis Facility (AMRAF) with the infrastructure requested in this proposal will provide Dr. Ho with the ability to evaluate and analyze technology platforms for the prevention and/or reduction of HIV infection.

Project Title: Social Observation Laboratory
Project Description: This proposal aims to establish the Social Observation Laboratory, which will support the simultaneous collection of video and gaze tracking data in real face-to-face conversations. This work will transform our understanding of social behaviour and provide an empirical foundation for communication interventions.

Project Title: Scanning Electron Microscope
Project Description: The goal of this research is to investigate processing problems of aluminum and γ’ superalloys with additive manufacturing (AM). The focus will be developing a combination of multi-scale modeling and microstructure characterization. Outcomes will include new alloy design strategies adapted for AM.

Project Title: Long Term Performance of Bituminous & Modern Geomembrane Liners with High Interface Shear Strength
Project Description: This research will examine the long-term performance of modern geosynthetic barriers, both in their ability to adequately contain contaminants and their stability on steep slopes, to contribute to innovative and cost-effective environmental protection for waste containment and mining applications.

Project Title: Multi-modal Functional Brain Technology
Project Description: Dr. Lin’s research will advance existing neuroimaging techniques, such as MRI, to improve diagnostics and treatment of brain disorders via less invasive procedures and more effective treatment, particularly for neuroscience studies and clinical applications in neurology and psychiatry.

Project Title: Analysis of Infectious Diseases Systems with Long-lasting Transient Dynamics and Feedback Delays
Project Description: Dr. Magpantay aims to derive new mathematical methods to improve our understanding of disease systems that exhibit (1) long-lasting transient dynamics (e.g. the honeymoon period after the start of vaccination) and (2) complex dynamics arising from delays (e.g. delayed public health action).

Project Title: Scanning Electron Microscope for New Generation Applied Research
Project Description: The objective of the proposal is to obtain a Scanning Electron Microscope to support a research program focused on developing new materials for technological innovation and renewable energy applications as well as a diverse range of other research in areas of societal relevance such as drug delivery, health care and climate change.

Project Title: Learning Representation in Machine Learning for Healthcare
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will create a unique automated engineering system that combines a robotic synthesis platform and computationally powered iterative screening algorithms, enabling accelerated materials discoveries for healthcare, energy, and other industrial applications in Ontario.

Project Title: Urgent Replacement of Critical Infrastructure: Console for 600MHz NMR instrument
Project Description: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is of critical importance for Brock’s cutting-edge research in chemistry, biochemistry, and biology, and for continued partnerships with local industries. The existing Bruker 600 MHz NMR spectrometer is a magnet worth >$1,000,000, and requires an updated console to extend its lifespan.

Project Title: Advances in the Search for Dark Matter with Bubble Chambers and Spherical Proportional Counters
Project Description: The project’s objective is to advance the technologies used to search for dark matter with bubble chamber and spherical proportional counter technologies. These advances will help maximize the scientific potential of dark matter search experiments at SNOLAB, in Sudbury, Ontario.

Project Title: High-throughput Whole Genome Sequencing for Improved Disease Risk Prediction
Project Description: This research aims to advance the state of personalized medicine by developing methods to predict an individual’s risk of cardiovascular disease. This will be accomplished by leveraging all of an individual’s genomic information (DNA) using whole-genome sequencing and computational approaches.

Project Title: Laboratory for Plant Cell Biology
Project Description: This proposal will establish a state-of-the-art lab (including a custom-built microscope for live cell imaging) to advance our fundamental understanding of plant cell wall signaling, to generate knowledge for applications in agriculture and biofuel production, and to prepare Canadians for future careers.

Project Title: Patient Specific Bone and Joint Health Technologies
Project Description: In this project, we will develop a modular, experimental apparatus to test how muscles, cartilage and bone may promote each other’s growth and adaptation. Future technologies to assess and treat musculoskeletal disorders will be personalized for each patient and designed to improve quality of life.

Project Title: Past, Present and Projection of Lake Ice Characteristics Under Climate Change
Project Description: This research will support the emerging spectrum of environmental issues throughout cold regions, more specifically, lake ice as a sentinel of climate change. It will study the response of lakes and incorporate satellite observations of surface and subsurface processes in mesoscale numerical models.

Project Title: High-capacity Distributed Privacy Enhancing Technologies
Project Description: This project will create distributed privacy enhancing technologies that can be used by tens to hundreds of millions of people, far surpassing the current state of the art. They will be used to protect the private information of Internet users when they go online and when their information is processed by companies.

Project Title: The Syntax Laboratory
Project Description: The project focuses on the study of language-structure building and utilizes advanced experimental neurolinguistics techniques to understand language cognition, including Indigenous languages of Canada. Contributions to computational linguistics and Indigenous language revitalization are expected.

Project Title: Canadian Robotics and AI Ethical Design Lab
Project Description: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly common in robotics and autonomous vehicle technologies. This research program addresses the ethical, social and policy implications of these technologies, and develops engineering methodologies that deeply integrate ethical considerations into product design.

Project Title: Systems Biology of Host-pathogen Interactions
Project Description: This research program will leverage the power of quantitative proteomics and advanced bioinformatics to better understand fungal infections from both the host and pathogen perspectives. This “systems biology” approach will be used to develop innovative strategies to combat infectious disease.

Project Title: Impact of Learning History on Individual Susceptibility to Developing an Addiction Phenotype
Project Description: Neural and behavioural factors influencing who does and does not develop problem drug use interact with drug experience. The research program of Drs. Murray and Khokhar at the University of Guelph aim to identify sources of addiction vulnerability for the purpose of developing new individualized treatments.

Project Title: The Origins of Social Learning and Behavior
Project Description: The objective of this proposal is to create a highly innovative research laboratory to study infant social cognitive development at the University of Toronto. The equipment is necessary for the implementation and analysis of novel experiments to investigate infants' socio-moral knowledge and behavior.

Project Title: Optimizing Motor Learning through Music-based Behavioural Interventions
Project Description: This project will investigate how people including individuals with stroke, learn complex motor skills such as playing the piano. The main objective is to determine if learning can be enhanced when it is paired with aerobic exercise and/or non-invasive brain stimulation.

Project Title: Real-Time Tracking of Motivation-cognition Interactions Across the Lifespan
Project Description: How do reward and motivation boost cognitive functions as we age? This proposal leverages state-of-the-art, portable neurotechnologies to shed light on the effects of motivation on aging minds and brains. Findings will drive innovation in cognitive training for Ontario’s growing senior population.

Project Title: Platform for Antibiotic Dscovery and Investigation
Project Description: We seek to address the growing problem of antibiotic resistance by discovering new antibacterial and anti-fungal drug leads and carrying out cutting-edge experiments to understand how they work.

Project Title: Measurements of Atmospheric Gases using a Deployable Infrared Interferometer
Project Description: By measuring the gases produced by boreal forest fires, this project will improve our ability to model the impact of these emissions on air quality. As forest fires are occurring more frequently due to climate change, this project will provide a better understanding of the nature of fire-generated pollutants.

Project Title: Lab to Assess Food Web Fate and Effects of Aquatic Contaminants
Project Description: The health of Ontario lakes and rivers will be examined in areas impacted by resource extraction, and municipal and industrial effluents, to understand how systems are adversely impacted by contaminants and reveal locations/conditions with increased health risks to aquatic species and their consumers.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Research on Social and Intelligent Robotics
Project Description: The project will develop a new generation of socially intelligent robots that interact with people in a social, trustworthy and ‘natural’ manner. The infrastructure requested provides the robotic platforms and sensors to investigate a range of human-robot collaborative and team scenarios.

Project Title: Mobile User Experience Lab
Project Description: The Mobile User Experience Lab will provide a deeper understanding of the accessibility, and usability issues facing older adults and disabled individuals when interacting with information and communication technologies allowing them an equal opportunity in shaping the design of such technologies.

Project Title: A Microbial Pheno-genomics Platform to Assess Microbiome Effects on Virulence of Salmonella
Project Description: Salmonella, a foodborne pathogen, causes 150,000 deaths each year globally. Dr. Goodridge will study   Salmonella’s growth and gene expression during infection of the human gastrointestinal tract. The project will lead to better control of Salmonella in foods, thereby reducing Salmonella-caused illnesses.

Project Title: High-Intensity and High-Resolution X-ray Diffraction Laboratory
Project Description: The requested laboratory implements modern diffraction-based defect characterization techniques to enable innovative research on predicting the irradiation-induced degradation of critical components of in-service nuclear reactors, and developing novel materials with improved irradiation damage tolerance.

Project Title: Exercise Oncology and Cognition Lab (EOCL)
Project Description: The Exercise Oncology and Cognition Lab (EOCL) will identify effective and modifiable management strategies to enhance cognitive health and slow functional decline in cancer survivors in Ontario. The EOCL is necessary to promote effective exercise interventions for brain health in cancer survivorship.

Project Title: Verification and Validation of Autonomous Software Systems
Project Description: Software is needed to operate critical economic, security & safety systems. Yet, traditional methods of Software Verification and Validation (V&V) can no longer ensure the dependability of increasingly complex systems. This research program will develop methods for automated and effective testing.

Project Title: Facility for Research on Sustainable Energy and Battery Management Systems
Project Description: The requested equipment will be employed to allow for seamless, efficient and high integration of renewable energy sources and electric vehicles into electricity grids through (i) developing/testing power-electronic converters and protection relays, and (ii) managing/testing batteries and battery packs.

Project Title: The Centre for Health Behaviours and Well-being in Daily Life
Project Description: The objective of the Centre for Health Behaviour and Well-Being in Daily Life is to understand the psychological and biological links between health behaviours and mental health. These links will be examined in real time and in participants’ natural environments via mobile technology.

Project Title: On-surface Design and Synthesis of Molecular-based 1D and 20 Nanomaterials
Project Description: The proposed Scanning Tunneling Microscopy represents the essential instrument of the Nanoscience Laboratory led by the proposed Canada Research Chair Tier 2 in 'molecular-based low-dimensional nanomaterials'. This instrument offers atomic-to-molecular scale investigation of nanomaterials.

Project Title: Learning Representation in Machine Learning for Healthcare
Project Description: Machine Learning has made massive progress in recent years thanks in large part to advances in computing resources. Healthcare is a natural arena for the application of machine learning. Clinical data requires advanced lab infrastructure to further machine learning for health (ML4H) research.

Project Title: Expanding Cell Capabilities to Sense their Environment for Therapeutic Applications
Project Description: The number of medicines made from proteins and peptides is expanding rapidly. The proposed research will harness our bodies’ ability to make these molecules to build a modular sensing system that enables our cells to detect disease and trigger the production of a protein or peptide medicine in response.

Project Title: Lakehead University Driving Simulator
Project Description:
We propose to replace our outdated driving simulator. This will allow our team to continue to study 
driving behiour in a standardised, affordable, time-efficient, and safe manner, while maintaining a good level of correspondence with on-road driving.

Project Title: Quantitative Imaging
Project Description: This proposed research program aims to develop innovative computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) analysis tools for widespread use by academia, clinical partners and industry to help prevent the onset and progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Project Title: Optical Metasurface for Optoelectronics and Renewable Energy Applications
Project Description: The proposed research aims at developing ultrathin planar optical devices using the concept of metasurface. These devices will replace conventional optical elements including lenses and mirrors for many applications, and will have transformative impacts on technology and economy.

Project Title: State-of-the-Art Research Facility for Earthquake-resilient Infrastructure
Project Description: This research program is being undertaken to improve the resilience of civil infrastructure from damage due to earthquakes and other vibration sources. Experimental testing is being conducted on specialized control devices to identify and improve key performance characteristics and develop life-cycle planning.

Project Title: FISHSPACE: Novel Cost of Life Metrics of Fish for Improved Understanding of Spatial Management
Project Description: Understanding the cost of life of aquatic organisms is key for assessing both anthropogenic impacts on species and populations and the success or impact of conservation and management measures such as marine protected areas. Technological advancements in tracking animals now provide new high residence telemetry equipment that can for the first time provide continuous high resolution location data for fully aquatic species that do not surface and can be used to monitor individuals across a broad range of body sizes. This proposal will establish pioneering approaches to measuring the cost of life of fish and promote data generation across diverse aquatic habitats and environments.

Project Title: Person Perception in VR
Project Description: Dr. Troje will use virtual reality technology to study dyadic communication along a continuum of display conditions that span from classic video communication to true face-to-face encounters. Results will inform the design of efficient videoconferencing systems that mediate real face-to-face experience.

Project Title: A Therapeutic Device for Otitis Media
Project Description: Otitis media is a prevalent disease in children. In this project, an innovative device for treating otitis media will be developed to replace the current clinical approach of using tympanostomy tubes. The innovative solution will overcome drawbacks of tympanostomy tubes.

Project Title: Haptic Computing Lab
Project Description: Haptic technology produces touch feedback like force and tactile cues or vibrations in wearables. The Haptic Computing Lab builds tools to create haptic hardware and software for research and industry applications. The proposed project will provide essential equipment to the Haptic Computing Lab.

Project Title: Multimaterial Characterization System for Developing and Testing Micro-/Nano-layered Composites and Foams
Project Description: This research focuses on developing multimaterial nano-structured composites and foams with tailored properties. The resulting engineered structures will be useful as ultra-high barrier packaging films and high-performance foams with ultra-low density and superior insulation properties.

Project Title: Engaging Technology and People to Achieve Advanced Building Performance
Project Description: Canada’s first Zero Carbon certified office building serves as a ‘living lab’ to overcome the failings of many high performance buildings. The study uses advanced building sensors to enable people to make sustainable decisions, add value, and achieve the building’s potential.

Project Title: GIS-based Virtual and Augmented Reality Tools
Project Description: This research will develop web and mobile tools for citizens and decision makers to visualize proposed developments and historic sites in urban and rural municipalities in Ontario. The effectiveness of these advanced techniques for engaging public feedback will be assessed.

Project Title: MFARR-Asia Computer-assisted Survey Interview and Participatory Video Production Lab
Project Description: This international partnership will leverage Canadian social science expertise and global human rights commitments to address huge gaps in data and knowledge on sexual and gender minority populations. The project will advance human rights protections for LGBTIQ people in Ontario, Canada and globally.

Project Title: Live-cell Imaging of Inter-chromosomal Contacts by Confocal Super-resolution Microscopy
Project Description: Contacts between different chromosomes regulate genes and are important for development. By looking at chromosomal contacts in living cells using an ultra-sensitive microscope, we can better understand gene regulation and genome organization in development and in disease.

Project Title: Sweptfield Confocal Microscopy for Fast and Low-damage Live-cell Imaging
Project Description: Purchase of a microscope that uses novel technology enabling low light exposure and rapid imaging, resulting in high-resolution 4D imaging of live cells. The capability will lead to new understanding of cell dynamics, cellular communication, and immune response for the study of cancer and infection resolution.

Project Title: Enhancing CAR Cell Immunotherapy of Brain Tumours with MRI-guided Focused Ultrasound
Project Description: Brain tumours are among the most lethal of all cancers. There is hope that genetically engineered immune cells may greatly improve survival. This project will study the effects of combining focused ultrasound with engineered immune cells in animal models of cancer with the aim to improve survival.

Project Title: Iethi’nihsténha Ohwentsia’kékha (Land), Resurgence, Reconciliation and the Politics of Education
Project Description: This Land-centered project focuses on significantly improving education for Indigenous people in Ontario by reframing teacher education programs through critically engaging Indigenous and settler communities around decolonizing and Indigenizing research and teacher education.

Project Title: Centre for Biomedical Research and Biosensing
Project Description: About ½ million of Canadians are affected by neurodegeneration, the healthcare costs are at ~$15 billion each year, and they are greatest for Ontarians. Dr. Martic’s research program aims to develop innovative diagnostic platforms, and identify viable and effective therapies to combat degenerative diseases, improve overall health and reduce healthcare costs.

Project Title: Social Neuroendocrinology Lab
Project Description: The effects of gendered social experiences on testosterone will be examined with the “Q-HuBBSS”; Queen’s new Biobehavioural Spectrometry System, providing new insights into a “gender-testosterone pathway” and the interconnections between social experiences and hormonal aspects of our bodies.

Project Title: Extrinsic Control of Neural Precursor Cells: Molecular mechanisms of brain development and repair
Project Description: Our focus is on neural stem cells (NSCs) in the adult brain and how these cells are established as the brain is built. This proposal will study how the NSC environment tells these cells to become dormant, thereby enabling potential strategies to ‘wake-up’ these cells for brain repair after brain injury or disease.

Project Title: Resource Management in Heterogeneous Clusters: Maximizing efficiency and guaranteeing security, privacy, and fairness
Project Description: The long-term objective of this proposal is to design the next generation of mechanisms, methods, and tools that enable intelligent controllers to maximize efficiency and performance of shared computing systems, while guaranteeing security, privacy, and fairness assurances.

Project Title: DNA Damage and Cellular Physiology: Rewiring for a cure
Project Description: The proposed research project aims to investigate how cells sense and repair DNA damage and to apply this knowledge to improve cancer therapies. By selectively preventing DNA repair in cancer cells, current treatments can be made more effective with reduced side effects.

Project Title: Generation of Stem Cell-derived Pacemaker Cells for Biological Pacemaker Applications
Project Description: This proposal will leverage Dr. Stephanie Protze’s unique expertise in electrophysiology, heart development and stem cell differentiation to deliver a novel biological pacemaker that can be used to treat patients with abnormal heart rhythms.

Project Title: High Resolution NMR Facility for Structure Elucidation
Project Description: The requested infrastructure is required to facilitate basic research in chemistry and biochemistry. The three primary investigators work in key areas in which Ontario can be a world leader, including bioanalytical instrumentation, drug development, and materials science.

Project Title: Rational Design of Multiphase and Multifunctional Renewable-resourced Polymers
Project Description: The project aims to develop robust multiphase and multifunctional polymeric materials and processing technologies based on sustainable feedstock for a range of material applications. Target applications include coatings, antimicrobial films, structural components, and adhesives.

Project Title: Spinning Disk Confocal Microscope to Probe Molecular Networks of Cell and Tissue Morphogenesis
Project Description: The lab of Professor Tony Harris at the University of Toronto is a world leader in defining how molecular complexes organize cell and tissue structure for the multicellular development of animals. The requested spinning disk confocal microscope is essential for probing fundamental mechanisms involved.

Project Title: A Protein Engineering Laboratory to Probe and Rewire Cell Signaling
Project Description: Using newly developed approaches in protein engineering, this project will identify synthetic molecules that can be used to elucidate and reprogram important cell signaling events involved in DNA repair. This work will establish a pipeline for the production and optimization of novel therapeutics for cancer.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Image-guided Magnetic Micromanipulation of Cells and Tissues
Project Description: This project will use the powerful technique of magnetic micromanipulation to investigate previously unstudied biomechanical properties of organelles, cells and tissues and to explore new frontiers of cancer treatment. This work has a strong potential to improve Ontarians’ health over the longer term.

Project Title: Autonomous Docking and Active Perception for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
Project Description: Today’s unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) excel in open space operations but are unable to fly precisely at high speeds or in wind. Prof. Waslander will advance UAV modeling and learning-based control to improve flight accuracy and enable autonomous UAV landing operations on moving vehicles at speed.

Project Title: Indigenous Life Promotion and Social Action Labs
Project Description: The Indigenous Life Promotion and Social Action Labs will be a hub for community-engaged research on Indigenous suicide prevention. Integrating cultural knowledge with advanced research technologies, the labs will lead to a better understanding of Indigenous suicide and promote knowledge sharing.

Project Title: Haven: The Asylum Lab
Project Description: Haven will be a hub for the storage and comparative analysis of data on global migration. It will provide data access to researchers and students who will use technology to develop innovative methods and new knowledge. It will enhance Ontario’s leading role in research and policymaking on migration issues.

Project Title: Defining cancer and immune landscapes in multiple myeloma using single cell transcriptomics and ultradeep DNA sequencing
Project Description: The researchers will use advanced genomic technologies to study multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer. They will reveal how individual cancer cells can contribute to disease, and identify the properties of cells that enable them to resist drugs such that new, more effective therapies can be developed.

Project Title: System for Flame Synthesis, Collection and Characterization of Customized Nanoparticles
Project Description: This project focuses on scalable synthesis of nanoparticles for use in energy storage, material synthesis, emission sensing and quantification of their impact on the environment to bridge the gap between nanoparticle development in labs and their use in valuable commercial products.

Project Title: Mechanics of Active Fluids and Bacterial Physics Laboratory
Project Description: An innovative experimental platform is requested to establish the Western Mechanics of Active Fluids Laboratory. It is comprised of two suites: a microorganism culture, selection and growth analysis facility, and a novel microfluidic test facility comprised of two parallel micro-active-fluidic platforms.

Project Title: Mobile LiDAR System for Geologic Applications
Project Description: We seek to acquire a mobile LiDAR scanner to determine the fine-scale roughness of geologic surfaces. We will compare these data to radar remote sensing data of the same region, and use our interpretations to determine what geologic processes are occurring on other planets in the solar system.

Project Title: Evolutionary genetics of plant reproductive strategies
Project Description: Understanding how organisms interact with their environment is key to protecting biodiversity, and requires knowledge at the gene, species, population, and ecosystem level. Our research integrates across these levels to understand how plants adapt to ecological conditions and climate change.

Project Title: Attosecond Nanoscopy
Project Description: Nanotechnology can make static measurements at the atomic scale. Attosecond science is a branch of ultrafast physics that uses intense lasers to study electronic motion. We aim to combine these two research areas, the ultrasmall and the ultrafast, to understand and develop novel materials.

Project Title: Development and application of isotope tracers for geolocation and surface hydrology
Project Description: Organic and inorganic materials inherit geographically specific chemical signatures from their environments. This project seeks to use these chemical fingerprints (isotopes) to trace the movement of individuals in ecology and forensic studies, and to investigate ancient and modern river hydrology.

Project Title: Confocal Imaging Infrastructure for Cell Biology and Biochemistry
Project Description: We request confocal infrastructure needed for studying animal cells. This will enable researchers to visualize structures within cells, and intricate shape and composition of cells in animal tissues. It will enable discoveries and applications in a wide range of biomedical sciences, aquaculture sciences, and environmental conservation.

Project Title: Autonomous Mobile Manipulation in Human Environments: Learning Algorithms and Robot Systems
Project Description: We will enable mobile manipulation robots to (a) learn to manipulate objects based on visual neural program induction and to (b) seamlessly and safely interact with humans in dynamic environments, by predicting their intent and their objectives on tasks of shared control and collaborative manipulation.

Project Title: Flexible automated chamber system for quantifying the effect of disturbance and restoration on peatland GHG exchange
Project Description: An automated chamber system will be used to measure peatland greenhouse gas fluxes to understand the effect of climate change, human disturbance and restoration on the ecosystem. This knowledge can be used to manage peatlands as natural climate solutions.

Project Title: Performance Evaluation of Networking/Computing Resource Management for Wireless Internet of Things
Project Description: To support research leading to robust, efficient, and intelligent resource management solutions for Internet of Things (IoT) networks, this project will establish a configurable and integrated IoT-edge-cloud infrastructure, develop proof-of-principle implementations and conduct performance evaluations.

Project Title: Optical and wearable motion capture system for precision medicine solutions in osteoarthritis.
Project Description: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease that results in pain, disability, and reduced quality of life for over 2 million Ontarians. This research will use smart wearable technology to provide clinicians with actionable solutions to improve our standard of care for those affected by this devastating disease.

Project Title: Computational phenotypes of cancer
Project Description: My goal is to transform how clinicians treat patients with cancer using a data-driven approach to help move the field from the “treat everyone to help a few” paradigm towards precision medicine, defining relevant biomarkers to guide targeted treatments and improve human health.

Project Title: Neural circuit changes in decision-making across the lifespan - relevance to mental health disorders
Project Description: This project will characterize the neural circuit basis and dynamics of decision-making from adolescence to adulthood and establish how neural circuit function is altered in rodent models of addiction and schizophrenia. This research will reveal new therapeutic targets for early intervention in mental illness.

Project Title: 600 MHz NMR Spectrometer
Project Description: Advanced technologies in manufacturing require advanced materials. The state-of-the-art 600 MHz NMR spectrometer will support the development of innovative functional materials containing main group elements for the advanced materials and manufacturing sector of the Ontarian economy.

Project Title: Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) Research Laboratory to Target Acute Myeloid Leukemia
Project Description:
The objective of this research is to understand determinants of treatment response in acute myeloid
leukemia based on understanding processes that happen at the level of minimal residual disease after
treatment and facilitate the translation of these findings into novel treatments and biomarkers.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Large-scale Integration and Processing of Structured and Graph Data
Project Description: This proposal deals with the development of technologies that enable the full exploitation of big data. It focuses both on making data reliable and trustable for analysis and on supporting advanced analysis techniques based on machine learning and graph processing.

Project Title: Monitoring of emerging water pollutants and development of next-generation sensors
Project Description: The requested infrastructure will be used to investigate the sources, fate, and transport of emerging pollutants in water and wastewater and to develop new and novel sensors for their monitoring.

Project Title: Infrastructure for Canadian National Caries Network
Project Description: Dental caries is the world's leading chronic disease. Our goal is to discover new and novel anti-caries products for better oral preventive dental care and treatment. Our discoveries will contribute significantly to improving the oral health disparity of, and healthcare delivery to, all Canadians.

Project Title: Zebrafish as a preclinical platform for modeling childhood cancers and rare genetic disorders
Project Description: Genetic defects lead to many childhood cancers and other rare diseases. The Berman lab has pioneered the use of zebrafish to model how genetic defects cause these diseases. With these zebrafish models, Dr. Berman will uncover mechanisms of disease and identify effective therapies.

Project Title: Versatile Platform for Measuring Molecular Structure and Conformation of Linear and Branched Biopolymers
Project Description: The requested equipment will characterize nanoscale materials, providing new insights into their physical properties and function. These new insights will inform the development of new, improved, safer products for food, health and personal care.

Project Title: Elucidating the basis of photosynthetic adaptations to extreme conditions.
Project Description: The objective of the proposed research is to understand how extremophilic algae and land plants adapt to permanently cold Arctic and Antarctic environments, with a focus on how low temperatures affect protein function. Ultimately, we seek to improve low temperature productivity of crop plants in Ontario.

Project Title: Extracellular Vesicle and Patient Avatar Technology Cores for Translational and Clinical Research
Project Description: Dr. Leong’s mandate is to advance the most effective drug treatment of metastases: by using chicken embryos that grow the patient’s tumour for drug testing and to deliver next-generation blood tests that are highly accurate in identifying patients who have lethal tumours that require immediate treatment.

Project Title: DNA nanotechnology for spatially-programmed immune receptor activation
Project Description: This proposal will develop DNA nanostructures for vaccine applications. The key unique element is to exploit the programmable nature of DNA self-assembly to control antigen presentation parameters – e.g. spacing, density, valency – as means of shaping the strength and quality of the immune response.

Project Title: Advanced scanning electron microscope for in situ and liquid-phase electron microscopy study
Project Description: The requested scanning electron microscope will be used to develop in situ and liquid-phase electron microscopy, which will provide dynamic structural information in key areas, including advanced materials and manufacturing, clean environment and water, renewable energy productions and many more.

Project Title: Sleep and Human Evolution Lab (SHEL): testing evolutionary hypotheses in a clinical, controlled space
Project Description: The major goal of this research program is to test hypotheses relating to the evolution of human sleep, physiology, and cognition. In order to accomplish this, Professor David Samson will create a one-of-a-kind sleep laboratory at the University of Toronto Mississauga.

Project Title: Computer systems support for machine learning and artificial intelligence
Project Description: This proposal is aimed at bridging a critical gap in Ontario’s burgeoning machine learning and artificial intelligence landscape through research on advances in computer systems to support running these data-intensive applications at scale on emerging heterogeneous hardware.

Project Title: Recovery and Recuperation: mobilizing the next generation of GRASAC
Project Description: The research engages with digitized cultural heritage to: 1) recuperate Great Lakes’ Indigenous knowledge practices, artistic practices and languages, 2) model Indigenous data sovereignty, and 3) support community-directed digital strategies including VR, AR, 3D digitization and mesh networking.

Project Title: Ottawa Pre-clinical PET/CT Imaging Core
Project Description: The infrastructure request is for a state-of-the-art, small animal hybrid PET-CT scanner. This critical infrastructure will accelerate biologic and therapeutic research in heart failure, arrhythmias, inflammation and its link to chronic disease, regenerative medicine, and brain-heart interplay.

Project Title: Chemspeed Automated Chemical Synthesis System
Project Description: This project will build an Automated Chemical Synthesis System (ACSS), which will combine automated robotics platforms with artificial intelligence (AI) to create a self-driving laboratory. The resulting rapid feedback will reduce discovery time, changing the pace of research and development in chemistry.

Project Title: Water and Ice Research Lab, the sequel: A whole new WIRL.
Project Description: This project focuses on the use of state-of-the-art autonomous aircraft and underwater vehicles to explore remote and inaccessible environments that are rapidly changing due to cumulative impacts of climate and land-use change, and to improve land-use management, conservation and protection in Ontario.

Project Title: Infrastructure to study the movement ecology of declining avian taxa.
Project Description: Birds are defined by movement. The proposed research will use biotelemetry to study the movement of declining bird species in southern Ontario and the Canadian Arctic. Understanding factors that influence movement is critical to predicting how these species will respond to environmental change.

Project Title: Charting Diversity in Brain Maturation.
Project Description: Holland Bloorview is developing appropriate research infrastructure suitable for high-throughput MRIs of children and youth with disabilities. This work is essential for informing personalized approaches to removing boundaries faced by individuals in Ontario and Canada-wide growing up with disabilities.

Project Title: Advancing detection limits and in situ isotopic chemical chromatography for astroparticle and geochemical research.
Project Description: We will develop new methods for determining metals and their isotopes at ultra-trace concentrations. These advances are needed in areas such as mineral exploration, toxic metals in the environment, and in the development of ultra-pure materials for space science research.

Project Title: The Northern Environmental Geoscience Laboratory.
Project Description: The proposed Northern Environmental Geoscience Laboratory at Queen’s University will support climate change adaptation and vulnerability assessment initiatives in the north to improve our ability to predict the terrestrial impacts of climate change on ecosystems and people in northeast Canada.

Project Title: Molecular and Biochemical studies of Giardia intestinalis.
Project Description: The proposal is for instruments that support and expand our research on the gene expression and biochemistry of the freshwater parasitic protist, Giardia intestinalis. Our research will lead to a more complete understanding of this enigmatic parasite, and may lead to improved treatments for giardiasis.

Project Title: Neural substrates of cognitive influence over sensory-motor control: Implications for learning and stroke rehabilitation.
Project Description: The proposed research will use a new, innovative, non-invasive method to study the brain to enhance our knowledge of how the brain learns new skills. This will allow for the development of new approaches to recovery of behavior following acquired brain injury, such as stroke.

Project Title: Stress-mediated trophoblast proliferation: adaptation or pathology?
Project Description: This proposal will investigate the ability of the placenta to respond to stress in order to gain insight into complications of pregnancy, including preeclampsia and intrauterine growth restriction; so that new treatments may be identified and developed to result in the healthiest moms and babies possible.

Project Title: Transmission Electron Microscope.
Project Description: Materials innovations are essential to realizing useful quantum technologies and next generation batteries. This CFI supports the development of a transmission electron microscopy centre, which will provide insight into new paths to materials and device fabrication.

Project Title: Neuroscience & Learning Disorders.
Project Description: The objective of this research is to examine how social deficits impact learning difficulties in infants and children with autism. Infants who are at risk for autism will undergo assessments for stress and brain imaging. Models will be developed to identify risk factors for learning problems and inform interventions.

Project Title: Investigating the effect of physical activity during classroom instruction on student attention and learning.
Project Description: Dr. Fenesi’s research will inform how physical activity impacts the brain and mind, and the corresponding effect on students’ ability to focus their attention and learn. Her research will also identify the optimal duration, types, and frequency of physical activity that best support classroom learning.

Project Title: Engineering materials: advancing in-situ electron diffraction and imaging techniques (Engine-Tec).
Project Description: Electron imaging and diffraction techniques will be used to develop novel approaches to characterize the performance of metals and alloys used in the core of CANDU nuclear reactors. This research will focus on measuring localized stress fields that controls the nucleation and propagation of cracks in metals.

Project Title: Readout The Answers.
Project Description: The objective of this research is to answer the remaining questions about the Standard Model’s most elusive particle, the neutrino. This will be achieved by developing and building the data acquisition infrastructure for the DUNE experiment and using it to search for sterile and non-standard neutrinos.

Project Title: Dector Prototype Units for Long-Lived Particle Searches.
Project Description: The identification of dark matter is among the foremost unresolved questions in modern physics. This research program aims to construct sub-unit prototypes for a new detector called MATHUSULA to find dark matter particles and study cosmic rays. Its performance will provide critical guidance for the construction of the full-size detector.

Project Title: Source to Sink Transport Dynamics: Exploring Evolution of Deltaic and Deepwater Systems Through Physical Modelling.
Project Description: An experimental facility will be built to physically model deltas, coastlines, and deep-water environments to explore fundamental controls on the delivery of sediments from river networks and enhance predictions of environmental change and interpretations of the geologic record.

Project Title: Graphite Furnace for Catalytic Prolysis of Biocarbon from Waste Biomass: Engineering Biographite for Biocomposite Uses.
Project Description: The graphitization of plant material has huge potential to generate highly desired graphitic materials for industrial scale applications in materials, electronics, energy storage devices, etc. The requested high temperature pyrolysis furnace (reaching 3,000°C) will be used for graphitization of biomass wastes.

Project Title: Next Generation Polymeric Microparticles for the Treatment of Osteoarthritis.
Project Description: This proposal aims to develop novel therapeutics for osteoarthritis, which will be achieved by designing microparticles that can be injected into the joint of an affected patient, allowing for the long-term release of the drug. Since the drug is localized to the diseased site, it will minimize any off-target drug effects.

Project Title: Advanced graphene oxide-based porous materials for water treatment.
Project Description: The goal of Dr. Yousefi’s research is to develop advanced and efficient Point of Use (POU) water treatment devices as economic alternatives to centralized water treatment for remote areas and disaster zones. He will use advanced nanomaterials to improve the efficiency and reusability of POU devices.

Project Title: Design and Development of Diagnostic and Therapeutic Drug Candidates.
Project Description: The proposed research aims to design and prepare novel therapeutic tools and diagnostic tools that have potential to improve prevention, early diagnosis and management of diseases and help paving the way for personalized medicine.

Project Title: Nanostructured membrane fabrication and characterization facility
Project Description: We will engineer new membrane technologies that dramatically improve the efficiency of separation processes used in the water, oil and gas, and chemical industries. Membranes patterned on the nanometer-scale will surpass current limits of membrane performance for cleaner industrial processes.

Project Title: Characterising sound and vibration-based communication systems
Project Description: The requested equipment will enable an understanding of how animals use their body’s biomechanics to appropriately filter sensory information. Such body-based filtering provides a mechanism for intelligent behaviour at low computational cost, and can inform the design of autonomous robots and sensors.

Project Title: Enabling toughening and damage tolerance in adhesive bonding of multi-material lightweight structures
Project Description: The aim of the project is to enable the fabrication of damage tolerant, lightweight, adhesive bonded structures used in the automotive and aerospace industries. The long-term goal is to encourage these industries to use adhesives more broadly, thereby maximizing benefits such as reduced CO2 emissions.

Project Title: Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence for Smarter IoT
Project Description: This research program will develop technologies and algorithms for communication-aware distributed machine learning and artificial intelligence in smart cities, smart health monitoring, augmented reality, as well as other areas where distributed sensing, localization, authentication, and deep learning is required.

Project Title: Advanced Design and Measurement Facility for Adaptive Metamaterials
Project Description: This proposal will create a modern design and measurement facility to conduct research in support of universal wireless high-speed internet. The research targets 5G and satellite technology, using electromagnetic metasurfaces to develop better antennas, thus increasing data transmission rates.

Project Title: Protein crystallization and molecular characterization platform
Project Description: In response to the antibiotic resistance crisis, Dr. Little's lab will identify key determinants contributing to bacterial pathogenesis for the development of vaccines or new antimicrobial disruption agents that will benefit Ontario’s healthcare system and agriculture industry.

Project Title: In vivo neurochemistry laboratory
Project Description: Our proposed research will visualize changes in neurotransmitters and neuromodulators during cognitive tests to uncover the neurochemical basis of brain diseases. This research will contribute to understanding how changes in neuronal activity contribute to behavior in health and disease.

Project Title: Integrative sociobiology and pollinator health: wild bee ecology, evolution and genomics
Project Description: Dr. Rehan’s research focuses on sustaining native bee populations through a combination of landscape ecology, comparative genomic and sociodemographic approaches. Her research combines the interplay of nutritional ecology, pathogen susceptibility, and social environment on bee health.

Project Title: A Non-Invaisive Approach to Visualizing Tumour Growth in Vivo Through Space and Time
Project Description: With access to leading optical technology, researchers throughout Ontario will be able to monitor and evaluate brain tumour initiation, growth, progression and response to treatment in living models, accelerating the translation of basic and preclinical studies into therapies for patients across Ontario.

Project Title: Equipment for Advanced UAV-based Hyperspectral Remote Sensing
Project Description: The objective for this project is to develop methodologies and framework for the use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-based hyperspectral remote sensing in precision agriculture, including sub-field scale nitrogen estimation, crop biomass estimation, crop disease detection and weed and crop discrimination

Project Title: Plant phenomics: Understanding trait covariation across scales
Project Description: This research asks why plant traits covary across biological scales (from individuals to species) and how this affects plant performance. It will examine the coordination among carbon- and water-use traits in leaves, stems and roots of model and crop species, and in temperate tree species of commercial value.

Project Title: Climatic Human Factors & Performance Laboratory
Project Description: The Climatic Human Factors Performance Laboratory will assess acute and chronic responses to extreme environments during exercise and occupational challenges and evaluate the effects on performance along with the genetic and molecular characteristics of positive response.
Lead Research Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project Title: Cardiac Regeneration and In Vitro Disease Modelling
Project Description: The proposed research will help us better understand the mechanisms of heart disease and how it is affected by diabetes. It will also test new regenerative medicine techniques to try to repair damaged hearts using stem cells and engineered blood vessels.

Project Title: Elucidating the Evolutionary Enhancement of Enzymatic Efficiency
Project Description: We aim to determine how enzymes evolve to efficiently accelerate reactions. Our studies of enzymes over evolutionary time will show the specific mechanisms by which these catalysts develop. This will facilitate efforts to engineer novel industrial biocatalysts of useful and challenging chemical reactions.

Project Title: kinadas: walking about on the land
